train.question:
title: Wowzers! text: This is a massive kit! My wife is ecstatic about it. She got herself a switch with her Christmas bonus, but didn't have any accessories. This literally has everything we will ever need.

--Small case is a perfect fit, is solid, and has lots of storage. My wife is very happy with this.
--Rubber grips feel nice, BUT they're too big to use with the charger.
--"Pro Grips / Wheels" -- The little plastic control holders are nice. Makes it easier to use them for two player games. Almost as large as an old NES controller. Decent quality, too.
--Plastic game case - VERY nice. Will definitely be using this when we get some more games.
--Stand - It's a stand. It's better than the little fold-out piece on the back of the Switch.
--Charger - Now this is nice. Cable is long enough to reach behind the TV to the outlet. Holds four joycons and charges them. Really works well.
--Headphones - Meh. They're good for a kid, no doubt. Nothing to write home about. Haha
--Grip Case - LOVE THIS. The grip case not only looks cool but it also makes the Switch much more comfortable to hold as an on-the-go gaming system. Probably the best thing in the whole pack.

All around a great set of accessories for the price. We are getting a lot of use out of it already. Saved a bunch of money over buying the pieces we wanted individually, too. Great.

title: E-YOOSO Mechanical Keyboard, Outemu Blue Switches text: I‚Äôm not an expert on mechanical keyboards (that‚Äôs a rabbithole I don‚Äôt want to go down, or I‚Äôll be building my own in a week), but I do love them now that I‚Äôve switched to using one on a daily basis. My daily driver is a HyperX Alloy Elite with Cherry MX Blue switches.

I‚Äôve put this E-YOOSO mechanical keyboard to the test for about three weeks. The switches are Outemu Blue Switches, which is a knock-off of Cherry MX Blue switches. I definitely noticed a difference between the Outemu and the Cherry. The Outemu are a little noisier and don‚Äôt feel as smooth. I feel more resistance when I type on the E-YOOSO keyboard versus the HyperX one. Over a few hours, the resistance adds up.

Of course, the HyperX keyboard is more than double the price of this one, but the E-YOOSO is lacking in some basic features that I‚Äôve become used to. There‚Äôs no attached wrist rest, and I really feel the lack of it. Muscle memory keeps my wrists up as if there was a rest under them, which gets tiring. There are no multimedia or sound controls on the keyboard; I really miss that easy adjustment when I‚Äôm mid game. The keycaps are basic plastic, without any texture. What you‚Äôd find on a normal cheap keyboard, and again, this is a matter of preference, but the keys are slippery. Not great for gaming.

The silver screws on the keyboard continually catch my eye. This is a minor thing, but I wish the screws were flush with the plastic case rather than sitting above it. I‚Äôve snagged my fingers on the screws a few times. The USB cable is plastic instead of braided.

The lighting options are preset, you can cycle through them via the FN and INS keys. I do like that the keyboard includes options without needing to download additional software, but for most people, the first mode (steady rainbow) will be the default. If I‚Äôm gaming in the dark, marquee or snake are useless. Another minor quibble, but I really don‚Äôt like the orange row of the keyboard, I wish another color had been chosen. The orange just doesn‚Äôt fit with the other colors, in my opinion. It‚Äôs too similar to the red row right above it.

I do like the dust resistance; I‚Äôve had the keyboard sitting out for three weeks and haven‚Äôt noticed any dust building up on it.

title: Adorable and many hours of fun text: This game is incredibly fun! (And a massive best-seller in Day One.) The Wild Area with the Dynamax Raids is a source of endless amusement. There are mini games, like you can ride your electric bike at high speeds in a little timed race. Best of all, the Camping feature is so adorable and so much fun ‚Äî they fetch, they race each other, they enjoy your cooking!

I‚Äôm sad my daughter let the internet hater mob of entitled crybabies get to her and color her enjoyment of the game. She doesn‚Äôt even want to play it even though she enjoyed Let‚Äôs Go. This game is stand-alone: it doesn‚Äôt need one million old pre-leveled monsters. We get our baby Pikachu or Eevee from Let‚Äôs Go and that‚Äôs the important part.

The only real issue is that you can‚Äôt pet your adorable Pokemon! That was a great feature in Let‚Äôs Go which added so much enjoyment.

PS Amazon when many reviews lead with a hashtag from an organized gamer-gate style mob you know it‚Äôs being review bombed!

title: A surprising but informative chronicle of his life.
text: Growing up in the greater Boston area, I remember Ted Williams was loved by most everyone, but he had a surly dark side that sometimes tarnished his image.  This book explains his unusual upbringing and helps the reader understand how he was affected by his heritage and especially his mother.  I haven't finished the book. I'm still digesting his early years and circumstances which he had never disclosed to the public until very late in his life. It provides a whole new perspective on the man we loved, admired and routed for long after his playing days were over.  He was far more vulnerable than any of his fans had imagined.

title: So much fun! text: This game is a blast as far as it goes. The problem I'm encountering it that it starts me from the very first challenge every time even though I've gone through and completed the first five. I have trouble with Buckethead (the fifth challenge on the first show), but I did get through it the last time I played. Unfortunately, when I started the game up again, I had to start back at challenge one. If anyone out there knows how to get around that, please let me know. The instructions clearly say that you start from where you left off and the game says it's saving throughout the play, but it still shows that I've done zero challenges.

Other than that, though, it's a blast. Enough movement to be fun, but not work up a sweat. Better than watching TV in the evening. So far I've gone through five games and loved them. I just wish I could start at the point I left off because these games are getting a little boring and I have no way of playing the others except for training.

All in all, though, I would recommend this for anyone who liked Minute to Win It on TV.

title: I Enjoyed it
text: I've wanted to play this game since it first came out, but it's hard for me to buy games for 60 bucks when in six months they might be 30 bucks. lol So, I finally bought Alice: Maddness Returns pretty recently and I have to say 20 bucks is a great deal for this game. It's not short and it's fun to see how the makers turned wonderland into this mad hellish place because of Alice's bad mental state. The monsters are creepy and the world of wonderland is well designed. I find the whole game very interesting and the gameplay itself is pretty fun. Each part of wonderland is very different and you have different weapons to choose from to mix up your fighting style. Though it's a hack'n slash I didn't feel that it was at all repetitive because of how unique every chapter was and all the new creatures you have to fight in each area. I say now that the price has dropped it's defiantly a game worth getting.

title: Mostly great! text: Some people have complained about the weight of this headset, but so far it's been pretty comfortable for 2-hour gaming sessions.

This is a wireless VR headset, so everything is onboard---and that's why it's a little heavy. The games are stored in memory in the headset itself, and capacity isn't upgradeable. Keep that in mind when you are making a decision between the 64 and 128GB model.

Setup is easy. You will need a phone to download and use the app for setup and to get games. Then follow the instructions and in minutes you're ready to play.

Graphics aren't going to rival PC or console games---they're a little bit retro in terms of resolution, but that kind of comes with the territory and the small built-in screens in the headset. Besides, that might be a good thing when it comes to VR. If the the graphics are too good, things might get a little "uncanny valley" and not so fun to play for long. That's not a complaint, just a personal opinion.

The wirelessness is a huge convenience during gameplay---you won't feel a cord brushing against your arms or running down your back. And the controllers are responsive with no noticeable lag. Battery life is good enough for a several-hours-long gaming session.

Game availability is coming around, but isn't really vast yet. Maybe the prices of games will come down as more are brought to market.

title: A Very Decent Mechanical Keyboard text: I am not a gamer. I ordered this keyboard mostly because I prefer using mechanical keyboards for typing, especially ones that have the old school IBM type keyboard feel. One of the distinct features of IBM style mechanical keyboards is the clicking sound that they make which is absent with this model. Honestly, the clicking noise does not add anything to how well the product works. It's just something I mainly enjoy out of nostalgia, so I'm not going to deduct any points for the quietness of the product.

Fortunately, this is still a high quality mechanical keyboard with a number of useful features including USB port passthrough. The product is extremely well built with high quality parts and is weighted heavily enough so that it does not move around that easily. When it comes to keyboards the heavier the better so far as I am concerned. Keyboards that are so light that they feel like they are made out of cardboard are usually the lowest quality ones.

The keyboard is extremely responsive and is more than adequate for day to day use. I can't really say how well it acts as a gaming keyboard, but for my purposes it works excellently. I will say that the price is a bit high compared to similar models made by other brands. Dell has been cashing in on the Alienware brand name ever since they acquired the company and sells everything with the name at a premium price. There are definitely better keyboards out there for the same amount of money (or less) though.

title: What a Blast!! text: For perspective, I am an "accoustic" guitar player (mid-range "Taylor," without electronics). Slow to adopt new technology, I finally purchased a Wii console for my family this Christmas. So we would be ready to go as soon as the wrapping paper was ripped away, I also had "Wii Fit with Balance Board" on hand, as well as a copy of "Guitar Hero III" to use with the "Logitech Wii Wireless Guitar Controller." Basically, the entire family has been playing Wii for most of the last 48 hours, and "Guitar Hero" for most of the last day. I will incorporate comments from my daughter who has never played guitar, as well as from my son who plays electric guitar and has used other guitar controllers and is more accomplished with the games. (He plays most often at the "Hard" level, with occasional strolls into "Expert.")

My controller started right up right away the first time without any problems. Its easy to set up using the Wii controller that comes with the basic console. If you are reading this review, its because you want a high quality experience, so you want your guitar to look and feel like the real thing. Hard wood maple neck. Dark rosewood fretboard. Mother of pearl-like "Logitech" logo on the lower neck. Chrome throughout. It is a very realistic, high quality. If you want the plastic "toy," for your six year old, I suggest getting something cheaper and smaller. It was a very sweet moment, taking this beast out of the box.

I commented to my son that the neck might be slighly shorter than an actual electric guitar, but he said that this controller (entire unit is almost 34" top to bottom) actually has a longer neck than most typical Guitar Hero controllers! For folks who have never played guitar, or are familiar with the "el-cheapo" plastic devices, and people with smaller hands, you will notice that one of the costs of realism is that it may be more difficult for you to get your fingers around the neck. But the five buttons and slide are easy to get used to. Even my daughter (5' 4" - never played before, but with good hand eye coordination) was able to work the neck with her left hand with no problem. (We are all right handed. I don't know what the options are for you lefties out there....If you don't mind the location of the "whammy" bar, I guess you just flip it upside down.) You will need the strap that comes with it, because it weighs alot just like the real thing.

The traditional black picking area over the glossy white is very classy. It is shiny, hefty, and totally cool. This is the kind of gift you want to get your child to guarantee a "wow" moment when it comes out of the box.

My son thought the strum bar was a little longer than he'd seen in other controllers (almost 3 1/2 inches long), which allows plenty of freedom to move the right hand all over the place, and still have some bar to work with. I suggested he learn to strum with up and down motion to prepare for the lightning fast songs, but he is still getting great speed with the Logitech strum bar just strumming as fast as he can with a downward motion, and its relatively quiet.

The buttons work nicely. My son assured me any issues I was having were due to me, not the mechanics of the buttons. And I think he calibrated the timing of the "notes" for a little earlier strumming (using the Guitar Hero software) than I would have preferred. Nevertheless, I'd say the buttons work just fine. Logitech's write-up on the Amazon website is spot on, except perhaps for the sounds the buttons make. Again, it was probably me - my son was playing more difficult songs, and making fewer clicks. But I personally have no problem with sounds coming from the buttons. Just like I have no problem with the sounds my fingers make travelling up and down the base strings on my accoustic Taylor. This may be the software more than the controller, but I like the fact that when you mess up big time, the controller emits a gentle twang; nothing too harsh.

This product is consistent with other Logitech products I've reveiwed in the past. If you take care of them, fidelity is never an issue.

I've got to tell you, for this accoustic player, hitting a few hundred "notes" in a row, tilting the neck up to the sky to activate the bonus and feeling the vibration, fooling around with the "whammy" bar, etc., is hella fun. The star power button is disguised as the pickups, and the "+" button is the bridge. Basically, with the styling and color of this guitar, a little more practice, and a little less shaving, (I already wear glasses), I'll be an Eric Clapton look alike!

And thats what its all about people.

title: Love my PS5, it's worthy of the hype! text: Ignore all the low ratings from non-verified buyers. Stock was incredibly low and these consoles were near impossible to get. People are rating out of rage instead of merit.

I was lucky enough to score a Playstation 5 from Amazon on release day. I LOVE YOU AMAZON!!

This system is a beautiful masterpiece. Everything is cleaners and smoother AND OH SO MUCH FASTER than the PS4. Games have NO load times. Example CoD Cold War to load a single player match of zombie mode took nearly 2 minutes for the PS4 version to load on my PS4 Pro. The PS5 version repeating the same process is literally 2.4 seconds to be ready to play. Even downloading games from PSN is much much faster.

The only negative comment I can honestly make about the PS5 is the hard drive size. The wanted to make the system affordable and large SSD hard drives are very expense so they kept it under 1TB. As SSD prices fall in the future hopefully they release larger drives. PS4 games CAN be played now from external if you like. I installed multiple PS5 games and my most played PS4 and still have 200GB free so it's fine for the near future before juggling games becomes a thing.

Currently 30 hours into Demon's Souls and so glad Amazon had stock on launch day!

title: order this mouse new, stay away from the refurb
text: I ordered this because I am a longtime fan of Logitech products (20yrs+) I have purchased Logitech refurbished items in the past and they always looked and functioned like brand new. I bought this mouse mainly to play Quakelive. My old logitech mouse finally quit after 18yrs. (wingman gaming mouse) The first mouse I received looked brand new. I like this mouse. it feels good, its very precise, my aim is better with it,  but mid game it started changing settings on me on its own. I researched it, set up the software, unbound all buttons I wasn't using, made only one profile and deleted the rest, tried onboard memory and auto game detection,tried everything to be tried but nothing would stop it from changing settings on me mid game. I spent 2 days trying to get it to work, but determined it must be defective. I shouldn't have to spend 2 days and disable all other buttons and functions to get a mouse to work right in game. So I did a RMA with Amazon and asked for a replacement. My replacement came very quickly, and it was not in new condition. It was disgustingly filthy and I spent 10 minutes cleaning it. then I plugged it in and the left click does not even work. it is stuck down and doesn't click. The white box both mice (mouses?) came in say "Logitech Certified" refurbished. In my experience I've purchased dozens of refurbished items and they always look and function like new. I don't know how a company with Logitech's reputation for quality can certify a mouse that the left button doesn't even work on and is filthy dirty. I have already proceeded with RMA's for a full refund, and I ordered a brand new one for $20 more. Its a good mouse but I would not recommend buying the refurbished. spend the extra, buy it new and save yourself the headache.Amazon's customer service as always has been great.

title: MW2 basically w/Minor Changes. text: This game is good. I love the Call of Duty franchise and I love the Battlefield Franchise. I've been playing both since I was a kid.

I can say that both games are good. They are fun.. much fun. Both have their pros and cons. I'm not a hater on CoD or Battlefield.

The thing is with MW3.. It's really just MW2.... nothing changed really with the menu, nothing changed with the guns, nothing changed with the graphics really, nothing changed with the sound effects. It is all the same!!! If you can remember the sound effects of the flashbang and concussion bang and frag grenade dropping, it will ring to your ear as MW2.

It's boring kind of. I was playing it and I felt like I was playing Modern Warfare 2 just with different maps and kill streak settings.

Modern Warfare 3... you are fun. but you aren't new. It's still the same. I think the Modern Warfare era needs to come to an end after this one or the next one.... and I hope if they do make a 4th MW... it's no where near the same as these last 3. If Call of Duty does continue... please make some kind of Colonial game or go back into history of the Civil War, try something new? I have no idea, but the idea of World War I and II is really to old to keep making games around and the Modern era of war fighting games is kind of boring now because its something we see every day on the news or t.v. or in movies.

I'm disappointed in the game pretty much you can say. It's a big big let down from all the hype in my opinion. It's just Modern Warfare 2. ..thats all it is. Just with a few minor changes and small upgrades that aren't noticeable really.

title: Repetition- fairly brainless
text: Disappointed in this game. My son and I get bored after 10 minutes. Compared to excellent strategy games like Empire Total War, or even action games like Uncharted, James Bond..., this game takes place in a depressingly run down Arkham City, nothing pretty, or inspiring, just lots of repeated kicks, punches, etc. Sad to see such graphic potential wasted on brainless action.

title: Great options for the price text: I‚Äôll start out with the one con, it‚Äôs a little small for pro headphones. The width of the bar they hang on is not as wide as others and if you have large headphones they just barely fit next to each other without pushing/knocking into each other.

The height is also a bit low for pro headphones, mine almost touch the base and it‚Äôs not a big deal but if I wanted to use the plug outlet it would be interfering/bumping into the headphones themselves.

Otherwise, I really like this stand for its usb outlets (including usb-c) which has cleared up a lot of chord clutter and I really like the LED display, it looks really cool when it‚Äôs moving.

Even though the material is a bit cheap feeling, it‚Äôs pretty sturdy once you get it out together and looks nicer/more expensive than it is.

Overall I‚Äôm happy with it, just wish it was a bit taller and wider.

title: Enormous Amount of Review Material, Many Practice Tests, Clearly Explained Answers text: This BARRON‚ÄôS AP ART HISTORY WITH ONLINE TESTS book holds an enormous amount of art history review material, many practice AP tests, and clear explanations of why the correct answers are correct. The major drawback is that all of the illustrations of the art under discussion (paintings, architecture, sculpture, etc.) are printed in black and white.

Actually, because the book‚Äôs paper is very cheap, the illustrations are gray and white, and are totally lacking in detail. This problem is alleviated somewhat by the availability of full-color ‚Äúflash cards‚Äù of the art on the Barron‚Äôs site, but the illustrations are nevertheless disappointing.

I ordered this book because I have a college degree in art history, and I was curious about the design of AP courses in art history. It makes me kind of sad that the Barron‚Äôs book places so much emphasis on dry facts (e.g., dates, current locations of the art, artists‚Äô materials, artists‚Äô biographies, etc.). Apparently this is what is tested in the AP exam, but having to memorize all those facts and canned answers about periods in art history takes the joy out of studying fine art.

This book should provide everything that a student needs to obtain a high score on the AP art history exam.

title: I Love This Mouse
text: I needed a new gaming mouse as the cord on my old one had long since started to fray (it was woven, just like the DeathAdder's). It amazes me how well the DeathAdder fits in my hand. The buttons have the perfect amount of "give" to them. The green lighting makes the mouse look awesome. If it annoys you there is an option to turn the lighting off in the Synapse software, among all useful settings for the mouse (sensitivity, etc). I currently use it on my Mac, but will definitely be using it when I finish my PC build. I would definitely recommend the DeathAdder to any gamer looking to get an amazing mouse that won't break the bank.

text: I am disappointed with this headset. It is definitely better than the vanilla chat headset the comes with the xBox One, but not as good as my other stereo headset by Turtle Beach. The sound in the ear is pretty good. I like the "open" ear feature that allows me to hear my family when they try to talk to me. The part that I'm not as happy with is the mic and the cord. The sound quality of the mic isn't as good as the stereo headset. My chat friends notice a difference when I switch and say they can't hear me as well with this one.The other problem is the cord.  I've owned this headset for less than 3 months, and the cord has frayed and is breaking at the base of the connector to the controller. Where the plug-in becomes wire gets pinched against me when I hold it. It can't be avoided, therefore it is breaking. I wish the connector was a 90 degree plug-in that I've seen on other headsets. Those seem to hold up better.

It just degenerates into a build and shove to the front.
In short, it is pretty good but lacks any deep plot or replay value. And after a few hours you will just hate the battle anims.

title: Lack of instructions is annoying. Should include positioning tape.
text: I got this to give to my mom for Christmas to go with her Nintendo switch light that I bought her as well. Thankfully I decided to put one on my own switch and then put a screen protector on hers rather than just give her the package. Because she‚Äôs never put a screen protector on anything and I know she would‚Äôve had no idea how to do it.  There are no instructions whatsoever in the box. Many times manufactures just stick a piece of paper in there with a link to a YouTube video to explain how to do it, but there wasn‚Äôt anything like that either. I‚Äôve done screensavers on phones and iPads and digital cameras and stuff before so I know how to do it. but not everybody does. Missing from the package were the positioning tapes that most glass screen savers use to make it easier to apply the screen in the correct place. I used washi tape I had laying around. Also, they had a little sticker that said some thing about this being the back. I pulled that little tiny sticker off and the protective film on the back did not come off. I stuck the little sticker to the box to get it out of my way and then realized that you were intended to stick it on another portion of the protective film on the back of the screen protector and then it would stick and you could remove it. I do not understand why they did that that way and with no instructions, you were left to figure it out for yourself. The screen protector itself is nice. Once I got it on I had no bubbles, I don‚Äôt even know it‚Äôs there, it doesn‚Äôt seem to interfere with the touchscreen, and it seems to be good quality. But the lack of instructions and other issues make me unable to recommend it.

title: Better options in Windows than Mac text: The headset I bought from Amazon didn't come in a box and was very much used, regardless of me paying full price for a new set. Fortunately, I was able to return it for a full refund and bought it from OfficeMax at a much lower price.

Since there are a lot of reviews out there, I'll make this quick:

Pros:
* Clear sound.
* Works as intended.
* The mute LED is super useful.

Indifferent:
* Will pair to multiple bluetooth sources, as long as you manually disconnect and connect it at the sources.
* Bluetooth volume is adjusted by clicking the volume button down and going through the menu.

Cons:
* The headset will automatically disconnect from the PC, but will not reconnect without turning the headset off and on again, while bluetooth has no auto-disconnect/off feature. There may be a way to reactivate the connection to PC because the headset never really turns off, as it'll make the powerdown sound if I actually turn the headset off. I'll have to find out if I'm just using this feature incorrectly.
* I get some distortion/buzzing with bass in certain circumstances, notably when watching some YouTube content, but fiddling with the equalizer seems to mitigate this.
* Range isn't as good as I was expecting, and bluetooth doesn't always make a solid connection when reconnecting, as my coworkers said that I sounded like a robot when I left the room and came back.
* If you wear these around your neck, be prepared for them to be uncomfortably snug, and the mute button to turn on and off while it rubs against your chest.
* I was expecting deeper bass, but it performs decently well.
* Battery life isn't the greatest in comparison to newer stuff out there, and the battery saving options are almost non-existent.

I haven't read the manual and only had to go online for a couple things I couldn't figure out, but it has been working great so far. It's a great headset, although I'd prefer better battery life while also foregoing the swapping battery "feature". I bought this headset for work and play, pairing to my work laptop via bluetooth and my gaming laptop via the dock.

I've found that the audio options in the GG application are a bit different between Windows and Mac. On Mac, you only get an equalizer with presets, volume limiter, live mic preview, and mic sidetone adjustment. On Windows, you 'also' get DTS 7.1 surround, surround profile, stereo profile, bass enhancement, and dialogue enhancement. I suspect this is due to licensing, and to be honest, I these extras don't do a whole lot, IMHO.

title: The only NES game that was ever any good. text: I grew up when the Atari was the machine to have, so I largely missed out on the entire beginning of the Nintendo craze till the SNES came out, at which point my mother (who was and still is a total console-game freak) gave me her 8-bit Nintendo and all her old games. She had about 40 games, all the old favorites like Zelda, but none of them caught my attention till I tried Final Fantasy.
It is a rich, multi-layered game that's extremely straightforward. There are few puzzles (I hate them, so that's good), few mazes, and few trials that are overly difficult. It's a straight hack-and-slash game -- go kill things, go through this new level and kill things there, get objects, find the big bad guy and kill him too at the end. Basically, if you're persistent, you'll figure it all out. And there's none of that irritating "ensemble cast" design that the later FFs seem to like. As simple as the game design is, it still manages to tell a rich and involving story that actually, considering this is a Japanese game, makes sense. It took me a month or so to beat the game, and I immediately made another party and set out again at level 1, it's so good.
Since then, my mother's given me her SNES too, and I think some other system that involves CDs, but I still play Final Fantasy almost exclusively and still love it. If you actually manage to find this game, and you're a puzzle-hater like me, then I think you'll like it.

title: <Loading...> Initial <Loading...> impressions. <Loading...> text: (For some reason my review keeps reverting to the PS4 version, even though I delete and resubmit under the Switch version. This review is based on playing the version for the Switch.)

CTR was the first game I ever 100%'d. Even for years after, I tried my darnedest to unlock Nitros Oxide, refusing to believe all the confirmations out there that he just wasn't unlockable. My sisters, dad, and cousins would play this game non-stop for months. I still have my original copy, and purchased it on PSN for my PS3 and PSP. This is the only game I have to get on all possible systems (besides Plants vs. Zombies). So I was pretty freakin' ecstatic when they announced a remake.

First, the loading times. They are awful. I was talking to a co-worker about the game this morning and he said he was reading reviews that the game was great but that they mentioned the long loading times. I didn't believe it, but I was wrong. They occur when you load up races, and at the beginning of the story mode. They sort of kill the enthusiasm. I had heard that they're not that bad on other systems, but on the Switch it takes anywhere from 30 seconds to a minute before every track. Definitely needs to get fixed. I can see myself bringing this to friends' houses only for the loading to create a buzzkill.

Once you get past them, though, you can actually play. And here's my other biggest problem: the hopping. I can't play CTR without the boosts. I've played MK8D and TSR and I'm always drifting and boosting, and it's all thanks to CTR when I played starting 20 years ago. I don't know what it is, but the jumping doesn't feel the same this time. Either the jumps are too high or they're too long, but they're definitely floaty. I'm actually able to change the direction mid-air, which I don't recall doing. I played the original to confirm, and the jumps definitely are slightly longer/higher here than in the original. In the original, the characters feel a wee bit heavier, which is far better for power sliding.
Subsequently, I'm not able to time and complete my boosts as I was before. I really hope I'm wrong and it's just me being a bit rusty, but if it's not the same then I'm going to have to change the way I play this game.

Now, as for the positives, I love the extra content they added without really detracting from the overall experience. The visuals are beautiful, and they've added things here and there to the tracks without really changing them (e.g., Coco's track has a statue of Coco, Crash Cove has a sculpt of Crash, etc.). I played CNK back when it released, but don't really remember it. I really like that they added the CNK tracks and the other character; there were a couple of CNK tracks I remember but the characters I don't recall at all. Still, a nice touch.

The customization really worried me when they announced it, as I had thought it would change the driving mechanics, but not so. In kart racers like MK, there are way too many customizations and I can never find one that feels right (and by right I mean one that drives like CTR). Here, the customizations are purely cosmetic, which I more than welcome. Each driver is the same from the previous iteration, and the little changes to the character and kart are just for show.
Thank goodness.

Here's hoping Activision/Beenox updates the loading times for the Switch and, if necessary, the jumps. Right now, the jumps need to be either lower or shorter.

title: Engrossing and Entertaining
text: Born a Crime: Stories fro a South African childhood is just a brilliant book. All I knew of Trevor Noah prior to this book was seeing him on The Daily Show and admiring his comedy. This book takes you into his childhood and it is fascinating. As the title says he was born a crime from a white Swiss father and black Xhosa mother. Pretty much born into poverty Noah's mother would not let that slow her down. She was a good Christian woman who took Trevor to church all day Sunday, to black church, to white church and mixed church. During the week prayer meetings and bible study. She was a good woman that wanted the best for Noah. She spoke English, Afrikaans, Zulu, Xhosa and German. Speaking all those languages helped her navigate through life and get a secretary job. Trevor also learned quite a few languages which was excellent because being light skinned it was harder to fit in with childhood friends and he spent quite a bit of time alone. Trevor was smart, high energy and mischievous which got him into plenty of trouble in his younger years. This is a totally engrossing book about Trevor Noah and about the politics of South Africa while he was growing up.  Moves quickly and keeps you laughing.

title: A Nice Bag For Your Expensive Investment text: If you're lucky enough to have secured a PS5, then you know what an investment it is between the console, controllers, games, peripherals, etc.. So, having a solid way to transport your pricey gear is paramount.

This PS5 carrying case from Connyam is a great way to store & carry your system. The bag quality is on par with a heavy duty nylon laptop bag. And it's very roomy once fully expanded. Plenty of room for your unit.

There is a zipper pocket on the outside of the bag. However, there are no pockets or compartments on the interior. Instead, you are given padded fabric dividers (again, like you would find in a laptop case) that will allow you to construct compartments for your accessories, cables, etc..

There are no images or instructions included with the bag. So be sure to look at the Amazon listing for the intended layout.

I would say this bag is water resistant, but NOT waterproof. So if you had to bring it through the rain, I think you would be OK. But standing with it in the rain, I'm not sure I would want to risk it. There is also a carrying strap as well as a stitched set of handles.

So to wrap up, if you think of this bag as a heavy duty laptop case, but instead for your PS5, then you will have a very good idea of what to expect.

title: Excellent Value for a One-Handed Mechanical Gaming Keyboard text: RedThunder One-Handed Mechanical Gaming Keyboard is a functional half keyboard with mechanical keys. The only issue I ran into during my use of this item was that once the re-bindable macro keys were altered, I was unable to revert them into the original "F" keys they began. The instructions were difficult to fully understand. I am uncertain if it was due to translation difficulties or a lack of space on the small pamphlet.

RedThunder One-Handed Mechanical Gaming Keyboard allowed me to conserve space on my desk. The keyboard is a good starting point for any gamer interested in an mechanical keyboard that does not want to commit to the higher price for a full keyboard.

With small rubber-like feet to help keep it in place and the light weight design the product can help on-the-go laptop users. The keyboard had built in anti-ghosting, so you would not drop keys when pressing multiples at the same time. This will allow more hectic game-play without dropped inputs. The half of the keyboard you get with this covers most basic PC games (most First person shooters), but may leave you lacking for games which expect a full range (such as Smite or a multitude of strategy games).

A small card that came with the keyboard from the creator pressing for those with issues to reach out to the makers and those with positive opinions to share their opinion. The website advertised by the production company was mostly not useful as I was unable to find anything of great use and there was a number of translation errors on the physical box [example: "Fast eating chicken stability with many key no conflict reaction"].

Overall, I find RedThunder One-Handed Mechanical Gaming Keyboard is a good product. It's ideal for someone who is looking to reduce their wear and tear on a laptop, shared keyboard, an addition to their portable/space sensitive options, or anyone wanting to dip their toes into a mechanical keyboard.

Of note: the box does not mention support for windows 10. They keys are click-y and the extra volume can be jarring for those whom live in close quarters.

Thank you for reading my review. I hope you have found it helpful and informative.

title: Fun update of NES Track & Field text: Some people apparently find it difficult to use the controls. I did not have this trouble, although a few of the events had a minor learning curve (3-5 tries to get decent at them), but nothing frustrating. Even my 3 year old was able to play many of the minigames (in fact, he was better than me at the triple jump haha).

Several reviewers said their arms hurt from playing this (because running requires you to move the nunchuck and wiimote back and forth). This was true for me at first, but then after messing around a bit I realized that you don't have to forcefully move them to run fast. You can use small, quick, gentler motions to get to a good speed. My 3 year old doesn't get to full speed, but he consistently gets the blue signal that he's running fast...and he does not even hold them right. Don't get me wrong; you definitely get a very minor workout and will probably sweat a little :)

Several of those lower rated reviews also compare this to Mario Party, which is a bad comparison in my opinion. This game certainly is not trying to be Mario Party. This game is more like an updated NES track and field with Wii Controls.

The only negative I have is the misleading Wi-Fi tag. You cannot actually play others online, which is what I assumed. You can upload your records and see how your records rank against the world which is nice, but online play would have been fun.

I enjoy the "Circuit" mode which makes you compete in 4 events against the computer. Winning these adds trophies to your collection, opens more circuits, and opens more Olympic events.

I also enjoy the Mission mode where you have to take finish meet certain goals for 6 different events. I have not completed one with all 6 yet as I still have to open up a couple of minigames. It'll be fun trying to complete the goals for every character.

One of the low reviews also mentioned that there was no replay value. This is hard to comprehend since I have found a ton of replay value. Trying to master the events, set world records, rank higher than online records, completing circuits to open up new events/circuits, and mission mode are extremely fun and you are replaying events over and over. Not to mention getting family or friends to play with you so that you can compete against each other.

My favorite events so far are: Trampoline, Skeet Shooting, Javaline, Hammer Throw, and rowing (scully or something). I like the running events, especially the 400 meters where you have to focus on the character's stamina to keep him from slowing down due to being tired. Archery is fun. I have the most difficulty with table tennis, long jump, and triple jump (the jumping events my 3 year old can beat me at heh).

Overall, I really enjoy this game. Online play would have put this over the top for a 5 star rating, but there is a lot to do without online play. I too am a Mario Party fan (I give Mario Party 8 four stars also). Don't expect this to be Mario Party, but a sporting event at the Olympics and enjoy!

title: Great simple game for puzzles and missions !

title: Kickass headset!
text: My son loves everything about this headset and his ability to enjoy gaming - crisp audio, booming bass, full immersive sound and captivation while he is in the zone, so much so that I gotta smack him upside the head to get his attention, LOL. There are headsets that are ridiculously expensive and they shouldn't have to be - this is a solid headset with all you need and at a price that you want.

title: Good waste of Time and Money text: I've been playing now for over 2 weeks.
Problems:
1. Max level of 20.
2. Grinding for items.
3. Not able to adjust attributes when leveling. Must use items to adjust.

If you can over look those items then the game is ok for you.

It is an hybrid open world. You must link to areas. Those area go back to map screen.

You can craft items (grinding necessary).

You are allowed to select you skills (20 only, 1 per level)

I am disappointed in the game. Bioware really limits the character development. The story continues to follow the previous story. As in the PrimaGuide collectors edition, it states you will die die die die and die again.

I love the series. I own the previous 2 versions.
If you have kids, this will take them weeks to finish.

I guess that is what BioWare wanted, a long drawn out game.

Update:
The game follows D&D.
20 is the max number in everything.
The DM causes the story to be what he wants.
After playing for 90 hours the story becomes drugged out.
Tis the story of one whom thinks they have the right to be worshiped and "the adventurers" who stop the "bad guy".
Items in game that the player have are so weak tis insane.
Once player learns how to make items, making your own, you rule the game.
I find the game in a lot of aspects to be boring.
hmmmmm ...

title: Flashy but Boring Game Loop text: This game, stylistically similar to the Persona universe, is a grindfest with a thin storyline and average musical score. You basically roam around areas, fighting groups of demons, and try to recruit and fuse them to get more powerful demons to aid you. You can talk to demons to get items and recruit them but they might also ask for things from you or attack outright.

This series, unlike Persona, is centered around grinding more than story. I find it to be quite boring, actually. You need to grind to find collectibles, grind for XP, grind to get items, and grind to fuse and level demons. It's just grinding. The story is forgettable and trite.

I got this game and played it for about 10 hours total. Then set it aside and will probably sell it. It's like the other entries in the series; if you love a boring grindfest, you'll really like this one because the mechanics are set up well. If you want a story or some character development like P5, you are better off skipping this one.

title: Love it, more fun than the biggest loser games for Wii!!
text: After using The Biggest Loser Challenge(TBL) for Wii and the TBL: Ultimate fit version for xbox360s kinect for a few weeks I got this game to change things up. It wasn't expensive and I was beginning to feel a bit discouraged with a lack of weight loss(although a ton of muscle gain). I have done maybe 4 workouts with this game so far and I love it!!! It is much more upbeat and fast paced then TBL game which was really nice. You sweat [...] with my fitness coach and are suprised when you look at how much time has passes. Also this game gives you a timer of how much workout time is left total, shows the workouts that are next and a bar passes showing how much longer you will be doing that workout. the setup was fun and extensive as well as the original fitness test. The moves seem a bit silly at first, even simple, but your arms will start killing you from lifting them up in every routine and you know you are getting a good workout. I use my heartrate monitor with this game and burn about 300 calories in a 30min workout, opposed to the 100 it tells me on the game. I encourage people to try the 30 min to start as it goes by really fast and you get a great workout while having fun. I have noticed a profound difference in just using this a few days, it was a good switch up from what I had been doing and I like it better. I can already see my waist is smaller than right before I started with thisgame and am excited to see the difference in another week. I HIGHLY reccommend.

title: Nice, practical case for the price.
text: I really wanted to do away with the stacks of 3DS cases I had lying around, so a simple case was in order. A pink one seemed ideal, and I stumbled across this one. While it's certainly not the sturdiest or most rigid plastic, it seems tough enough. The hinges on the 'pages' operate smoothly, and the case closes with a rather satisfying click. 3DS and DS games alike snap in securely. There are two spots for SD and/or MicroSD cards as well, I haven't tried these. It appears that a MicroSD card would fit behind an SD card in that slot, so theoretically I think you could put two of each in this case. I'd probably prefer just another game slot there, as I don't really swap out the Micro SD card in my 3DS, but it's not a big deal. All in all, for the price this is a pretty nice little case.

title: Lots of fun, but very, very buggy

I'll earn a token, but when I go to buy it, it flashes back and forth between "locked" and the purchase price.  If you catch it quickly enough you can buy the token, but sometimes you can't use it when you go into free play mode.  You need certain characters for certain parts of the story (a goblin for keys, dark wizard for dark magic, strong person for pulls, etc) so this takes the enjoyment out of many areas of the game.  Overall I really enjoy the game, but I wish these things could be fixed so I could play the whole game, and not just parts of it.

title: Awesome overall but spotted a couple issues text: Just got done watching them all. Really fantastic set. Includes all the original scenes as they aired in my childhood. The quality is great.

However I do have a couple grips.

First, no matter what play I use, the audio track defaults to the Euro dub with the exceptionally boring music. So I constantly have to remember to switch to the other English audio track. So I'm taking off a star for that annoyance.

Second, the creator of this set was very lazy about updating the intro, intermission and outro. This set sometimes updated the intro but the intermission and outro were the same as season 1 until part way through season 7. =/ I was very much looking forward to seeing the awesome intros, intermissions and outros introduced as the series went on. Like what I would have seen watching Saturday morning cartoons as a kid. So for that I'm taking off a star.

title: Great controller! text: This controller is fantastic. It feels good in the hands, operates flawlessly via wireless connection, and uses 2 AA batteries (mine are rechargeable, which helps a lot ... I always recommend rechargeable batteries for game controllers). I can sit far away from the TV and still play without a problem. Having no wires is great because there is no tripping or tangling going on.

Btw, I should add that I am very picky about my controllers. I have had several bad controllers in the past (e.g. buttons that stick, buttons that you have to press really hard to get a response, controllers that die within a week of use, etc.). Thankfully, this controller has given me no problems. I actually got it used and it works just fine. I highly recommend this product.

title: Worth it

He eeked out the use of that headset until we could get another one. It took awhile to get this since every time I tried to order it, it was on backorder but patience is a virtue and once ordered, it came in good time. It works as expected which is a pretty high expectation. It isn't just the sound that is good; it is the fit. He's particular about the fit of headsets and this one is the most comfortable. A little outside the budget but definitely a worthwhile buy.

title: Heaven's hitman has no hands text: This game is most similar to Serious Sam than any other game I can think of except whereas SS is mainly in large open spaces with hundreds of opponents, this one is more commonly in large rooms with dozens of opponents. That's OK - it's pretty much what I expected.

But what I don't like is the way you have no way to stack items except to repeatedly hit them randomly until they fall the way you want them. Then you better quick save because as soon as you try to jump on them they'll fall down and you'll have to start again. All the surfaces except the floor seem very slippery and moving on them is another exercise in frustration. I quit at the military base because I didn't spend $20 to waste 30 minutes randomly hitting tanks to stack them up so I could move on.

Most of the secret locations and holy items are almost impossible to reach unless you are prepared to spend a ridiculous amount of time on it. I'm not - I have a life - and it doesn't include this stupid game.

title: Better than the Curious Village! text: I loved the game more than Curious Village....and that's saying something!!! What a great series! This game has Professor Layton and Luke traveling by train to solve the mystery of the Elysian Box.....which is believed to kill any who open it.

* The puzzles are challenging....the music is great....the story line is intriguing.

* The mini-games in this one are even better than Curious Village. The hamster maze challenge is my favorite. There is also a tea challenge. As you go through the game, different tea ingredients are unlocked. Some people in the game will want a specific cup of tea (to rejuvenate them, relax them, etc.). You have to experiment with the tea pot to find the right mix of ingredients to complete the request. There is also a photo challenge where you are given 2 photographs and you need to try to spot the differences. Sounds easy....buuuuuttt, it's not. Not all of them anyway.

* Just as in Curious Village....this game has bonus puzzles that are unlocked as you progress through the game.

* Additional weekly puzzles available through Wi-Fi.

This game is fantastic!!! A great buy....you won't be disappointed!

title: Mandatory text: This is hands-down the strap replacement you want for the Quest 2.

Even wearing glasses I'm able to run 4+ hour VR sessions with no discomfort thanks to this head mount. It's easy to adjust, easy to take on and off, and distributes weight evenly around your head. Construction seems sturdy and I expect to get more than a year of heavy use out of it.

The one caveat is that mounting a battery is tricky, but lucky for you I've already gone through the trial and error.

I'm using these power banks:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08XQQ2LC5?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2_dt_b_product_details
installed into this mounting bracket:
https://www.amazon.com/dp/B08P1N8LDQ?psc=1&ref=ppx_yo2_dt_b_product_details
and threaded through the included BOBOVR top strap. Check the pictures for details.

There's a bit of wobble when I pitch my head at extreme angles but when the battery is kept as far back as possible this doesn't happen often. If you went through the trouble of trimming a top strap to a perfect fit you could eliminate this problem but I'm not bothered enough to do that. You could also look for a lighter power bank.

Overall I'm extremely satisfied and with this running cheaper than the Elite strap it's really a no-brainer.

title: Im wholly disappointed in this text: Im wholly disappointed in this. They didn't bother to update the activities to use the Wii Motion Plus, and the result is that games like snowball fight where accurate tracking is required are unusable. When trying to aim quickly, the target jerks around the screen. I've researched this and it seems that it's not a setting. The regular wii motion sticks don't have enough resolution to work properly with wii U.

I wish I knew this in advance. I never would have purchased the upgrade. If you have the old wii, there's no reason to upgrade just for wii Fit.

There's only 1 activity in Wii Plus (rock climbing) that uses the motion plus feature. What's the point of it if even nintendo games don't utilize it?

title: Great Customizable Gaming Mouse text: I have been extremely frustrated with wireless mice in the past and due to that, I got this mouse after hearing many positive reviews. its not a very expensive gaming mouse by any means, I got it for about $60. The mouse as is, comes with a nice set of features and accessories right out of the box, it comes with weights and a different grip, which can be easily swapped and adjusted with ease. the mouse also is very nice since it has sensitivity adjustment and two extra buttons right at your fingertips to make in-game adjustments and play style adjustments simple. I find myself thankful for the DPI adjustment buttons whenever I switch between sniping, regular gunfights and piloting vehicles, since they all work better with different levels of sensitivity. like any Logitech mouse, you can easily change the DPI levels to suit the situations, and the G9x can set 5 levels per profile, anywhere between 200 and 5700 DPI. Personally I have 500 DPI for sniping, 1800 DPI for other combat or general use and 2400 DPI for vehicles. ever since I switched to this mouse, it feels like I can finally point EXACTLY where I want to in games, and with most of the games I play requiring lighting reflexes and precision, I have been able to stay alive longer in FPS games and kill enemies with much more ease, the moment I get hit by any enemy, I am able to whip around and accurately return fire in an instant. one thing I have to complain about is that the textured grip wears down very quickly.

on another note, I have pretty small hands, and I still find this mouse to be very comfortable, it just took a bit to get used to it, since its between a large and mini-mouse in size, i guess you can consider it medium-large.

This is one of the best mice I have ever used, and would recommend it to anyone that is looking for a very nice and very customizable wired mouse for gaming without shelling out too much.

title: Nintendo DS Cake Mania review
text: I originally played this game as a download on my cell phone and was hopelessly addicted to it.  So when I got my Nintendo DS....I thought I'd get the DS version and try it out.  It is definitely a keeper.  I have now tried Cake Mania 2 and 3 as well....and this one is still a winner.  The cake/frosting/icing buttons are nice and big.  It is easy to distinguish the shapes on the layer cakes.  And my personal FAVORITE thing about this game......it saves your final score!!!!  I really wish the other 2 games did that.  I like the challenge of trying to beat my previous scores.  At 1st,  I wasn't too crazy about the fact that the screen has to scroll over to get to the place for the toppers...but I got used to it and now it doesn't bug me so much.  It is definitely a time management game worth having.  If it actually SAVED your progress on each level so you could quit and turn off your DS and then get back to it the following day....I would have given the game 5 stars.  As it is....to get a really high score,  you have to play the game all the way through.

title: Somewhat decent. Wait for a sale. text: This one was decently fun. War mode is very cool. But like most COD games, the matches are full of quickscopers using snipers as shotguns. Hit detection feels really weird. I'm not a fan of the TTK. Many guns you'll hit 3-4 shots and the guy will still be alive.

Zombies is there, and if you like zombies mode, you'll like it. I'm not a fan of the mode myself, but did think this one was much better than BO3.

Headquarters is kinda ridiculous. A social hub-like area kind of like Destiny where all the players congregate. They put this here so you can open lootboxes in front of other players, enticing them to buy them. Scummy move. The UI in headquarters is atrocious. Player names everywhere, tons of voice chatter which you're not able to disable permanently, you'll need to do so every time you go in. The shootout challenges are pretty decent. Compete against other players doing target practice.

I mean, it's COD. If you generally like the COD franchise, I think you'll like it. Glad it's back to boots on the ground and not running along walls and jetpacking. Personally, I'd rather just play battlefield 1. It has operations which is like war mode, and bigger fights, so you're not just running around killing the same 6 guys over and over again.

title: Best headset I've used over 15 years of playing on Xbox Live
text: Microsoft's first-party Xbox Live headsets are a complete sham and the very definition of planned obsolescence. This headset, however, has clear and crisp voice chat, never gets uncomfortable to wear, is easy to clean, and sends a very clear voice signal through Live. As many others have noted, the first time you use this on a new controller, you'll need to open your Xbox settings and adjust the ear volume manually from the menu. It defaults to a very low volume for some reason, but I bumped it all the way up once and have never had a single technical issue over three (!) years.

title: Decent choice if you need to use Xbox One wireless text: I have a variety of gaming headsets, including several from Turtle Beach. Sound was clear, though not great (good enough for most game audio, but nothing to use for lossless music). I'd compare to basic Bluetooth headphones (nothing with LDAC or even APTx or AAC).

It's heavy and well built and comes with a case, silicone adapter for 2000 and 3000 series PSPs and a microfiber cleaning cloth.  On the downside, it gets a little fatiguing to hold after awhile. title: Barron's AP Art History with Online Tests text: This AP Art History Reviewer goes over the AP Exam and how to approach the test, offers a diagnostic test, and then reviews the following topics: Prehistoric Art, Ancient Near Eastern Art, Egyptian Art, Greek Art, Etruscan Art, Roman Art, Late Antique Art, Byzantine Art, Islamic Art, Early Medieval Art, Romanesque Art, Gothic Art, Gothic Art in Italy, Renaissance in Northern Europe, Early Renaissance in Italy: Fifteenth Century, High Renaissance and Mannerism, Baroque Art, Art of New Spain: Spanish Colonies in the Americas, Rococo and Neoclassicism, Romanticism, Late Nineteenth-Century Art, Early and Mid-Twentieth-Century Art, Indian and Southeast Asian Art, Chinese and Korean Art, Japanese Art, Art of the Americas, African Art, Pacific Art, and Contemporary Art.
There are practice tests and access to online flash cards that make up for the black and white pictures that come in the book.
The book gives a both an overview and exposure to different art movements and specific works of art.

title: Disappointing text: Writen By Jimmy's Son J.T. Nolan, (look young, Feel young) lol

I pre-ordered this game simply because the PS3 version is awesome.In the PS3 version the Create mode enables you to...
1) have 3 layers of depth that allow you to make your created levels more apealing to the eye and more diverse in the veriety of electronics and machines you can create.
2) Be able to easly make any shape of any size in a short amount of time.
3) Not be restricted by the operating system.

Such in not so in the PSP create mode. It only has 2 layers of depth. And it is very difficult to make a shape that you want. (Being an advanced creator I sometimes make very complex polygons and things of that nature) Also the controls are very hard to get used to. By now you should have realized that my primary purpose in LBP is to Create.

On the up side of things. The story levels in this new version are quite exiting. (I doubt that Media Modules only used the controls and items offered to you in the create mode to make their complex levels.) Anyway they are very fun and enjoyable for awhile. Being as early as it is in this new versions history, I'm not suprised at all that there are very few fun community levels. This is understandable due to the restricted tools and ability of the new create mode. So don't expect to be wowed by the imagination of your fellow Sackboys in the version.

So to close I say that If you want this game to be able to create while on the move, I wouldn't recomend it unless you have the patience to handle it. If you just like to play the levels, it's not a bad idea to try this new version out. If you have a PS3 and do not have this game for that particular system I would highly advise you to purchase it!

I hope this review helped you.

I <3 LBP

title: Home ports of some of the most notable arcade titles of the 80s & 90s, and some original games too. text: Note - I got this as part of the premium bundle.

I am much more acquainted with Data East's arcade output than their home ports, so this has been really interesting to explore. I'm still trying out everything, but so far Magical Drop 2 has absorbed most of my time. The NES Burger Time is off from the arcade version in frustrating ways, but maybe I'll get used to it. Joe and Mac 2 is good as ever, and Side Pocket is weirdly addictive. Burnin' Rubber, aka Bump'n'Jump, is probably my favorite title here.

Karate Champ has not held up well. Fighter's History is not a patch on Street Fighter II, but for a system with few fighting game options so far, it's one of the best. Bad Dudes and Two Crude Dudes aren't quite as sublimely over the top as their arcade versions, but they're still a good laugh and really fun examples of a genre that I'm not great at. Midnight Resistance, a spiritual successor to Heavy Barrel with tons of Contra influence, is new to me; I'm enjoying it a lot.

I wouldn't have bought the system for this collection, but I'm having a lot of fun with it nonetheless, especially for the "free" game with the premium edition!

title: Taking sound to the next level text: Prior experience: First set of dedicated gaming earphones.

Used with: PS3 - I don't have an Xbox360.

Using the Quick Start Guide that was supplied, the cable connection part was easy enough, but the overall setup experience was a bit of a pain - first pairing the headset with the PS3 via Bluetooth, and then configuring the PS3. I didn't get any sound out of it at first (except for it telling me that it was powered on or politely saying goodbye) until it was fully charged, and then everything fell into place after that. It needs to be paired with the PS3 first as instructed or you cannot set it as your input/output device in the PS3 settings.

There are three modes - game, movie and music. With game mode, you can choose from eight presets to enhance your gaming experience. There are also about eight presets for chatting, some of which can alter the sound of your voice. In addition, you can plug your headset into your computer and go to the Turtle Beach website (http://www.turtlebeach.com/community/preset-community) to customize the sounds of your favorite games to give yourself a competitive advantage, or to immerse yourself in the game through the use of audio presets and voice prompts. You will need to register to get access to the customization tools and to download Turtle Beach and Community created audio presets.

The sound quality is excellent for game play, (for example, you can hear the footsteps of your opponents even before they come around a corner) as well as for chatting with other players while playing. In addition, the earphones are very comfortable for long hours of use and block out any surrounding noise.

Another great feature is the Dolby surround sound. There are six easily accessible settings that you can use to get the effects to suit your current gaming mood.

It takes about 6 hours to charge, but this is not a problem as you can continue playing while it is charging. The manufacturer states that a full charge lasts about 15 hours, but due to real life interruptions I have not been able to verify this.

The headset can be paired via Bluetooth to two Bluetooth enabled devices simultaneously. For example, you can chat via your PS3 when playing a game and still receive/make phone calls, but I haven't tried the phone part as yet. There are separate Bluetooth volume controls on the right ear cup to adjust the chat/phone volume (Game volume controls are on the left ear cup)

Finally, using the mobile device cable supplied, you can plug it into any regular earphone jack and the headset can now be used as regular earphones with your audio device (music/MP3 player, computer, tablet, smartphone, etc.)

Overall, the sound is great and truly enhances your entire gaming experience.

title: Looks awesome! text: I ordered the 'Tilted Nation RGB Headset Stand and Gaming Headphone Display with Mouse Bungee Cord Holder with USB 3.0 HUB for Wired or Wireless Headsets for Xbox, PS4, PC' for review and would like to share my thoughts.

It's sturdy and looks really nice on my desk. The RGB lighting is pretty sweet and the color options are nice and work well, although I have had one time where the lights shut off and I had to unplug the device then plug it bag in to get the lighting back on. I am not sure what happened but since then it has worked fine. I love the fact that I can also use the base to plug in a couple other USB 3.0 devices such as my RGB mouse-pad and even an SD card reader. Another great feature is the flexible mouse cable arm that keeps my mouse cable from getting snagged. I have never used anything like this before and I must say that it is pretty nice! Overall I love this stand and think it is a great value for what you get.

title: It will break in a few years. Don't spend this amount on a headset text: Its probably a common flaw in all headsets but the plastic will break at a joint at some point. The warranty will be 1-2 years depending on where you live. I would assume that it would break the day after warranty and decide if spending 300$ on something that lasts that long is worth it. Probably not the case for most people.
I would suggest finding a headset that costs less to begin with because "stuff" happens. and also find a headset that strong support frame, especially at any jointing. Durability was a very under appreciated consideration when checking reviews for gaming headsets.
Side note: Right to repair laws would be great in this situation. I would be happy to spend 20-50 dollars to order a replacement part of the plastic piece or receive a 3D print file to print a replacement myself.

title: Short but sizzling single-player experience text: Medal of Honor: Warfighter is one of the most enjoyable shooters I've played in some time. The single player campaign was thoroughly immersive and even portions I normally don't enjoy (car chases, for example) were set up so that repeated trial and error allowed you to advance. The combat, the weapons, the diversity of missions and terrain and settings all felt realistic and were a blast. I just wish there was more of it. I think I finished the campaign in about 6-8 hours (and I'm older and a slower gamer ;-). I could see others finishing in 4-5 hours and $60 is a bit much for games that short.

I played multi-player a bit and it didn't really hold my attention like the Call of Duty series. It feels a lot more realistic, a lot more one-shot, one-kill in Medal of Honor, but the fact that it doesn't support same console split-screen coop as part of it's special forces multiplayer mission sort of forces you to play online in two-man teams with near strangers and that isn't super conducive to the type of stealth and support tactics necessary in this seriously hard core multi-player mode.

If the single player campaign had been longer (maybe twice as long) and the multi-player supported same console coop missions, I would have given this a 5 star rating.

title: Amazing mouse text: My 13-year-old son who is into gaming says this is an "amazing mouse." It is the best mouse that he's ever owned, and over the years he's gone through many of them, constantly upgrading. It is awesome paired with a mouse bungee. The two side buttons are great because they are programmable and you can do whatever you want with them. My son owns many Razer products and he says this is one of the best.

He has a few minor criticisms. First, the two DPI buttons are easily hit and that has sometimes impacted his gaming performance. Also, when he first plugged in the mouse it prompted him to download a lot of Razer software that he didn't need. He would have preferred if it was more simple because he had to uninstall half of it.

Just getting started playing and noticed the option for standard glyph map or expert. Evidently the expert was available in international versions and just included in US remastered version. Storyline holds up after many years and the gameplay is great for older gamers whose eyes can't handle fast paced FPS's like we used to be able to.

title: Not enough lift, poor grip on the mouse cable. text: I wanted to keep my mouse cord off the desk because it's a cloth wrapped cable and the sound of it dragging across the edge of my mouse pad is fingernails on a chalk board level of annoying to me. Initially I did not want to spend twice as much on the Razer Mouse Bungee, but after receiving this I wished I had.

The rubber arm didn't do a good job of gripping my mouse cable, so I was always pulling more slack into the cable, and within an hour of adjusting it, would be dragging the cable against the edge of the mouse pad again. Also, this product doesn't provide as much lift as the Razer product, which I thought would be a good thing. I was wrong. The extra lift and spring arm of the Razer product does a better job of keeping the cord up without reducing your mousing range.

title: Good Xbox Headset text: Razer Kaira Pro Wireless Gaming Headset for Xbox Series X | S: TriForce Titanium 50mm Drivers - Supercardioid Mic - Dedicated Mobile Mic - EQ and Xbox Pairing - Xbox Wireless and Bluetooth 5.0 - Black

The Razer Kaira Pro headset has a lot of on-ear controls, dials to control headphone volume and game chat, and buttons for power, Bluetooth, and pairing for Xbox Wireless. For me the battery lasted about 20 hours with the Chroma on. The headset Is comfortable and lightweight. I had no issues with glasses and a long gaming session. The headset sound is pretty good, it has a ton of bass and large battles can sound a bit crazy. It has two microphones, one is a detachable boom mic and an internal one when you‚Äôre connected to Bluetooth.
