title: An entertaining but imperfect ride text: BioShock Infinite is the third installment in the series of games which began with 2007's much-acclaimed BioShock. While the game has some similarities to the earlier games of the series, Infinite is quite different in other areas which are sure to make some fans rankle. Overall I found it an entertaining, if somewhat flawed game. To explain why, I will start with the "cons", since that seems to be what most people are interested in when reading reviews, and then I will follow with what I think worked rather well in Infinite.

SPOILERS! -- THERE WILL BE SPOILERS HERE -- DO NOT READ IF YOU DO NOT WISH TO BE EXPOSED TO SPOILERS! -- SPOILERS!

CONS:

1. Combat System. The combat system has been substantially simplified in many areas.

First, the player is limited to carrying only two weapons. This appears intended to require more tradeoffs to be made by the player, but can feel like an irritating limitation as compared with the previous games. It can also discourage upgrading too many weapons, because the player will most likely have one "keeper" weapon and one "off" weapon using this system, which tends to make the game play very similarly over the course of the game.

Second, the setting of the game features mostly wide open areas, unlike the cramped conditions of Rapture from the earlier games. This makes the gameplay much easier as a practical matter, and much more typical of a generic shooter type game.

Third, the game lacks truly challenging enemies like the first two games had. No enemy here is really like a Big Daddy in difficulty or challenge, and even the tougher enemies (patriots, handymen, firemen, ravens) are really not very tough to beat in terms of requiring significant tactical thought and adjustment.

2. Linear design. Unlike the earlier games, where the player could move around the entire map freely, exploring or collecting resources and the like, Infinite is a linear experience where the player progresses through areas that are then closed. These can be reloaded from a chapter menu, but that is simply "replaying a zone" -- it isn't exploring a city organically as was the case with the earlier games. This serves the narrative, but tends to make Infinite feel more "gamey" than the earlier titles in a forced way.

3. Story Problems. SPOIILER!-- SPOILER! -- SPOILER! Here there will be a lot of disagreement among the playerbase.

The storyline essentially revolves around Ken Levine's narrative gloss on the theoretical physics theory of the multiverse. Some players will find this irritatingly similar to films like Inception, and others will just find it confusing.

The issue I have with it is that it kind of plays lip service to some of these theoretical physics ideas (multiverse theory), and makes various hand-waves at quantum physics throughout the game (some of which are bound to go over most players' heads, but that's a separate problem), but then violates these ideas in substantial and problematic ways without explanation. For example, it is a known time travel paradox that one cannot travel back in time because doing so will compromise one's contemporary existence -- this is even more the case where one is going back in time to kill oneself, or precisely to allow oneself to be killed, by one's offspring --> this is an impossible paradox, because if you kill yourself at an earlier period, you would never exist to come back in time and kill yourself to begin with. It's a paradoxical loop, which is one reason why physicists have been skeptical of time-travel. Now, time-travel is fine in a setting where the plot is fantasia and soft and so on, but if you are throwing in references to quantum mechanics and string theory and so on throughout the game, playing fast and loose with some of the ideas feels, well, snarky.

A similar issue is raised with respect to the entire treatment of multiple universes in the game. The multiverse theory, which is more speculation than hard science anyway but is still a theory floated by theoretical physicists, posits that there are infinite universes. This means that, in theory, there are infinite versions of you, and infinite possibilities for how your life plays out in an infinite number of universes. The game's name itself is a reference to this theory. But the multiverse theory also implies that no *one* universe is dispositive of what happens in the others -- there is no "core reality" from which the rest of the possibilities emerge. There is simply an infinite number of parallel realities. This is problematic for the game, where clearly the suggestion is that the drowning of the player's character in the game dispositively removes all instances of the game's main antagonist in all possible universes -- something which doesn't make sense per the actual theory of the multiverse. Instead, the "game's theory" appears to be that there is a core reality which is determinitive of other possibilities -- which is a nice theory, but it isn't the multiverse, and it isn't explained in the game, either. Now, I realize that this is a video game and not a physics textbook, and that therefore the narrative should be more important than the science. That's true. But, again, if it's just a case of "making stuff up" in a nice way to serve a narrative purpose, then the game ought not do so much hand-waving and term dropping from *actual* quantum physics -- this just comes across as intellectually snarky.

Clearly the game and its ending were designed to cause controversy, and thereby generate attention. That has been a success. Upon further review, however, the ending becomes more problematic, even if taken from a purely narrative point of view. Paradoxes are fine, but raising *known* paradoxes and not addressing them at all feels ... sloppy.

4. No Manual Saves. I realize that this is a point of contention in the player community, some of which seems convinced that the ability to save anywhere outside combat is game breaking. However, the problem with Infinite is that the automatic save points are very spread out. It's not uncommon for a player who likes to explore to lose 15-30 minutes of game time if they need to quit the game on short notice -- as is not uncommon for people who are fairly busy. This is a very unfortunate design for a game like this one, and really should be changed in a patch.

PROS:

1. Fun game world. As noted above, this isn't Rapture, it's Columbia. Rapture probably had more personality, and was certainly creepier, while Columbia is airier and more subservient to the overall narrative. Columbia here is a backdrop, whereas Rapture was a character. But ... it's an entertaining backdrop and filled with fun details.

2. Interesting switch-back themes. While it was thought prior to Infinite's release that the game would mostly be a pointed criticism of right-wing American mytholog(ies), in reality it is more the case that the game whipsaws themes around in an interesting way. Thus while it's true that the initial portrayal of Columbia as a racist, fundamentalist bubble that worships the founders of the US is an easy and over the top take on something most people already see as false, this theme is not a main one in the game. In subsequent chapters the game takes the freedom fighters (whom the player probably identifies as "good guys" as compared with the racist fundamentalists of the game's early chapters) and turns them into vicious violent killers which it explicitly says are just as bad as the racists. This challenges assumptions which the player had probably already internalized about them by then, which creates discomfort -- that is well done. The game also portrays the scientist couple -- which one would "normally" see as the foil to the fundamentalist zealots -- and makes them morally ambiguous at best, portraying them as almost amoral and more or less powerless to stop, if not downright helping, the fundamentalists. And, finally, the game takes the female character, Elizabeth, and kind of toys with whether she will be a love interest for the player character before revealing that she, or a previous version of her, was his daughter (in this or another universe, apparently), which, again, challenges assumptions. The way that these themes cascade to challenge assumptions is fairly well done in the plotting.

3. Some fun fight sequences, like the rail fights (which are not spectacular by any means, but fun) helped make the combat, which is overall fairly lackluster, a bit more interesting at times.

=======

Summary (TL;DR):

Infinite is a good, but not great, game characterized by a good narrative which nevertheless plays fast and loose with theoretical physics and average shooter style combat which is occasionally livened up in a few sequences. It's fun to play and I found it enjoyable, but I think that the "it's the best game ever!" type of breathless reviews it is is getting miss the mark by overlooking some aspects of the game that are less than stellar or simply problematic.

title: Not realistic -- in fact, not usable text: I ordered this product along with Grand Slam Tennis for the Wii, based largely in part on the 5 star review by "J. M. Manson". After receiving the item, I realized that the aforementioned review is so inaccurate that it must have been written deliberately to mislead buyers. Probably by someone with some financial stake in this product.

1. Let's start with the most important issue first: the product doesn't work as described. When you play tennis on the Wii, the controller is held so that the buttons face the ceiling and the left and right edges represent the forehand and backhand. Well when you do that with this device, guess what? The racquet faces the ceiling also. Anyone play real tennis with the racquet facing the sky? Didn't think so.

2. It is not the same size or weight as a real tennis racquet, unless you play tennis with a racquet 16" long that weighs 4 ounces.

3. You can't use the Wii jacket with it at all.

4. It holds the remote very loosely, using only a few flimsy plastic tabs.

5. The product is made of cheap, thin plastic that I have no doubt would have cracked within a month had I bothered to use it more than once or twice.

Take the money you were going to spend on this and use it to light a fire in your fireplace and it would be a better use of the funds.

title: Among the best, creepiest (in a good way) and scariest games of all time text: You've come to the correct place because this is where it all began an yes, you should play them in order. Among the best, creepiest (in a good way) and scariest games of all time. You battle scary and powerful necromorphs. People who are killed by a necromorph become necromorphs themselves so the stakes are high. I read that some people stopped playing this because it was too scary. This, the first of the trilogy, is a little clunky in the game mechanics but play it first anyway. This game trilogy is the bomb.

title: Troublesome install on Mac. text: Bought for a friend running OS X 10.10 on a 2011 MacBook, which met the system requirements for the game. I had to assist her getting the game installed, manually installing the needed patch and doing some other things to get the game running.

There are instructions online to get the game installed, patched and working, so as long as you can follow those instructions, you should be okay. It can be intimidating, and a time-consuming process if you aren't super-comfortable with troubleshooting software issues. Searching for "Sims 3 mac super-patcher" should bring you to the EA site or the bluebellflora site with similar steps on installing the patch manually.

Also, once everything was installed and the game actually launched, the "Late Night" expansion gave a disc authentication error. Just removing and reinserting the disc, and restarting the game seemed to fix that. Apparently it's a common issue.

No players joined and I waited about six to seven minutes and started it, all I had was a shot gun which wound up being useless at the beginning of the game so I more or less had to wait for my team to get me through to the next part, I did help all I could with my shot gun again stating, second game I made because the shot gun was lame I picked a character with a rifle automatic or something like a gun of some sort that doesn't scatter shot and shoots fast over and over.  Much Much better, actually was kicking some but and said this is more like it.  Till the first monster guy came into play, he chases you (spoiler by the way) all the way back from where you came and kills you a few times if you don't flee fast enough.  Till you finally have to fight him is the part I'm at right now and can't hit his weak spot for the life of me, yeah I know bet I wish I had a shot gun now.  LOL  No I wish my teamates would blast the hell out of him keeping him busy while I nuked his ass with hand granades and hit the weak spot with a stream of bullets.  Not hitting the weakspot just stuns him for two sec or so sometimes.  Now the part that is lame as hell is I can't beat him dinners ready, I want to watch my movie now but can't just shut it down because either it hasn't auto saved yet or I didn't see the icon showing it did, and I can't manually go to save game because there is no save game icon on half these high end games anymore.  Which means playing stuff you already played over again just to get to where you where when you quit and that could be ten or fifteen minutes of gameplay, such ka ka.  So tomorrow, maybe I will start it up and see where I am and watch the Rad Brad video again on how to beat this guy or boss or monster.  Should be two stars but it's not a bad game and I love res evil, oh yeah died like six times at beginning in like the third battle area, when the reinforcments come and of course had to start all over from beginning of game, which means a half an hour wasted and still right at start point.  Why have auto save and no manual save games, what about when mom says turn it off now, sorry mom I have to play till I see the little icon that means game saveing and that could be ten minutes to a half hour generally.  Technology is such bull s*** sometimes, they just don't care just another way to keep you hooked, spending and going in the directions they force us to go in.  Peace and Live Long and Prosper.  Please no jerk comments back, thank you.  ps games worth six to eight bucks I guess, surely not fifty or anything close to that.

title: Lord of the Rings Fan Review text: The game was very very short, but fun while it lasted. I loved running into characters I did not expect to meet and travel to parts of middle earth mentioned in the books, but not in the movies. However, the map will show a ton of places that look like destinations that you can eventually travel to, but it turns out they are just there for show which was a little disappointing. I haven't played with two people yet, but there is an option for co-op. The graphics were great and the combat was pretty fun. The story was pretty sweet too. I'd recommend this game for any lover of rpgs but defiantly can't be passed up by a lotr fan! Just be sure not to spend too much money on it because you'll beat it in like three days if that. :P

title: Awesome keyboard, but not for people that ask questions text: Cons: The location of the question mark on this keyboard is going to drive me nuts because it's non-standard. For those of us that know how to type, it will be very difficult to get used to. The "DEL" key also is an issue, because you have to press FN to use it. The right shift key is also a bit smaller than I'm used to, so I sometimes press up-arrow by accident when typing fast (90+ wpm).

Pros: The quality of the keyboard is awesome. The form factor is awesome. Nice and small and doesn't take up a ton of room on the desktop. The light-up features are really freaking cool.

Conclusion: I really wanted to give this keyboard 5 stars. I can live with having to press FN for the Function Keys, and can also live with the smaller right shift key, but I really can't live with where the question mark is placed. I wish they made a version just slightly larger to make up for these downfalls, and then they would have a perfect small form factor keyboard.

title: Perfect for game console and accessories!
text: The material of this case is strong, not super thick, but not too thin. It is durable. The zippers work well and the game console and accessories are held in place with Velcro straps. There are little slots for holding game cards. There is a front zippered pocket on the outside of the case, but it is tight, you can only fit thin items in it, game cards, or some papers. The Velcro straps are easy to open and it is easy to put the game and accessories in their place. As the pictures show, there isn't really any extra space for carrying other items. It does hold the game console, game cards, power cord, and a hand held controller. When zipped up there is a thin carrying handle. I recommend this game case if you just carry the items listed but if you want a case to hold a lot of other personal items you might look for a larger case. It's perfect for the game console and accessories!

title: D'oh, oh dear! text: Let's start at the very beginning.
If you're new to gaming, this is NOT a very good place to start.
You're better off beginning with I, II, III
Or you'll go directly to d'oh (and probably give up)

The graphics are fantastic, and the settings and story line imaginative. There are new weapons, skills, maps, characters and modes, but unfortunately the controls are confusing beyond my comprehension (my fault entirely, I'm sure)

Loaned to a friendly (and mature) teenager who had prior experience with the game, it came back a couple of days later with rave reviews about Ezio defying Templars in the hunt for an ancient library in Constantinople using hookblades and bombs (or words to that effect)

Not for the uninitiated, but from all reports this is a challenging game for skilled gamers, and well worth the time spent to master it.

Amanda Richards, December 3, 2012

title: Good for Left-Handed Gamers! text: This mouse originally came with my RoG G74S a couple of years ago. It's seen a LOT of heavy use, has traveled around the country with me, been dropped, been spilled on and the original now has one button that's a tad "sticky".

As a left handed gamer/mouser with long hands/fingers, this has been the best mouse I've ever used. It fits nicely in my hand and because of the placement of the side buttons, I can use them easily with my ring finger. I appreciate that it doesn't have teeny tiny buttons too small for even toddler fingers to press singly, but rather nice sized buttons that won't having accidentally casting (and wasting) a spell/ability.

The new RoG mouse doesn't feel the same in my hand and has different button placement - it may have been a matter of being used to this one and not giving the new mouse enough play time to get used to it, but I switched back to this mouse and ordered a 2nd for when this one bites the dust.

title: A (very custom) perfect tool for certain jobs text: This product is partially 3D printed by a small team. It is more expensive than a mass-produced product...but you just can't find a similarly well-designed controller on the market today.

If this is something you are looking for, it is great. It works great for gaming. It can also be used for people looking for a tool to use for video editing and other hotkey intensive applications.

The software is easy to use to set keybinds. The hardware is fully customizable to all kinds of hand sizes and preferred positions. The buttons are well placed and have a satisfying click. The thumbstick seems to be solid and responsive.

It has a bit of a learning curve, but that is to be expected with something so different.

title: Feels like the real thing... almost. text: HORI did an excellent job reproducing the look and feel of the original GameCube controller. Compared to the first-generation "bar of soap" classic controller, this is a major step up in comfortability and functionality. To my knowledge, this is also one of the first Wii classic controllers with a turbo feature, so if you play any button mashers, this will definitely give you an edge.
PROS:
- The ZL, ZR, A, B, X, and Y buttons and the D-pad all depress with a satisfyingly loud, uh, button-pressing sound, and they have a strong, quick return.
- The analog sticks feel just like the originals and recenter perfectly.
- The turbo feature works for the L, ZL, R, ZR, A, B, X, and Y buttons and the D-pad, and any number of them can be set to turbo simultaneously.
- The turbo speed switch is easy to move without being too loose.
- The Pikachu artwork on the front is applied with the same quality as the GameCube logo was applied to the original. It doesn't stand above the surface visibly or tactilely and it feels like it's going to last. It's not some cheap decal or stencil-job.
- The case screws are regular Phillips-head screws, not Nintendo's proprietary tri-wing screws, making the controller somewhat easier to repair.
CONS:
- The C-stick was cast with a slight misalignment. It left an obvious, though structurally-sound, seam on one side.
- As there is no analog trigger support in Nintendo systems following the GameCube, the L and R buttons now hinge from the top (like the B button on a Wii remote) and have about the same amount of travel as the other buttons, leaving me to miss the plunger-action and satisfying *click* of the original L and R buttons. They also have a shallower curvature, making it easier for your finger to slip off.
- The turbo, start/+, select/-, and home buttons are all rubber like TV remote buttons instead of hard plastic like the GameCube controller's start button was. There's nothing inherently wrong with this, but they feel less satisfying to press and will likely wear out sooner than plastic.

title: Has big pros and some faults.  But pros outweigh cons.  9/10 game
text: The boss fights are meh compared to most Soulsborne.  Lots of weapons are useless reskins you‚Äôll never use as well as the armor a la Dark Souls 2.  Lots of reskinned assets from previous games.  Having said all this, game‚Äôs pros outweigh the faults.  The absolute mammoth size all tailor made and handcrafted, is just amazing.  Dungeons often have some of the best level designs any of the Soulsborne games.  Tbh, it‚Äôs not my favorite Soulsborne but the pros greatly outweigh the negatives, and anyone who says this game deserves anything less than 9/10 likely never beat first boss.  But also, it is a little bit overhyped, it doesn‚Äôt deserve 10/10 either.  I‚Äôve had so many cheap deaths.  I finished all Soulsborne games from Fromsoft and like them all, but never have I had more deaths from behind the camera.  Malenia fight is cheap and encourages cheapness to counter too.  A lot of the boss fights make you wait too long for opening. But, eh, some of the most incredible maps I‚Äôve ever seen and tailored maps this big are undoubtedly a huge accomplishment.  Great game overall and worth a buy.

title: Weak text: As a fan of the original Rygar game, I was really looking forward to this version. The original version had, for the time, great graphics, music, plot, and overall gameplay.
The only thing that's great about this updated version of the game is the graphics.
Unfortunately, there's a lot about it that's not only less than great, but horrid:
- Movement/action/animation is jerky at best; I find it almost feels like the original 8-bit Rygar was superimposed over the beautiful 32-bit graphics.
- User interface is absolutely horrible. I found that attacks were difficult to control (at best) and I often had no idea where I was aiming. There is no "camera control" available, and it's quite easy to navigate Rygar off the screen entirely. Also, game play forces the user to use the analog control, whereas I prefer the cross-bar control; strangely, the options screen only responds to the cross-bar and not the analog. It's obvious that Tecmo spent little time doing usability testing on this game.
- Enemies and fighting sequences are repetative and dull. Yawn.
All in all, pass. Maybe rent it for a night just to check it out... But if you want an entertaining platform game that you can play again and again, save your money.

title: This is the best XBox-style controller ever made - as many top PC reviews have acknowledged text: I have own several MS controllers over the years - first the 360 series, then two controllers since, the latest MS controller was the XBox One Wireless for XBox and PC. It was a solid controller. BUT....

Fast forward just a couple years and Razer have delivered truly superior controllers. In my opinion, the best of these is this one, the Razer Wolverine Ultimate. Not only are the extra paddle controllers seriously well-designed and implemented, but the alternative shoulder buttons [two of the six extra controls in all] are, for me, more easily accessible and that translates to better mobility and faster response for me.

I was a bit disappointed to discover that the full setup and sensitivity adjustment is only available from their XBox Controller Setup and Configuration utility (their own website and documentation indicate that this can be done from their Synapse software, but it cannot be. That is wrong [not a misprint really - it blatantly says that Synapse will handle setup]. This is not an issue for most, but since they make the utility ONLY available from Microsoft Store, it is an issue for many like myself.

Fortunately, most game software today will provide at least minimal adjustment of sensitivity [for stick controls, i.e. deadzone and x/y responsiveness]. The MS Store is often a corrupted mechanism on Windows computers - just google a little and you'll find out that many suffer from MS Store AppxBundles not being handled or failing to install due to "unknown error 0x800700005" and similar - which turn out to be registry permissions corruptions (mine were caused by a Windows patch via "Windows Update" of all things). This means no Razer setup utility for me. (I am not going to reinstall the OS and all my software and configuration tweaks just to get this utility working). I don't need MS Store and I will never use it... even though MS cons their direct competitors (yes, MS manufactures an XBox controller too, did you know? lol) in to relying upon them for this Software Distribution.. i.e. fox and henhouse. They make Synapse, along with the Macro module, and the Chroma/RGB software available from Razer's website, but not this one controller setup utility [which is Razer software, after all]. Not sure why.

You can get by FINE without this Razer utility though - the controller is ONBOARD programmable, i.e. the means to override the default settings for the six "M buttons" is built in to the device itself and documented in the user guide. There is even a MACRO capability available via Synapse and an add-on module. This allows complex keyboard sequences to be associated to one or more button presses [i.e. L-Shoulder longpress + A, B, X, Y, etc...].

This controller is the best I've ever used for PC gaming [if I still used XBox that would apply as well]. I love it. I don't really need the RGB light-show, which is admittedly cool I guess, and even rarely use the M buttons. It is just the feel and response that I find unequaled.

title: Exactly what I needed text: I love these. I needed a new set of mic‚Äôd headphones for work from home calls and gaming, this fit the bill.
Features I like:
Comes with a little carrying bag
Comes with ear cup covers so if you don‚Äôt like the original leather ish ones, you can use the foam/cloth covers.
Long headphone cord with a remote to mute mic, increase/decrease mic and headphone volume.
The headphones have about a 2-2.5‚Äô cord from the headset to the aux jack, and the extension portion contains the remote and converts to a usb input.

Things I dont like: the cord links easily. When I take them off, I have to lay them down in a very specific way to keep the cord from tangling. Something about the material feels like it wouldn‚Äôt be good if it linked. Also the headphone line does not disconnect from the headset, so if the audio line breaks, you‚Äôre SOL and would have to buy a whole new headset.

Mic seems to be good, way better than my previous headset. I like that it can be detached. The mic attachment bends / adjusts really well, much better than the headsets with the fixed straight mic

title: Excellent Headphones text: The sound is very good. The headset is perhaps the most lightweight and comfortable I've used so far. It's also completely plug and play. You plug the headphones in and you are good to go, no drivers or other software needed. Some headphones show up as unique items under the audio settings. So when you want to use them, you need to go to your settings to manually select them after you plug them in. Not these. Just unplug your speakers, plug in the headset and go from there.

A lot of manufacturers seem to think all gamers are middle school kids who need and want flashing lights on everything. The last set of "gaming" headphones I tried put ridiculous colored lights on the headphones. I say ridiculous because you can't see those lights when you are actually wearing the headset. So I appreciate the fact that this headset eschewed such nonsense, focusing instead on audio quality and the comfortableness of the headset.

There are two cautions I need to add. Though neither was a big deal to me, you should be aware of them. The first is that the cord on this headset is shorter than other headsets I've used. My set up is a main computer that I actually game on with a second computer to the side that I run Discord on. That way I don't have to flip in and out of the game to deal with Discord issues. The cord on this headset is fine for use with my main computer but is too short to reach the secondary machine. Depending on your set up, the length of the cord may or may not be an issue to you.

For me that also means I haven't tried the microphone on this headset, just the headphones. Given the quality of this product I wouldn't expect there to be an issue with the mic, but you might check the other reviews here to see what they say about that. Thanks for reading this and I hope you enjoy this product.

title: Loving this game so far text: **Final Update** I think I finally get why this game has been getting a lot of meh reviews. I just finished playing Stardew Valley, and PoOT feels so empty in comparison. PoOT is fun starting out as you begin exploring the area, but it really is just a huge knock-off of Stardew without any of the flare. Super sad to realize this.

**UPDATE** I can't knock it down a star because I love this game so much, but... the glitches have definitely started. I've frozen and had to restart the game once while in a mine (now I save every time before I enter a mine), the frame rate when I enter an area of my farm with lots of building or crops is terrible, and every five or ten (real time) minutes the whole screen freezes for about half a second. Super annoying. I really hope this gets fixed in the May patch.

It has literally been a decade since I enjoyed a Harvest Moon game (last played was Animal Parade in 2011), which I am sure is in part due to Natsume's decision to drive the "Harvest Moon" brand into the ground. I have been hearing about Story of Seasons for years, but this is my first time actually playing one of their games. I am THRILLED. No more overly complicated constructions schemes for farm buildings, no more pointless and complicated sprite mini-games. Just a simple farming sim that is relaxing to play in the way that AWL and FoMT were (maybe not QUITE as simple as FoMT).

This is also the earliest I've ever played a newly released HM (I guess now SoS) game, and it's really not bothering me at all. I have quite a few upgrades on my farm and no glitches yet. I started playing April 12th, so it's possible that I'm not having problems because I started after the first couple patches had cleared. I am looking forward to the patch in May -- but personally, I already like the townspeople's personalities and don't think they're bland at all. If anything, they're more reminiscent of the oldest HM games to me. Lots of simplicity and focus on aesthetic.

title: Bad sound and a hassling set-up make these tight headphones cruddy. text: As you might tell from my review, I'm not wholly pleased with these headphones. When I ordered them, I was initially excited about them. I have some Turtle Beach headphones that are slightly more expensive than these, but they do tend to become slightly uncomfortable after long periods of time.

So I ordered these. I was on the boat about the cord, but I actually prefer cords over wireless in such devices so that I don't have to worry about scrambling for batteries or charging it when the battery's low. The length of the cord is good for my living room.

When I plugged it into my PS3, having not yet read the instructions, I was surprised that there was no sound coming through. So I perused through the quick setup and was aghast that I, indeed, had to use the included audio jacks. I really really really really really don't like audio jacks. I understand that they might "improve" or have a work-around for audio, but the fact that I have to get my jacks out of my PS3 box just to plug `em into the back of the TV for audio (and since my TV has only one set of RCA ports, into which my Atari is plugged), it's really inconvenient and messy when I have to use the ol' red and white audio jacks. Haven't they done a work-around for this? I have HDMI cables, and I love `em. Surely Thrustmaster can do better. My Turtle Beach headphones, while understandably more expensive, connect into the front USB port...and that's it.

So when I finally did what Thrustmaster bid, I tried the sound quality, and it didn't negate my already negative feelings toward the headphones. The sound sounds almost tinny, and the headphones and their longest stretch barely fit `round my head, and I don't even have a big head! I usually click two or three times on headphones to make `em fit, but on these Thrustmasters I had to pull `em all the way and even then they fit just so.

I tried these on my iPhone, but the jack is a little big to fit with the case on my iPhone, so I took it out and tried the sound. It was rather worse since it was meant to utilize the red and white audio jacks.
Disgusting.

Overall, I am disappointed. Perhaps I'm spoiled by my Creative and Turtle Beach headphones, but for the price Thrustmaster could do better. Or maybe even lower the price point. My $20 Sennheisers sound better, but I'm a big fan of Sennheiser. So there.

title: A great last hurrah for the Sims 3. text: Note: this is a stuff pack, which means that it is a bunch of add-ons for the Sims 3 game. You must own the base game for this to work for you. This pack does not add any kind of additional game play options and is just clothes, hairs, and objects for your existing game. You do not need anything except the base game to install or run this stuff pack. You also don't need the internet, if you're buying it on a disk, and it works just fine in both a Mac and PC.

This is a really cute stuff pack. It has three distinct themes: a Western theme, a gothic/vampire/spooky theme, and a superhero theme. They're all nicely detailed and imaginative, with no obvious misfires. And there are a *lot* of things in this set--a lot more than in a normal stuff pack. I'm just amazed at how much stuff is in here.

* Western: Very versatile and boasting a lot of little decorative touches. The recolor channels are nicely done, so you can really use this stuff just about anywhere. I especially loved the clothes and hairs in this theme. I've been using one of the men's outfits just about everywhere. The objects are also excellent; you could use them (even if slightly recolored) just about anywhere, but especially in any old-fashioned theme at all (like a saloon or Country/Western bar). I especially really liked having more rocking chairs--these are probably the nicest ones EA has done yet--and more Western-themed wall art. Loved this set. The whole Stuff Pack could have gone along these lines, and I'd have been fine with it. The feather hairdo is beautiful too. 10/10.

* Spooky theme: Not bad. Garish and Tim Burton-feeling. Midnight Hollow and Moonlight Falls fans will love this stuff. The clothes are lovely in a Miss Havisham sort of way; the hairs less so. The object set is, with recoloration, usable for the most part. I did especially like the deco stuff, though some of the other things are off-putting in anything but a strong Gothique set. 6/10

* Superhero/Villain theme: There's a shocking Frank-N-Furter outfit for men in here, and the women's costumes are really cute--this stuff would work well for performer Sims in Showtime. The objects are a little childish-looking--but by that token they're good for kids' rooms and other similar spaces (like sports bars). The laser ray-gun sculpture on the cover is actually a very large floor lamp--and it's really cool-looking to see ingame. I guess if you like this kind of theme, you'll like this part of the stuff pack. I didn't really, though I do respect the artistry and imagination involved. With recoloring, this part of the set could fit into a futuristic build. 4/10.

Overall, I'd say that anybody who does a lot of Victorian/Western type building, or who likes the more supernatural/spooky type of play, will love this set. If you see something in it that you like, rest assured it's well-made and will look good in your game. If you don't care about these themes, like if you really like a more hipster/urban look to your game, you may not care for this stuff pack at all. Also, if you like to buy stuff that adds new functionality to your game, none of these things will do that. This is just three really nice sets of stuff and create-a-Sim things. They are however very nice and plentiful, and I recommend it to those who are drawn to the kinds of themes depicted.

title: Capcom presents‚Ä¶ text: HADOUKEN! Alright, Alright so if you‚Äôre on this page you know what this is! You‚Äôre either a retro gamer, A collector, Or someone whose experiencing these titles for the first time (I wish I was) it‚Äôs a VERY nice collection with tons and tons of Museum pieces to learn about the history of each game. The presentation is crystal clear and you can literally customize it to your complete liking! Then why not a perfect 5 stars? Well‚Ä¶.
There‚Äôs no new ground here. Aside from the unreleased darkstalkers title, Most have played these games in various other collections, But what baffles me the most is that this came out 2 weeks apart from capcom Arcade collection 2, Which included most of the games listed on here already! I feel like it was a bit of a cash grab to do that to the fans. I love old school capcom (You can only like current time capcom if you enjoy resident evil or Monster hunter since that‚Äôs all they seem to put their efforts on to these days)
It‚Äôs an amazing little collection, Is it worth $40? A little hard to say. If you don‚Äôt love retro gaming or are new to the genre in general this would exactly be the best place to start. The games are unforgiving in difficulty, Although you can change the settings technically but my kids tried at the lowest difficulty and failed. I can rock it with the difficulty almost all the way up so it‚Äôs honestly just a matter of patience and learning curves, Which you will get! But if you want a quick fix, Try Capcom arcade 2 on the digital storefronts. If you want some Hadoukens, Yoga fires, Vampiric and (oddly enough) Cyber mecha fighting, Then look no further! Beautiful graphics that can be smoother out in options or even made to look like the days of the arcade!
Great selection of games (Although a bit lacking on it being different properties rather than SF, Darkstalkers, etc)
The sound is top notch and everutging can be customized to your liking! All in all this is a very well rated 8.5/10!

title: cloud feature is disappointing text: I upgraded (from 2012) in order to have mobile access to the data. And that is a useful & long-desired improvement.

Unfortunately, Intuit did its usual half-hearted, half-designed job with this feature, and it's quite disappointing:
1. You can't sync investment accounts. The old investing.quicken.com site is very limited, not worth using. (For example, you can't see simple consolidated views of your investments, can't run basic reports. etc.)
2. The sync from the desktop isn't automatic, and takes a long time. If you're used to other online products that sync to the desktop (think Dropbox & Google Drive as two very popular examples, there are many others), you will find this clunky & old-tech. Everytime you open Quicken, it will tell you you made changes, whether you did or not, and suggest that you sync. This should be an automated, behind the scenes process, it's not hard.
3. The alerts are rather dumb, and they're essentially hard-coded. You can't create your own rules, and you can't even do a lot with the built-in rules (you can just pick some parameters from a limited list). You can't delete them all either, if you consider them dumb and pointless. Again, not hard to do a lot better.

There are no significant improvements in reporting, or in investment analysis. If you look at the "What's new in 2013" page, you see mobile, alerts, and "more flexible budgeting", whatever that means.

There is a tweak to how accounts show up in the nav bar, where you can put some accounts in the "Separate" list, which means "show but don't include with main set of accounts". This is mildly useful. There's also a feature to mark an account "closed", also slightly useful -- in theory. These account still show up in the list of accounts when you're doing a transfer between investment accounts! Clearly someone forgot what the word "closed" might mean.

So all in all, same old Intuit, same old Quicken. Buy it if the mobile feature is useful to you. (BTW, I tried Mint as an alternative, and I couldn't stand the heavy-duty selling on every darned screen. Maybe some people can tune this stuff out, I couldn't.)

title: Protection and handy light outweigh its cost text: With the reduction in price and the advent of the Special Offer Kindle, countless more will find their ways into the homes of readers all over the world. The Kindle itself would not give a true bibliophile the sensory stimulation of a bound ink on paper book, but this leather lighted cover adds a little bulk to the electronic device making it more resemble a small book in size, while providing protection and illumination.

The Kindle Lighted Leather Cover is lighter in weight than I'd expected, more rigid, better constructed of a high quality beautiful leather, and ergonomically designed for every day use. With care during installation of the Kindle, I expect it to have a long life, particularly since I do not attempt to move the rear cover away from the Kindle device while it's housed. Letting it be and simply lifting the front cover to open, folding it back for reading, and returning it to the closed position for storage should keep it intact. When the front cover is folded back for reading, the round elastic band can be reversed around both front and back covers to keep them joined and make the covered Kindle easier to hold. When the case is closed, the elastic band fits into a small groove on the front of the case where the two different leather textures are seamed. I love that detail. A small leather tab can be slid along the elastic and it also can be flipped to face either right or left. I sometimes move it up or down as a hint to remember something. It has the impression, "amazon kindle," so I'm likely to remember what's in the case. The light is powerful, considering its small size, and it's very easy to pull out and push into it's corner home. It is unobtrusive and quite functional. My brain on more than one occasion guided my hand to the rear of the Kindle for the reading light and it took a few seconds for me to realize I needed to put my fingers on the case and not the Kindle. Because of its angle, the light makes the screen a bit brighter in the upper right quadrant, but my eyes quickly adjust as I read further and become immersed in the words. If I find myself thinking about the irregularity of the lighting on the screen, I go to my Home Page and select another book.

I highly recommend this cover for Kindle owners who want to protect and illuminate their investment and their eyes. Once you make the decision to purchase, good luck when deciding on a color!

title: Still a Great Game All These Years Later!
text: I have been playing this game every year since it came out in 2007, 2K Sports have always had the edge over EA Sports when it came to basketball games. The fluid motions, ease of playing and overall enjoyment is great. For those who are unaware, College Basketball games have stopped being made since 2009, the last of which was NCAA Basketball 10 by EA Sports. While the EA game has an ESPN feel, the game seems to lack the heart and excitement that College Hoops gives you. The legacy mode in College Hoops cannot be beat, everything is controllable from recruiting, training, schedules, even creating your own chants. Oh and of course the weekly NCAA show, (the same thing EA still has yet to put into any of its games). The fact that NCAA Basketball 10 is 2 years older than the last College Hoops game is the only reason people are paying 3x the amount than Hoops 2K8. If you are stuck on the fence between the 2, choose 2K8, you will not regret your decision.

title: One of the smaller collections, but still full of great or at least interesting stuff text: The Interplay compilations were a major appealing aspect of the Evercade. I spent a lot of time with Battle Chess, Boogerman, Earthworm Jim, and Clayfighter as a youngin', so I looked forward to playing them again. Battle Chess is agonizingly slow to me now, but it's still pretty fun if you can take a deep breath and relax. Clayfighter has not aged well, but it's still reasonably funny. Boogerman has always been a very solid platformer buried under puddles of snot, and it still is - if you can stomach the "humor", the gameplay is pretty darn good. And Earthworm Jim is a stone-cold classic after all these years.

I was very interested in the Titus games I never played before. Incantation is a gorgeous platformer with an extremely small viewport (think Bonk). It's a little fiddly, but I'm having a good time with it. Titan is an all-direction Breakout takeoff, except you can slow down time and have to shepherd the ball all over the place. It's a very interesting takeoff. I don't know how long I will enjoy it, but I've found it really rewarding so far.

There are tons of amazing games in the Interplay vaults beyond what's included in Volumes 1 and 2. I hope we see more!

title: what a disappointment text: The TLDR version:

I am giving the game 2 stars because it is fun at first, but if I could give the endgame a negative rating for being a cynical mechanism for extracting the maximum amount of money and/or time from players in return for unpleasant and unrewarding gameplay, I would.

The details:
I played both D1 and D2, and while I have fond memories of them, I don't feel all that attached to the franchise. Nonetheless I was looking forward to it since Blizz announced its release and ponied up for the CE.

I was not one of the people who raged at release because of server crashes, glitches, bugs and frequent "maintenance" sessions lasting hours, sometimes with little or no warning. I figured that Blizz was fielding a lot of new ideas and processes with this game. I was happy with the game, despite huge numbers of reports of botting, duping, hacking, exploits, session spoofing, etc, I figured it didn't really affect me or the people I played with. I was wrong about that, but never mind.

Then two things happened: the Real Money Auction House (RMAH) and patch 1.3. I think others have probably gone into a lot of detail about why those two things proved real game changers for more casual players like myself, but for me the net change was that the "end game", such as it is, is now basically pay to win. You need not only to play skillfully, and to understand your class inside and out, which I would expect, but in addition you need really really good gear. Gear that, because of the way itemization works in the game, you will not get by farming. You must go to the AH, where you will need millions, yes millions, of gold per end game item (unless you want to spend hours surfing the terrible, horrid AH interface for the occasional deal). A little to much for ya? Well, off you go to the RMAH, where you can buy what you need for real money! Don't worry, there's a per-item cap of $250, so you can't go overboard.

Subsequent patches have only reduced the options of making in-game gold legitimately, and many of the changes seem to force players more and more to the RMAH as Blizz figures out where exactly players are managing to farm gold and items, and then nerfs those places one after the other.

Knowing what I know now, would I buy this game again? No, and for sure not the Collector's edition. The one nice thing I can say about the CE is that it did include a free copy of D2, which has been fun to check out again since I stopped playing D3...

Should you buy this game.? Maybe... I had fun with it through Hell Difficulty and Act 1 Inferno before the RMAH/patch 1.3/repair cost fiasco. If you feel that playing up through Hell Difficulty will give you $60 bucks worth of satisfaction, then it might be worth it. PersonalIy, I was hoping for a little more longevity, but oh well. *Goes off to play Path of Exile*

title: Versatility. Zero Lag. Poor battery life even incompatibility at times. text: Read the headline. If you do not purchase high drain batteries my friends, the dollar store will simply not do the trick. It's okay, I bought some rayovacs rechargeable's regular, but I should have got high energy. These batteries last 45- 3 hours and not days at a time like a Xbox controller.

Compatibility is out the wazoo. It can switch PS3, PC, Xbox, Steam and functions as a mouse depending on the platform you operate. The home button even tells you your FPS, CPU usage and memory and press home button again and it goes away. You are getting extreme value and if I could do it over, I would get 2300+ maH batteries because this baby gulps power, but the trade off is zero lag right, so nitpick aside...

I play my android games on my phone with OTG adapter and switch to PC instantly. Zero drivers install. Instant play. I've never had to restart steam, it's one thing I wish it had. Haptic FEEDBACK! 5 stars

title: One of the best headset available on the market right now text: The sound quality is awesome. The sound comes out of the headset in addition to the tv. This is useful for gamers who like to stream their game play with sound (through such devices as Elgato). However, this gets annoying after a while but we just muted the TV. The mic is fantastic and picks up my voice clearly. The earmuffs cover the entire ear which is good for excluding outside noise and the gamer can focus on game play. The headband is comfortable and it doesn't feel like my head is being squeezed.

The best part is this headset is wireless! The freedom of movement given this wireless feature is priceless. The wireless range is about 20 feet. Once the headset is beyond 20 feet of the transmitter, sound quality quickly drops off. Depending on the distance between the game console and the bathroom and kitchen, 20 feet may not be far enough for bathroom breaks or getting a snack (while still wanting not to miss listening in on game action). However, 20 feet range is plenty for stretching and other movements without worrying about cables.

The packaging was marginal. Would have like to see more cushion to prevent damage while shipping.

title: Cute story about a writer struggling for independance text: My main interest in this movie was the story of Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings. She is a writer who is leaving her life to pursue her writing dreams and find fulfillment in publishing a novel.

Her husband is not interested in her dreams. She decides to seek solitude in an isolated orange grove in Florida. Little does she know, this will not be an ideal life. After 30 years of urban life, she is not prepared for a small Florida town.

After many rejections, Marjorie finally realizes "Gothic Novels" are not her specialty. Her agent helps her see how interesting her life actually is and she begins to write about what she knows best. In the process she falls in love, makes a best-friend, helps the community by hiring everyone who lives around her to help remodel her house and fix up her orchard.

Cross Creek is based on the best-selling memoirs of Marjorie Kinnan Rawlings and has some very human moments when you realize the beauty or ugliness of life. The local business man (Peter Coyote) who falls in love with her, does something so amazing. It reminded me of when my father bought my mother her first car. I only know the story, but the situation is similar. Marjorie of course is very head strong and not about to take help from another man. Until she realizes what Norton Bascomb has secretly done.

Slow-paced movie that is more "cute" than "dramatic." Although, there are a few heart-wrenching moments. I thought they dwelled too long on the party, however the chocolate cake sure did look good!

Only view this movie if you have chocolate cake in the house! Preferably decorated with candied orange slices.

~The Rebecca Review

title: Story is meh, theme is meh, graphics and gunplay are FANTASTIC! text: While the CoD franchise has become stale and predictable over the recent years, the gameplay and graphics have improved greatly. I am blown away how polished and well-optimized this engine is compared to whats being used in other games. Graphics look fantastic - textures and movement are very realistic looking. And even with the great graphics, performance is awesome. Very good game for even middling machines.

That being said, the story line of this game is just uninteresting to me. The modern warfare theme is tired and blah. I'd rather see this tech (graphics engine, audio, and gameplay) used in an old WWII themed game... or even in another war era (just not modern day). I prefer the older warfighting era due to the simplicity and increased focus on the solider and his gun, rather than all of the network-centric stuff - flying drones, EMP, communications encryption. With Infinity Ward's polish and use of an excellent graphics engine, they could really make a solid older-era warfighting game. Set it apart from the original Medal of Honor and CoD games (i.e. MOHAA and CoD I) though... maybe a vietnam theme? Or WWI theme?

All things considered here, MW3 offers very fun gameplay and great eye candy. It's just too bad all of their latest releases are pretty much all the same, thematically. Time to refresh the franchise!

title: Come on Squaresoft!! text: I wish Squaresoft games will do what they did for Final Fantasy X & X-2, and rerelease Final Fantasy 7-9, completely reformatted to play for BOTH the PS3 AND the PS4, so die hard fans can finally play their BELOVED Final Fantasy games again. *pouts*

Who wants to download it and play it on the COMPUTER, when just about ANYTHING can go wrong in the game play from computer viruses wiping out EVERYTHING in the system, to the computer itself breaking down, etc. Or in some cases that I've read from other download buyers, the downloads don't even WORK at ALL on their computers, so it was a complete waste of money to begin with.

I want my Final Fantasy games where they BELONG which is right on my Playstation system, hopefully with an reprogrammed and updated version of the games so they will play on the PS3 and PS4 without problems, where I simply relax either in a comfy chair or lie down on the floor or my bed, as I watch my favorite game characters fight to the death against their enemies. *lol*

Plus has anybody heard the 'news'? It seems SOMEBODY is rereleasing the strategy guides for Final Fantasy 7-9 in hardback mode coming out in November of this year in a box set for $89.95 amazon price. What's the point of rereleasing the guides when barely anybody can play the games unless the guides coming back out is a sign that the games themselves are going to be rereleased soon in PS3 or PS4 format.

text: Not so large or so small to be uncomfortable but just the right size.  Nice wrist rest with a rubbery texture.  it has blue cherry keys and I thought the lighting would be blue but the lighting is red.  This is not a problem in my opinion.  The keys click like a Royal standard typewriter I learned to type on many years past.  There is no need to type too hard to know a connection has been made.  In my opinion it is not noisy.  The keyboard is aluminum and has a dark grey color--nice unless you want something chrome like.  I find the keys a good size also being rather standard and not too big or little.  You can turn off the lighting if you wish or change the intensity of the lighting.  All the necessary keys for game playing are present especially for those that prefer first person shooting.  I have no complaints about the k70.  it is a little pricey but you cannot buy steak for the price of beans, I believe.  YouTube has several reviews available for your scrutiny.  I researched keyboards for quite awhile before choosing the K70 and believe I made the best choice for quality and price.  It is not a plastic keyboard but light enough to be easily portable.  Would I buy it again--Yes.

title: A Good investment. Works well with Oculus Quest 2 VR text: [[VIDEOID:16ef0f4b44ae49555383a8c87d52d50b]] I wanted to invest in a good quality Oculus cable and came across this one on Amazon. Furthermore, it's powerful enough to charge the headset while playing, so you absolutely never have to worry about it running out in the middle of your gaming session.
I've yet to encounter any sort of issues so I am leaving a five star review.

title: Worth every penny text: While I haven't done any real time comparison tests, I've had my Nkyo-powered 3DS off the charger for 9 hours now (I don't use the dock), and it has only consumed one bar of the battery meter. I'm running White 2 with the C-Gear turned on. Playing it 15 minutes here, 30 minutes there, etc, only closing the lid when it's time to take a break. Using the original battery, the 3DS would have been long dead by now. I would comfortably say this can at least double the battery life. Since it's only a week or so old now, only time will tell if it continues this performance.

It does add some weight and thickness to the 3DS, which can be noticeable over lengthy gaming periods. Couple that with sharp edges of the 3DS (unlike the smoother edges of the DS series) it can cause a bit of discomfort. On the positive side, the bottom of the battery is a rubbery non-skid material which does make it slightly easier to grip, and sits on a table-top without fear of sliding away.

The battery is really easy to install. Just four screws, pop off the back lid, pop out the old battery, and insert the new battery. While the included tooth-pick style screwdriver is a nice gesture, don't use it. Any game geek or computer nerd worth their salt should have a precision screwdriver set; if you don't have a set, ask around. You don't want to strip the already-easy-to-strip screws, so be careful. If you're not comfortable with this, find a friend (the same one you borrowed the precision screwdriver from).

Be careful how long you take, because many games are time sensitive, and if you take too long, the clock will reset. I did not notice this, and when I tried to sync White 2 to the Global Link, it detected a time change and placed a hard-wait of 24 hours on me. I think I saw a discussion here how to quickly pop it out without losing the date/time.

Finally, not sure if it's worth noting, but my 3DS is one of the original NA releases (Ambassador Certificate), so the original battery might have already been approaching its end of life anyways.

title: Excellent, But Needs to Return to Open-World Format text: My five year old son beat this game with pleasure and relish and then continued to return to it for months afterward. It was easy enough for him to beat without being discouraged, while containing enough extra challenges to keep him engaged. The puzzles that each level posed were perfectly placed for his age group and the story was interesting enough to capture my attention as it played in the background. I wish that more games were able to work as well for the five-six year old age range.

We also own Lego Marvel and unfortunately this game, while wonderful, is not as well organized. The complexity of maneuverability from one area to another worked against this game when compared to the open worlds of Lego Batman 2 or Lego Marvel.

title: Worse than Useless text: These are cheap plastic shells for the Wii remote meant to give more realism to some of the Wii sports games. They are worse than useless. In order to fit the Wii remote into them, you have to 1) remove the soft plastic covering that Nintendo says must be used (when not using these items, presumably) and 2) unplug and remove the Wii motion plus sensor from the bottom of the Wii remote. Of course, when finished and/or switching to another Wii game that does not involve these faux sports items, you have to 1) re-attach the Wii motion plus sensor and 2) put the soft plastic cover back on the Wii remote. It it hard to imagine that repeating these actions can have anything but a deleterious effect on the Wii cover and remote and/or motion plus sensor.

In addition to all this, the Wii remote functions just fine without them for tennis, fencing, baseball etc.

I ordered this along with my first ever Wii without really understanding what I was ordering and what I really needed to play the sports games. Big mistake. Now I know. You don't need this stuff and even if you have it, I think you are unlikely to use it. The Wii itself is amazing beyond belief. This plastic junk is as bad as the Wii is great.

J.M. Tepper

title: Join the CSI team text: This game is based on the popular original CSI show, the actors from the cast provide the voices. The premise is to solve a series of crimes along with the CSI team. Clues are located by sliding over the crime scene then using the appropriate method to interpret the evidence. Witnesses and suspects are questioned using prompts provided, the answers are added to the physical evidence and used to obtain warrents and ultimately solve the crimes.

The graphics are well done, the plot lines are interesting and the game runs quite well, without the hangups or crashes I have experienced with some other Mac platform games. So why only 4 stars? It is possible to locate clues simply by rolling over the scene until the clue reveals itself, wrong choices of tools are met with only a prompt as are other wrong guesses, which 'dumbs down' the experience. The game can be solved by persistence, intelligence only makes the process smoother and quicker. The biggest problem, however, is that once the game is solved it is done a problem with all games of this puzzle genre. Unlike the more complicated MYST or Seventh Guest games this one is not sophisticated enough to make going back over solved puzzles to enjoy the experience or challenging enough to make this a long term project.

Still it is a fun game, a good way to spend a few hours. If the more difficult puzzle games have frustrated you or you are new to this type of game, then this one is perfect for you. If you are a fan of the CSI series this is a good way to spend sometimes between episodes but if you are a serious puzzle gamer and looking for a real challenge this one is not for you.

title: Exactly as described

title: Over Engineered to my dismay text: After using these very expensive headphones for several months I can steadfastly state that I am thoroughly disappointed in Turtle Beach's flagship headphones for ONE INCREDIBLY BLATANT DESIGN FLAW;

For some reason these headphones clip sounds quieter than a given level.

So, to restate: extremely QUIET sounds are choppy and sound like they are fading in and out rapidly.

Now, these headphones are so complicated and overwrought that of COURSE they come with software designed to tune them to any specification you desire...that is if you own a windows computer. After searching high and low for a Mac compatible headset, AND READING that these Ear Force XP Seven MLG Pro headphones are in fact Mac compatible, how sad was I to find that though these headphones do in fact work with my Mac - THE SOFTWARE NECCESSARY TO TUNE THEM TO WORK is NOT MAC COMPATIBLE.

The so called Advanced Sound Editor...necessary to make the headphones useful? Yes.

Will run on a Mac? No.

Go figure on the mac compatible claim.

ANYWAY - I borrow a friend's PC, fire up the HORRIBLY DESIGNED SOUND EDITOR, find the controls that allow me dial down the "Silencer Feature" - why you would every want to remove quiet sounds is beyond me, loud sounds make sense, quiet sounds? - so after correctly saving the changes to my super complicated headphones guess what? It almost works.

ALMOST! IT STILL CLIPS VERY QUIET SOUNDS! SHOOT ME IN THE $230 HEADPHONES!

$230 later and I ALMOST get a decent gaming experience. Thanks a lot turtle beach for spending TOO much time trying to make something cool instead of making something work. Never again turtle beach...never again.

title: Suitably creepy mystery
text: For fans of the Nancy Drew games, this is one of the better ones.  This game features Nancy in New Orleans trying to unlock the secrets of a creepy old mansion possibly haunted by a legendary crystal skull.  Nancy investigates the mansion, and her friend Bess handles the neighborhood around their hotel, including a voodoo supply shop.  This game has many of the elements that make Nancy Drew games great.  The setting is *really* creepy- think spooky mansion and graveyard on a rainy night.  The story is involved and gameplay is long.  This is one of the more difficult Nancy Drew games- I found some of the puzzles to be really tricky, even on the Junior Detective level.  Fans of Nancy Drew won't want to miss this one.

title: If you like fishing.... text: First and foremost if you hate to fish- then avoid this game. Its all about fishing. I've only played it for a short while so far, but I can tell this is gonna be a fun game. Graphics are better than expected (especially the fish themselves and the water scenes). Controls are easy enough (even without the wii pole). Hint you dont have to revolve the nunchuck in a circle- just bounce it up and down when reeling- works the exact same. The game also has a real sandbox feel to it (even if you CAN'T fish off your hotel room balcony)and you don't feel limited or confined like so many of the other Wii fishing games (Rapala fishing esp.) The pop up hints get in the way after a while, but they can be turned off. So far I've ignored all the other characters except the initial fishing tutor, and the hotel girls. There are a lot of different "quest" fishing challanges so you should not get too bored. There are also a lot of different areas to fish with different quarry at each one.
This game does have a few downsides that stop it from being 5 stars. No Mii support is a real bummer. You can customize (to a limited extent) your stock character- but I really believe they could have tossed out the clothing shop and just allowed you to play as your Mii (I mean isn't that the reason you bought a Wii in the first place? so you could use your own creation as a player?). There is WAY to much talking in the game (well reading actually). I find I'm pressing the A button so fast that I often miss what is being said (ok lazy on my part- but I really don't need to hear the same schpeal each time I cash in my fish). Camera angles are sometimes messed up when walking around. This could be user error but I have not found a way to change the camera angle when I'm walking around.
All in all if you enjoy fishing (either real or video game) you will get a kick out of this. The game is a lot of fun and JUST misses the mark on being one of the BEST Wii games out there.
update after YEARS of playing I still stand by my original thoughts. I have completed just about every aspect of the game and own my own cruiser, have the top tier aquarium, caught every species, and am only missing a dozen S level fish. I keep coming back and playing this. It is really enjoyable even if I maxed out my points (999999999 or something like that) I even bought every lure, piece of clothing, and every piece of tackle. The game is still fun, and I started another character, just to start it over and work throught it again. It has good play value even after many hours spent playing.

title: Very Pleased - Build Quality is Fantastic text: Reactions to this mechanical gaming keyboard:

* Keyboard is a pleasure to use - the key presses travel well and feel great.

* Clicking is definitely noisy - this is true for all mechanical keyboards but this one seems a bit louder than average.

* The wire has a cloth mesh around it - pretty common in higher end pc peripherals and this one looks nice.

* Comes with a cover in case you transport it a lot - don't have to worry about stuff breaking it or getting in the keys.

* The keyboard's USB cable is detachable which is nice for storage.

* The textured keys are a neat novelty. If you play a lot of FPS games or MMOs you may really appreciate having the textured keys so that you can place your hand correctly.

Additional thoughts:

Full disclosure, the HyperX Alloy FPS mechanical keyboard is my first and only experience with mechanical keyboards. Thoughts, in no particular order.

Build quality & hardware: The build quality of this keyboard is superb. The specs list that the keyboard has a solid steel frame, and I believe it. The entire thing feels very weighty and solid; there‚Äôs no give to the frame at all and no plastic squeak. The keyboard is very portable (I‚Äôve brought it between computers in my apartment and back and forth to work) and has a detachable cable. It includes an extra charging port for ‚Ä¶ something? The port works as a pass-through; the male end of the USB cable has two connectors though you‚Äôll only need to use one if you don‚Äôt plan on using the extra charge port. I‚Äôve used it as a convenient place to plug in my mouse. The port isn‚Äôt particularly high amperage (0.9A with a standard USB 3.0 port, as compared to 2 or 3A with modern phone chargers), so I wouldn‚Äôt suggest using it to charge your phone or tablet. Overall the keyboard feels extremely sturdy and the build quality is excellent. The aesthetic is very loud ‚Äì read: 'gamer-y' black with red accents ‚Äì but doesn‚Äôt look too out of place so long as you don‚Äôt enable the goofier light modes and stick with the default key caps.

Extra features: Advertising for the keyboard touts it‚Äôs 100% anti-ghosting ‚Äúgame mode‚Äù. For those of you not in the know, ghosting is the problem where some keyboard keys don‚Äôt work when multiple keys are pressed simultaneously. Microsoft has a great write-up to explain the problem. I don‚Äôt expect to make use of this feature; I don‚Äôt play fast-paced games where this has been a problem. Still, it's a novel solution to a problem that would be infuriating should you encounter it. On the keycap front, HyperX includes some additional contrast color and textured keys (WASD, 1234) that can be swapped in if desired. They even include an installation tool that worked well. Ultimately, the keys were hideous and I didn‚Äôt find that the texture was helpful for my use case; I chose to revert to the default keys.

Mechanical keys: This is my first experience with a mechanical keyboard. The HyperX Alloy FPS uses Cherry MX mechanical keys. I wasn‚Äôt sure what I‚Äôd think about these, but now I believe the hype! I‚Äôd expected to tinker with this keyboard a bit before putting it into storage, but it‚Äôs become my preferred keyboard in the house. The travel distance feels just right, and the ‚Äúclick‚Äù that comes with each button press provides the perfect amount of feedback. That being said, this keyboard is loud! It‚Äôs not an issue if I‚Äôm just playing games or reading the internet, but my family members have requested I switch to a different keyboard if I work from home while they are in the room.

Overall experience: I‚Äôm very pleased with this keyboard. The build quality is fantastic and it‚Äôs very satisfying to use. I‚Äôve used the keyboard for roughly 30 hours at this point, in between the others that I have around the house. It‚Äôs not something I‚Äôd reach for in every circumstance ‚Äì again, it‚Äôs not a quiet keyboard ‚Äì but I find myself looking forward to breaking this out.

title: It seems like this is all you would need for your Oculus Quest 2, but... text: I went through a bit of flip-flopping with the Eyglo 5 in 1 Accessories Case for Oculus Quest 2. When I saw the listing for this product, I thought that it was a great set that included everything I needed for the Quest 2, although from the pictures, I did note that the hand strap seemed flimsy.

When I received it, I found that the head strap was made of stiffer plastic than the original straps so it was very difficult to install. I was still worried about the click-in button at the top of the hand strap and the fact that it was so narrow. I expected that any swinging of the controller could slip the strap off. The silicone eye piece fit well, but at first, it gave me a fright because when pressed against the head, the cover would flare out and obstruct the sensor that Oculus proximity sensor, making it think that the headset turn off because it didn't detect a face. I thought my Oculus was broken! Lastly, I found that the controllers were hard to fit into the case (They needed to be looped through each other just so) and even then, the case didn't close without the back piece of the headset pushing against the top, creating a slight bulge. I found that this was a case of "looks good on paper" but not great in actuality.

Because of all of these problems, I was going to give this product 3 stars, but after spending some time with it, I found that I didn't mind any of those shortcomings. The head strap is much more comfortable and secure than the original oculus. The eye piece is MUCH better than the original cloth as sweat is easily wiped off (Facebook is currently addressing this issue and the Oculus will now come with silicone eye pieces). The hand straps turned out to work well enough. I don't worry about losing the controllers because I find that I don't have a tendency to flick the controller with my hand completely open. Lastly, I find that I don't need to use the case when I'm at home so I will only face the awkwardness of putting in the goggles when I intend on taking it on travel.

In the end, I got a complete set of accessories all in one package and they do work. I'm much happier having this set than not. The out-of-the box experience with the Oculus leaves much to be desired and accessories are just a fact of life. Just as purchasing a case for a phone or tablet is just part of the cost of the device.

title: The Best Keyboard I have owned since my last IBM Model M worn out,
text: This is the best keyboard I have owned since my beloved IBM Model M's. The last of the ones I had wore out back in the 1990's.  Since that time I have had a succession of less than satisfactory Logitech keyboards. With the demise of the Logitech MK710 I decided enough was enough.  I looked around and the review everywhere for this Das Professional 4 keyboard bordered on idle worship. The Model M had it's version of a mechanical switch clicky-claddery enough to get you killed by the person in the next office cubicle.  I am retired so I don't care how clicky the keys are. The Cherry MX Blue switches are a real joy sold not wobbly, clicky but a nice refined click. One thing about this keyboard is the fact the replacement of the Cherry switches would be very easy for somebody with soldering skills, the MX Blue switch costs .89¬¢ each at Mouser Electronics, three solder points it is out, and three solder points to install. The case on this keyboard is very solid. The top is aluminium and the bottom is plastic.  I very much like the standup that doubles and a ruler. it goes all of the way across the bottom of keyboard and is much steadier than the puny fold out feeties on other keyboards.  I am sold. If you are an old computer user who started out using the very expensive but very solid IBM Model M's and other heavyweight keyboards from the 1980's here is your keyboard.
