title: TS3 returns to its fun and zany roots. text: University Life is probably one of the strongest additions to the Sims 3 franchise, and I suspect a lot of its fun factor comes from the fact that its original creator, Maxis, is finally back on board after a long time separated from the title. I for one welcome our new reptilian overlords. This was a reunion that needed to happen a long time ago.

The first thing you'll notice is that there's a whole new world that your Sim can go visit: the University. Similar to the vacation worlds in World Adventures, University is a separate, self-contained neighborhood where your Sim will find a place to live (dorm? Frat/sorority house? or rent an apartment or share a house with roommates or even rent his/her own house?), attend classes like a job, and do all those extra-curricular things college offers like parties, short-term temp jobs, library study, streaking, demonstrations, and visits to the new venues on offer like the Comic Shop, Bowling Alley, and coffeeshop. As usual, the world is extremely thematic and well designed. The cheap dorm feels like a cheap dorm. The frat house came right out of Animal House. The expensive sorority house feels like the sort of place a well-bred young woman would want to live. The object set is terrific and really shapes and sets the tone for the activities to come and the venues and houses in this new world.

A Sim can go to the University at any time. The best time is after learning basic skills, since those skills shape how well a Sim does in college just as they shape how quickly a Sim advances in a career. Going to University can be expensive, but a Sim can get a scholarship by taking an aptitude test (thoughtfully dropped off upon entering game by a llama-costumed school mascot), which measures a Sims's traits and skills and determines how long the Sim will need to get a degree and how expensive the schooling will be. This evaluation is a neat bit of code that never fails to give me a thrill. There are several degrees a Sim can earn, each with its own schedule, study materials, and locations. While the Sim is in school, just as when that Sim's on vacation, the "home world" freezes in place, which isn't maybe so great, but I can see why it happens that way. A couple can go together, or one Sim can go alone. At the end you get a report card; you can't fail, but doing better gets you perks.

This is not a world geared toward children. It's not specifically geared toward any other age except adults, specifically young adults, and the interactions are decidedly mature (allowing streaking, among other things, and "juice" pong). But that said, the object and CAS sets here are some of the best-realized in the TS3 franchise. This set seems like one of the most modern and au courant of the entire expansion library. The limited edition object, a statue that can be "set" to different types of costumes that any Sims present on its lot will try to emulate, is ingenious and charming.

The new special objects include things like a bowling lane and a coffee counter, and to go with the coffee counter are new harvestables like various sorts of coffee beans and herbs (some fantastical, like Wonderpetal, and some real like cinnamon and chamomile). It's unfortunate that these new plants don't really interact much with the gameworld's existing expansions and base game; you can spice up dishes with herbs, eat the raw herbs, and throw them into a bonfire, and they'll give various effects to Sims who eat or smell them. Cinnamon, for example, makes a Sim more amorous and allows an interaction called a "cinnamon kiss," and eating raw cinnamon has the same effect as the YouTube "cinnamon challenge!" Otherwise, though, there aren't new dishes based on these herbs and they don't figure into the alchemy system. Other special objects include a megaphone that can be used for anything from proclaiming the Sim's love, complaining about things, or demanding social change, a whiteboard that can be used to scribble ideas in meetings, a portable radio station, a skeleton for studying anatomy, a brain-scanner and science lab, and a gigantic group-science machine that has some interesting effects.

The cell phone every Sim has is upgraded to a smartphone finally, with skins the Sim can earn over time; the Sim can use this phone to make a blog, too--and blogging is unbelievably fun. Blogs can go up to 5 stars based on readership size; they earn their makers money ingame and can eventually be sold for cash. Sims have a skill in Social Networking that they can use to make their blogs more popular more quickly, and this skill also figures in to another cute touch, a Sim Finder that works a bit like a dating-site profile to bring potential friends and lovers to your Sim's door. Also, every Sim now starts the game with an actual camera object so they can take "real" pictures rather than having to have World Adventures to obtain cameras and the Photography skill.

One new versatile lot type is the new apartment residential lot that allows a Sim to have roommates. These roommates aren't under the player's control, but make life in the house more lively and entertaining and presumably lower the rent. To make things a bit easier, the player can specify who's allowed to pass through the house's doors so that a room can be kept private (so Sims don't wander in and out and hog the bed or amenities).

And I couldn't finish talking about this EP without mentioning the new caste system. Your Sim can belong to any, none, or all of three new social groups: Nerds, Jocks, and Rebels. Each group is ranked 1-10 like skills are, and the further you go in each group, the more interactions you get. Rebels, for example, can "show off a gizmo," Jocks can "take a photo" with friends, and Nerds can enthuse about comic books, among several other things each. When you get to level 10 in a caste, you are awarded an extra trait of your choice (YES!). Also, if you graduate well, you get another trait. So Sims can now have potentially up to 7 traits. YAY!

In terms of mechanics, I bought the DVD copy rather than a digital download, so I can see how it runs on either the Mac or PC platform. It runs great on my PC. I waited until the 1.50 software update for Mac to install it there, and it seems to run just fine on the Mac too. I get error 12s on the Mac, but that's not really anything different. A Mac user with 4GB of RAM and maybe an older system (like mine) might do well to carefully consider how many expansions, Stuff Packs, and Store content is on the system first; when I tried to run University on my Mac when everything was installed (every EP and SP plus a slew of Store content), it barely even loaded a new game and almost immediately began throwing memory errors. I uninstalled almost everything (keeping only EPs with the exception of Late Night and Showtime since I knew I was unlikely to use those aspects of the franchise while playing on my Mac) and it's been all right since. So I'm going to say that there might be some serious problems running and using this expansion if a Mac user has too much other extra stuff in their build. In terms of age-appropriateness, I'd say upper teens and that parents need to exercise discretion; I can easily imagine that some parents might object to the more mature interactions.

Overall, this is my favorite expansion. I definitely and heartily recommend it and consider it indispensable to my Simming experience.

title: Instructions would be helpful text: This is a great set, but the instructions leave a lot to be desired. Here are some tips for anyone struggling with the covers and knuckle straps:

Attach the bottom part of the knuckle strap first after removing the original strap. Then, reattach the cover.
Cover the controller with the silicone cover, sliding just the bottom part of the knuckle strap through the bottom.
Then, attach the top part of the knuckle strap by sliding the controller through the loop.
First, adjust the velcro, then adjust the loop so that it is partially over the front panel and not obstructing the trigger button. It seems like this will slip, at first, but doesn't seem to in practical use.
Finally, attach the strap by looping it through the holes in the bottom part of the knuckle strap.

The silicone covers are very well made, so it's worth it just for that.

title: Plasticky Easter Egg quality plastic case. Laughably sad quality. text: The foamy packaging material they put inside the plastic shell feels more protective than the actual product itself. I think it is a bad sign when your "protective case" requires soft, foamy material to keep the case from getting broke in the mail.

The case even sounds like the same material as those 2 piece plastic easter eggs when you grip your Switch tight in your hand with the case on. I suspect this case will crack and break very easily if dropped or handled with much pressure. It is sturdy when the top is down but if you accidentally put much pressure on it in your bag, expect no protection and a broken case. It comes across very junky material. And to add insult to injury: it looks like my fingers are dipped in ink - that's how bad it holds on fingerprints.

Another point of discontent, is that the top flipper is removable but the way it is removed is a joke. You bend the extremely hard, brittle, slippery plastic cover and this dislocates two tiny little plastic pegs that comes out of the round holes they are stuck in. It feels like it is going to break in my hands.

In conclusion, I am hugely disappointed with the feature item of this set: the bonus items are the best part, as they are the parts I am not disappointed with. This is one of those cases that shouldn't have even been made IMHO. It feels like a dollar store item. The control caps are hard to get on but I like them. The gray matches the gray switch. I am not going to try the screen protector because I am returning. It feels like a decent screen protector. The set is worth keeping if you need a screen protector and joycon thumbcaps (I notice those items are expensive here on Amazon but I don't think they should cost what they do). I think you get a dispostable easter egg plastic case for free, basically, but I don't care to have the additional accessories enough to pay $12 for them. Overall, if the set was $5 I would keep it for the screen protector and thumbcaps and use the case until I am sick of it.

title: Good sound, too big for me text: These headphones work well. The sound is good. Not fantastic, but good. The headphones do well with low sound, like bass. But they're a bit cloudy on the mid and high tones.

I like the cool lights on the sides. I haven't used the mic yet.

I wish they plugged in with a regular headphone jack so I could use them for other things than computer gaming. The USB plug limits that. I guess I could get an adaptor?

My only real complaint is that they're very large on me. They have a flexible strap to adjust them to different sizes of heads. Being a small female, that strap sits way below the top of the headband, leaving a big gap in between. They look a bit ridiculous on. But for people larger than me, this is probably a good selling point they will fit much larger heads than most headphones I'm used to. and the harde plastic part won't touch, only the flexible band.

title: Lovely keyboard, worth considering. text: [Note: I updated this review and changed rating to 4*, since I was mistaken about the lighting.]

This was the first mech keyboard I tried, and I really liked the feel and responsiveness. I was switching from a Logitech Wave keyboard, and found that the slightly smaller keyboard and different layout gave me a little trouble at first, but I began to adjust fairly quickly. The Logitech G-Hub software is ok: in my opinion not quite as good as the Razer Synapse software in ease of use and configurability, but good enough.

Unfortunately, the new GX keys do not allow the secondary characters on the keys (the symbols accessed by using Shift) to be illuminated. So there I am, looking at brightly lit characters, and finding myself peering occasionally to be sure I'm hitting the right key for the shift character. Maybe a perfect touch typist wouldn't care, but I need to occasionally look, especially when I'm typing the less frequent characters. (My understanding is that this is a limitation of most mechanical keys: only the upper part of the key can be properly lit, so the only solution is to have the two characters side by side at the top.)

A minor flaw is the need to use two USB slots to plug in the keyboard, because one powers the pass-through USB slot. What? How is that useful? I'd rather just use a separate USB cable or hub and have the option of using USB 3, multiple ports, etc. I think this is just dumb, although I know that many buyers want a pass-through no matter what.

I ended up returning this one and switching to a Razer TKL with linear switches, which has even better responsiveness and feel, and is just a bit more convenient to position. And as I said above, I like the Synapse software better.

title: No user manual, driver mode layer doesn't work text: Comes only with a quick reference card that implies many features but there's no indication of how to use or access them, no user manual, no website or online reference or help!

The FN+Q mode (driver mode) doesn't appear to work. Apparently zero customer support.

Not worth the price if I can't access the functionality. Will be returning.

Update:

Spent some time hunting around for information. Found downloadable driver on several sites for GK64 keyboards sold under various builds and names. Driver App doesn't display properly on my computer but magnifier makes it accessible. Learning how to use some of the functionality, but a user manual would be appreciated.

Also would have liked double drop keys and have ordered replacements. Will also install dampeners and most likely also replace all switches, but that's probably just personal. Don't like the feel or sound that much.

Best part is the solid aluminum case - this thing will last forever and feels good. Decided not to return, but it's still way overpriced. If I need another minimal, high quality keyboard I'll get the $79 plastic version.

title: Exceeded Expectations! text: When Sony first announced the Move controller, I'm sure everyone was scratching their head with questions like: Why bother, Nintendo already has this covered? What's with the glowing ball? Why the camera?

Forgot all you've learned with the Nintendo Wii. I have the utmost respect for Nintendo for getting the motion control ball rolling, and I enjoy the Wii system for what it is, however, the motion control on the Wii is not all it's cut out to be. I'm sure like many of you, when you first got the Wii at launch, thought the motion sensor would track your every move. You couldn't wait to bowl, box, or swing a sword, just like you would do in a real environment. The sad truth is, all of the wiimote's movement which "talk" to these games could easily be accomplished on your couch - even laying down. A simple flick of the wrist would translate to an on screen action. No need to stand up and bowl, why bother doing a full arm swing of your sword when it can be done without much effort on your part. In 2009, Nintendo released the Motion Plus add on for the Wii mote which certainly make it a lot more accurate, but not enough games support it just yet, and it still doesn't come close to what Sony has done.

So what makes Sony's PS3 Move such a big deal? Well, for one thing, we're dealing with true 1:1 motion control. That funky glowing ball that was the brunt of many jokes happens to be the key to tracking your every moment; this, in combination with the PlayStation Eye. Once you begin to play any of the Move's games, you immediately sense you are not dealing with anything like the Wii. Not only does it sense anywhere in view your hand is, but it also detects how close or far you are to the TV.

Sports Champions is amazing. The Table Tennis is so realistic, it's almost eerie. All the sports included are a blast to play (well, except for the Frisbee thing which I don't find interesting even in real life). Unlike WiiSports or Resort - you WILL work up a sweat because you will not get anywhere trying to sit in a reclining chair while the PS3 reminds you that your not in range. ;-)

The other two games I've checked out were the EyePet and Start the Party. Both games use live camera feed, so now the player is inside the game! Yes, true augmented reality here folks. Your pretty illuminated PlayStation Move Controller, suddenly becomes another object. Just look at the screen, you're now holding a Paint Brush, a tennis racket, or Ray gun! Folks, you have to see this to believe this. Yes, combining the player with the game's objects and its surroundings is another thing the Wii can't acheive.

Overall, I'm so blown away by the Move's accuracy, The starting line up of games isn't much yet, but there's something for everyone and any choice will put a smile on your face. Plus, Sony and other manufacturers are already releasing patches to incorporate Move control into existing games like Resident Evil 5 Gold Edition, Tiger Woods 11 and much more. Oh, and loving the demo of "The Shoot" - can't wait for October. The system is very easy to set up -- and calibration is easy and super fast.

title: Seems to work well text: I recently purchased a used Dreamcast that didn't have an AV cord and since I was hooking up to a modern TV, I knew that it would be better to be able to hook up via HDMI. This connector appears to be working well. It doesn't upscale the image, but it does output the Dreamcast's 640x480 VGA mode image through the HDMI cable. The image defaults to a stretched 16:9, but the TV I'm using has a button to switch to 4:3 which presents games in their original aspect ratio. 16:9 also works fine but the image will be stretched horizontally a bit.

I've only used for a few hours, so I can't comment on longevity yet. The image is nice and crisp for an older console and it looks like it is sending out correct colors, etc. Some sites online mention that there are some Dreamcast games that do not play nicely with the VGA output function, but everything I've tried so far looks pretty great. I'm not a retro gaming purist, so I can't say if this is the best way to hook up to a modern TV. For a simple solution to play some Dreamcast games on a newer TV, this feels like a good value for the 20ish dollars spent. I like that the adapter doesn't require any additional power to connect.

Small update: the connection at the Dreamcast seems to be a bit finicky. If I plug it in right and don't move the Dreamcast, it seems to work just fine. If it gets jiggled at all, it either loses picture or keeps picture but causes only reds to transmit. I can't confirm if this is a problem with the adapter or the Dreamcast itself as I got the Dreamcast used and it is 23 years old now. It is not keeping me from enjoying the console, but I wanted to update to make sure buyers are informed.

On a side note, Crazy Taxi is still a great game. I've had it in its re-released forms on PS3 and PC, but for both of those, they replaced the soundtrack. I'm not even a huge Offspring fan, but there is nothing like starting every run with "Yeah, Yeah, Yeah...."

The Dreamcast=Pre-9/11=simpler times...

title: Great Quality - Long Lasting
text: After much careful thought and research, we decided to go wireless with our Xbox 360. What an awesome decision that was! I waited on a review to make sure that the wireless controllers all functioned properly, held their charge and could be played at all angles/distances up to 30ft from the TV and then some. To be on the safe side, I ordered one charge and play just in case one of the controllers went out during play. To date, it has not been needed. The controllers hold their charge just fine for all our gamers - and they tend to play up to 6 hours at a time. As to the quality of the controllers ... one was subjected to an English Springer Spaniel trying to use it as a chew toy and survived. Another was dropped on ceramic tile- when one player threw a fit- and showed no signs of damage. All 4 are still going strong months after use. I would definitely recommend going wireless for all families - especially if you have pets or young children running around that can trip on the cords. It's great for storing neatly away and not having to worry about cords being wrapped too tightly or getting tangled up. Amazon did have the best price at our time of purchase. I'm sure it's still the best deal now.

title: Nice and relaxing
text: A low-key and stress-free game that I am enjoying more than I expected. Maybe not for everyone: there is no combat, no death and the sole source of conflict is a passive plot device called "The Murk". If you fall in the water, you'll be transported to the closest shoreline. If you fall off a mountain, you'll pop out an umbrella ala Mary Poppins and land safely on the ground. No quest timers, no rush. Great game to pop into for an hour or so after I get home from work or when I am getting ready to go to sleep. Probably well suited for children, but some of the crafting recipes are very recursive, which I find a bit frustrating. If I have any criticism, I find the character designs to be a bit bland and unattractive. Would prefer anime-style characters. Hopefully the developer does well enough to consider future releases.

title: The ONE to rule them all? *NO SPOILERS* text: PACKAGING

Amazon did a fantastic job packing. It had four custom fitted foam padding on each corners. I took this for granted, until I saw how other merchants packed their gear, which was just thrown into a box with barely any padding.

FIRST IMPRESSION

I didnt like the intro music. It deviated from the atmosphere created by prior Souls series starting from Demon's souls. Didnt like the remake intro either. But Im used to it now. There isnt much music in older Souls games. But what little it had, was perfectly suited to the world. Elden rings, other than the intro, is no exception. In Elden Rings, there is music almost all the time. The compositions are perfectly suited for the world and paints a wonderful picture. Beautiful with bleak and dark undertones.

35 HOURS IN:

Character creation- Alot of interesting possibilities including cosmetics, which wasnt much of a focal point in the past.

Graphics- Top notch. Beautiful artwork. The only issue is inconsistent 60FPS even in performance mode. But not choppy at all. Performance mode highly recommended. Quality mode looks good when standing still but otherwise I wouldnt use it.

Gameplay- Dedicated Jumping on foot and horseback adds a vertical dimension to Souls games which makes it more interesting to play by giving more strategic options to tackle bosses and areas.

Overworld- interesting and actually fun and not just mindless wandering unlike other games. Game gives you subtle directional clues to major areas of the game but still get to decide where you want to go. I didnt realize this until 30 hours in as I wanted this to be a completely blind run and not reading any youtube videos. Its easy to get around and many transfer/resting stations. I usually dont like open world games because there is just alot of random filler/boring things to do. But this game was truly an except for me. I really enjoyed exploring on horseback.

Dungeon/Castle combat- side areas are easy and straightfoward understandably but the major areas have the same souls like intricacy and detail. Enemy/Boss AI is top notch and fun. It can get incredibly difficult. Just spend time on it and get to understand the timing and moves.

Story- same as prior series. A bit sparse by todays "standard", but less so than prior Souls games. Still need to piece things together and use your imagination. It takes a while for the story to unfold. Games/Movies today are often too verbose that it leaves little to the imagination.

Difficulty- Easier than prior souls games. It seems that they have more respawn/transfer stations, which makes backtracking and progressing easier. Also, a much bigger stamina pool to start off, which means you dont have to raise this stat unless you want a tank/block build. This makes the game easier in some sense. In other Souls games you dont have to raise it either even if you played the glass cannon builds, but the stamina pools were smaller and so you had to be more offensively selective and strategic. There are also more clues as to where to go. The map is well done and interactive allowing you to pin areas of interest. Also they give you summoning options in certain areas, which makes it easy for you to do damage while the npcs tank for you. Works on many bosses. Not all. You still have the option of summoning other players.

I personally take it slow to soak it all in to enjoy this wonderful creation. I try to avoid grinding/power leveling and collecting every little thing while playing unless Im stuck for a while. Its fun figuring out how to beat bosses. Its part of the fun. On difficult bosses, I usually spend one night dying over and over again, thinking through strats and then the next day I beat it rather quickly. Which makes me wonder why I couldnt do it before. I find this a rewarding experience. Usually im underpowered so my strats have to be perfect. But obviously there are ways around this by leveling up more or just coming back to that area later on after accumulating better equipment.

title: Recommend for Entry Level Console Gaming text: The Cloud Stinger Core is a fine entry level headset for console gaming. We also have a Cloud Core headset in the family. It's another entry level set with a slightly greater frequency range and slightly larger driver, but on a console, I cannot hear the difference, and the Stinger is more comfortable for me (smaller head). It's also more convenient to use the in-line volume control and mute.

Basically, the question is going to be whether you want pc-gaming and, if not, whether you want to pay an extra thirty bucks for slightly better sound and a removable mic. Really, if you are looking to spend more money, you can do a lot better by spending more than just the thirty bucks to get up to the Cloud Core.

I recommend this headset if you're looking for something inexpensive.

title: I just got this 2 days ago and I already love this keyboard text: This review is for the CM Storm Quickfire Ultimate with Cherry MX Brown switches. I just got this 2 days ago and I already love this keyboard. The sound and feel of this thing is extremely pleasant.

At first I was thrown off by the depth you had to press the keys - I have been using a very shallow keyboard for years and it took about an hour for my fingers to get used to the "throw" of the keys. I learned touch typing on this style of keyboard and I love going back to the deeper keys. You don't have to press the keys all the way down for the keypress to register, but something about the pleasant "clack" of the key makes you want to complete each press.

It is louder than I expected - but in a good way. The sound is pleasant, giving immediate sonic feedback to key presses. If you were in an open office, it might irk colleagues. It is odd but it makes you sound productive when you type.

The light options are fantastic. The ability to set the brightness is great. I have it at the lowest setting - it is bright enough to see during the day and not glaring at night. There is space bar light bleeding - if you are far away from it. It might be annoying to others if you were sharing a dark office/lan party; though I doubt it. All of the LEDs work on mine (some people commented that they had lights out). The FN key and the F12 key LEDs are off on purpose - unless you activate them.

I have a hard time imagining typing fast enough to have to modify the response time of the keys - but you can - giving 8ms, 4ms, 2ms, and 1ms options on the numpad.

I use Linux. I was pleasantly surprised that the media control keys work for Amarok. The volume control keys don't seem to work; I am going to try to fiddle around see if I can't fix that.

I had one major issue: the keyboard wouldn't work during the bios startup screen. I solved this issue by moving the keyboard to a different usb port. I believe it has to do with the read order of the usb ports - the bios activates the usb ports in order and a lower port is activated more quickly.

title: Great keyboard, but be careful with other keycap sets text: I really like the keyboard, the layout is excellent, it's much better than the smaller ones without function keys and a too integrated cursor block, and it is more compact than a standard TKL layout. I have a smaller (Drop ALT) and a larger (Drop CTRL) and this one is from a layout perspective better. The Gateron red keys are silent and VERY smooth. They are much smoother than the Cherry Silent Red I'm using in the two other keyboard, but not quite as quiet. There is a certain amount of movement in the stems as well and they don't feel as solid as the Cherry switches.

The keycaps are decent but slighly cheap. I was hoping for better. Some of the hollow sound is coming from the keycaps. I tried solving the problem with my Drop cap set (Matt3o MT3 Susuwatari), but the problem is, that the Keychron keyboard has a fraction of a milimeter less spacing between the keys. Some of the keycaps touch and create a slight scratching/binding against each other. The overall with of the keys (e.g. from Caps Lock to Enter) is 2 or 3 millimeters less than the Drop CTRL, which means, there is overall a bit less space per cap. While I do like the Drop keycaps better (and they are much higher quality), I switched back to the Keychron caps since there is less binding with them.

Overall this is a great keyboard, I just wish it would fit other keycap sets better, since this is the biggest weakness of the keyboard.

Soundwise the keyboard sounds fine, the one complaint I have is the spacebar which is much louder than the rest of the keys. Slightly annoying, but I guess I'll get used to it over time. The configuration software is decent, but clumsy to use and doesn't recognize the keyboard, so a download of a JSON file is in order to unblock that.

I do like the knob for volume control, alhtough I do realize that it is just a gimmick, with no actual value over using keys.

title: Awesome RGB gaming keyboard! Great feel, looks amazing!
text: [[VIDEOID:cef5dd17b5d81257aaf19474925af520]] This is such a great keyboard if you want some color and customization as well as good positive key feel and durability. The first thing I noticed was how heavy and solid the keyboard felt, it won't be pushed around when typing or gaming. The buttons feel very solid and mechanical, but not as loud as some keyboards which I appreciate. I don't like some really loud keyboards. There are lots of options for colors and patterns that all look really cool depending on your preference and you can change the speeds. You can also turn them off. The 60% keyboard definitely gives you more space on your mousepad for using the mouse which is nice for first person shooters or any game where you move your mouse a lot or if you have a smaller desktop. Overall, great buy, highly recommend!

title: Sounded Good for a Few Hours
text: We are fans or Corsair products.  However, this is the first of two misses.  We bought a black headphone and a red headphone to help settle ownership in our family.  The red headphone lasted about 12 hours before the left ear cup blew up.  You can still hear distorted sound from it if you balance all the sound to that side, but it's basically a paper weight at this point.  The black pair remains functional when plugged directly into a headphone/mic port on a laptop.  But due to the physical vulnerability of headphone jacks we'd tried to use the boxed USB audio adapter that came with both sets.  As it turns out, the adapter began to send intermittent bursts of full blast audio into our listener's ears after being used for gaming and group calling.  Now we suspect that the USB adapters may have been part of failing the red set.  No matter though, companies need to realize that sending out cheap gear from unreliable vendors or productions has the potential to ruin the perception of their premium products.

title: Just right price for the product, cool looking though text: I think this mouse works just well as other mouse. So here is what I think about this piece.

Build Quality and Design: It does have typical "gaming" gear outlook - exaggerated edges, black & red color theme (I don't know why all gaming "something" are always designed this way.) The whole body is plastic, no silicone grips or something, yet there are stripe engravings on both side where you put your thumb and ring finger. The tip of the mouse (The upper middle art) is pretty sharp so it is lifted pretty well so I don't think it is very safe for young kinds as well. There are off-sets here and there but we are talking about $10 mouse, so I think I should stop and move on.

Functionality: It is quite responsive but I don't see much difference between this and my Logitech office mouse. Meaning, it works very well but nothing "gaming" nor "giga-speed response" in this. I am a mediocre gamer but not Faker, so probably I am not the right person to review this part. The clicking sound is slightly louder than other mouse but not too bad. Overall, it works pretty nicely as other mouse does. It does have forward/backward red buttons on the left side of the mouse as well. Further, you need to put 2X AAA battery which doesn't come with the product.

Buy this if you want to : have mouse with "gaming look" without bleeding your wallet
Don't if you want to have: silent, safe and well designed mouse that you can use it for long time

title: Really fun Hidden Pictures game text: Very impressive hidden pictures game. This game is cleverly made. You'd think the hidden pictures wouldn't be that difficult to find but they are very cleverly designed and even an adult can run out of time without being able to find all of the pictures. The game is made more difficult by having some of the hidden pictures in a darkened "room" and you have to search using a "flashlight" which only lights up the area around the cursor. (For more fun, the game makes you find the battery for the flashlight in another room so you can only search the darkened rooms after you find the battery in another room.) Interestingly, the game continues to come up with a different and challenging list of pictures to find no matter how many times I seem to be playing it.

My 7-year-old child and I play with this, and both he and I absolutely love it so it's a good family game as well. Another reviewer has an excellent description of the game. If you enjoy search and find games, this is definitely one to get.

title: Too slow to play text: Downloaded from Steam, running on Intel DuoCore 3.16GHz, Windows 7 Home 32bit with 4Gb RAM, 1.5 Tb Hard drive and GTC295 video card with 2Gb graphics memory.

This is the first, and the last, Rockstar game I will ever buy. Thank god I didn't pay much for it. To start with, before they will let me play I have to join some stupid Social Club and give my email address - good luck spamming me on the email address I gave you Rockstar. Screw that. Then I had to wait for a patch even though I had only just downloaded it. After the patch was installed I got some bogus error message that I had no driver installed, so I restarted Steam. It took almost ten minutes from launch to actual game play. And I was barely getting 2fps with my processor pegged at 100%. The graphics aren't that great. I even dumbed down the resolution and textures to no avail. My graphics card is perfectly capable of handling anything I throw at it so I have to assume the bottleneck is my cpu. So we have to have a QuadCore to play this game. This sucks!

Update: I loaded this onto my XPS QuadCore and it's playable although there is still noticable lag. If it ran well on a computer costing less that $1500 I'd give it three stars.

It's still a bad port with major playability issues. Driving is very difficult with most vehicles having a turn radius larger than a four lane road. Moving in cover is awkward because the same key that is used to toggle in and out of cover is the same key that does special moves while in cover. Consequently Cole will sometimes come out of cover and run into the open while under fire with obvious results.

The good graphics are reserved for the stars of the game - the automobiles. This is the best part of the game - seeing and driving these beauties. BTW, steal an ambulance for manouverability, steal a fire truck for fun. The driving is just like driving in LA - all the lights are red and all the other drivers are idiots.

title: Nintendo DS Imagine Interior Designer review
text: I just got this game yesterday and so far,  it's a fun little game.  Basically, you are an interior designer, working in your cousin's design shop.  Customers come in and ask you to change color schemes in their rooms, design lamp stands or flower vases, refinish furniture or frames, etc.  Or you might be painting a picture for someone's room.  Or moving furniture around to make a room more functional. You get to work a potter's wheel to make the vases and lamp stands. The game is very detail oriented. Overall....I like this game....and I think kids who are interested in interior design would like this game also.  The reason I gave this game 4 stars, is because some of the missions can be VERY tedious and difficult to figure out. I found it annoying when designing dressers/bureaus that each drawer had to be colored individually (maybe there's a shortcut to doing it that I just didn't figure out).  And I had a difficult time with some of the instructions for specialty designed walls/baseboards.  There are some assignments that will probably require some assistance from an adult to figure out (if this game is being bought for a 7-12 year old). But I would recommend getting the game used....it IS fun! :)

title: Great for the PS4, okay for the PS3, not so good for the Vita. text: It has good audio prompts, like "Charging Battery", "Powering On" and "Powering Off", so you are clear on what it is doing, which is cool.

It can pair to the PS4 two ways. You can plug the Optical cable into the USB dongle, plug that into the USB port, and go fully wireless. Or you can use the enclosed audio cable plugged into the PS4 controller. Both are easy to set up. Both work.

For the PS3, you need to plug the Optical cable into the USB dongle, plug that into the USB port, and then go monkey around with the settings until it finally works. That one will work, but it is more of a pain.

For the Vita, or any other media device, it should be simple. You just plug the enclosed audio cable into the headphone jack, turn on the headphones, and you're good to go. Only after a little while it says "Automatic shutdown enabled. Press the power button to cancel." If you press the power button, it says "Automatic shutdown disabled". What it does after that is up to a coin toss. It will either tell you it's powering off and then proceed to do so, or it will stay on. I've yet to figure out the pattern. I would have assumed that I did not press the button, or that it did not register, were it not for the audio prompt that automatic shutdown was disabled. I might have blamed it on the battery if it didn't happen less than an hour after a full charge, and right before staying on for an additional 45 minutes.

It has little blue Turtle Beach logos on either side that glow red while the device is charging, blue when it is charged, and flashes blue when it is in use. I would have preferred a stable light to the flashing, or even no light to the flashing. If I can hear noise, I know it's on. The flashing is just annoying. It has separate volume controls for each earphones and microphone, and audio presets such as "bass boost", "bass and treble boost", "vocal boost" and "natural sound". I favor "vocal boost" for most games and videos, though some games sound better with "natural sound".

They are good for noise cancelling, and the sound quality is excellent. In "vocal boost" mode, videos level (the voices are not drowned out by the special effects) which I very much appreciate. Turtle Beach is known for excellent audio equipment, and the sound quality on this is flawless. Were I judging it by sound alone, it would be five stars.

The microphones attaches and detaches easily, for use as a gaming headset or just earphones. There is a mute button on the right ear, that is quite easy to get to. The buttons are spaced well enough, and distinctively enough, that they are easy to use while you wear the headset.

They are comfortable when worn on the head, but when I wear them around my neck they get grabby with my hair, which is, for me, the biggest negative.

title: Excellent for the price-$39
text: I wanted this for Decap Attack, Sonic, Altered Beast and the Streets of Rage so I feel like I got my money's worth.  Super portable...easy to hookup.  I did notice some sound being off key in the first Sonic game BUT I didn't notice any game lag or slowdown....I like the speed of the Sonic games much better than on the PS2 compilation disc.  Of course, if you have the original system, stick with that.  If you sold yours long ago (like I did) or never had one, this is a good way to go.  I had no problem with the controllers after I positioned the system at a higher level on the coffee table by just sitting it on some stacked books.  The range is NOT great on the wireless part but you CAN plug in a controller if you have one...or two.  I had just one cart, Road Rash and it plays very good on this tiny little system. The system itself is not much bigger than that original cart and is ultra light weight.  This is about convenience of not having tons of cartridges laying around but it sure does play them nicely if you want to use them.  Is it the same quality as the original system?  No.  Is it effective?  Yes. I mean, really...are you going to devote the hours to retro gaming you did when it first came out?? If you ARE then you might want to find a really clean original system.  This is nostalgic fun to me and worth it if you find it for 50 or less.  Fun for parties or a play session here and there.  I'm not sure what people really expect for 40 bucks these days but this is less than the price of one new game and for WHAT it is and ISN'T, I give it an 8.5 out of 10.  Can't wait for my friends to play Streets of Rage 3 with me, I've been practicing!  HAVE FUN!

title: Cool looking case, gluing issues, locks that can be defeated by hamsters text: [[VIDEOID:eb5860fecee5ac4fd869b2cb7f95f448]] Let me tell you this thing looks cool. It is cool. But it's not that cool and suffers from some excessive cheapness. Oh, I love it and it now is where my Quest 2 lives, but let's go through this.

The case - this can be found on Amazon for about half the price. Not the foam cutout mind you, but a higher quality metal carry case. I suspect you're mostly paying for the foam on this one because there's nothing special about the exterior case.

So, paying for the foam let's look at picture #2 above - all the foam was glued into the case (what you have to do, I'm not complaining. All the foam at the edges looks like picture 2. Just not particularly neat. If you're going to charge $40 or so for foam work, make it neat.

Unit comes with two keys to lock it. You can unlock with a fingernail. Handle connection just looks cheap.

Positive: foam cutouts will keep your Quest 2 from moving. Negative: There's so much space they could have used to put things like booster batteries or a remote or just storage that was not cut out right. I mean sure this looks cool but rearranging the cutouts you would have had so much space free.

This is the type of case I'd expect to pay half of what they're asking... It's lightweight aluminum, cheap locks and handles, and non-expertly glued foam.

I do not hate it, I actually like it, but it's just cool looking, not cool functioning.

title: Great wireless mouse, did not disappoint. text: Bought about 1 year ago on Amazon, have 0 regrets. I have had a wireless mouse in the past and I hated it, lots of random 'freeze' issues during FPS, heavy weight, didn't glide on surfaces well. Not the case with this mouse. No freezing or lag issues whatsoever, it is heavier than a wired mouse but it doesn't take long to get used to. I don't game daily, however I do use the computer a few times a week. I can tell you with using batteries built for digital cameras, in the 1 year I have owned this mouse, I am literally on the very first set of batteries for this device. I have never turned the mouse off in this time, it just idles. It's insane. I have never replaced the batteries and every time I sit down I wonder if today is the day, and it never comes. The battery life claims on this thing seem to be legit.

The only downside is that my hand is a bit larger and with the grip I have, my thumb can't reach the furthest back button right above the thumb. If I try to hit it, I end up hitting another button at the same time, so I just unmap it. Not the fault of the mouse, so I won't detract a star for it.

If you are in the mood to switch from a wired mouse whether to cut the cord or replace an old mouse, I would recommend this mouse for sure. My wife is a graphic designer and uses Photoshop on my gaming rig, and she doesn't mind it either, it's a good balance between gamer and useful.

title: First thing I have to say, they are incredible. text: Don't hesitate on buying these. I wore mine out a week ago playing God of War 3 and I was originally planning on sending them to Sony for a replacement. The rubbers wear out on some Playstation 4 controllers that are first generation.

Long story short, delivery was quick, and easy to install. My original were split in the center which created a "lift" on the rubber in the center that could be felt. I was skeptical at first, but after they arrive they fit perfectly. I removed the split rubbers from the old controller by hand. They come right off with no resistance or left over residue. Slide these sideways and they wrap around perfectly. They are slightly loose, but not overly and when playing they stay still. This was probably made that way so you could angle them in from any direction and then straighten them once on. They look nice and make the controller stand out. You could possibly add these on a controller that are not worn out like mine for extra grip.

Pros: solid grip, they look nice once on, adding a little flare and originality to your controller. (i'll upload an image)
Cons: The only con I can find by being picky would be they can be ripped while putting them on the controller. This can be avoided by simply going slow and angle them sideways when installing. After in "locks" in one side, you can slide the rest on and pat it on the top so it slides under it.

title: Great sensor, great battery life, iffy buttons after a bit text: I love this mouse. It's fits my hands better than most (big hands) and it feels great to use a while. Unlike my Corsair wireless gaming mouse, battery life lasts a while (like Xbox One wireless controller a while--not 1+ years of like like regular wireless mice), and the sensor tracks as good or better than many great wired mice.

The buttons started a bit tough to press, which was bad since the wheel works so great. All worked well enough however. In time I started to get a couple double presses and non registered presses when I pressed both buttons quickly after each other or at the same time. I was going to still give it five stars if it was isolated, but it seems like the issue is a bit more widespread.

Pros
Great ergonomics
Amazing sensor
Great battery life (for a rgb wireless gaming mouse)

Cons
Buttons

title: Amazing Game!! text: I have to admit that I put off buying this game for a long time as I dislike turn-based games other than the Civilization series. Since this is by Firaxis, who of course makes the Civ series, I decided to try it out. Now I wish I had given it more attention before!

The gameplay is incredible. There are basically two parts to the game. One where you manage your base, finances, etc and the other where you go on missions. The missions are all turn based where you hand pick the team you want to go on the mission and then tell them where to move and what to attack. It is very strategic and leaves plenty of ways to complete the mission.

It is very challenging, even on "normal" difficulty, but it is very rewarding as well. Just remember to save often and you'll do fine.

Overall, I think this game deserves all the praise it got and I can't recommend it enough if you like strategy/tactical games.

title: It is an interactive movie text: I will start out with the apparently heretical statement that I was not a fan of the earlier final fantasy games. I am a big RPG fan, but please don't shoot, maim or otherwise attack me, because it is true. I found them all to be overly melodramatic, meandering, very predetermined, and frankly too much to sit through until the end. However, Final Fantasy X has hooked me.
That is the great thing about the PS2. I have tried several games that never interested or whose predecessors have failed to entertain on my PC or the PS one. This game falls into this category.
The major improvement is in the voicing and the movies. The story moves along with incredible cut scenes and plot exposition. No more reading along with out dated graphics and long load times. There is more room to wander for those of us who like the side quests. The battle system is much improved over the "real time" system, and now leads to more strategy and thinking during battles, not just fast paced button pushing and hoping for a good outcome. Yes, it is less realistic, but this is a game. The grid system for leveling up is major improvement, and you can spend considerable time weighing the pros and cons of each direction you can pursue and which locks to use up your key spheres on. Another place for fans of increasing the strategy.
All in all, the game can be tailored to whatever the player prefers. It can be fairly fast if you plow strait through to the end and (like I did) feel that the prior games got a bit tedious, I did it in about 45 hours. But, you can spend days traveling around with the side quests and some get extremely hard, and I have not completed them all yet.
To keep this short and not delve into all the technical stuff that most of us honestly don't care about, I will put it this way. The game is beautifully done, the right mix of gameplay and melodrama have been met, the controls are adequate and easy to learn, the strategy can become challenging, the music and movies are tremendous and the battle system is probably the best on the playstation 2.
All in all, this is like watching an interactive movie. It is challenging enough for the adults and entertaining enough for the kids. For PS2 RPG fans it has set the standard.

I find that I really enjoying the underwater dogfights with other submarines, slower than air combat in simulation games but really engaging, you'll play this game for hours and hours at a time.

The back story isn't much, but it's easy to ignore. The enemies are challenging without being impossible to beat. Diving below 140 meters will cause hull damage to your submarine.

The graphics are pretty good. The gameplay is excellent, really absorbing, which is exactly what I wanted in a game like this one. Really a fun game, a favorite of mine.

title: Really, Really, Very, Very, Super, Quiet!!! Highly Recommend! text: Really, Really, Very, Very, Super, Quiet!!! Exactly as the listing claims!
I recently got a new laptop. I could never get used to the touch pad mouse on the laptop.
So I need to hook up an external mouse.

I keep the laptop on a cart next to my bed. Occasionally, I turn on the laptop in the morning before my husband has awoken. The mouse I had was too noisy. This mouse is so quiet... it's perfect! (Only problem is that my keyboard is now louder than the mouse! Such is life!!)

In addition to the quiet, the mouse has a very sleek ergonomic design. It glides nicely, and it has some additional buttons and features that I have not yet had an opportunity to figure out.

I would have to say that I believe that this is the nicest mouse I have every had!!!

title: Not Recommended text: It took numerous tries to get this out of IOS mode and into Android mode. Once in Android mode it took a couple more tries to get this to pair with my Samsung tablet. Once paired I was in mouse emulation mode and could move the cursor around the screen but not select anything. I scanned their QR code in the manual to download 'Happy Chick' which I assumed was a freebie Angry Bird game giveaway. The first warning sign was the absolutely insane number of permissions the app required to install. Many I'd never seen or heard of. Once that was downloaded it turned out to be a downloading app from a non-US site where you could supposedly download games compatible with this controller. I then checked the Google and Amazon stores for any reference to GameSir and found nothing. Unwilling to download further software from both a site and country I didn't recognize I attempted to remove the 'Happy Chick' app from my tablet. While trying to find the listing (it was at the very end of the app list because it was named in English) I found several strange entries had been created that had names of other apps on the tablet in them. Those apps would immediately crash when tried to run from their original icons. I finally found and removed 'Happy Chick'. I had to restart my tablet twice before the almost dozen affected apps would run properly again. Once I had things running properly and the controller was still paired with the tablet I tried several different game apps and the controller worked with none of them. I unpaired the controller, made sure it was off and tossed it into the garage awaiting next week's trash pick-up. I should have stopped the moment I saw the page after page (I think I had to 'continue' four or five times to reach the end of the list) but I wanted to trust this company but I'm not installing any further apps or software from sites I don't know in countries I'm unsure of. Not recommended at all.
I received this item in exchange for my review.

title: Getting the game to work on Vista
text: Just to let Vista users know, I just bought this game and it does not work without tweaking, but it's pretty simple to fix.  I had to uninstall the latest and greatest Quicktime to go with a lesser version, 6.5.2.  After you install the game and the proper version of Quicktime, right click on the desktop icon for the game and click Properties.  Click on Compatability and choose for Windows 95 and then check the box for 256 colors.  This is exactly what I did and now it works with no problems.  Quicktime's latest version can be reinstalled whenever you want.  Hope this helps.

title: Loud text: This keyboard and its switches are every bit as loud as my husband's Razer Black Widow with green (equivalent Cherry Blue) switches. With raised keys, it's not loud because of the key caps hitting the body of the keyboard when depressed, and it's not loud when you are pressing the switches down. That volume can be muffled with silicone o-rings. These switches are loud when they jump back up from being pushed down, and there's no way to muffle the sound. This isn't a real problem for gaming, except that people can hear you typing over your headset. But it is a problem if you are using the keyboard for typing during the work day, like I am. I'm dreading the process of trying to change all of these switches out for quieter ones.

The body seems very sturdy. The media keys are responsive, but not mechanical. I appreciate the white color, which looks snazzier to me and I enjoy the LEDs more on white. It's four stars from me.

title: An OK Product text: First of all I have to say I don't know why some people are confused about how many screen protectors come in this package. It comes with two. Not two of each, two total-- one for the top, one for the bottom. You also get a cleaning cloth and a "Soft Card" which I assume is to get the air bubbles out, but it doesn't say. Works well for that anyway.

I was a little curious as to why it did not come with instructions, but I guess the process is easy enough to figure out.

I used the cleaning cloth to get the DS screens clean. I peeled the backing off the top protector and laid it on the screen going from one side to the other, smoothing the air out as I laid the film down. I used the "soft card" to push the air out from the edges of the screen. I was satisfied with how it looked.

Then I did the same for the touch screen. Despite thinking I had laid the protector on perfectly straight, one of the corners did not fit exactly. I pried the screen up with my fingernail and peeled it off. This was my BIG MISTAKE. Pulling the film off resulted in so much static that very small fibers were attracted to and stuck to the film. Unfortunately since the backing is covered in adhesive (as opposed to being a static cling), it was impossible to remove the very fine particles that were now stuck to the protector. I did not notice this, however, until I laid the protector back down on the DS. Where ever a piece of fuzz was, an air bubble had formed around it and I was unable to push the air out.

The bubbles were VERY noticeable on the dark screen of the DS when it was not turned on. When playing a game however, the bubbles were hardly if not at all noticeable.

The next day I decided to pull the bottom protector off and rinse it under the sink. I used a dab of soap and rubbed very lightly. I expected the adhesive might get ruined in the process but it doesn't appear to have been. I was able to wash the majority of the big fuzzies off. Reapplying the film showed improvement, but there are still one or two small bubbles. I can live with it though.

In conclusion ...

- make sure you wash your hands and clean the screen very well before applying these things. You might consider using a higher quality cleaning cloth that absolutely will not shed.

- once it's down, DO NOT pull the protector up again (with the intention or reapplying it).

- applying the screen slowly and firmly, going in one direction will eliminate most air bubbles.

Three stars out of five. An OK product. I have had no sensitivity problems, and I just hope it does its job!

title: I really wanted to love this game, but I just couldn't. text: First off, I am a big Assassins Creed fan. I especially loved the Ezio franchise due to the story, the awesome gameplay, and the fact that Ezio himself was such a bada$$. I beat all of the Ezio games within a week because I was so eager to finish the story.

Then, AC3 came out. I was very excited to continue the story. However, I was disappointed and here is why:
-Connor is boring. I'm sorry to put it so bluntly, but it is the truth. He bores me. There is nothing exciting about him at all. When it came to Ezio, he at least made me feel like a true Assassin. With Connor, however, I just don't get that same feeling because his character is so dull.
-There is too much running around! I swear, I can't tell you how many times I had to literally run, and run, and run some more to get from point A to point B. You are slowed down by so many things too, such as a mountain range. I will be running in a straight line, but then bam there is a mountain in my way and I have to figure out a way around it.
-Too many cut scenes. I enjoy cut scenes, but not when they are as excessive as this game is. I feel like I'm watching a movie with the amount of heavy cut scenes they added to this game.
-The story is on the dull side. I get bored to the point where I stop paying attention anymore.
-I feel as though all I do is fight those guards at times. It's fun at first, but it loses it's appeal quickly. You can only fight so many guards before it gets repetative and therefore boring. The older games, such as AC2, were not anywhere near this bad when it came to the guards. The guards chased you down in the older games, but it was not as excessive as AC3 is.
-Most importantly, this is the FIRST AC game that I put down and have yet to finish. I do plan to finish it one of these days for the sake of the story line, but the game is just such a big disappointment that I can't pick up the controller just yet. In time I will, but I need a break from this terrible game.

It saddens me to leave a bad review. I gave it 3 stars only because it is an AC game and it is fun to a very small extent. I do like to know what happens in the story too. Other than that though, it's just not a super fun game like the others before it.

title: Solid product text: I'm 5' 11", 240 lbs, and 60 years old. I am a Forza addict and decided I needed a wheel, for which I needed a seat. I'm glad I picked this one to go with the Logitech G920.

I added the lift kit (Amazon B07G67FB1W), for a more "normal" seating position, and it was easy enough to install. All the tools you need are provided with this seat, and another wrench with the lift kit. There's no lack of adjustability. It's very solidly built. The seat itself is better than I expected. It's tempting to get two extra for my 2000 Frontier.

If you have a favorite car seat, it's also available without the seat, and it should be no problem mounting a car's seat to the frame. It should bolt right up.

Well, back to driving imaginary cars and learning how to use a wheel, after taking 5 years to learn how to drive with an XBox One controller.

My other car is a 2017 Freightliner Cascadia.

title: Red Dead Redemption PS3 text: For me, GTA was a fun series a few years ago, but I had dropped out of it since it seemed to be getting too repetitive & too similar. So, I was super-excited when I heard they were making Red Dead Redemption, but then disappointed when the release date kept getting pushed back. Thankfully it has been worth the wait!

The missions for the most part are good & action-packed. Generally they involve shooting a lot of bad guys, who are all displayed with red dots on your map. The red dots make it easy to find them/ count how many are left to shoot. A few of the Bonnie missions are dull, slow, boring and involve general farmhand stuff, but thankfully that's pretty early on in the game.

Something as mundane as riding around in the desert from town to town is actually fun. The scenery is beautiful and epic. I can waste hours just riding around the countryside helping people out, hunting down escaped prisoners, or hunting animals. The hunting aspect is surprisingly fun & addictive, and hunting is a very entertaining way to rack up some money if you need it.

Normally side games are lame and not-interesting, but here in RDR - Poker, Blackjack, Liar's Dice, Horseshoes, Arm Wrestling - are fun and pretty realistic. Liar's Dice is a game I'd never heard of before, but it's really fun, and I think would be a great drinking game with friends.

For my first play-through, I've been trying to be as honorable as possible, but occasionally an innocent bystander will get whacked (sorry about that). Another thing to note is that you can't use cheats in this game if you want to save & progress on the storyline. I haven't found the need, though, to cheat like in GTA with full ammo, full health, reduce wanted level, etc. If you are interested in the cheats, search online for more details.

For some people who complained that the targeting was difficult, if you double-tap the L2 button, the game does a great job of locking right on to the target - actually almost too good of a job. There is no overall easy/medium/hard Difficulty setting on this game. I'm generally so-so at video games, especially as I'm now in my 30's and can't devote hours-upon-hours to gaming like I did in college. Thankfully RDR is not a throw-down-the-controller-because-you're-so-angry difficulty. In fact, if you're a hardcore gamer, you might think it's too easy (?).

I haven't touched the online multi-player yet. The single player is so engrossing right now, and I'm generally not a fan of online shooters - and also because I suck at them. So if you are really into that genre, you're probably better off sticking to Call Of Duty or Battlefield 2. I assume most people aren't buying this game for multi-player though.

For a few of my negatives, the cut-scenes are slow-moving. The talking & overall flow of them just seems so s-l-o-w. I wish there was a double-time option for it. But you can skip them altogether, and then review the dialogue in the journal later if needed. Also, I wish you could just press select to get to the Map instead of having to go through Start -> Map. I've only had the game lock up on me once; once isn't bad, but glitch-free would be ideal.

Also, I'm a big fan of customizing your character, or better yet, creating your own guy altogether. I wish we'd have had that option in this game. As it is now, you can really only change your outfits as you unlock them. A huge Rollie Fingers mustache would be an awesome choice.

For the full price of admission, I am definitely getting my money's worth on Red Dead Redemption. It is literally hours-upon-hours of fun. I have been staying up way too late playing RDR, which unfortunately leads to a rough time going to work the next morning! Highly recommended.

title: Good quality, excellent value text: Great full coverage headset. Bass response isn't enhanced, so it seems to have a "flat" audio spectrum, which can be a good thing if you're an audio purist. A flat spectrum is also an advantage when it comes to hearing dialog and chat, whereas enhanced bass can make everything sound woofy. If you're looking for a lot of bass, I'd rate these as a 6 out of 10 in that area.

The ear pieces are comfortable and full coverage but don't completely shut out the outside world. You can still hear some ambient sounds. The automatic adjustable fit is excellent.

The mic is inconspicuous and easily moved around. The lighting is a bonus but only operates when connected via USB.

The only negative is the volume adjustment knob has a budget feel, kind of like a toy, but it works fine. Not enough of a complaint to knock a star off the review.

Great value.
