title: UPDATE 11/5/17 - STILL My new favorite game as of 3/8/17 - 5 stars - WITH SPOILERS text: This is a great game--my new favorite. I have to give it 5 stars overall. The scenery is probably the best I've personally seen on the PS4. The weapons and equipment are pretty realistic, in my opinion. I just recently stopped playing Metal Gear Solid 5 after playing that and nothing else over the last 9 months. I believe this game is like Far Cry 4, GTA 5, MGS 5, and Fallout 4 all wrapped into one (with a little imagination). I own all those games for PS4, and I believe this game takes most of the best elements from the others mentioned above. The sheer number of vehicles and weapons and equipment is amazing. There are some significant pros and cons to this game, however. In no particular order, I don't agree with being able to switch to any weapons that have been unlocked whenever I feel like it. I'm not carrying all my unlocked weapons with me at all times--that would be extremely cumbersome. For the fun factor, tho, it is great. My favorite sniper so far is the MSR. I don't have the 50 cal unlocked yet, but I'm told it can even shoot down the Apache helicopter with 1 shot. My favorite machine gun is the M249. Nothing stands up to the 249 except the "Apache" Unidad helicopter, which incidentally looks almost exactly like a Cobra helicopter. I was carrying a bullpup assault rifle with a grenade launcher, but that pales in comparison now to the damage the trusty M249 deals out. I'm still using the standard 45 caliber pistol. I use everything suppressed except the 249. I absolutely HATE that (at least on Arcade level) I cannot drag off the bodies of enemies I've killed. I believe that should have been implemented into this game. I loved that on Far Cry 4. As for the Unidad, I think it's total BS that I can shoot down a gazillion Unidad helicopters, obliterate hordes of Unidad soldiers, and destroy lots and lots of Unidad vehicles, and they just keep coming and coming and coming--and then they kill me. I have pushed the Unidad alert level to LEVEL 4 on several occasions, just to see if I could kill them all. Even on Arcade level, I can't kill them all. Another thing that is hokey is a minivan should not be able to go up an almost vertical mountain. It is fun, tho. The vehicles take an extreme amount of damage before they blow up, generally. In real life (which I realize this is a game), I would not be able to take a Lambo-looking sports car cross-country and run over cactus after cactus and smash into stone walls, etc, etc, etc, without totaling the thing out in the first crash. I LOVE the sync-shots. It really helps with the stealthy sniper approach. When all else goes to hell, tho, I bring out the M249 and get to work. I really like being able to upgrade weapons, as with Fallout 4. I like stopping vehicles and pulling people out and taking their cars as with GTA5. The scenery really reminds me a lot of MGS5 and FC4. Not surpising, considering who produced this game. What I really, really, really like about this game is it IS fun. I have probably spent 30 hours playing so far, and it has gone by like a snap of my fingers (almost). And, I'm just on the very easiest level. I am going to have to get a lot better at this game to even think about upping the difficulty level. The AI on this game is really pretty good. My AI soldiers, as in my 3 teammates and the rebel soldiers, are really pretty good. They have senior moments on occasion and can't figure out where to go, but for the most part, they are right there beside me or at least very close in a gunfight. The enemy soldiers AI reminds me a lot of MGS5. One shot unsuppressed (and sometimes even suppressed), and they have my location, and they are coming for me and my team. I hate the SAM missle sites. I have gone in and wiped them out in order to steal an aircraft only to discover that there was another SAM missile launcher in range that enjoyed shooting me down. Flares would have been a nice touch to be able to drop out of an airplane or heli, I am going to try switching seats with another player and try decoying an incoming missile with a flare gun, but I bet it won't work. But I am going to try it if I can line everything up. I have gotten stuck in the map 3x so far. Each time, I have fallen down into a crevice somewhere, and the only way I could get out was to fast travel out. That used to happen to me in Skyrim back in the day. But for the miles and miles or km and km of map this game has, I suppose I can excuse a couple glitches here and there. I'm pretty sure this is operator error, but I am not good at base jumping yet. I've got it figured out how to jump out of a heli or an airplane, tho. The parachute is really cool. There are a ton of different vehicles available. I hardly have to walk anywhere, but I do it just to try to discover everything on the map. Usually everywhere I go there is lots of ammunition available, which is nice. Not sure how realistic that is, but it makes the game more fun. I don't like how I have to stand directly in front of the ammunition crates in order to re-load ammo. Same thing goes for the supply tagging. It seems like I have to be right in front and touching each crate in order to load or tag. When doing air-to-air combat, it is difficult for me to fly a heli and shoot the guns all at the same time while still trying not to get shot down. Luckily, my guys out on the sides of a small heli do a lot of shooting, and they take out a lot of enemies while I perform my "circle of death" going around and around a target. I'm sure some company will come up with a game better than this in the future, but for now, this game is the bomb. 5 stars.

*** UPDATE 4/3/17 ***

I still love this game. I'm level 28 now. I've unlocked a lot of cool weapons and gear. My favorite loadout is still the MSR in the sniper slot, M249 in the light machine gun slot, the P45T in the pistol slot, and the standard drone. For destroying vehicles and especially that pesky Unidad "Apache", I do switch to the HTI for a 1-shot kill. I have been using the explosive drone a lot for taking out SAM sites and generators. Some of the bases are almost impossible to get into, and the explosive drone really helps on occasion. For example, there is a Serpentidad (or something spelled close to that) in the bottom center of the map. It is crawling with Unidad. It also has a SAM site and a generator. Blowing up the generator opens all the gates, and destroying the SAM site helps with a mission underneath it on the map in order to steal a +3000 medical supplies helicopter. I had to attempt that mission 3 times to get it done. I got shot down 2x, and then I figured out that the SAM launcher was in that Unidad base. So, I had to take out the SAM site first in order to not get blasted out of the sky by missiles on the 3rd (and successful) attempt. So far, the SAM launchers and Unidad are my worst enemies. I can't say for sure how many, but I think I shot down about 15 Apache helicopters one time when I was discovered sneaking around the Unidad base after I had released all the prisoners out of the prison. It is ridiculous how many soldiers and land-based vehicles and helicopters spawn almost immediately after the previous units have been destroyed. They just keep coming and coming, in waves LOL, and the only way I have found so far to get the Unidad alert down from 4 stars is to run and hide somewhere that Unidad cannot find me. Eventually, they give up, but it takes a really long time to outrun Unidad. I have still been playing on the easiest level so far since beginning the game. I have discovered almost everything on the massive map, but I still have a long, long way to go before I can finish the game. I also think it is a bit unfair for me to spot and mark targets with my drone and my AI crew somehow targets them and can wipe them out with a single shot, sometimes even thru what appears to be solid walls. My recommendation is to get the MSR, HTI, M249, and the explosive drone as soon as possible. I also think that the fastest revive skills and best binocular skills are a must. The binoculars are very handy maxed out for when drones are jammed. I have now seen videos where the streamer uses the EMP drone almost exclusively to take down road convoys. I haven't done that yet. I usually just assault the escort vehicles from the air and then land next to the truck and loot it. From the ground, I usually shoot up the rear escort vehicle and then run the other 2 vehicles off the road and loot the truck. I love the helicopters for close air-to-ground combat. I fly, and the AI teammates shoot the crap out of everything once I give the order. I'm thinking I may start playing online, but I haven't done it yet. I'm thinking that human teammates will probably do better than the AI. BUT, the AI teammates are very good, in my opinion. The AI enemies are almost always very good. A couple times the AI teammates and the AI enemies have gotten stuck around vehicles or other obstacles, but usually they are very, very "smart", sometimes too smart, especially when I get surprised by an enemy AI it seems that way. I've gotten stuck in the map a couple more time and have had to fast travel out. Not a huge deal, but a minor irritation. Even when I happen to get KIA and re-spawn fairly close to the mission objective, I hardly ever do it the same way the second (or third) time around. It just seems like the AI soldiers surprise me sometimes by taking different routes, especially in the cities. At a fixed location, like a "steal an airplane" mission, they are pretty much in a concentrated area, but they do walk around a lot sometimes, and if they are alerted, they will come looking for me. I absolutely hate the "X" being the machine guns on my helicopters setup. The way I fly, I don't think I can (or will) change the button to control the fixed guns on helicopters. It is a huge pain in the butt to shoot missiles or fixed guns. In order to shoot from anything other than head-on, I have to tip the nose of the heli way down in order to shoot down from any significant height to engage targets on the ground. I believe I have crashed my helis several times because I was pushing too many buttons and manipulating the joysticks on my PS4 controller all at once. I love (and hate) the bullet drop on the weapons. I don't think there is too much side wind pushing on the bullets, but there is definitely bullet drop for many calibers once I'm shooting over 200m. I like this so much better than Far Cry 4 in that respect. The game is still really fun for me, and I'm going to keep playing it until I'm tired of it. 5 stars remains!

*** UPDATE 11/5/17 *** with SPOILERS

Still my new favorite game. I've discovered some glitches with the game since the last patch, but overall the game is still very good. I finished the game for the 2nd time on EXTREME/TIER ONE Level 19 when Karen Bowman shot El Seuno a few times and finished him off.

The good:

TREMENDOUS improvement in the helicopter controls over the "classic" controls. In my experience, I can't play the game on the hardest level (EXTREME) and Tier One without using armed helicopters. If you haven't learned how to fly helicopters, you'd better learn. I need them and so do you, especially to take out the armed convoy escorts. I've almost perfected the takedown of all convoys.

I like the realism that comes along with the helicopters. It seems like the wind and rain have an effect on flying. I also like that my helo doesn't slide down the fing mountain now every time I land at a slight angle.

Along with Tier One came the HTI BDC Desert Camo, etc, etc, etc, on STEROIDS, lol. I maxed it out to Level 15. Nothing else even comes close. This 12.7 / 50 cal sniper is an absolute MUST. I also leveled up my ACR to Level 30. It is the best assault rifle for me.

I also like the ballistics of each rifle in the respect that I have to compensate for elevation on all rifles, and windage and elevation on moving targets. No more putting the crosshairs on a target 500m away and headshooting him every time. I think this last patch improved on the distances targets are visible thru the high-power scope. My longest shot has been 795m. I've seen on the internet where somebody made a 1200m shot? On my PS4, I can't even see an enemy that far out, so that shot must have been on a PC, I think anyway.

The bad:

One shot (even suppressed?) and everybody in the world knows exactly where I am? I'm calling BS on that one. I haven't gotten stuck in the map lately, but today when I was transferring El Cardinel from a 4-door sedan to a helicopter, the game wouldn't let me cross some terrain. Really pissed me off. I had to put EC back into the car, drive the car right up to the helo, and then take him out of the car and stuff him into the helo. Good thing no Unidad or SBC were around or I would have gotten smoked. Still pissy about wave after wave after wave of SBC and Unidad that miraculously appear from thin air to fight me with soldiers and vehicles and never seem to run out. Still hate the SAM launchers. I have found that I can land close but still out of range and blow the SAM launchers up with Explosive Drones or C4 or grenades. Once you blow up a SAM launcher YOU CANNOT GET SHOT DOWN AND REVIVED, or the SAM launchers will miraculously re-appear--fully intact and ready to shoot you down. It is amazing how quickly a bunch of soldiers and drug dealers can rebuild a complicated piece of machinery like that... The only way I have found to defeat the SAM launchers is to blow them all up (there are 3) that surrounded the area where the mission was to "Open the Bank Vault". I used an armed helicopter to fly in and out of that area after I took out the 3 SAM launchers in the vicinity (and never got shot down or revived). It is almost impossible to defeat the hordes of soldiers unless you have an armed helicopter, did I mention that? The little SBC white helicopter with machine guns is the best one. The one with rockets is OK if the targets are (and they are rarely) stationary.

Still a great game, and I have been playing it and nothing else for almost 8 months. I am going to keep playing it until I find something better. Far Cry 5 is supposed to be coming out 2/27/18, so I'm sure I will need to be playing that when it arrives.

I paid about $60 when this game came out. Now it is about 1/2 that. If you like an intense action shooter where you can drive and fly and deal out massive amounts of destruction, you owe it to yourself to play this game. The harder levels require some careful planning to get thru the missions. No more smash and grab with brute force. The hardest missions for me were the ones where I had to remain undetected. If you like strategy/careful planning (sometimes) to go along with your mayhem, this is the game. Buy it and plan on spending a lot of hours playing it. 5 stars remains.

title: Frustrating but utterly enjoyable. text: The Guild 2 Renaissance is without a doubt, the best of the Guild series, as there is so much to do. You start businesses, court lovers, run for political office, you can become a thief or a robber, post nasty political propaganda around town, and you need to keep on top of things like war, the plague, and political undercurrents. It's very complicated, but worth learning. What's more is that this game actually works, which is not something that you can always say about the other games in this series.

Unfortunately, there is no tutorial with this game, and the options of things you can do are sometimes very difficult to figure out. I still haven't found out everything, and I've sunk many hours into this game. There are plenty of somewhat-tutorials on Youtube, but even they can't cover it all. This is a really fun game to explore, and although frustrating, it's worth it.

title: Better than my other devices! text: Update, I‚Äôve been using it on my PS4 and enjoy it very much. I love wireless VR but the benefit of this is you will never run out of battery charge as it don‚Äôt use batteries. I use it from bed to play games and media and don‚Äôt have to worry about that.

As far as people reporting that it looks blurry well that‚Äôs not caused by the headset, it maybe be a fact that some people may have myopia (nearsighted) and never new about it. I have myopia so if I used this device without my glasses in then it will obviously look blurry. So when I put on my glasses it‚Äôs perfect.

My wife on the other hand does not have nearsightedness so when she uses them she says it‚Äôs razor sharp even more so than our large screen tv she says. Tidbit all VR are designed to have the sharpest part of the image towards the center as that‚Äôs how human vision works we see in a 120 degrees arc. But most of that arc is peripheral vision so most of what we can see in total focus is towards the center of our vision, same goes for VR.

Anyway with this I enjoy best of both worlds wired, and wireless with my other devices.
I also plan to get Oculus Quest, but this psvr can handle full featured games and not just VR experiences.

I can‚Äôt help it, I‚Äôll review the psvr in two parts.
Okay 1st part and at a later time I‚Äôll review the vr experience as I got the headset ahead of my ps4 arrival.

Okay let me make this clear, as of now I‚Äôm using the psvr on my Xbox One as a monitor for media and Xbox one games
until I get my PS4.

I own both the Samsung VR and Oculus Go and can assure you even with my myopic eyes I can see that this looks far better than either the Samsung Vr or Oculus Go without a shadow of doubt! And I don‚Äôt have to worry about the other headsets having to charge batteries ever again!

Let me tell you something...
I would get this just for media use alone for fact!!
Okay now the comfort of this device can‚Äôt be matched, it‚Äôs so darn comfortable comparing to my other devices,
I‚Äôm shocked how comfortable it is! They nailed it they put lots of TLC into this!
The build of the headset and the cushion pads are fantastic!

I don‚Äôt know what other people are doing wrong with a bad experience with it, because I am more than pleased with it, and should have gotten it sooner !

Thanks Sony!

Not comparing with other high end pc vr units, I‚Äôm speaking specifics about Samsung Vr and Oculus go and fact is this is way better nuff said!

title: Solves BlackWidow Keyboard Problem of No Backlighting for Upper Case Symbols text: These RAZER DOUBLESHOT PBT KEYCAPS (for Mechanical & Optical Keyboards: Compatible with Standard 104/105 US and UK layouts; Razer Green) work great with my Razer BlackWidow Ultimate keyboard. I have always loved the keyboard, because it‚Äôs so customizable, but have hated the lack of keycap backlighting for the uppercase symbols. I‚Äôm a touch typist, but have a bad habit of peeking at the number keys to get the uppercase symbols.

As you can see from my photo, these keycaps solve the problem. By placing the number and symbol labels side by side at the top, both are properly backlit. You do have to remember that the label on the left is for the lower case (usually a number) key, but that‚Äôs easy to do.

It‚Äôs too bad that the keycaps for the BlackWidow Ultimate keyboard weren‚Äôt designed like this in the first place. The box of keycaps comes with a keycap puller, as well as with stabilizers for the larger keys. The instructions are very easy to understand, and swapping out the keycaps is a simple job.

title: More Build a Lot
text: I really enjoyed the thematic content and artwork in this latest Build-a-Lot game.  It has pretty fairy-tale colors, and really well-done artwork.  The problem is that this is really the same old Build-a-Lot in different clothing.  The objectives are the same.  The gameplay is the same.  The developers really need to add some new elements to these games to keep me interested.  We're now at #6 in the series, and I feel like I'm playing the same game over and over again.  For those who crave more of what they loved in the first Build-a-Lot, then this is a slam dunk.  For those who are looking for some advancement and something new, there's not enough here to keep the long-time player interested.

title: Good party game
text: So I tried this game out with some friends; the only couple we allow to be in our house during these covid times.  The game is very simple:  there's a phrase that ends with a blank, eg, "Why do Americans ________", and each person or team guesses which is the most popular rest of the phrase entered into Google.  We were really surprised at some of the top search results, and some of our initial guesses were clearly "in the gutter".  Lots of laughter; we played 3 rounds total (each round is composed of guessing 5 different phrases.)  I bought this game to play via Zoom, and it's simple enough that it should work pretty well since there's no board, just scorekeeping.

title: Easy application, smooth-feeling product, excellent value for the price
text: I ordered the two-pack not realizing my husband had bought me a Nintendo Switch as well, so we definitely got good usage out of the two-fer.  They were very easy to apply; I'd forgotten to use the cleaning towelettes provided for the first application but in the end I never needed it.  No bubbles, easy application, piece of cake.  The package contains a microfiber cloth and a stiff cardboard credit-card-sized smoothing card as well as two packs of wet-and-dry cloths; there is also a strip of hinge-stickers but it indicates right on the front to not use this on the Switch, so I did not use them.  If the seller is reading this, a couple suggestions: 1) It would be great to include some Switch-compatible tape strips in future versions of this product, because in my experience applying screen protectors, that is an invaluable step for a bubble-free application. And 2) you may want to consider converting the smoothing card from cardboard to a plastic product as the latter would have worked a little better for smoothing, if needed; the cardboard card bent a bit under my attempts to de-bubble.  It all looks great now, so these are suggestions for future improvements on this package.  Finally, I had some issues registering my product for their lifetime warranty, and reached out to their customer support team, who responded speedily (thank you Stephanie!) and were very helpful for my issue.  Great product and I will add this vendor to my list of preferred suppliers for screen protectors in the future for my tech-heavy family.

title: Blends empire building and tower defense really well.
text: I really enjoyed playing Dungeons. It's not Dungeon Keeper 3, as a lot of folks think. It's more like Evil Genius and a tycoon game mixed with a novel approach to tower defense. While you're trying to build the coolest dungeon so that you can earn back your reputation as head of the Dungeon Lords, you attract a number of different heroes. However, you're not trying to kill them,  you just want to "fatten" them up a bit, and all the hero classes expect something different to be entertained. Only once they are plump with entertainment (soul energy) should you trap them in your prison to maximize your return, allowing you more resources to build an even cooler dungeon. Most of the action is hands off, which you placing spawn points and trusting to your monsters and good dungeon design to keep the adventurers in your dungeon long enough to be captured, but often  you have to jump in and directly control your Dungeon Lord, who is a tough fighter in his own right. The graphics are beautiful, the story is funny, and the assaults on your dungeon are challenging. I do wish I would have a bit more direct control over the monsters to send them to intercept heroes, but this isn't a real time strategy game after all.

title: Worth Getting part 2 text: I waited six months for this game and I'm not disappointed. This game has a few similarities to Sims 3 and I do mean a few. The rest is a stand alone game that I would definitely buy expansion packs for. I am so glad that the create a sim feature created sims that looked realistic. Unlike Sims 3 these Sims actually look attractive. I was a little worried about how to provide all of the needs for my sims plus complete the quests plus do my daily responsibilities. EA must have read my mind and narrowed it down to hunger and sleep. Plus your daily responsibilities are only two tasks which gives you time to focus on your quests. If you are looking to build your own buildings and change them at will, you will be disappointed. I myself never really cared about that feature so when I selected a barracks and POOF! there it was and fully furnished, I was delighted. I've only played about four hours, but so far I love it. It is new, and refreshing and I must add that my knight I created is quite handsome. :)

Ok so I originally submitted my first review after only 4 or 5 hours of gameplay. Sorry to say I had to drop my initial rating from 4 stars to 2. Why? Well I've had this game one week and well, I finished it. Yep, completed the kingdom in one week. It wouldn't be so bad if I had completed all the quests and all my heroes were maxed out right? Nope. My blacksmith was level 1, didn't get to play him at all. My bard was level 6 and my spy was level 4. None of my heroes got to level 10 AND I didn't get to put all of the buildings in place either. I still had two more buildings to put in. *SPOILER* What is with the last quest? I'm told make a crew and some builders and use one of my main heroes to lead them to a new kingdom, they get on a ship and disappear. Buh bye main character, hope you saved them because they are gone permanantly. EA I feel cheated. I didn't get to do all the quests, my heroes didn't get to level up all the way AND one of my main characters disappears permanantly!!! Oh and another thing, what's the point of having knights If you can't use them to control the robbing problem??? I swear there was a theif on every corner. My poor merchant was getting robbed several times a day!!

It has an extra pouch in the front, which works perfectly for Gift Cards or something. This is a great upgrade from my last case that could only fit just my switch. I have much more space.

Here are some things I didn‚Äôt like:
The cover that holds the pro controller in spot pushes the right stick to the right when it is in the case.
That is basically it on the things I liked and disliked, it works great for travel can hold a lot of accessories with the switch.

title: Im really liking this charger. text: I dug out my old Xbox and needed new rechargeable batteries. I selected this one because I can charge it with the built in USB cable or plug in a USB-C cable with fast charging.

It works great. The batteries last days before needing a charge and using the USB-C they charge very quickly. It took just a from when I got a warning. Since I had two batteries, I have one on standby. When you put the battery indicator light will turn green when it is fully charged.

What I like
Built in charging cable and USB-C port for fast charging
Closes up into a simple box so you can put it in a case with your console if you travel
Long battery life.

What I don't
I really don‚Äôt have any complaints. It works as advertised

title: Great Mouse if You Don't Mind Holes or Creaks text: I own a lot of mice- probably every mouse you could buy at Best Buy and a lot of up and coming mice companies' mice.
With that said, I appreciate the Xtrfy M42 for at least trying something new. The swappable shell is nice and sturdy. Doesn't feel cheap at all. You basically get a sensei type shape, or a flatter viper mini shape. I preferred the Sensei shape. Over time, the shell began to creak a little bit. It doesn't really bother me, but I know some people really hate that kind of thing.
The feet are fantastic. Very smooth and clean.
The clicks are awesome- well, the main mouse 1 and mouse 2 clicks. The clicks are sturdy and satisfying. The side mouse buttons are alright. Nothing special, but not noticeably worse than other other mouse I use. The scroll wheel... this ones tough. Basically, the actual scroll is one of the best I've experienced. It's smooth but tactile enough to be pleasant and discernable, but the click of the scroll wheel takes a noticeable amount of force. Like, I really have to think about it when I push the thing down. It's a big reason that the mouse isn't my main mouse.
Lastly, the cable is ok. It looks cool on the retro version of the mouse, but it's heavy and it is felt whenever I move the mouse, even in a bungee.

TLDR;
Great M1 and M2 clicks
Passable side button clicks
Tough scroll wheel click but satisfying scroll
Great feet
Good shell shapes with a bit of creak over time
Cable is... ok. Bungee helps but it's still weighty compared to the mouse

title: Used does not come with batterys text: The controller itself is pretty good, but if you buy it used just check if your getting the internal battery pack with it.
amazon basics has a pack for a bit cheaper then the official one, but it actually puts it a few dollars above just buying a new controller outright.
Still works with AA batterys or a phone charging cable anyhow, but not the point.

This controller seems more responsive then the older one, and I like the textured grip on the joysticks/hand holds.
It also is a bit quieter on button press, and seems to be a bit more ergonomically designed.

title: Must buy. text: It's difficult to describe the attraction of Xcom: EU. I never played the original and had no desire to play EU until I read some of the glowing reviews. As a big fan of bother Western & Eastern RPGs, I value the time that is placed into a game. I was not disappointed. If I could summarize EU's story in any way, it would be described as the deveolpers giving you the tools to write your own story. The charaters are randomly generated and have no backstory other than the one that you imagine for them.

Sound corny? Trust me, it isn't. For the console version, there are a few minor bugs, but otherwise it plays out wonderfully. It's definitely worth the money and time.

title: The Legend Returns text: Pros: This mouse is everything a Cadillac wants to be. Large, slick, elegant, superb handling, all with a modern design. It's butter I tell you, BUTTER!!

I got mine for $47. I would happily pay up to $65 for one more button and bluetooth with USB-C recharge cable

title: good basic handhold for the switch.
text: This turns the joy cons on the nintendo switch into a more user friendly standard form controller. The biggest complaint my kids had was it was a little big with the buttons awkward for them to tap. However, that isn't the fault of the holder but of the actual joy cons being a bit on the small side. The grips made it easier to hold for longer periods of time, but after only a little bit of use kids decided it was just easier to use the smaller controllers. There are very few games on the switch that would benefit from a standard controller grip. So for now, this is probably not going to be used very often. Product free in exchange for an honest review.

title: Better sound on replacement unit text: Updated review:
The company reached out and offered to send a replacement unit. The sound works well on the new unit and the mic has a really impressive pickup range. I also realized that you can adjust the placement of the shark fin, and rotating it a bit made the earbuds fit a little better (especially the left one which is weighed down by the mic). It comes with a clip to secure the cord to clothes, etc. but the length of the cords makes that a bit awkward. I ended up clipping the individual cords through it just above the volume controller which works okay but is still not ideal. While not perfect, these now work pretty well for me so I have increased my rating accordingly.

Original review:
The color (blue) was nice, but nothing else about these was. The shark fins were too large for my ears so the fact that it comes with different size ear pieces was irrelevant since there is only one size fin. The braided cord material seemed to snag on my clothes because it wasn't smooth/slick enough. The sound quality did not seem good but I don't know if that was because I had a bad unit or because I could not use them as intended. Maybe these would be fine for someone with larger ears and that is more stationary, but I bought these to use with my phone when walking around (when a full sized headset would look silly--too many comments from my family about looking like I should be directing airplanes) and they did not work for that purpose.

title: Singstar pales in comparison to Karaoke Revolution - just not fun text: My wife and I have tried all of the karaoke games available for PS2 - and Singstar is the worst. It's not even close.

First, the inability to dial down the voice but leave the background music is enough alone to dump this for a good used Karaoke Revolution. Then the mics - they're MUCH heavier - perhaps 5-10x as heavy as the K-R microphones, and much bigger meaning harder to store when you put everything away.

The game itself, well it's not really a game. It's just karaoke. K-R is a game, where you compete, unlock things, win trophies, etc. SS does allow you unlock a few songs, but the gameplay is boring and unfulfilling.

The scoring is obnoxious and annoying compared to K-R as well. It grades 10x more for singing the exact PHRASING as the original than singing on pitch.

Go buy a PS2 - they're terrific. Then go to ebay and type in KARAOKE REVOLUTION PS2 and actually enjoy singing into your TV.

title: Really fun game!
text: Really fun well made game! Have had a lot of fun dancing to this! Very easy to use for all different ages and shapes and sizes of people! Love this!

title: Great gameplay, online play sometimes spotty text: I have logged 281 hours playing this game. That in itself shows how much I like the game. The campaign mode is challenging, and fun. Online mode is where I spend most of my time now that I have finished the campaign. I love the hacking invasion of another player. It‚Äôs a lot of fun to mess with people by blowing stuff up, sending gang members after them etc. My only complaint though is a big one. The online play frequently locks up and actually causes my Xbox One X to shut off! This happens about 20% of the time. I‚Äôve reached out to Ubisoft, but they have no response other than reinstalling the game, which isn‚Äôt the problem. It ONLY locks up when playing online through their Ubisoft servers. Watch dogs 1 did not have this issue, and checking the forums, I am far from alone, yet Ubisoft refuses to release a bug patch.
Overall, it‚Äôs one of my favorite games, which is why I‚Äôm so frustrated when the game randomly locks up hard. I have also found that there doesn‚Äôt seem to be a whole lot of people playing online. The group races, or showdown events are rarely useable because of the lack of participation from online play. I‚Äôd recommend this game, but be aware of its pitfalls.

title: Get the one with the Portal instead. Here's why. text: Highly recommend the Skylanders Giants game. We got it the day it came out. Even though we could have gotten the Portal Owners game, we were thrilled to buy the one that came WITH a portal because the Skylanders Giants portals PLUG IN to the game console, instead of using batteries (yes, even rechargeables will drive you mad replacing them constantly). Just a side note: In the original Skylanders game, the XBox version had a plug-in portal, but the others all used 3 AA batteries. So we would really suggest getting this one instead: [[ASIN:B0088MVPRY Skylanders Giants Starter Kit]]

My 8 year old son pointed out that I'd never have to change batteries in the new one, as well as saying we could use our battery one as a backup if the new one broke. (proud mommy)

The Skylanders Giants game: you can use all of the characters from the original game. Of course there are many different types of new characters that your children are convinced they need: ones that light up, the Giants ones, Series 2 ones (which is the same one as in the first game, but modified slightly to make the child want the new one, too!) And there are new regular-sized ones for the Giants game as well.

It's so fun, even for adults, and there are a zillion layers in it. So many different ways to enjoy the game, mini-games, etc. I'm astounded and delighted that there are games like this out for my son and his friends.

It reminded me of when I was young, and got the Final Fantasy game for the first time. And you realized then that there was so much more to do than the basic video games ever prepared you for.

Just my two-cents. It's very fun, the levels, characters, mini-games, even the art in the game, it's all amazing. Besides buying the various characters, you can also buy add on worlds. I've been distressed that my son's 7 and 8 year old friends are playing Call of Duty type games. I'm so glad that there are wholesome games like Skylanders around so my son can enjoy being a kid and killing little bouncy froggies for now, finding gems, doing puzzles, playing a very addictive stone card game, earning money, buying upgrades (that you get to choose from, not just live with, doing battles and hero quests, and so much more that you may get so lost in the game that may or may not stay up late a couple nights "checking the game out." ;-)

Last year we went all out in what we jokingly referred to as the Ultimate Skylanders mini-game, that's when the parents run from store to store, or online site to online site, in order to track down the various just-released or hard-to-find Skylanders, especially when Activision was caught off guard by the HUGE interest that didn't match up the with the inventory.

We set a budget on it this year, though. And whatever we get, we get. But the game itself is so much fun, and has so much to offer, that we would highly recommend it. Hope this helps someone.

title: The story with PS5 text: I was really curious to know if this would work on PS5, but couldn't find any information about that, here or anywhere else. So I decided to buy it, try it, and report back.

If you're interested in game audio, but turned off by Xtreme Gam3r features like RGB lights, ultra mega bass, and the promise to ruin your EQ to emphasize footsteps, the world of gaming DAC/amps rapidly shrinks. Hey, guy: not everyone is focused on competitive shooters. Some of us are over here playing Death Stranding, feeling the feels when the desolate landscape opens up at the same time as the lonely soundtrack. I was left looking at this GSX 300, and the Fulla E. The Fulla is beloved when it works, but costs more and the company has a bad rep in quality assurance. It made sense to start with the GSX 300, risking the Fulla E if this doesn't work out.

It does work! Despite the Q&A section here being full of assertions from EPOS that it absolutely needs a Windows 10 PC and their special software to operate, right out of the box it is detected by the PS5 as a headphone output and a mic input. Up and running in seconds. It does seem to need the console's front USB port to power it, as the others did nothing.

Sound quality is subjective, but I challenge you to compare this with the congested sound coming directly out of a controller and not be impressed. I've seen tests showing the GSX 300 delivers a genuinely flat EQ, so any tonality is really down to your headphones. I'm driving a pair of EPOS Sennheiser Game Zeros, the latest version, which I think are 50 Ohms, and getting a nice balanced sound, with a taut, clean bass that reaches low, and some bite in the mids and highs when you turn up. These phones are great at making sounds in the game world feel solid.

The biggest surprise after plugging in the GSX 300 was that Sidetone mic monitoring was also working right away. If you have access to a PC, then Hallelujah: against all odds, changes you make to the Sidetone level using the EPOS Gaming Suite software are retained when you reconnect to the PlayStation. By default it's at around 30%, which is subtle but enough to avoid that screaming into the void feeling on closed-back headphones. I like it around 50%.

That's about it for advanced features. The button on the front does not function when connected to a PS5. So no switching through custom EQ profiles or enabling simulated 7.1 surround. This is as I'd suspected, and suits me fine as I was really just shopping for a flat EQ and 2.0 stereo.

That volume knob on the front is not a real mechanical volume pot, with a beginning and an end; it's a digital parameter wheel that spins and spins. As such, the GSX 300 forgets where you've set the volume each time you switch off the power, which is not super convenient. Luckily, it defaults to a sensible, usable level each time you switch on, probably 50%. My last gaming DAC/amp, a tiny thing from HyperX, would default to 0% volume every time, which became irritating. The GSX default volume might not be thrilling, but it's enough for casual day to day gameplay, and I can clearly hear my friends and the game's audio. If you want more, reach for the dial.

While we're on volume: everyone seems to have their own requirements, but to me, with these ears and these headphones, with both the PlayStation output and the GSX cranked all the way up, it's just on the edge of being uncomfortable. Gunshots have a hard movie-theater bark, and bass develops that strong sensation of pressure. I wouldn't play like this for long. However, it won't go to crazy levels. If you like to feel like you've always got more in the tank, this may not be for you. Curiously, on both PC and Mac (yes, it works on my MacBook, too; the knob natively controls the system audio level) it's about twice as loud. I don't know why console audio is attenuated by half, but it seems we can't blame EPOS Sennheiser, as it's the same deal with my old HyperX DAC/amp. This is after the latest firmware update, which promises increased max volume.

One last caveat. The blue LED around the volume control is large and bright. It seems predictable that a device like this will end up near your screen, whether that's your desktop monitor or a TV, and therefor in your field of vision. Making it as big and distracting as it is feels like an oversight. I hoped to find a control in the EPOS Gaming Suite software to lower or disable this light, as AV amps tend to allow, but no luck. I find myself facing the device away, which is a shame, as it's an otherwise lovely, simple piece of design, so much visually quieter than the usual gaudy gamer hardware. The white version compliments the PS5 nicely.

title: Not a reliable unit with terrible warranty support from Razer. text: Unfortunately the product broke after about 3 months. The thumb switch under the dial started bouncing and providing double clicks per single click of the paddle. This is with only about 300hrs gaming on the device.

It‚Äôs not unusual for gaming peripheral developers to design devices that really are not up to the repeated actuations of gaming usage, but what distinguishes them is how they handle problems when they occur.

Razer is doing everything possible to avoid taking a warranty return and replacing the unit. Past the normal want proof of purchase they want pictures then videos and just wont issue an RMA and repair it.

If you‚Äôre a light gamer or happy with buying a new unit every few hundred hours this might be the product for you. If you‚Äôre expecting Razer to make good on their two year warranty without cornering them like a rat in trap and spending way more of your time than a faulty product RMA should take then this is likely not the product for you.

The main reason for me is that this mouse has a fixed mouse cord (-1 point..) and cannot be replaced. It also has no option for wireless, but is ridiculously lightweight..

title: LOVE this game - great graphics, fascinating to play text: My husband and I bought a Wii on a whim after Thanksgiving and 7 different games to get us started. We bought games in a variety of genres so we could get a real feel for the system & figure out what we really enjoy. After trying a couple of other shooting games with the Wii pistol attachment for the Wii Remotes, "Dead Space Extraction" is the winner! This game is by far the best of all the games we've tried, including those that are not in the shooting categories.

The graphics are amazing, the story line was quick-paced, made sense and the story actually had us wanting to know more. We loved being able to play side by side on a single screen without having to do the whole split screen effect - each of us has our own cross-hairs to aim and shoot the aliens with, but on one screen so we can make full use of the 50" television. The other nice thing about this game was that the main characters change without losing the flow of the story and the point of the game - keeps things interesting and stirs up the skill set. There are multiple difficulty levels here as well so when you think you've mastered it, you can come back and let it kick your butt all over again. SO GLAD WE BOUGHT THIS ONE!

title: Awesome Game

I loved the storyline, the ease of the gameplay, and how your character improved as the game progressed (i.e., more hearts for health, better weapons, and armor).  It was a cherished moment when I beat the game for the first time.  If you still have a Nintendo, this is a game you want to check out.

The joysticks are smooth, the buttons are responsive and clicky, and the D pad is much better than any of the other controllers I‚Äôve tried. The only thing I had trouble with is a binding and all you have to do is take out the batteries and see what button, are used to do. For example switch is Y and power button.

title: Tricks Wii U into thinking you have a Wii U Pro Controller text: I got this soley so I could play 2 games that only support the Wii U Gamepad and the Wii U Pro Controller. Those games are "Ocarina of Time in HD" and "Twilight Princess HD"

Both games do NOT allow wii remote + controller to play them. You HAVE to choose either the Wii U Gamepad or the Wii U Pro Controller.

Thankfully this Procube controller tricks the Wii U console into thinking this is a Wii U Pro Controller. So now I can play Wii U Pro Controller supported games with this.

Now, I'll admit it does NOT feel as good in the hands as an original Gamecube controller. The buttons are a bit stiffer, clickier sounding. The handles are fatter than the original. And one of the most noticeable differences is the trigger/bumper button shapes.

But despite all of that, the layout is very nice and is perfect for playing Gamecube Games, and even N64 games. I also love how in virtual console games, the Wii U allows you to remap the buttons on this. You can remap however you wish with most virtual console games.

Overall, I'm satisfied and would buy again if needed.

title: Wonderful Dungeon Crawl with a Strong RPG Feel. text: As a fan of the classic CRPG's Baldur's Gate II, Fallout and Planescape: Torment, I had high hopes for the Neverwinter Nights series. I was hoping for parties of characters that shared colorful banter. This game isn't that, but that's not necessarily a bad thing! Even though this game is rather old, it still holds up, in my opinion! Yeah, the graphics are a bit dated, but they still look nice. The game play is a mix between Baldur's Gate style games, and Diablo. It's a top-down dungeon crawl with a bit more menu to work with. Combat will be a bit slower than Diablo, and you pay more attention to detail in this game than you would in say Baldur's Gate (you only have one character to deal with, not 6.) I've only played through the main campaigns, and here's my summary of them:

NWN: The game is fine enough, as the story line is only fairly interesting. The game-play is where this one shines, though! I found the combat in this game to be very fun. I played through most of the game as a rogue, then all the way through as a paladin. You only get one side character at a time, and each one has a little bit of story. Basically, take one with you and do some adventuring. As time goes on, they'll fill you in on their past and ask you to do a favor for them. Once it's complete, they will reward you with a magical item that'll prove fairly useful. As the game progresses, these trinkets can be upgraded. My personal favorite character was the halfling rogue. His story was the most interesting, and his skills can be very useful. The cleric wastes all her magic on destroying undead, so I found playing through the as a paladin and taking the rogue with me whenever possible was the best for me. This portion of the game gets a solid 4 stars from me.

SoU: This expansion basically serves as an interlude to get you form the previous to the next. The story was only OK, and there wasn't much new added to the game-play (though you lose karma in this title if you use the rogue to pick locks!) If I recall correctly, you get some ability to control your NPC's inventory, which is nice. I mostly took the dwarf rogue with me through this portion. None of the NPC's really had my interest for long. She took care of traps for me, and that was enough. This part only got 3 stars in my book...

HoU: This expansion was AMAZING for me. Going through the Underdark is a lot of fun, and you get a wopping 2 NPC's at a time. YES! THERE IS BANTER! The kobold bard from the previous title (was pretty annoying then) follows you through out. He's pretty much comic relief. I really enjoyed the story and the characters here. I think there might have been a slight graphical upgrade too. Also, there is a way to customize your gear, so you can make your awesome magical gear even more awesome! 5 stars! It's pretty awesome!

One day I'll get to King Maker and some of the other modules. If so, I'll be sure to edit this post with my input!

title: Very Nice but Hard to Install text: I usually keep my 3DS in a plastic shell, but found out that removing the gadget out of the shell left a scratch or two, I was just horrified. I didn't want its beautiful purple exterior scratched more so I decided to buy this skin.

This was the first time I ever tried ordering this sort of gadget protection. After ogling at the prettiness of the box it came in, I buckled down and started aligning pieces. The instruction videos made it look so easy, I swear! The hardest part of the installation were the flat surfaces that angle down a bit at the edges. All I remembered was a lot of frustration, a lot of pressing slippery pieces into place and a lot of application fluid. Proly just a noob thing, but eventually I got the hang of it, how much fluid to spray on and all then, and the rest of the installation went smoothly. Not a perfect job on my end, but GOOD ENOUGH.

Proly took a few hours to do all this.

I still have a few pieces left as I only needed the exterior of my 3DS covered. I kinda futzed around with the pieces on the hinges, but what they said about imperfections was true, you can hardly notice bubbles, and residue when it's fully dried.

I love the feel of the plastic film, I can really say that my 3DS is fully protected now thanks to Skinomi :D

title: Nice, But Not THAT Nice text: While this is definitely a nice wireless mouse I think that you would have to be a bit crazy to pay anywhere near $150 for it. Honestly, if you made me use it without looking directly at it I would not be able to tell the difference in feel or performance between this and any other wireless mouse costing less than $50. Yes, it's nice that it is rechargeable and that the charge lasts quite a bit longer than with most others, but is that really worth paying an extra $100+ for?

Let's face it - most computer accessories built for gamers is wildly overpriced. Labeling something to be used for gaming seems to be like a license to print money without having to spend a dime extra to produce something.Just slap the name "gaming" on something and you can get away with charging 3x as much. That seems to be exactly what is going on here. Other than the fancy packaging there really is nothing that makes this product stand out above most "normal" mice. I mean, it's a nice mouse, but $150 worth? I don't think so.

title: A great game to rent text: Overall the game is fun, realistic, and engaging. I really appreciated not having to learn a new button sequence as they kept everything the same as COD. Therefore, there's really no adjustment period to get used to the controls. The first thing I usually do when I rent a game is play through the campaign on Normal. I enjoy playing on Hard difficulty, too, but usually save that for games I purchase. I was done with the Normal campaign in about 6 hours. It was certainly the shortest game I have played, and I found myself wishing it was longer.

However, similar to COD, they do a nice job mixing things up so that you have a chance to use many different guns and vehicles throughout the game. Combat is great - the first time I shotgunned a guy in the head...HOLY cow. Anyway, I think it's definitely one to put on your "rent list" and then see what you think. Luckily, I didn't purchase this game right away since COD was coming out in early Nov. I would have seriously wanted my $60 back.

title: Wireless Headset (but not bluetooth enabled) text: This headset is great! It has simple functionality with only a volume knob, on/off button, and port for USB charging. It is quite comfortable with the normal cushions on the ear pieces and an additional padding on the top part for your head. The microphone works perfectly. The speakers are also great - they insulate the sound so that it doesn't bleed; meaning that people around you can't hear anything.

I tested it out on a Mac, PC, and PS4. For the Mac, I needed to go into my System Preferences/ Sound and change my output and input to the headset. Once I did that, they worked with no issue. I tested it with a video chat and the quality was great - both the audio and my microphone. With the PC, I didn't need to do anything to set it up; the PC automatically sensed the headset and started working right away. On the PS4, it also paired fairly quickly. I only need to change the settings to toggle between Chats Only and all sound.

The headset connects to your devices with a USB hub; so it is wireless, but not bluetooth enabled. So, it is great for computers or gaming, but you can't use with your iPad or phone. It would have been nice to also have a blue tooth feature so that you could use the same headset across all technology platforms.

Bottom line - awesome headset, great quality!

title: very immersive FPS with some RPG elements text: If you are looking for a great shooter game that focuses on the atmosphere and story, you will very likely enjoy Bioshock.

Its by the same people who made System Shock 2, another great immersive shooter, except its in a sci-fi setting compared to Bioshock, which has a steam-punk vintage Atlantis feel.

The gameplay is quite solid, you have a good selection of weapons and abilities, combat can get quite fun, but the best part is just discovering exactly what happened when the city of Rapture turned from the imagined utopia under the sea to a hell-hole of death and insanity.

title: Players voted it Best Game of 2019 for a reason... text: Just like the title says: this game was voted by gamers as Best Game of the Year.
Not the critics, the PLAYERS voted for it so, yeah, it wasn't an award they bought.
From what I understand, this is the first Fire Emblem title to hit it big anywhere outside of Japan and, having played it, I'm glad the devs got some recognition.
At first glance (or first couple hours of play time) the game seems straightforward enough. It's a turn based RPG. Pretty much 'nough said in most cases. You either like them or you don't.
But.
When you're "released" from the normal and necessary exposition and tutorial that always comes with starting an RPG, and you can wander around you meet all the usual characters. Of course you do. It's an RPG.
Yeah, this time the premise seems interesting and the "downtime" activities might be a little unusual-- voice acting is certainly a solid notch above what you usually get in an RPG but it's still an RPG though. I mean, you even have the standard archtypes (if quite a few more than usual): the jock, the socially awkward girl, medieval cheerleaders, geek with the glasses in the back.... They're all there.
At least, that's how it STARTS...
As you start playing though, between managing inventory, leveling, combat, and, of course, unraveling the main plot etc, etc, etc-- something starts to happen.
The One Dimensional archtypes that you've written off actually start taking on... well, DEPTH.
And the STORY actually starts getting interesting too!!!!
I won't front, it had been SO LONG since I had seen this level of good writing that I had honestly forgotten that it was even possible in an RPG. And the acting is just... WOW.
Ok. Yeah. Graphics won't make you weep at the beauty and magesty of realistic 4k as you count the individual hairs on the back of your character's head but... that story and that acting more than make up for it.
First off you canNOT hope to get through everything on just one playthrough. Forget multiple ENDINGS, this game has MULTIPLE PLOTS. No joke. The WHOLE STORY is different depending on what you pick in the first few hours.
Now, you want multiple endings? OMFG!!!
Apparently, after spending do NOT tell me how many hours with these characters, the game actually generates a little ending for each and every single character you have gotten to know based on what YOU were doing during your playthrough.
Computer-wise, it probably didn't take that long but the writing chops to go through and figure out what would happen to every single possible pairing of 40 characters and never miss a single beat...
Wow. Just. Wow. You have REALLY got to have a definitive idea of who these characters are in your head and remain true to that idea in order to do that- I mean, Hollywood has a hard time doing that with less than FIVE over 90 minutes a lotta times. So, yeah, hat's off there. Lol.
So, the writing and the acting rocks but, this is a GAME, how's that gameplay, you're asking...
I haven't had this much fun with a turned based in a long, long time.
The loads of menus IS a little intimidating at first but it's honestly not that difficult to get the hang of things. Tiny touches and flourishes make things both a little easier to pick up and a little rewarding as you do. I love the real time prediction mechanic that shows you how much damage a character can make to an enemy and how much damage they can do back so you can experiment a bit BEFORE you confirm a command. Another nice touch is the little action cutscenes when an attack is made. You CAN turn them off if you want but I left them on because they actually seemed to add a little more drama to the fights.
Now, I will admit that this game is a Completionist's NIGHTMARE. Because of all of the different characters and all of the different details and all of the different plots. I tried to do my normal grinding for levels, etc but eventually learned that that's NOT how you're supposed to play this game. You're supposed to just play the game and pretty much let the cards fall where they may when it comes to the details. And that is how I recommend playing it.
Also, folks who gots ta has their eye-candy and/or looove that space bar when it comes to playing on the computer (skip cut scenes alot) will NOT find any fun here. Nor is this a good game for action junkies. Y'all got Devil May Cry, etc for that. Go enjoy Astral Chain. Great game too and far more enjoyable for button mashing.
You want to wander through a great story with interesting characters and excellent acting though?
Yeah. Stop debating, just hit that buy button and-- well, cancel any future plans you got for the next few months. U gon b buzy.
:D

title: Perfectly useful case text: First, I detected no funny smell from this. It smells like nylon or vinyl. Nothing offensive.

I use the straps sometimes, and just ignore them other times. Depends on how much I think the thing will be bounces around in my bag. If you just put the device on top of the straps, they hide out of the way. The case holds the device snugly, and is very well padded.

The zipper is stable, closes easily, and doesn't jam or open on its own. I think that's important for a case like this.

I highly reccomend keeping the little baggie the clasp comes in. It's perfect for storing the super-tiny Sony storage cards. Then you can stuff that in the webbed area and have them together with your system and not easily lost in the case. I find no use for the clasp, but as clasps go, it's a nice, sturdy one.

It's large enough for the AR cards to sit in the top compartment, though a slot for them might have been nice. They don't fit in the webbed area--not quite.

It's a good, basic case.

We both really like that there is a sound control and on/off switch in the cord that is easily accessible too. The microphone rotates up when not in use which was a sticking point for her. I should note that they do light up, something we didn‚Äôt expect is that there are two cords to plug in. One is the headphone jack and the other is a USB plug that powers the lights. That‚Äôs all it does. So if you don‚Äôt want them to light up, they don‚Äôt have to. However, when they do light up they rotate in a rainbow of colors. They don‚Äôt stay a solid color that you can choose. This was not that important to either of us but was a fun feature nonetheless. Overall, we both recommend these headphones. The quality of the product is sturdy and doesn‚Äôt feel like it will break any time soon. Great purchase!

title: First Impressions: It's the BioWare MMO text: My main first impression, a little more than ten hours in and around level 13, is that this is "the BioWare MMO".

What I mean by that is that if you are used to playing BioWare's games (particularly the more recent titles like Dragon Age or Mass Effect, but even also the older KOTOR series), you'll find that this game plays mostly like a BioWare game with MMO elements -- it's basically a BioWare storyline game stiched together with MMO elements. Whether you like this or not will depend on the degree to which you like the BioWare approach to game design, with its strong emphasis on storytelling, cinematic cut-scenes with interactive dialogue, choice-driven character development, and the like.

I have always liked BioWare's games, and so these elements are welcome in an MMO experience for me. Gameplay is also what you would expect in a BioWare game (in my opinion): good, but fairly "standard". In my opinion, BioWare does not design its games around gameplay, but around storyline and setting, and gameplay is intended to be engaging, but essentially to forward the story line in an interactive way. TOR is no different from this general approach. The gameplay, in terms of nuts and bolts, is very similar to what you have in other "theme park" style MMORPGs -- quest hubs, leveling advancement, training/banking/trading hubs, leveled zones and the like. It is all done competently in TOR, with remarkably few glitches, but the gameplay isn't revolutionary, new, groundbreaking or anything like that -- it's standard, good, gameplay for the genre which is used to advance you along the storyline with its many interactive cinematic scenes.

What does this mean for potential players? One point is that if you are a veteran MMO fan, looking for something that is new and groundbreaking in terms of the actual gameplay elements, this isn't going to be it. What is new and groundbreaking about TOR is the interweave of the BioWare elements of storyline and interactive cinematics and dynamic character development, rather than actual gameplay mechanics. I think that quite a few of the people who are liking the game less fall into this category of people who are MMO vets and "want something new" from the perspective of gameplay mechanics, and find that TOR is a competent iteration of familiar gameplay mechanics for a theme park MMO, but with a lot of the elements from BioWare's single player game design ideas woven in.

It also means that if you are a big fan of BioWare's single player games, you'll probably like this MMO more than most, due to its emphasis on many of the same elements that BioWare has introduced and emphasized in its single player titles. Having said that, because it is an MMORPG which has to have a lot of other elements involved, the storyline and cinematics and so on are not at the same level -- in my opinion -- as what we have grown used to in, say, the Mass Effect series. In other words, it isn't a single player game. It's an MMORPG "chassis" stitched together with BioWare's game design ideas from its single player games, but done in such a way that they "fit" in the context of an MMORPG.

Where this game goes remains to be seen. It's solid, not very buggy or glitchy, and has a huge pre-existing fanbase both for the setting/IP and for the developer, and is fairly easy to pick up and play. That confluence of factors hasn't aligned this way in the MMORPG world since .... WoW. We've had games made for great IPs that didn't turn out to be great games (STO, AoC, WAR), and we've had games made by respected developers that didn't turn out very well, too, but this kind of confluence hasn't happened in a while. We will have to see where it goes as the game develops over the course of the next several months.

title: Far Cry 3 - awesome game text: I have 3 games for my PS3--MW3, Black Ops 2, and Far Cry 3. I enjoy them all. I stopped playing BO2 for a while so I can play FC3. The creators have thot of almost everything for this game. I am thoroughly impressed with the graphics and scenery of FC3. I haven't read anyone else's reviews, but I see that it is at 4.5 stars with over 90 reviews currently. The action is fantastic. Just buy this game and play it is all I can tell you, and you will see for yourself. Keep picking up plenty of green leaves to keep up your strength/health. Use silenced weapons whenever you can. Use your camera to identify enemies whenever you can. Crouch whenever you can to avoid being detected unless you are a hard charger and don't care about being detected. The vehicles and weapons are awesome. If you like off-road driving, multiple weapons, and fast action, this game is for you.

**WARNING** Lots of F-bombs and vulgar language. Extreme violence. Extreme drug abuse / references. Not for little kids unless you are OK with them being exposed to this sort of thing.

title: Fun for casual and hard-core gamer. text: My wife and I played this with our 5 year old son. It's easy enough for him to get through most levels to move the story along which is why it's fun for the casual gamer. You don't easily die or lose. There are usually 5 or so additional goals to beat if you really want more of a challenge (ie: collect over x number of gold, finish with more than 2 minutes left, make it through the level without getting wet, don't take any damage, etc etc) along with 3 special treasures to find in each level. Plenty of replay opportunities and difficult tasks for the hard core check-lister type player.

My 5 year old enjoyed it more than my wife and I. We enjoyed the comic style, hand drawn art, and puzzle/level design. Some of the wii remote gimmicks were excellent (ie: controlling your rocket ship thrusters or Subwarine with the wii remote). Wario is not a lovable character / hero nor is the story much (not that we expected a lot). I was ready to be finished with it by the halfway point, but we continued through the end for my son's sake. Luckily it wasn't too long to complete since we weren't trying to finish all the goals...it's great that the designers created it for casual and hard core gamers.

title: I think I'll stick to the free version - too basic and did not detect recent infections text: I had a free version of McAfee provided through AT&T that I had been using for many years until I was offered the chance to try the Total Protection version; so far, my computer has been infected with several adware / malware outbreaks that McAfee did not catch (instead, I had to resort to downloading and running Malwarebytes and SpyBot). Even while infected, the full McAfee scans came up "clean" each time. I had no issues with the PC install on Windows 8.1, but the "free" mobile McAfee app I started getting e-mails about did not work and I uninstalled it.

Compared to other "premium" packages I've used in the past (including Endpoint), the interface is very, very basic and does not seem to allow for advanced options. I also wish this had a built-in Facebook wall scanner like Norton offers as FB is becoming a common place to download infected files through shared links, etc.

And the fact that several Potentially Unwanted Programs / malware were not detected despite running the most recent version of detection files did not boost my confidence either; I think I'll stick with the free version provided by my Internet provider.

title: Constantly looses connection to dongle. text: When this mouse works, it works. Accurate, good liftoff, pre-set DPI functions are fine.

EDIT: I'd drop this to a zero star if possible. Started having issues with my scroll wheel that might be as result of a hair or something wrapped around it. A easy fix i've done on just about every mouse I've ever owned at one point or other. Take it apart and instead of standard Philips screws this little bastard has the tiniest torx I've ever seen. Smaller than any torx bit I own. There is no reason for this beyond a middle finger aimed at customers trying to fix their own gear. End edit:

Downsides, in order of severity.
It doesn't always work. It can go a week without issue or I could loose signal to the mouse half a dozen times in a day. When this happens the only solution is to unplug and re-plug the mouse. This has occurred on both my desktop and laptop, so is an issue with the product, not my hardware.

Battery life is less than 1/4 of what's advertised. This is honestly fine, but I strongly recommend getting a few sets of rechargeable batteries and having them ready.

Every time you plug it into a computer it automatically installs it's garbage bloatware software without prompting. This, on it's own, would qualify this mouse for a one star review from me.

title: Great Change of Pace text: I love this game, but then again I don't like games that depend on how fast of a mouse I have, or how fast I can click my macros.

Some of what you read in these reviews is only partly true.

Can you lose skills that you've worked for weeks to learn? Sure, but only if you don't clone yourself.

Is fighting like being on Auto-Pilot? Not that I've seen. My missles don't fire automatically. Yes, I can set my ship to stay a certain distance from an enemy and it flies itself, but I still have to choose my targets, lock on, and fire.

PvP. Well, you don't die first of all. Your ship blows up (but you did buy that insurance right?), and you go to your homepoint in your life pod. Can the other players blow up your life pod? Yes, but I've never experienced it. Besides, I have my clone and lose nothing if they do.

With the huge expansion coming out, now is the time to get your 14 day trial, plus the 30 more you get when you buy the game code.

44 days of play for $20. What do you really have to lose? (Besides your job from losing track of time and staying up until 4 AM!)

title: Too complicated for the layman... text: THE GOOD:
-------------
* Terrific build quality. Good heft
* USB-C

THE BAD:
-----------
* Not for layman. Manual is useless. You are basically on your own from the get go, and you just figure out things blindly. I figured the FLYDIGI app is what I needed, and sure enough I found it on the Playstore. The app uses lingo and terms only gamers probably understand. Classic mode, native mode, mapping mode, Flashplay mode, etc. There is a big learning curve to understand what all these modes mean and does. Next to word CONNECTED, is the word UNACTIVATED. Apparently you need to activate something, and it gives you a choice of using U-Tool or the PC. What is U-Tool? I don't know, but the app assumes you do know. So I googled "U-TOOL flydigi" and I discover it's some sort of rooting dongle. So then I figure, I'll check out the PC method. For this option, they tell you to go to their website and download the PC tool. Except, the only option is an Android APK. SMH.

They have an email, and they seem to have a community, but I'm not that much into gaming to put in this type of effort. I wanted a controller that would hold my phone, so I can play roblox with my kids, that's it. LOL! Because I hate the touch controls in Roblox. This is too complicated. I'll go 3-Stars! I'm sure this is 5-Stars to people into gaming. Knocking 2 stars for the lack of directions.

title: Irritating to play text: I have never played Dungeon Keeper so I am not/could not be basing my expectations from that game. I bought this game because the concept sounded fun; build your own dungeon and attract/kill heroes? Sure, I'll try that. But the biggest problem with this game is that you are so busy reacting to annoying diversions that you never actually get to play the game you wanted this to be.

Instead of actually making a fun dungeon, you are tasked with watering a zombie's flowers while she is away selling magazine subscriptions (seriously) or some other mundane task which has a ridiculously short time span to accomplish, and which if you fail to accomplish you pretty much die. Or your dungeon heart is getting attacked by zombies... again... every five minutes... requiring you to drop what you were trying to do to defend it. I swear it is as unnerving as having a toddler grab you by your ears, put his face in yours, and demand your attention every five minutes. The game might appeal to a type-A multi-tasker who thrives on chaos, but as a form of relaxation and entertainment it totally misses the mark in my opinion.
