title: Bugs and Design Flaws text: EDIT (April 1) -- Well, the game has been out almost a month now, and while the servers are mostly stable now (rollbacks are still not uncommon, but connectivity is mostly stable), nevertheless the game is riddled with questionable design choices and outright bugs currently. One might hope that the bugs will be addressed at some point in the not too distant future, but it appears unlikely that the design choices will be revisited. These impact things like city size, traffic functionality, the interplay of demand between R, C and I, the trade system, and the overall problem that the simulation is, frankly, too easy and too streamlined to provide the kind to depth that SimCity's fanbase would have liked to have seen in the game. I would be very careful before deciding to buy this game, as a result.

=====

It's been a long time since the last iteration of the series was released -- January 2003, in fact, just over ten years ago. So, you can afford to wait a bit longer to buy the next iteration -- and you should.

SimCity has been reimagined as a multiplayer online game. The ostensible game-design reason this was done was to permit people to play in a region together with other people online, each controlling one city in a region, trading resources, specializing their city and cooperating with the other mayors in the region to achieve challenges and build regional great works like large airports. While that may sound well enough, the side effects of this core design decision are many -- both technical and gameplay.

First, the technical -- and this is why you should not buy this game right now, but wait to buy. Because SC has been recast and redesigned as a multiplayer online game, it is played on servers, as is the case with an MMORPG. The city you are playing exists on a region on one of EA's servers, and not locally on your machine. You must be connected to EA's servers and logged into them in order to play, just as if you were playing an MMO. And, if a server is down or offline or full, you can play on another server, but, just as would be the case in an MMO, your "character" (here, your city) is located on the other server which is full -- if you want to play on a different server, you need to create (claim) a new city. This will all seem familiar to gamers who have played MMORPGs, but may seem surprising to players of the previous iterations in the franchise, because this kind of architecture has never been present in the franchise before, and is not common in city-builder simulator games in general. And, as is the case with MMORPGs, this kind of design generally leads to a lot of problems when the game is first released due to the heavy volume of player interest. That is, the servers are set up to accommodate a stabilized player load, and not the rush of new players when the game is released. So, currently there are massive, massive server problems for this game, making it barely playable -- servers are offline, or being maintained, or simply full, there are queues, there are rampant disconnects from servers in which one's city fails to save to EA's cloud, meaning that significant progress -- perhaps 30 or more minutes of play -- is simply lost into the ether. At this point, because of the server problems the game is experiencing and the large load of players (the game just released in Europe, meaning more players inundating the already full servers -- and, no, the servers aren't geographically limited in terms of who can login to them), it just isn't very playable. Your best bet, even if you are intrigued by the new design, is to wait 10 days or so for the initial rush to die down and then check on internet sites to see if the servers are stable yet.

Second, the impact of this design on gameplay is substantial and wide-ranging.

For starters, the basic idea of the game is now to play in multiplayer regions where the cities depend on each other. As a part of this design, the size of any one city in a region is rather small and limited -- very limited when compared to SimCity 4, for example. You aren't supposed to be building the one great city, but a specialized city that works together with other cities -- trading resources and services with each other based on comparative advantages. In this way SC adds a regional cooperation simulator into the game, but it's more of a cooperative online game than a simulator, as you are really playing trade-offs with other players. The main impact of this is that it limits what you can do with your own city, because you are kept to a small enough space, and with only certain resources and not others, so as to force you to specialize. Now, you can play this in private mode, where you control all of the cities in the region, but this is still a very different kind of gameplay than previous versions of SimCity featured.

Another set of impacts from this is that, unless you are playing in something called "sandbox mode", you lose a lot of control over what you can do in your cities. The reason, again, is that this is designed as a multiplayer game, and like many multiplayer games it therefore polices what you can do, as a player, when you are playing. Even if you are playing in "private" mode, you are still restricted, because in theory your gameplay could result in leaderboard rankings, achievements, challenge rankings and so on. If you are playing in sandbox mode, these aspects fall away -- that is, your play is not "counted" towards any of these -- and you get more flexibility to control what is happening in your game. But, keep in mind that even though this sounds like "single player mode", it is still taking place on EA's servers and streaming to your computer, and therefore you need a continuous connection to the internet to play in sandbox mode as well.

The game has some interesting features as well, like upgrading public buildings, more variety in road design, and, of course, much better graphics. But prospective buyers should (1) wait at least until the server rush dies down and the servers are stabilized so that you can actually play the game for more than 20 minutes at a time and (2) consider carefully whether you want the kind of design that the game is -- a design that is focused on the regional level of play to a much greater degree than earlier games, and which is fundamentally designed to be played on a regional level with other players rather than as a single player game.

----

Note that this is an initial review -- I will edit this review as time passes and I can experience the game without the current server issues and become a bit more attuned to the new design.

title: 2 for 2, failed buttons. Just get a Deathadder text: I wanted to like this mouse. I like the position of the buttons (particularly the toggle DPI that lets you have a "snipe" button - more mice need that) and the general shape of the mouse, but it's just got so many problems, including abysmal build quality (which is shocking for logitech)

For starters, it's weirdly draggy and a bit heavy, even wired and with zero weights in it. I can't see anyone wanting to add more of the included weights - the point of this kind of mouse is to start LIGHT and let you tune it, not start heavy and let you make it worse. Genuinely heavier than my full size WIRELESS teknet mouse that I use for my media PC.

The feet lasted okay, they're starting to feel worn after a year of use on an aluminum banshee pad mousepad (I usually got about 2-3 years out of a set of feet on a Razer Deathadder) And they're very sensitive to picking up schmutz. Replacement feet are not readily found, you're gonna be using teflon tape. The combination of really meh feet and really heavy/draggy weight makes the mouse wildly imprecise after only a couple months. Even with teflon tape over the feet, I still can't make a "clean" drag across my mousepad with a smooth cursor movement. Not even sure it would when it was new. The aforementioned teknet mouse still absolutely glides after years. I think it's just because the 502 has SIX absolutely gigantic pads, and other mice I use tend to have 3 or 4 much smaller feet at most, which keeps the inherent friction lower.

Cord is okay if used with a mouse bungie.

The scroll wheel is abysmal. It has a side/side rock, which is already not good for a proper gaming mouse (they all have a habit of mis-registering mouse 3 clicks) but this is easily the worst I've ever experienced. I am used to the design, but this one is so bad and vague that I had to straight up disable the rocker, so now I only get about 15% of my middle clicks mis-sensed. The ability to unlock a scroll wheel is nice when I have to turbo scroll through a 300 page document, but again, in GAMING practice, is just one more way the scroll wheel feels incredibly vague and inaccurate.

mouse 4 is just set too far back. You have to press it with the knuckle of your thumb, which requires an incredibly awkward "palm pinch". If you use all the mouse buttons in a game, you're going to hate this thing so much.

And the thing is INCREDIBLY fragile. My first one's left click broke just sliding off my chair onto carpet, the whole mouse button itself sheared off. The second one's L2 switch itself is now failing, as it registers right click but doesn't register HOLDING it. After only a year, this is appalling. If you play MMO's, this makes steering an absolute nightmare. If you play FPS games, right click iron sight/scope becomes agony.

And there's something about this mouse that gives me really sweaty palms, which is weird because I have a kind of hybrid palm/fingertip grip that keeps my palm usually hovering just above the mouse

My deathadder was only replaced by this mouse because I suspected the skin flakes embedded in the chassis had evolved a new form of life. This one is getting hucked in the garbage because it fell to pieces in a little over a year and a half. I am staying away from Logitech for a few years after two absolutely atrocious peripherals and going back to the good old iron duke of a Razer Deathadder.

title: Currently my favorite! text: [[VIDEOID:15c368008dd4839790dca1b2e254fb9a]] I ordered the 'HyperX Pulsefire Raid - Gaming Mouse - 11 Programmable Buttons, RGB, Ergonomic Design, Comfortable Side Grips, Software-Controlled Customization' for review.

I am not as much of a gamer as I used to be but I do appreciate a quality gaming mouse. I used to be a die hard unmentioned brand fan boy at one time, but I have found that there are many others that have risen to compete against the best. HyperX happens to be one of those. I have a few other products from them that have blown me away in performance and quality. This Pulsefire Raid is most definitely my favorite at the moment. These days I mostly use a good mouse for video and photography editing and though I don't game much anymore, I would rather use a gaming mouse over a standard boring mouse. The Pulsefire Raid is anything but boring. It feels good in the hand and with the responsive clicky buttons, it makes for a better editing experience. I love that I can still take advantage of the programmable buttons as shortcuts within my editing software. It has become my new obsession to find the most useful and time saving shortcuts to map to my mouse. The Pulsefire Raid makes this so easy and I couldn't be happier with the overall performance. The customize-able lighting is fun to play with and that lighted logo is just so sick looking. Plus I love how smoothly it glides across my mouse pad. HyperX really nailed it with this one and I think it'll be a long while before I find another gaming mouse that I like better. I hope that this was helpful!

title: The DRM is much too invasive for me, I won't be buying this game text: My husband & kids were looking forward to getting Spore as a Christmas present. Unfortunately due to the invasive nature of the latest SecuROM we won't be buying. I see no point in being required to connect to the internet to play a computer game that isn't played online, besides the kids gaming computer is not connected to the internet.

I'm not at all happy that EA continues to force this DRM on us when according to articles, it hasn't done much to stop the software pirates. All it does is punish the paying customer. So I'll find my family a game that isn't so draconian with it's copyright protection software. The same goes for Sims 3. I've been a long time Sims fan, but if it has this garbage on it I'm not touching it.

title: Total Garbage. Batteries and Charging Station are Garbage. Save Your Money!!
text: After less than 1 month I am returning these batteries. These are the worst that I have purchased so far. After around 3 charges each the batteries don‚Äôt hold a charge anymore.  Also, the batteries would show that they were ‚Äúgreen‚Äù and charged. I put them in my Xbox controller and it would show 3/4 fully charge then after about 10 minutes of playing a game, the controller would disconnect. I also NEVER got a warning when the batteries were getting low. I would be in the middle of a gaming session and the controller would just disconnect and it would be because the battery was dead. Another thing I don‚Äôt like is the charging unit which charges the batteries is poorly made. My brand new Xbox One controller would show the battery as dead. Would not even connect to my Xbox. I put it in the unit to charge and it would show ‚Äúgreen‚Äù as if the battery was fully charged. Then after being in the charging unit for about 5 minutes the light would turn red and then the charging sequence would start and it would go from green to red to orange to green. It never showed as red when I put the dead battery in the charging unit. I purchased other rechargeable batteries that are wonderful and are still working perfectly. I just bought these to have extras because the first ones I bought was a 2 pack of another brand. I‚Äôm about to do a review on those also. But those work great. I‚Äôm going to order more of those and send these garbage ones back.

text: This is by far one of the best family games on the Wii.  I know this is geared towards children but I can tell you from a 30 year old who has broke this out NUMEROUS times for family functions, game nights with our friends, with my nephews and niece, etc, it's been a great game for everyone of all ages.  The oldest has been 60 and the youngest has been 6, if that gives you a spectrum how fun it is.  There is fun games for all like (dodge ball, tether ball, slot cars, paper racers, dart shooting, and wall ball).  Dodge ball seems to be the fan favorite as 4 people can play and it gets really competitive (especially when adults are playing).  Anyway, great family game for all ages and I would recommend buying this for your Wii.

title: Must have game for any role player gamers
text: Simply fun for a long time so far.  I play about three to four hours a day since I got it now for about fourteen days.  I'm not as good as some I see on you tube beating stuff on level one they do and I'm level seven and still calling it a fight.  Besides me being lame, the nice part is you can level up quick by making weapons like daggers non stop in white run, or by making potions again white run, or by even if your level one or so just take a rubber band around your xbox controller and make your character sneak for an hour against a door or wall where there's people around, you will go up in sneak quick and probably a few levels for character and no work other than watching for the the system to make you reconnect or return on you controller which will shut off in about every twenty minutes or so.  I just bought a house and am about level fifteen or eighteen not sure now, cash will come later and a lot of time is spent with potions, smithing, and using soul gems to make weapons to then sell them for good cash instead of peasly amounts for unmagical stuff.  I get two hundred to five hundred an item now, turn undead weapons pay the best I've noticed, even with just a few charges in them.  It's a game that will draw you in to wanting to just get one more thing done or get ready for the next day as is the way I play.  Killed my first dragon today and two ogres (ogres from distance with arrow one hit from them or two would kill me) was a rush.  I highly recommend this game though I don't appreciate how now I can smith dwarven and elvish armor and it's barely any better than just leather or studded, kind of ticked me spending perks since you only get one perk point a level to spend.  Oh well keeps playing turf even I guess instead of becoming to bad ass, lol.  Get this game if you like role playing getting used to fighting is a slight challenge to keep facing the foe or being the right distance to hit him with weapons.  I use fire on my left hand and a sword in my right seems to work for me the best.  Good luck and enjoy the journey.

title: One of the best RPG games I have ever played
text: One of the best RPG games I have ever played. I don't use the 3D effect too much but the features are still really beautiful. I like that you can chose 12 lives. I recommend to become efficient in every life class. I started off with the Paladin and use him as my main character with whom I do the Bliss Quests which is the main story line. To learn how to mine and fell trees and to fish is very useful while you explore the different areas. Other trades such as Blacksmith, Carpenter or Alchemist and Cook are also useful to learn. I like making my own furniture or cloths as example. Each life has its own set of quests. Even if I finish a quest while I am in a different life the game will let me know. The credit though for completing those quests can only be received once you change into the life to which the quests belongs to. I try to keep an balance between fighting my way through the game and trying to create items I can sell or use for myself or meals I can also sell. In the game you have a general leveling up and also a certain level you can gain through your quests within a that life. Once you finish a certain pain in the main story you also invite other characters in  the game to fight with you and you can play through your internet  with other players once you befriend them and they own this game as well. I know the game can be redundant, you always have to collect items or constantly have to battle monsters, but I also like games like Harvest Moon or Rune Factory or Pokeman. I received 3 DS games this Christmas from my children, I am an older player, and this is my favorite game ever. I will buy the expansion pack eventually and I hope that they will develop more expansions to this game. I am totally hooked on this game and I do appreciate the prettiness of the game. I would buy this game again.

title: Not so great.
text: I thought this would be as good as the other Animal Crossing games but sadly it is not.  You cannot use your personal Mii like you can in the other versions.  Also, you cannot take your uniform off but only add different pants, skirts, shoes or hats from a very limited inventory.  You cannot shop in any of the stores you design or buy anything yourself since you never earn any money. You do not have a home of your own so at the end of each play day, you do not ever go home, the game just saves and asks you to continue or quit.  It becomes quite repetitive since all you can do is design other animals houses but cannot use anything yourself.  Would not buy again.

title: Classic game text: Back in the mid 1990's I worked for a small engineering company, and for a time you could tell when it was 5pm without even looking at your watch. That was because the sound of keyboards being pounded began to echo through the engineering department. Myself and seven other engineers would start playing Descent right at 5 o'clock and continue to do so till late into the night. It was a great game.

I never got around to playing the version for the original Playstation until years later when I had bought a Playstation 2 console. Just recently I purchased one of the new Playstation 3 slim consoles, and I was under the impression that the PS3's could not play Playstation 1 or 2 games. But a couple weeks ago I was reading a thread in the Amazon Video Game customer discussion forum and someone there mentioned that you could in fact play PS 1 games in a PS 3. I tried playing the original PS1 Silent Hill game and it worked! Finding that out I went and browsed the used video games here on Amazon looking for some old classics to buy. Descent Maximum was the first one I ordered. Got it in about a week later and have been playing it since.

The game play is as I remember it - with the exception you're playing against the game itself and not other people. Being an old PS1 game, playing it on one of today's 42" television leaves a lot to desire - the graphics are really blocky on a screen that size (still playable though). So I ended up moving my PS3 and connecting it to a smaller 24" monitor, which suited the low-res video resolution better.

Descent Maximum is very similar to the PC Descent II game - you have similar tunnel systems, weapons, and the addition of the guidebot to lead you to objects and locations. Like the PC game, you can rotate your ship 360¬∞ in any direction (which at the time made some people a bit queasy). There are six worlds to play, each with six levels (36 total). Blowing up the reactor on the first level when I played this PS1 disc for the first time brought back memories.

There are a lot of fun old games like this out there - I'm glad to find out that I can still play them and will be looking for more.

title: Feels cheap, but works well and has lots of features text: I don't usually go for 3rd party controllers, but Brook makes some nice products usually. The packaging is really nice, but when I opened it, right off the bat this controller feels cheap. It may be a little more than half the price of a Pro controller, but it feels more like a $15 offering.

It seems that Brook products never come with instructions even though they really need them. The advanced functions of this controller, like turbo and macros, are not intuitive to setup. You can get the instructions on their website, but a printed version would really be nice.

The first thing I did was sync the controller to my Switch over USB. I was extremely confused because the face buttons were all mapped incorrectly. The X and Y buttons were reversed and the A and B buttons were reversed, so attack and jump were on the right side of the diamond layout instead of the left that we're all used to.

The next time I booted up the Switch and the controller was already synced to Bluetooth, the buttons were all correctly mapped. I thought maybe it was just a weird fluke. So, I hooked it back up to USB and the buttons were reversed again. So, I don't know what's up with that, but playing wirelessly works great and playing over USB messes up the button mapping.

The analog sticks feel pretty good. I don't have any issues with those. The AL and AR buttons on the bottom are actually pretty cool. They are basically shift keys to hold down and reduce the speed of the analog sticks to make aiming easier. This actually works really well.

The turbo functions work, but require instructions to understand how to set it up.

The d-pad feels ok. It's certainly better than something like an Xbox 360 controller d-pad, but nowhere near as nice as the Switch Pro controller. It's responsive and not too difficult to slide your thumb around on it. Each direction is distinct and easy to find with your thumb.

The buttons are all responsive and actually feel pretty good, regardless of how cheap the plastic shell is for the controller.

The battery does seem to last a reasonable amount of time and the Bluetooth works well without dropouts.

I tried the controller with my iPhone. The phone fits nicely in the cradle that connects to the controller. I didn't really have any games to use it on, but it worked well navigating the Game Center menus.

TLDR;

Overall, this feels cheap, but is very functional. I wouldn't pay $40 for it when you can get a Pro controller for a little more. Unless you want the turbo, macro, or analog sensitivity modifiers, then you could probably get away with a cheaper controller that works as well.

Pros
- Responsive buttons and analog sticks
- Battery life and Bluetooth connectivity are good
- Lots of features (turbo, macro, and analog sensitivity modifiers)
- Comes with charging cable and mobile phone cradle

Cons
- Feels cheaper than the price suggests
- Weird button mapping when using USB
- No instructions included

Edit:
I'll add that the thumbsticks are actually quite slippery. The actual Pro controller isn't perfect either, but this one is definitely more slippery than the Pro.

title: I was skeptical but it works perfectly text: This is a new product by a new company and there weren't any reviews out anywhere on gaming sites. I preordered the shaft from the manufacturers website and just received it a couple of days ago. I have to say that it works awesome. It runs all the old VC games and works great with the N64 games as well. It is awesome playing Brawl with this thing too and I'm excited to use it with the new Mario Kart game.

The joystick fits perfectly in my hand and I like the feel of it. The buttons are the right size and the stick feels great as well. At first I thought it would have been nice if it were wireless but to be honest I think I like it better this way. It always seems that my wiimote batteries are dead and the response time with the classic controller has noticable lag. The joystick looks really good too. There is another joystick out there, the Hori, but it is an ugly box and it won't control analog games (N64 games, wii games, gamecube games).

I like some games with the wiimote but I still feel most games should use a controller. I hated playing Brawl with the wiimote and if this controller only worked with that game it would have been worth it. Great product from a new company. I'll be picking up a second one for my wife. :)

title: Not perfect, but it works, nothing was broken :-) text: From purchase to setup, I am pretty pleased. However the hiccups were there.

While others chose All Access, which is actually separate from this bundle offer, considered a "new model." I chose the Black Friday limited time offer, then paying in equal installments over 12 months, using Amazon Prime Visa. I did this, because I converted from Live Gold to Ultimate Access, recently, and have two years prepaid. Over two years, though, the Xbox One X bundle is actually cheaper, when considering Ultimate is two thirds of the cost. On top of that, All Access requires a Capitol One credit check, and I didn't want that in my wallet.

The order was shipped across the country, why? I don't know, I would have thought the local Amazon warehouse would have had it ready for same day delivery. When it arrived, it was raining, though no attempt was made to deliver it to the door. It was dropped 6ft over the fence. Strange, you tell them once, deliver over the fence for a soft package you weren't going to be home for, then for the rest of your life everything gets tossed over the fence, no matter what it is. Fortunately only the outer box got soaked. The rest remained dry.

Somethings I noticed. The Xbox One X was made mid 2019, yet Star Wars Jedi: Fallen Order is a new game bundle. There was a secondary set of circular stickers sealing the sleeve to the packaging. Also the primary box was dusty. I have a theory. Somewhere along the chain, the box was opened, and the contents replaced/changed/updated, then the bundle sleeve was added. I don't know who does this, Microsoft or Amazon.

I was disappointed that the game was a digital download, and not a disc. The item presentation suggests a disc. Still, I cannot play the game. After downloading over night, it has 11 hours left. Not everyone has gigabit.

Setting up the unit wasn't as easy as documentation suggested. The iPhone Xbox App does not use the camera, therefore you cannot use the QR code to set things up. Also because the unit was so old, there was a 700MB+ update required and this disrupted and complicated the setup. Where I could type in a code to setup the unit from my phone, it forgot after the update, and I had to do it again on reboot - the iPhone app was no longer able to participate. Also, I had to manually enter codes to add the game license and extend Xbox Live Gold, by 20 days. What ever happened to using the camera and OCR to read the codes? Oh that feature is with the QR code reader - non-existent.

I replaced my Blu-Ray player with the bundle, on a new 4K TV. I decided to reuse the HDMI High Speed 1.4 cable, already run to the previous component. This may have been the source of screen blackouts during setup. I have reseated the cable and it hasn't blackout since. But the situation has been noted.

I liked that the Xbox detected the TV was 4K and a switched over to the higher setting.

title: Boring but Beautiful but BORING text: The graphics are really good on the PS4 and the environments look wonderful but the controls are clunky and you can't really interact with much. Townspeople say generic things and most of the settings look like animatronic rides that cycle animations...all the people look wooden.

The story is kind of OK. I am 10 hours in and just don't care about it. Alphen and Shionne have a ridiculous relationship where they love each other one minute and hate each other the next. The little interstitial dialogues you activate with R1 (when you notice the tiny message in the bottom right corner) paint Shionne as a weirdo...in these, she's goofy, hungry, absent-minded, etc. but in the main game dialogue, she's an icy cold princess who will destroy anything in her path. None of the characters are well developed and it's hard to care about them at all.

The music is garbage. It's the usual symphonic mess that all blends together, sounds exactly the same as every other game, and offers no emotional cues other than annoyance. I turned it down to 10 in the menu, as should you. The voice acting is OK but the characters repeat the same phrases during battle over and over again in either Japanese or English. The Japanese-to-English translation is also pretty liberal and I switched over to the English-only option because my ears were hearing things that the subtitles were not saying.

The battle system is stupid. All enemies, even the low-level trash mobs, have a ton of HP and take an excessive amount of time to clear as you don't do much damage unless you get the ultra-precise combo strings every single time. You can also just run in circles to avoid damage but, since you don't do much damage yourself, it takes way too long to take out even weak enemies. It got to the point where I was trying like hell to avoid battles...but then this game requires you to grind battles to get any kind of levels to face bosses. You also don't get much money to upgrade your gear. Bandai Namco wants you to buy upgrades (+5 levels, 100000 gald, etc.) with real cash and the game reflects that in its core design. It's bullshit that forces you to pay with cash or your own valuable lifespan just to get to the next boring, non-interactive map.

The game is pretty lame; it has main characters with nice modeling and various sexy outfits that keep the incels happy but it's shallow, boring, and trite. A very, very poor showing for a late-generation PS4/early-gen PS5 game that could have been so much more.

title: Quality cable but they can't get the type of cable in your order right! text: This would be overall a nice cable. It is a stunning blue and 6.6 ft long. I did NOT get a USB-C to USB-C cable and I also did not get a 90 degree angle on one of the ends. The cord itself is nice braided cable that keeps it nice and sturdy. The reason why I am slowly switching all my cables over to this type, the 90 degree angle at the phone end is just so much better. It doesn't get in the way and is not as prone to damage as the regular straight on ending.

This cable seems to work for fast charging as long as your phone and charging output both are cable of supporting a fast charge.

This is a fail for me though since one, I didn't get the right plugs on both ends and I didn't get the 90 degree on one end as I was looking for. I am not sure how this company can stay in business. This is now the third time I realize that I ordered an item from this company and 2 of them they got wrong! I would recommend to purchase cables from a different vendor. They do sell nice cables but odds are you will not get what you wanted.

title: Fun and challenging text: This was the first Nancy Drew game I played and it got me hooked. My husband was walking by during one of the puzzles I was trying to solve and he sat down to see what it was about and ended up playing the entire game with me. We both found this game to be very challenging and addictive. This is a great game for all ages although it might be a little scary for some youngsters.

One thing that we found amusing about this game was a little hidden text. There is a challenge where you will go downstairs to a room (kind of like a lab) and read some letters and notes. This is towards the end of the game. The main part you are supposed to read is darker than the rest of the text. If you strain and read the lighter text, you will see some interesting things there. It's been a while since we played it so I don't remember the exact text but it had to do with views towards the current president. We thought it was amusing that the writer/programmer put that in there.

Overall a great game with some difficult puzzles.

title: Still the best... text: I bought soon after release. Still my favorite racing sim. Nothing else is close, although the other legendary release was Papyrus Nascar 2003.

Both the above have tons and tons of updates, new tracks, complete makeovers, and more websites devoted than any racing sim released since.

Nobody should be scared off from GPL because they think it too tough for their abilities. Simply increase the Global_Hype_Scaling in the drivers.ini file for all drivers and presto the opposition AI cars can go any speed you want. Slow them down to where you can outdrive them using your feet if for some strange reason you want to. Or make them go much faster than the game defaults to where nobody could ever beat even one of them unless the blow an engine. Or anything in between.

To test just go to qualifying stay in the pits and accelerate time. You will see the speeds of every other driver during qualifying that your new Hype number changes have accomplished. Then by trial and error take an hour and set the global hype scaling to where a few of the other drivers are slower than you, but most are faster. Now you can learn to drive without being discouraged!

Soon you will decrease the Hype to speed up the opposition as you learn how to drive.

This sim is the most configurable racing sim ever.
And therefore one of the best to learn with.
It is also the best racing sim ever. All hardcore racers love it!

title: Lightweight, average sound text: I was drawn to the Logitech G435‚Äôs because of the design for smaller heads and how lightweight they are. Headphones that are too heavy or tight give me a headache, and many of the headsets designed for male gamers are just too big for me.

The G435‚Äôs are VERY light, weighing in at 5.8oz. That‚Äôs light enough to dangle off my pinky finger. Some comfort is sacrificed to reduce the weight -- the headband has no padding. A tightly woven mesh sleeve covers the top portion of the headphones, I can easily feel the frame. I can see the mesh getting snagged if you put these in a backpack or bag, it‚Äôs not super durable. The earcups are also some sort of mesh, which I found comfortable for a few hours, but not a super long gaming session.

The earcups do not ‚Äúlock‚Äù or click into position. So every time you put them on or take them off, the earcups slide up and down, and you have to readjust the fit. The earcups are on the smaller side; these headphones are best for kids, teens, or adults with small heads. The description says, ‚Äúfits a wide range of people but designed for younger players with memory foam ear cushions and sizing for smaller head sizes.‚Äù Definitely younger and smaller head sizes, not a wide range of people.

Sound quality is on the lower end of average. Not quite tin can, but ‚Äúhollow‚Äù is the best way for me to describe it. Quite frankly, I expect better from Logitech. I don‚Äôt use a gaming headset for just gaming -- I use a headset for everything, including listening to music and watching tv/movies. When I was trying the G435‚Äôs and listening to music or watching a show, I found myself reaching for my usual headphones because the sound was just not great.

The headphones do not have any play controls on the earcups, only power, volume up/down, and a mute button.

The headphones have no noise cancelling, and in fact, I thought they magnified background noise. My mom watches videos in the next room and I could still hear her videos over whatever I had playing when using the G435‚Äôs. I have other headphones that don‚Äôt have noise cancelling but they still block out the background noise. Not so with the G435‚Äôs.

Battery life is really good. I did get about 15 hours right out of the box. The headphones charge via USB-C. They are only wireless via the Lightspeed adapter or Bluetooth.

Overall, these headphones are a mixed bag for me. I like how lightweight they are, but the sound quality is not what I expect from Logitech.

title: I love the concept, but certain things take away from the fun text: I love the idea of this game. Basically you play a character who chooses to quit taking his "joy" pill and instead try to remember the past, which is mostly your brother and what happened to him along with the rest of the world. The joy pill basically is a pill that does what it says. It makes you happy and joyful, and forget all your troubles. While on joy everything around you appears bright and colorful and safe. While off it you see the truth, a foggy and dull world full of rotten food, etc.

So the idea is great! I love it. However, my biggest problem with it are the following:

Food and water: You have to eat and drink water every so often. Failing to do so results in low stamina which means you can't run for as long, and it also affects fighting.

Sleep: This too affects your stamina if you fail to get enough of it.

The above (food, water, and sleep) offer no fun to the game at all. It's just annoying as hell to deal with. Why they thought this would add value is beyond me. Never once during any other game that I've played in the past did I say to myself "Boy, I wish my character required food, water, and sleep. That'd be so much fun!" -- NOT! It's annoying. The only game that gets away with that are the Sims.

Another annoyance: There comes a point in the game where you'll be made to take joy pills to blend in with the town you're in. The problem is Joy pills only lasts 1-2 minutes in real time. It's highly frustrating having to constantly search for a booth (where the pills are located) every 2 minutes when all I really want to do is explore. And no, you cannot fill a bottle with pills. You may be able to find a loose pill that can be carried with you here and there, but overall you'll be relying on booths. If you fail to take your pill on time the crowd will attack you. Even if you hurry and run into a booth to take it, they're still after you! So if you plan to explore, good luck. I struggled so I gave up.

Furthermore, there are glitches and bugs with the game still. I feel they released it too early. They should have waited until they were fixed.

Overall, still an enjoyable game. Could be better is all.

title: Not bad, but there's a buzzing sound when I have the lights on! text: I am updating this since it's been a few months.
During normal use (at work, so 8am-5pm, Monday through Friday...with some gaming thrown in), my space bar broke. There was a plastic piece that holds the actual key down and that broke off. I tried to use it without it, but it still pops off. It's rendered it completely useless :(
---------------------
I recieved this keyboard for Christmas!

Pros:
- You can very easily adjust which color you want and the brightness of the color.
- It feels very sturdy and a bit heavier than I anticipated.. not a bad thing.

Cons:
- I wouldnt quite consider this to be a mechanical-feel keyboard
- When the lights are on, there is a very light buzzing sound that is driving me nuts! I am just keeping them off for now, but it does suck because a main reason for getting this keyboard was the lights
- The keys pop off easily (not a big deal)

Overall its a nice little keyboard. Im just a bit salty because I cant turn on the lights without a buzzing sound :(

title: And the winner by knockout‚Ä¶is..
text: Rocky! Knocked out creed 4 times. If you ever wanted Adonis and Apollo creed to go at it, Rocky and Adonis, If you want to hear famous lines like if he dies, He dies. If you want over the top, non simulated boxing that isn‚Äôt quite a button masher and actually requires a bit of strategy and isn‚Äôt exactly easy even on easy mode, If you like ready 2 rumble, Super punch out, Non serious arcade simulation boxing game then this game is a no brainer. The story mode is based on speech bubbles and short comic strip like stories. The graphics are nice for the arcade feel it‚Äôs going for, Every single character has a story line, Some you‚Äôll know from the movie, Others you‚Äôll meet for the very first time and fall under the funniest of stereotypes. But in all honesty this game does what it sets out to do well, Arcade boxing. It‚Äôll hurt your fingers after a few fights from the button pressing and the frustration but it‚Äôs a fun fight. The sounds are funny to hear minus Rocky. When you pick Rocky in the story mode every single time his dialogue bubble pops on the screen he does a weird grunt in the most Stallone way possible it‚Äôs hilarious. All in all it does what it sets out to do, It‚Äôs not done incorrectly, It‚Äôs not budget made as most of us are used to. It‚Äôs a good quality, Arcade feel, Fantastical boxing game that gets a 4 out of 5 stars. Get it if you miss arcade boxing games, Get it at a lower price if you have no idea what arcade boxers even are üí•üåü

title: Not as good as previous games
text: I've been playing Mario Party games for a long time and this one is disappointing.  The game play is fun, but I miss the old game play style.  I miss getting vending machine objects to sabotage other players.  I miss choosing options for your board when you only want to play a short game with only 10 rolls.  And I miss the mini games after everyone rolls.  This game is just lacking.  I wish they would have integrated the Amiibo play into the actual game instead of making it a side game with the same board design with different graphics for every Amiibo.  Any Amiibo's that are not in the "super mario" category you can scan once a day and play a scratch card game to get points which you then use in the store.  The problem is after you play 3 games on the real board you have enough points to buy almost everything.  You get the unlockable characters right away instead of having to work for them.  I understand that they were trying to change the game so it wasn't the same as their other games but they took out the best parts of the Mario Party series.

title: Gonna give it more time. text: So far I like what I see. I have only gotten up to selecting a character/ I tried the quick fishing trip but could not cast. I thankfully got a copy with the booklet so I'm gonna read up on how to cast. Everything else up to this point has been good. If the graphics hold and the actual fishing are as good this will be fun.
Update. I played this all weekend. Once I figured out the casting this game started to be fun. Then I caught a 45Lb striper with 6 Lb test line (about 15 to 20 mins fight time) I was "hooked". I entered career mode and started really getting to the meat and potatoes of the game. I quickly earned my reputation points for the lake and entered my first tournament. SURPRISE!!!! you don't begin the tournament in the same location as you do for free fishing!!! Well I was totally lost and lost my first tourny. The next one went much better as I learned what to expect (FYI- DON'T be late getting back- even a second late means you lose a pound of fish!) After about 8 to 10 hours play I hve unlocked 6 lakes, won a boat, earned enough gift cards for 2 additional rod/reel combos, purchased a tackle box full of lures, and lost every boat race challange I have tried! Yea this game takes a bit of getting used to but it does have a lot of play value and I'm having a blast!

title: Disappointed Overall text: My daughter and I ordered the digital downloads directly from Nintendo's eShop, plus two pre-orders from Amazon to give as gifts. After playing my game for 15 minutes I was wishing I hadn't downloaded it because now I'm stuck with it. I can't give it away, and I can't trade it in or resell it. Only option we have is to play, and make the best of it. But I will be spending the $5.95 to return the two unopened games to Amazon.
We have played the two previous ds games and loved them both, the 2nd was better than the first one. Because of our experience we were very excited to play the new 3ds release.
There have been many changes made, some good, but more bad. The graphics are a nice improvement, and being able to play with in-game friends is a welcome addition. We think it's cute having Nibbles, the vivosaur follow you around.
We feel they have made what used to be a fun game very annoying, and more juvinile. The instructions are a little vague at times. The Bone Buggies, while nice, are harder to control. I realize that further in the game there are upgrades that improve this, but it will take some practice, patience, and feelings of frustration at the time wasted trying to maneuver into the position you want to go. We don't like how you only have one chance at digging up a fossil. Meaning you can't save before you clean a fossil in case you want to retry again. But it can be convenient because you don't have to keep going back to clean them when your pockets are full. It's nice that the jewels you find are automatically sold too.
Also, we do not like that they took away the ability to see where you are on the main Park. The bottom screen shows the map, but now there is no dot on the map making it easy to know where you are, and where you want to go. I found that convenient, and used it all the time on the other games. It takes getting used to this change, and wish it was still available.
One last thing I want to point out is there is no way we think this game should be compared to Pokemon. It is my opinion it's being compared as a selling tactic because of Pokemon's popularity. The Pokemon games are a favorite with our friends and family.

title: Rickenbacker is PAINFUL to your strumming arm! text: I'm a huge Beatles, Lennon, and Rickenbacker fan. But this guitar is flat-out uncomfortable and painful to use in Rock Band.

I'm talking about your strumming arm - the part of your forearm that contacts the edge of the guitar is just beat-up to no end while you're playing. There's no comfortable place to put your arm anywhere on the guitar while strumming. In stark contrast, the standard Rock Band Fender guitars always have a nice angled area that is perfectly designed for this issue.

I'm not pleased, and am planning on returning the guitar. For this much money, it has to feel good as well as play good. (And I will add that playing is perfect - spot on. No glitches or issues with the keys, the wireless reception, nothing. It's great)

One other note - I've heard from many other people online and in person that both the McCartney Bass and the Harrison Gretch have the same issue - painful strumming forearm syndrome (PSFS) "Puss-Fuss" is no laughing matter.

title: Worst Lego game, in my opinion. It's fine if you just want to pass the time. text: I love Lego games. I own them all. This is my least favorite for several reasons.
There are only about 14 levels. Most of those levels are ridiculously long. If you save halfway through, you are likely to lose some of your mini kits.
There are so many things crammed onto the levels that it can get annoying. I hate having to keep going back to change Batman or Robin suits. I hate that I can't just pick a suit in freeplay mode. I can only use a suit when it's there and needed.
My game only had a couple glitches, but it just added to the frustration I already felt. Google helped me fix the biggest problem....you finally defeat the Joker robot, Lex and Joker are together, and Robin comes to Batman's rescue. It would freeze right there so that I couldn't finish the level. I just pressed the big green xbox button on the controller over and over and over so that the game could "catch up". It worked, but there are other solutions online. The other glitch was in Lego World. If I used the batmobile to go up the ramp to collect studs, the car would crash over and over and over forever. I had to start over, losing my progress.
You can walk or fly around a really cool Gotham City. It's pretty cool, but it takes forever to get everything and it gets monotonous. The worst were the flying controls. I would be about to land perfectly, and the controls would stop me, turn me around, and leave me quite a distance away from where I was about to land. It was so frustrating, but I like to finish things so I just kept at it.
It took me forever to figure out the map, but once I did, it was easy to navigate and find the things I needed.
I'm at close to 100% on this game, but it has taken me forever. I only get a few hours to play every few days and I've been at it for weeks. With the other games, when I was almost finished, I'd just go through finding the mini-kits, then save/finish level. It shaved so much time off, but this one won't save the mini-kits unless you play all the way through. At least I hope they'll save that way. I haven't found out for sure.

title: Excellent addition to the game. text: Pets brings a whole new world to the Sims 3 title by allowing people to make friends with and family members out of animals of all sorts--cats, dogs, and horses are the main ones, but also birds, reptiles, and even wildlife like deer and raccoons!

The expansion installs easily, though CC users stand warned right now that most of your object-based content will likely need updating; hairs, clothes, stuff that animals don't interact with should be fine, but furniture and decor objects are probably toast. CC's always had a rough history with Sims 3, but it's eviscerated with this patch and EP. I use a Mac for my Simming so can't really use CC anyway, so it wasn't hard to live without it. Some CC sites have various hotfixes and patches available to make your CC work with Pets' patch, so proceed carefully. I'm also starting to get some crash-to-desktop issues and Error 12s (both issues with memory) after a fresh reinstall on a decent Mac, so suspect that a lower-end or older machine might have some real trouble running this game once this expansion is installed.

The expansion pack (EP) has a wealth of stuff besides animals. It comes with a town that is Western-themed and a ton of new objects and clothes. I didn't see any real misses in any of it. The objects are amazingly well-detailed, and the clothes/hairs knock it out of the park once again. EA's current artists are really doing good work nowadays; the original game and Store offerings weren't nearly this detailed and usable. It should be very easy to create a custom look with these objects. Of the animals, a number of breeds of cat, dog, and horse are available in Create-a-Pet; you can't make a kitten, puppy, or foal, but can adopt these ingame. Customizing a breed by making it fluffier or changing its build is complex but can be learned. Fanciful coat patterns are fun to apply and can be moved, sized, and colored as desired. The objects needed to care for these animals, such as a cat box or horse stall, are also available as objects to buy in build mode.

Gameplay is more fun than can be believed. Much has been made of the fact that unicorns can be enticed to join the household--and it's true. Black or white unicorns float around the game, and a Sim who has shown herself to be friendly to animals can make best friends with them and eventually get them into the household, where they act like a normal horse--except one that can breathe fire, paw vegetation into being, and bless or curse other people/animals. I immediately had my teen Sim get one, and I've been pretty much ignoring the rest of the game since then because OMG UNICORN. Riding is now a skill, and adult Sims can become professional equestrians, incidentally. The new concepts are very richly-woven into the Sims 3 tapestry. (Of course, if you don't want animals near a particular house or venue, there are KEEP OFF signs for that, just like in Sims 1, but these can also be configured to entice particular breeds of animal to the place OR keep them away!) Cats are a blast in this game--talkative ones yowl along with music, shy ones hide under the bed, and non-shy ones take their half of the bed out of the middle. You can play with them with laser pointers, pick them up and cuddle them, or even just sit by the fire with a kitty on your lap and pet them. It's fun to look through one's house and see a cat sleeping on the counter. Pets' attributes are not set in stone; by encouraging or punishing behaviors, you can shape the pet's personality to a great degree, so if you want a talky kitty, you can get one!

All in all, this is the EP I would recommend to people who can only get 1 EP and also would love to see animals ingame. It's amazing what EA's managed to bring into life, and a month after getting the EP, I'm still constantly amazed by the new things I see in it.

title: Almost a decent game text: Played on 2.6Ghz with 512Mb RAM Nvidia 6200 video card and broadband connection.

The Good: It's D&D with close attention to the rules. Graphics are good and the user interface is well designed and fairly easy to use. There's a wide selection of quests and most of them are fairly interesting. The mapping is especially good. The penalty for dying is not too harsh.

The Bad: Unlike D&D you only get XP for completing quests or quest objectives. There are no random encounters so you are forced to repeat the same quest multiple times to get enough xp to level up and become strong enough to face newer, more challanging quests. You have to find and join groups to complete quests because most are too difficult to solo and there is no advantage to soloing (no extra treasure or xp). Finding a group can take a long time - together with the long login process I normally I don't get to adventure for at least 10 minutes after starting the program. There is an xp penalty if a member of the group is higher than the quest level. I just tried a level 4 quest where a level 7 rogue joined us for 5 seconds and left (literally). We all suffered a 35% xp penalty :-(

There are also some minor problems with some of the quests. If you don't do exactly what they expect sometimes you have to start again or can't even complete the quest. I expect these issues will be resolved soon.

The Ugly: Lag. There is terrible lag as you enter new areas that can stop you from moving for up to 30 seconds. This is especially frustrating when you're in a dungeon being attacked and you can't respond. I'm sick of dying because of it. At first I thought it was my box but I managed to connect to a server shortly after it was restarted after it crashed (two server crashes in as many weeks while I was playing) and I had almost no lag at all so I'm pretty sure the problem is partially at the server end.

I just cancelled my subscription. I'm wasting too much time waiting for the game.

I would suggest downloading the drivers for this mouse as it gives you full control of the blue color on the mouse. You can change the pulsing frequency or turn it off, adjust the brightness of the lights, or even turn off the blue lights all together if they bother you. The software also lets you reconfigure any of the buttons on the mouse which is a nice feature.

I've been PC gaming for over 15 years and would recommend this to any serious gamer, there is no need to spend tons of money on more expensive mice. This does the trick and I've already recommended it to all my gaming buddies. I play fps games like CS:GO as well as MOBA, RTS, and MMORPGS. This mouse is great for them all!

title: Fantastic Reprise of a Classic text: Shogun: Total War was the title that marked the beginning of the Total War series of games -- games which feature a combination of strategic/turn-based play on a campaign map and tactical/real-time army combat on a 3D battlefield map. The original Shogun was a fabulous game, and, after years and several other iterations of Total War, including Medieval, Rome, Empire and Napoleon, Creative Assembly have returned to reprise their classic game, and done so fabulously well.

Shogun 2 drips with the atmosphere of medieval Japanese clan warfare and intrigue. The voices, the music, the scenery, and even the diplomacy are all period and region perfect, and give the game an unforgettable atmosphere. The campaign map reprises the clans of the classic game, with Japan divided among numerous warring clans, each headed by a Daimyo/warlord. The player controls one such clan, and must manage his clan's economy, trade routes and income, family relationships, general loyalties and roles, diplomacy with other clans, construction of buildings, military units and naval ships, spying/subterfuge/assasination/religious conversion and, of course, warfare. The basic outlines are, of course similar to those of the other games of the series, but with markedly less "bloat" than we have seen in some of the more recent titles -- units are more streamlined, which makes some aspects of the battles more intuitive.

The game, however, is set at a challenging level. Even advanced Total War players will find the challenging settings to be very challenging indeed. Newcomers to the series may find even the easy setting to be challenging as well. The AI in Shogun 2 is smarter, more adaptive, and more aggressive, at lower difficulty settings, than in previous titles of the series. This added level of challenge gives the game more depth, and keeps the player on his toes, although it can be admittedly frustrating if you have a low frustration tolerance or are more tuned to the difficulty settings of earlier games in the series. However, if you enjoy a bit more of a challenge, you'll find Shogun 2 to be a wonderfully engaging strategy game that will provide interesting play for quite some time.

In all, this is a must for any fan of the Total War series, and probably the best game of the series to date. Any serious strategy game fan should give this game a shot -- you won't be disappointed.

title: The absolute worst experience of any game I've played in years text: This is truly the worst customer experience I've had with a game probably ever.

As many reviewers have mentioned, Origin is absolute garbage. I had to create yet another account, download a software package, install two browser plugins, and then proceeds to be nothing more than a webpage. The website itself is irritating with a thousand different updates on every single server you played on and a bunch of other noise. The server browser is atrocious, and you literally have to exit the game and reload the browser page to switch servers. It's important to note too that it takes several minutes to load a map, and my computer is very fast.

The game itself is a buggy mess. I have played dozens of games on my current computer with zero problems, and I had to spend hours getting BF3 to actually work for more than 10 minutes without crashing. Even now, I still frequently experience crashes, but at least it runs. There are huge balance problems, game play is often irritating and feel is sloppy. This is coming from a big fan of multiple BF games since the original.

Almost every time I play this game it is nothing but frustration. From having to deal with the moronic Origin and crashing to hackers in game and balance problems, it's just not even fun. There really is a fun shell of a game inside all this idiocy, but it's outrageous to have to buy a $60 game and $15 expansion to put up with all this garbage. EA really earned their "Worst Company in America" award this year.

title: 6 system auto selector video/audio - CAUTION
text: First it isn't a game that I'm reviewing so I have no idea how much fun it is. This auto switch seems to work but be careful. It isn't actually a 6 system switch. It will switch 2 systems or 4 systems but not 6. It has 4 inputs for video/audio and 2 inputs for S-Video/audio. Then for output you have a single video, S-Video, and the R/L audio. The S-Video output only connects to the S-Video inputs. So this can be a 2-way S-Video/audio switch. The video outputs connect to the video inputs. So this can be a 4 way video/audio switch. It can only be a 6-way switch if you can connect to the exact combination of video and S-Video and you have both Video and S-Video inputs into your TV.

title: Great additions this year, plus what other football game are you going to get?
text: I don't usually buy Madden's 2 years in a row, but I caught this one for 40 bucks and I'm super happy I did.  New mechanics for throwing and catching, as well as defending passes have made Madden feel fresh again.  Big time receiver can make circus catches down field.  QB's can throw touch passes over the linebackers but in front of the safety.  This all makes defense a bit harder, but defenders have the choice of playing the ball(going for an INT), or if they're beat, playing the receiver(tackling and trying to knock the ball loose).  These are great additions to the series.  It is a little annoying how long it takes from the time you turn the xbox on until you can play, especially online.  It has to check and download rosters and profiles.  Alas, this is just the old man in me waxing philosophical about the days where you just put a game in and played it.  Madden 16 is truly legit, and it's not like it has competitors.  Go Packers!

title: Plenty of gameplay

This game has the player searching around a creepy carnival, where there appears to be some sort of devlish robot causing mayhem, a dark presence, and a missing person.  The game features enough new locations to explore to keep the player interested, and generally has high-quality graphics.  Recommended to fans of the genre.

title: it's pretty..but thats all. text: UPDATE 4-------
OK. now the eye candy has completely worn off. And I can see clearly, for the first time, that this game is just NOT a good 'simcity' at all. The cities are so small. And even such, I could live with 'probably', but even with the small cities, they limit the tools you have to work with. They only let you put a little bit of bus stations, street car depos, and NO subway. Even a small city needs more than they let you have. These people are banking on the fact that you will be overcome with the 'pretty' aspect of the game, and not notice how limiting it is. My nephew has a PS3 and the graphics, on this game, are about on par with his system. Graphics are no big deal anymore. Sorry Origin.
UPDATE 3-------
Twice, tonight. The system crashed. I just wanted to nix the schools in my ONE city, as so they would send their population over to city Two's way. And maybe they could make their city an educational one, for a specialaztion. But two, I was shut down. So now, they lose another star, from me. Although this is a PRETTY, PRETTY, eye candy game. It's, simulation quality, was not an aspect they cared much about. The MAIN work was put into the cosmetics of the game. Not the realism, part.

UPDATE 2-------
OK. They lose another star from me. For 3 days now, and this is the third, so it COULD continue tomorrow. The program has crashed on start up. Requiring a shutdown of the program, and reload all the way back to where you were, usually about 5 minutes. I really thought that the Sim-city was OVER the crashes. If you do get this, don't have, very high exceptions for it. Just the eye candy part. It is ABSOLUTELY BEAUTIFUL. But beauty is only special until the NEWNESS wears down.
UPDATE-------
as of may 14-2013, the hosting company 'Origin' has brought some more servers online to handle the increased bandwidth needed for all the Sim City players. And also, after the initial release, there has not been so GREAT of a demand on the servers. So the WAITING for a place in line to get a server, is almost over. There is still the occasional hiccup in the system, so it only gets a 4 star so far.

good points.
The game 'Sim city' has always been extremely error ridden. In every version, since the beginning back in the 1990's. I played this on my Amiga 2000. I thought it was awesome, but it crashed when my city got to a big size. And so did all the subsequent editions. Except for this one. They keep on 'patching' the program, as problems are discovered. And they are adhering to the job, rather well. I've reduced my action on the game to 2 times a week. But 1 of those times, will install a new update package, 3 minutes total. So on, that front, I am very pleased.

The graphics. Absolutely breathtaking. I think this must be the entire defination of the term 'eye candy'. I bet it takes all the power I have, an i7 3.4Ghz, 16 G ram, but there is NO slowdown or any other adverse effects. Well written code.

In conclusion.
Yes, I would buy the program again now. They were NOT ready to ship this on opening day, but the weather is better now. There is still an issue sometimes with getting a server. But if you have time to take an hour out, it'll be OK. Now, if you made a date to do this, with a Lil' time window, that has no room for alteration. That would not work. But I don't have those criteria. 'I' like the program, too much, to 'not' play it. so YES, I would buy the program.

I cannot even play the game, because of busy servers. I've been trying every 6 hours, for the last 36 hours. No server, then there was a server, it said. But after a big dance around and around, it could not connect to the server. I don't think there ever was a server. Shame on you, Maxis.

If your the type of person who only cares about the competition of it, this game is not for you. The scoring is way too inaccurate and you may end up throwing your wiimote at the screen on purpose.

title: Epic Fantasy RPG text: I've been considering getting this game for some time, but I was unsure. I bought it on sale recently, and it turned out to be one of the best games I have ever played. It is definitely worth it even at full price, and you will be hard pressed to find a game that will give you more play time and enjoyment for your money. Without completing anywhere near all of the side quests available, Origins and Origins: Awakening gave me a solid 72 hours of game play. And that is just one character! This game has great replay value, and you can easily milk hundreds of hours from it.
The game play is fantastic, and the world is huge and diverse, with very good voice acting and character writing, amazing stories, and satisfying reactions based on your choices. If you love traditional RPGs, this game is for you. But for a few bugs that are few and far between (and mostly inconsequential), this game is nearly perfect, and even though a couple of years old, it feels fresh and engaging.
The graphics are nothing overly special, but the game is relatively bugless, and feels great. You won't find yourself lamenting your purchase.
The game also has a huge amount of mods available online to customize the game play.
Overall, this is a great game, and in my top ten games of all time. If you are considering buying this, do it! I don't regret it, and neither will you.

title: Great set, but the dock will not fit your Switch if you use a tempered glass screen protector...
text: This is a beautiful colorful set! The case is obviously designed to look like Mario's outfit. You're getting a nice Nintendo theme without the Nintendo price tag. LOL! It comes with a dock, the power adapter, HDMI cable and a USB-C cable. It even has a strap to carry the case via shoulders if you wish. A great on the go solution. Unfortunately, I'm going to knock off 1 star. This would be 5 stars, but I'm rating it a 4. The reason is because the dock is useless to anybody who puts a tempered glass on their switch. The fitting is so perfect for the Switch, there is no room for anything else. I can't even force it in. I can see the plug on the dock pushing up the edge of my screen protector. If I force it, I'm sure it will crack the screen protector and scratch the real screen underneath. Everybody nowadays love to put cases and screen protectors on their gadgets. That is why marketplaces are inundated with smartphone accessories, as well game console and computer accessories. Why would you not take this into consideration in your design? The dock is a big part of the price tag, and it'll be unfortunate for those who can't use it. I'll only knock 1 star since it should work for people who do not use tempered glass on their Switches, and it might even work for those who only use a thin film protector. But hardened glass protectors are very popular, and I feel this should have been taken into account.

title: ASTRO IS BASICALLY LIKE ‚ÄúHeres the headset, figure it out‚Äù text: First off - No in depth instructions at all. Which is pretty pathetic for the amount of money Your spending here. Their Astro website is horrid to find the information Your looking for. I ended up giving up after I wasted 30 mins. It would be nice if they had a in depth tutorial video to take full advantage of this product. Your basically left to figure it all out on Your own for the more advance settings.

Mic - picks up any background noise. Pickups my fan thats not even near the mic and my breathing too. Gets so annoying trying to enjoy the quality audio when the annoying sounds get in the way of that. My 2015 Astro A40 model never had this issue. Its like they are forcing You to buy the $60 upgrade mic set. Friends say I sound fine but hear my fan.

Headset audio - sounds amazing at times, sometimes sounds like a low budget headset, and sometimes it gets too overkill on intense action. Like its not balanced well enough or won‚Äôt process audio correctly through the mixamp. It picks up certain friends mics humming interference. Gets annoying trying to hear the game and hear humming when friend talks. Other friends mics sound great, crystal clear. This headset would take a long time to get audio just right. Any factor could be a plus or minus the quality. Its also pretty disappointing this headset is no different in audio compared to my old 2015 A40 model. Such a let down. Wished the headband was more comfy. Its very basic comfort. My head is big so maybe that might be a reason.

The Astro Command Center is a bit difficult to understand cause theres no instructions but Im pretty tech savvy so I figured it out in 8mins. Had to google ‚Äúbest EQ settings for 2019 Astro A40‚Äù to even find help on that part. Glad it wasn‚Äôt buggy and did its job well.

Music - it distorts horribly on certain songs. Pickups strange messed up audio in some songs. Stuff I never heard before. Just ruins songs. You constantly have to be messing with the mixamp to get a song just right.

Its very lame they got cheap and decided not to add a AUX cable like they used too, to connect a mp3 player. And wished they added the Stream cable connection too. For the hefty price Your paying thats messed up its not included.

Overall - I waited 4yrs for these and turned out to be a big let down. Its nice You can customize the EQ settings and buy the upgrade kit. Sound Quality is great but mic ruins that. You basically would enjoy these if You play single player games and / or stream them. Not great for multiplayer games. No improvement in sound compared to my 2015 model. I feel my 2015 model is way better out of the box plug in play compared to this one. Which its constant experimenting to see whats perfect / good enough. I say keep searching for something way better. This headset should be way better for what Your paying here. Instead of a annoying headache.

title: Twisted... but oh so good text: American McGee's Alice is possibly the most bizarrely entertaining computer game I've ever played. If you have ever wondered what it would be like to live in a Tim Burton movie, this is your chance. Alice takes the classic Alice in Wonderland, combines it with the Quake engine, tweaks it into an incredibly dark fairytale and then carries through with style.
The game begins with a cinematic showing Alice fleeing a house fire than consumes her parents as they scream. If you find this image too repulsive to accept, then this game is almost certainly not for you and you can stop reading because the entire game continues in this vein. A booklet that comes with the game is the diary of a 19th century psychologist that explains that Alice has been catatonic in an insane asylum since the death of her parents. The game itself is the journey of Alice through various realms of Wonderland that are now a dark reflection of the Lewis Carroll book, and is representative of Alice's subconscious attempt to regain her sanity.
The game screen is a `follow' view of Alice, with Sanity (aka life) and Willpower represented by tubes on the sides. Alice can jump, climb, swim, etc as you would expect from the Quake engine. In the course of the journey Alice finds various "Toys" such as a Vorpal Blade, a deck of Cards, and Demon Dice. The Vorpal Blade (a large broken knife) is the standard weapon while all other Toys require Willpower to use. The Toys are usually fantastically twisted, i.e. when the Demon Dice is rolled it creates a portal that a demon comes through and fights your enemies, but if there are no enemies the demon must still feed so it attacks Alice. The Toys all have very different properties and the choice of Toy can make the difference between death and survival.
I am in awe of how well done the world is. Alice is not a parody of the original book, but more like a loving sequel and the world is all the more interesting for being so like the familiar Wonderland. The game is divided into a number of chapters that have distinct looks and feels, so the Skool is a demented version of English boarding school with huge bookshelves and insane children while the forest is inhabited by soldier ants (with muskets!) and killer mushrooms. I really enjoy each new environment.
I've never died so regularly in a game despite the fact that I'm only playing at standard difficulty. Alice has the most perilous environment I've every seen in a game, in particular from falling. The developers are not only inspired but also sadists. This is a recurring thought I have while playing: "I wonder what THAT is... Oops, dead again. Good thing I save every five minutes." Fortunately, the developers gave Alice different ways to die to entertain the player before loading a saved game. My persistence is amazing because normally I favor strategy and role playing games, and found Rune and Alien vs. Predator frustrating and boring very quickly.
So why am I not giving this game four stars? Mainly on technical issues. A patch is available on the Apple website, but for some reason the patch caused the sound on my game to become corrupted. After many reinstalls and calls to technical support I just reinstalled without the patch, which means that all the known issues are uncorrected. This has not been a major problem thus far, but it is annoying. The enemy AI is decent but sometimes enemies continue to fire ranged weapons into walls when taking a step to the side would give them a clear shot at Alice. Enemy pathfinding is also fair, though I did see a couple of Queen's guards caught on staircases.
All in all, I recommend this game highly. There's enough combat and gore to people looking for hack-and-slash. There are a huge number of mazes and other puzzles that require problem-solving skills. The voice acting is some of the best I've heard in years. The graphics, background music and environmental sounds are above average. The overall storyline gets a little fuzzy at places, but that can be forgiven in a game set in Wonderland, though it is lamentably linear. And most of all is the fantastic demented game world with a underpinned with a gripping story about the struggle for sanity.

title: best mouse I've ever owned text: Its only been 1 day, but wow what an awesome mouse. Finally a button on the right side.

Pros:
Very slick design, the artwork is also beautiful. It glows whatever color you want.
Polished surface.
Fits my hands like a glove.
Very accurate.
Software is easy to use.
Lots and lots of buttons.

With all the pros above, there are a few cons which led me to give it only 4 stars.

cons:
The right button takes a lot of pressure to click, and its in a wierd spot where only people with a 1-inch-long ring finger can get to. People with longer ring fingers are going to struggle with it.

Although there are many buttons, the 3 top middle buttons on the mouse are in a wierd spot as well. And its unrealistic to be able to press them in the heat of a battle.

The software was made for WOW, which I don't play. It'll take a lot of guesswork to re-configure the buttons to what you want outside of WOW.

overall:

still the best mouse I've ever owned. If I had it my way however, I would make a few design changes.

Edit: Today, about a year and a half from this purchase, I am happy to say that I am still pleased with this mouse. The craftsmanship of this mouse is just superb! All the buttons are working like new, and even the surface shows NO wear! All other mouses paint would've been reduced to ar white smudge by now where the two clickers are, but this mouse still has a shiny coat of gloss as if I just got it brand new (which I didn't)!
