title: Excellent start to the series! text: I have not played any Star Ocean games before this. I began playing this game on the heals of completing Chrono Trigger (DS) and Tales of Phantasia (GBA). It plays much like Tales of Phantasia as one might expect.

The cut scenes and voice acting are done well for a portable game and add to the game. The battles are real-time, but felt less tactical than Tales of Phantasia did. Battles were still fun. The AI for the other 3 characters in your party is pretty weak but workable. I fought with the primary hero (Roddick) for the entire game except the final boss. I had to take over Millie (the healer) because she didn't know how to keep the party alive and just let the AI beat down the boss.

It's a shorter game compared to most rpg's out these days, which was a good thing for me. I explored and did a lot of minigames/sidequests and finished it in 25 hours or so. Personally 25-30 hours is nearly perfect for me. The story progresses at a nice pace until the end where it feels rushed...but it all works.

My favorite part of the game was the skill system where you customize your characters abilities. There is a lot you can do to customize your party.

All in all, it was the perfect into for me into the series as I know Star Ocean 2 is a longer game. I will play through this one again.

title: Thought it would be better
text: At first this game seemed to be better than it actually is.  The premise is that you are a detective hunting down criminals.  You have to search hidden object scenes for clues, and use those clues to determine who the suspect is.  You'll get clues along the way as to the suspect's gender, height, hair color, etc., and you'll use those to determine who you're seeking.  The hidden object scenes are located around the world, and you'll need to determine where you need to search.  So far, this all sounds good.  The main problem with this game is that there aren't very many locations or scenes, so it gets repetitive VERY quickly.  It's good for approximately two games, then it starts to get boring.  Not worth the money, in my opinion.

title: I regret buying this at launch. I paid to be a beta tester, which isn't cool. text: If you're interested in the game, wait for a few more patches to hit before you buy it. I'm a huge Mass Effect addict, I love the original trilogy to pieces and was super excited for Andromeda to launch. I've never pre-ordered a game in my life, but I eagerly did for this game, because I assumed that at worst, it would be on par with the graphics in ME3.

Hooooly cow, Batman. I had no idea the kind of glitchy, disgusting trashfire I was in for. The face meshes were so bad I strongly suspect EA Games told Bioware not to worry about faces and to just use the leftovers from one of the Sims games. All the characters look like they're drunk or hopped up on some sort of drugs all the time - there are NPCs standing around on shuttle landing pads just.. staggering back and forth, people's eyes dart all over during conversation. The lip synch is TERRIBLE pretty much across the game. Just a ton of crap that should have been fixed prior to launch. They've since fixed the shading on the eyes in the latest patch, so it's much less "Everyone has crazy Manson eyes!", and that's good. They've fixed a few of the other glitches, but I'm still finding terrible ones. The faces don't always align during convo, and last night I had a glitch where Ryder's head did a total 180 on his neck like something from the Exorcist during a conversation. I was in an area with a chasm, driving well away from the chasm, and my characters kept screaming a swear word - which is the dialogue if you fall into the chasm, so their convo triggers are messed up. Characters talk over auto-dialogue all the time. If you're examining something, you're stuck in the examine dialogue and can't move even if enemy creatures come up and start biting you - there's no way to quit out of it or square-key skip it, and since some of the sites respawn Creepers, it's an issue. I've had weird crash issues where I have to restart the game, and suddenly my Nomad will be underground atop a Remnant pillar, or stuck halfway inside a rock wall, or on top of a building. I'm hitting glitch after glitch after glitch, and while I expect a few glitches in games right at launch, the level of glitches I'm still getting, two patches in, is just awful.

Other annoyances: The combat dialogue is repetitive to the point of annoyance. After you've heard Jaal say "We're not alone!" or Vetra say "Good job!" or Cora "Charging shields!" for the fiftybillionth time in the same battle, it's really just irritating. Also, whatever targeting algorithm they used causes Cora to constantly steal my kills and that makes me want to shoot my own teammate. It happens every time I target someone, and while this may be a game mechanics issue, it could also be a character personality issue, but it makes me want to kick her out an airlock. I no longer take her on missions, she gets to sit in the ship, because otherwise my poor Ryder gets no chance at combat.

Remember how annoying it was to have to run back and forth on the Citadel? Yeah, there's a lot of that literally everywhere. You don't have elevators but you do have a tram system that you will be constantly taking back and forth on the Nexus. CONSTANTLY.

If you have migraines that are light-triggered.. Eladaan is going to require sunglasses. For some reason, the designers thought it'd be ~awesome~ to put in a blinding white fade in desert glare ... for every time you open/close a menu, look at a map, or fast travel. My partner has average eyes and no migraine issues, and that white flash causes him to swear in pain when it happens.

You start on literally the worst planet for beginners, Eos. You'll have a new, upgraded Nomad and neophyte level characters.. and it's a radioactive wasteland full of rocks and slopes. Which your Nomad can't jump over or ascend. Half the missions you are assigned for the world, you can't even do until you've cleared the Vault and then gone to another planet long enough for the radiation to die down - read: until you've completed most of the missions on another planet. If you're a completionist type of player.. which I am.. this is infuriating. I hated this so much I almost stopped playing the game altogether.

Oh, and that brings me to the map. You'll drive into a new area, and it'll print their name on the screen, "Four Pillars area discovered". Did those labels make it onto the map? Nope. You have to kind of deduce where things are by the topo features on the map, because good luck remembering the names to all the places.

Y'know how you used to be able to interact with people on your ship? You can still do that, but now they hijack you for conversations that have nothing to do with anything. "So and so wants to talk to you." "I'd like to chat if you've got a minute." etc nags constantly until you go talk to them. I LITERALLY had a conversation with one of my crew about licking rocks. There was no option to make a dirty comment. There was no way to escape the conversation. It was painful. It's forced interaction and it's annoying. At least in ME2 and 3 when you were notified a character had to talk to you, it had something to do with a mission or the plot. If you wanted more personal info, you got to initiate convo, they didn't hijack you and nag you to death until you talked to them about inanities.

Romance conversations.. at least with Gil, lemme say that I am Not Happy. Y'know those creepy guys who flirt with the subtlety of someone hitting you with a brick that's on fire? Yeah.. in this game, that's Ryder. He's a lech. It's icky. There's even a point where it sounds like Gethin Anthony - the voice actor for Gil - was uncomfortable, he sounds taken aback at something Ryder says. Ryder's dialogue is written as though someone watched creepers at some meat-market dive bar hitting on people. Some of the 'heart' dialogue with other characters is decent, but pretty much every line he has with Gil is just.. grossly blatant "Nice shoes, wanna ...?" Not so much romance as "I spent 600 years in cryo, I have lots of adrenaline flushing my system all the time because hey, combat does that to ya; you're cute and I hear you're into guys too. Wanna?"

Things I like:
I love, love, LOVE that, aside from loyalty missions, I can bring whomever I want on a mission. I can spend skill points for everyone while on the ship, I don't have to take them on missions to be able to level them up.

I love the ship. I love the landing/takeoff sequences. All that effort they didn't spend on faces? They did spend on the ship meshes and sequences. They're lovely.

I love my Krogan. He is the best thing in the game so far. He is old and cranky and takes no crap from anyone, and the best dialogue ever is when he and Liam are in the Nomad together. I want to find the person who scripted those lines and buy them a beer, because every interaction they have is glorious.

The music is spot on. The soundtrack is, per usual for the games, a thing of shining beauty. I did get a good giggle at the recycled Geth and Reaper noises, slightly altered but still there in the game. Even the "BWAAAAAAHM!" Reaper Call is there, quietly in the background, but occasional enough that if that sound makes you scream and jump.. you're gonna have moments where you'll scream and jump. In a good way.

I like Ryder. I like that they differed this character entirely from Shepard. Even at the beginning of ME1, no matter what you chose to start with, Shepard had experience and was, for good or bad, kind of already a legend. Ryder's a shiny new kid with very little experience and no stature whatsoever. You have to earn your stature in-game.

I like the story so far. I like the goals.

I LOVE that there is a 'Turian Calibration Tool' as an item. This, and all the other little sly kudos toward the first trilogy, make me squeak with glee every time I encounter one. And there are a lot of them.

I like that things respawn. The worlds aren't just empty voids like in ME1.

Even with all the things I enjoy about the game, I am still upset that I paid ~$60+ to be a beta tester. The game - even after two patches - feels like they threw it out the door it to meet a launch deadline. While I'm happy Bioware is listening to the feedback and fixing things that players are screeching about.. most of this shouldn't have been a surprise to them. Those horrid facial meshes and the wonky movements? There's no way they thought people would be ok with them. The early pre-play should have been launched months prior to release and all this crap worked out then, instead of five days prior to launch. All of this is what game testing is FOR. I don't feel like they did much, if any.

I don't feel like I bought a game. I feel like I paid money to be in the beta tester pool, and it's detrimentally affected my enjoyment of this game. I'm kind of grimly playing through it to see where the story goes, but then it'll probably sit there unplayed until there's some new content for it that makes me curious enough to pick it up again - and right now, that would take some seriously spectacular DLC. I'm currently on something like my 22nd consecutive playthrough of the original trilogy, clunky ME1 game mechanics and all, and right now I just want to get through Andromeda so I can go back to playing the original trilogy. I enjoy playing those three games. I am not, right now, enjoying Andromeda enough to give it even a second playthrough.

Giving it 2 stars - 1 for the pretty ships and buildings, 1 for Return of Space Hamster. May revise this after they patch it a bit more, but.. doubtful. My disappointment with this game is the stuff of legends. :(

title: A very nice mouse which seems designed specifically for people with VERY ... text: A very nice mouse which seems designed specifically for people with VERY large hands or FPS junkies.
I have larger-than-average hands, and some of the button placement on this mouse still seems a bit too broadly-spaced.
It's very responsive, the buttons are very customizable, and it "feels" good overall. The firmware is without bugs and the drivers are very solid.
The cord is a bit too short for anyone who wants to use this from a distance - say, with a 4K TV - but the function overall is good. Don't let my buyer's remorse strop you from buying a good product, but the gist of what I'm trying to say is, it still breaks down to an average mouse for the price-point when compared to its function, DPI, and cord length.

title: I can't believe this controller gets such high rating. I've never owned a single Xbox. An unbiased review. text: I can't believe this controller has 4.5 stars. The only thing I can think of is Sony fanboys inflating the reviews. Here's my honest review from a casual gamer who's had a Sega Master System, Sega Genesis, N64, Dreamcast, Wii, PS3, and PS4. I'm not loyal to any brand or company, so my view should be unbiased.

GOOD:
1. The small speaker on the controller isn't much, but I like it and think it adds something to gaming.
2. The headphone jack is also helpful.
3. The light bar is cool, not only for looks, but to identify the player.
4. Sticks are better than the PS3 sticks.
5. L2/R2 curve in (not as much as it should) which is a big improvement from PS3.
6. The grips are a nice texture which give you a good feeling of control.
7. Sticks are symmetrical (I prefer this).

BAD:
1. Quality/design issues. I've had two controllers break with a faulty R2 button. I was able to repair them myself via YouTube videos, but as a casual gamer, this shouldn't happen since I don't play all that much (2 - 5 hours per week).
2. A big one....battery life sucks. The battery life is about half of my older PS3 controllers (even with the light bar dimmed all the way). I'm always having to charge or worry about if my buddy's controller will fire up since it might have been sitting awhile.
3. Quality/design issues 2: I just noticed the rubber splitting on one of my controller (the one I use the least!). This is unacceptable.
4. Not a big one, but annoying....the option and share buttons are too small and should be more triangular and follow the curve of the circle the face buttons are on (hope that made sense). And I have very small hands for a man.
5. The grips (though well textured) are just round cylinders and don't feel like they mold to your hand. It's not terrible, but could be much much better.
6. Touchpad. Love the idea, however it seems like it's barely used, which means that real estate could have been better used for a one color LCD screen or something else.

That's it! The controller gets the job done, but for how much crap people give the DS3, this DS4 improves upon the DS3 in some areas, and fails miserably at others.

title: Best mouse I have ever owned
text: I've been through a lot of mice. I've had a Razer Deathadder, basilisk, mamba, corsair m35, and a Logitech g502. Loved the G502, but I was looking for something wireless that was comfortable and lighter. This mouse is all those things. With it being ambidextrous, I thought maybe I'd get some cramping or discomfort, but a lot of the reviews on here were so positive that I decided I would give it a shot. It was totally worth it. After a small adjustment period (2-3 days), this was by far the most comfortable mouse I have owned. It fits in my hand so nicely, and the curves on the mouse don't allow it to really slip out of your hand. The clicks are nice and solid, but the coolest thing is the scroll wheel. It has a mode where you can just free scroll with it. Just flick it up or down and it will spin on its own. It's nice for reading comments on youtube videos or scrolling through your twitter or whatever. The battery is very solid. Lasts me more than a week with light use. The cord it comes with is really nice too. I have no complaints with this mouse!

title: Decent all around headphones, but nothing special text: In the end these are good but kinda get lost among the rest. They fit my giant head well, and they're quite comfortable. Despite this fit, if you lean your head down for even a second, they may well slide off. Not a common occurrence, but a bit annoying. The audio is good, even very good, but I could say the same about Logitech, Turtle Beach, etc... Isolation is a bit weak on the headphones, but the mic does a great job of noise canceling.

Setup is a breeze, but again nothing new. The rgb lighting and enhanced software controls are somewhat unique. Logitech has these beat with auto muting (when boom raised), and a better solution would be a removable mic ala some of my Turtle Beach wireless units. On the other hand, these pull ahead of Turtle Beach with their subdued looks (TB tries way too hard). There really is no outstanding pro--maybe the software and lighting, but that's not a big deal for me.

title: Diablo meets Fate text: Runic Games produced Torchlight in approximately 8 months. Of course Runic's personnel included the team (formerly of Blizzard North) that designed Diablo and Diablo II, as well as the creator of Fate. Those who have played Fate will instantly recognize the stark similarities here. Torchlight is bigger, prettier, smoother and the combat engine is fantastic.

You will LOVE this game; it's got everything an ARPG should have with a few notable absences: multiplayer and the ability to customize your toon. However the game is moddable, flexible and provides hours and hours of fun.

Torchlight II will be out soon and it is bigger, better, shinier, more customizable, has multiplayer and will be terrific...due out this year.

Hightly recommend Torchlight till its successor comes out. The price is right and the game is F U N

title: Using with hearing aids sound quality suffers, great all around headset text: Not a fair test for gamers . . . ops guess it is as we are all losing our hearing. I wear over the ear hearing aids, so I am always looking for headsets with large ear cushions. These are comfortable, cause a little feedback on one side, are very adjustable. The sound range and quality is OK to good, not great, but part of that is a function of my hearing aids. Definitely low-latency on the Bluetooth connection, way better than some of my older headsets. I like the rotary volume and off as well as the way the mic boom works.

I use wireless analog Sennheisers to listen to my TV, with the old analog there is no lag problem and the sound is great with my hearing aids. As soon as I figure out a connection to my amp that doesn't cut off the speakers for the rest of the family, I plan on trying these.

I do like the fact you can have two devices paired with the Bluetooth, lets me be on my computer watching a movie and be able to answer the phone with no problem.

title: The best deal for MMORPG's. Highly recommended for those who enjoy exploring text: I picked up Guild Wars 2 when it first came out, and at the time, thought it was only okay. I returned to the game a few months ago, and I have to say it has improved substantially. Many of the old mechanics have been modified/improved (added way points, loyalty bonuses, exploration bonuses) and there have been some great additions, like gliding. I really like how Heart of Thorns got rid of the cut scenes for story progression, as it feels more natural, and thus gives a more immersive experience. The addition of the mastery point system for max level characters is great. Nearly everything important is linked to the account (magic find, masteries, outfits, boon-bearing items, etc.) The lack of a subscription fee is very nice. The gem shop offers some cosmetic/minor game-enhancing items for a dollar amount. None of these are necessary to enjoy the game, but I can see why many folks would choose to spend some bucks on these items (mostly bag/character/bank slot increases, account-wide inventory slots, etc.)

Some of the most attractive features for me are the map events, the fact that you never really "outgrow" a zone, and the sharing of resources and kills. The map events keep things fresh, and provide decent rewards upon completion. If you were to enter say a "starting zone," you'd "level-down" to the appropriate level. Of course, your abilities and improved help out and you will be more powerful than other low-bes, but you'll still earn experience and rewards. Finally, the fact that everyone can mine the same nodes, chop the same trees, and gather the same herbs is wonderful. There are no "tagging of mobs," either. If you land a hit, you get full experience and access to the drops. These features give Guild Wars 2 a more pleasant play experience than some other popular MMO's (WoW, I'm looking at you!)

Ultimately, I'm really enjoying the game.

title: Another Madden game text: It is a Madden game, so it is going to be fun. The game play is great.

My complaints are that it is no longer intuitive. It is difficult to just start a season and play through. There are so many plays and formations that you don't even have time to cycle through them before the play clock expires, making it a long, arduous process to learn each team's playbook and what works. The coach's picks seem to be pretty lackluster and seem to repeat the same plays down after down.

The depth of the game and teaching of different formations is pretty great. If you dedicate yourself, you can truly understand almost every aspect of the game of football.

title: Project Mirai DX text: I played the demo, so I was sure I knew what to expect, but it turned out to be a whole lot more than the two songs from the demo. More than I can possibly cover in this review.

For starters, the main function of the game is the rhythm game, where you play different songs with different characters, at different difficulty levels. If you've played any rhythm games before, the fundamentals will be familiar. Here, you can chose to use "tap mode" or "button mode", where you either touch the screen, or press the A/B/X/Y buttons, respectively. Since I'm a bumbling oaf, I figured button mode would be the easiest, but it turns out I like playing with tap mode better.

When you start the game, you choose which character you want to be, and the style of room. I chose Miku and the green room, but you can change that. The game uses StreetPass, so make sure you have an open StreetPass slot (Nintendo really needs to increase that). Since I've only had the game for less than a day, I haven't tagged anyone, nor have I used the AR cards. Dunno exactly how many AR cards there were, but seems like about 10.

When you play songs you earn points so you can buy new decorations for the room or outfits. There's some mini-games you can play. So far I've played Go, which you activate while in Hang-out mode. There's also a Tetris-style game on the main menu. You can collect different different stamps for accomplishments. You can take photos in game, which are saved to the SD or post them to Miiverse in the usual manner (there's a new Miiverse community for the game).

In the interests of brevity, I'm going to cut this short, but there are plenty of other things I haven't mentioned. If you like rhythm games, or just like Miku or the Nendoroid Vocaloids in general, this is a fun game so far with plenty to keep me occupied.

title: A micro-managers dream come true text: This game was recommended to me by a friend who also loves real time simulation games. Next to the Simcity franchise, this is one of the most popular and well-received RTS games out there.

A little backstory... I started playing Sim Theme Park (1999) back in 2000. That was (and still is) a very fun simulation game. One of the best in my opinion. I feel the mixture of real-world accuracy and fun gameplay (even though very cartoony) was executed perfectly by the developers. Furthermore, the overall aesthetics and art style of the game are very appealing to me.

RT3, however, is a jumbled, overly-complicated mess in my opinion. The UI does not flow well, and the item menu layout makes it difficult to manage your park. Most importantly, there are just way too many options to play with! Everything (and person) in the park has a full-range of options to tweak... enough to make an OCD person go absolutely nuts, lol. I fully support real-world accuracy in these games, but I also understand that it's still a game, and I want to have fun playing it. And the developers definitely went full-tilt making RT3 as realistic as possible. Some people will no doubt love this, but I think that most people coming from Simcity or Sim Theme Park will find the game far too micro-manage-y.

The sandbox mode is fun, but since money is not involved, you quickly lose motivation playing it. What's the point if you can build anything you want, immediately? The campaign mode is not what I expected... I was thinking it was more along the lines of Sim Theme Park or Simcity where you start with a lump sum of money and an empty park, and you build your park from there, managing it along the way to keep a positive cash flow. Instead, the campaigns are somewhat preformed, giving you a basic park that you 'take-over' management of. Not very exciting in my opinion.

Overall, the game is not as fun as I had hoped for. If they allowed users to let the park run more autonomously (perhaps an 'auto-pilot' mode if you will) with the ability to tweak various items if needed, that would be better. Or, as an alternative, provide advice to the user on various aspects of the game (i.e. people find admission prices very cheap... people are not satisified with the quality of ice cream offered... etc). In it's current state, however, I don't want to go through my 5 hot dog stands and adjust the amount of mustard on my hot dogs.... and have to guess what the best selling price would be based on the insignificant amount of financial data the game provides real-time. The concept is great, but they just strayed too far in to the weeds without providing enough framework to allow the player to adequately adjust all of the options.

Those coming from Simcity- or Sim Theme Park-style games beware... you probably won't enjoy this one.

title: Excellent Midrange Gaming Headset text: I have numerous pairs of higher-end headphones but up to this point I have had no gaming headsets, so I was not entirely sure what to expect with the CM Storm Pulse-R headset. I have a teenage son who plays cooperative games on-line with a friend of his and so I let him use them for that purpose. It took very little time for these to show their strengths.

The first thing we noticed with them is that they are very comfortable. The padding is soft and the cans fit over the ear so there is no pressure on the ear itself. They can be worn for a good period of time without fatigue. The shape of the headphones themselves looks a little odd and as such I was a little concerned that the fit would be off, but this ended up being a non-issue.

We plugged them into the computer and immediately they lit up. I mean, there are lights on these things and when powered through the USB port they illuminate nicely. They look cool when they‚Äôre lit and the lights are not super bright so this is not a bad thing.

The sound quality is very good. We decided to test them out with some music tracks that have a good range of sound and the headphones managed to give us good reproduction of sound without distortion and without overdriving the highs or lows. These are not quite audiophile quality but they are better than a lot of more expensive headphones I have used. The detail is there too so there should be no problem hearing more subtle sounds without cranking the volume too high.

The microphone itself is a little tricky to attach but if one pays attention when trying to attach it, it is not all that difficult. Once connected, it works very well and the noise-canceling aspect of the microphone itself helps to eliminate some of the background noise. The result is a fairly clear transmission of sound.

The cord has three plugs on it: one for the USB power, one for microphone in and one for headphone out. It‚Äôs a nice, long cord too, so range of motion is not restrictive.

So far I can‚Äôt find too much wrong with this headset. The sound quality is great, it seems to be well constructed and the price is not prohibitive. This is a solid offering the midrange of gaming headsets, and it‚Äôs definitely worth a look.

title: Logitech G935 Wireless Gaming Headset text: I tried the Logitech G935 Wireless Gaming Headset for about two months before writing this review. I wish I liked the headset better, but after testing it, I‚Äôm still on the hunt for the perfect headset.

Currently I do most of my gaming with multiplayer Switch games, such as Splatoon 2. I have to use Discord on my computer or phone to talk with friends while we play. But I also want to hear game sounds, so the option to have dual sound inputs is what really drew me to the G935. I connected the headphones wirelessly to my computer and used the 3.5 mm cable to connect to my Switch. A bit messy, but I was willing to accept that if it worked well.

But it didn‚Äôt. No matter how many sound settings I adjusted, my voice was muffled when talking. I had better results using a normal pair of headphones and the built-in microphone on my computer!

Not to mention, finding the proper button I want to use when wearing the headset is difficult. I have to feel and count the buttons, which takes my attention out of the game and performance suffers. I suppose I‚Äôd develop some muscle memory if I used the headset for longer, but I still feel like there are too many buttons. And the volume rocker is at the bottom of the earcup, so if you take the headphones on or off, it‚Äôs really easy to change the volume and not be able to hear or get a screech in your ear.

Comfort wise, I tend to get headaches if a headset is too heavy and/or tight. About an hour was my limit for wearing the G935, or I‚Äôd have a headache from the weight of it. The earcups are actually pretty comfy and well padded, the headset is just big and I wouldn‚Äôt recommend if you have a small head.

Sound quality is good, one of the better parts of the headset. But I couldn‚Äôt find a way to adjust the volume on one source and not the other via the headset if I did dual inputs.

I just wasn‚Äôt thrilled with the G935 headset. At the level it‚Äôs designed for, I would have expected Bluetooth connectivity instead of a wireless dongle, better button design/layout, and better comfort overall, not to mention clear voice quality.

title: NCAA Football 11 text: I haven't owned an NCAA Football game since probably back on the PS2, but I had read really good reviews about this game. I've played a couple weeks now and thought I'd share some of the things that I liked:

First off, the graphics are really nice. Very sleek and clean. The gameplay is fast and easy to pick up, especially if you're used to playing Madden. The time it takes to play a full game on the default settings seems pretty decent for me (ie, it won't take you an hour to knock out a game).

Next I love the customization ability on this game. You can create your own College by using EA's Teambuilder website. Pick out your stadium, pick out your uniforms (at least 50 choices there), pick out your colors, upload your own log. I love that level of customization and hope that will be a feature that EA uses in all of their sports games going forward (especially FIFA).

I like that you can also customize your players easily online in the Teambuilder site instead of using the controller. Juice up their stats. Change them all to Freshman if you like. Change their names manually or have them randomly created. If it's a common name, the announcers will pronounce it during the game commentary too.

Then you can swap your made-up school with another existing school, and start a Dynasty that goes year after year (not sure how far out it runs). You can customize your non-conference games to adjust your strength of schedule. So I must say I really love that piece of the game.

The recruiting in the Dynasty mode is a bit manually intensive though. I'm not sure if that's a good thing or a bad thing. I personally kind of like it, but if you were only interested in the actual gameplaying of the dynasty, then you may be upset at how much time it requires.

Having played a couple seasons tweaking my strategy, it does require some devotion. You can't really auto-simulate it, or at least, not if you want a good freshman recruiting class. I turned off all of the Helper Options, which helps give you more control. I also limited myself to about 20 prospects, as this helps keep the board from being uncluttered. I preferably only add guys who have you in their Top 3 initially. I also found that if you wait around until mid-season, you can start recruiting some Junior-College (JUCO) transfers since they seem to wait until longer in the year to sign.

The recruiting piece almost feels like a Role-Playing-Game (RPG). You check back each week to see if you've moved up on their list, or you get upset if they committed to someone else after you wasted hours of recruiting time on them. If you want to do a good job at it, it'll probably take as long each week in recruiting as it does to play the week's given game. I haven't tried online dynasty against others yet.

Overall though, I think NCAA Football 11 is a really good football game. I agree with a previous reviewer who said that now NCAA Football doesn't feel like Madden's poor, red-headed step-child.

title: Great atmosphere, intriguing story text: Metro 2033 is a game developed by 4-A games based loosely on the book by the same name. It takes place in a post-apocalyptic Moscow, Russia. Nuclear bombs were dropped and the people of Moscow fled to the Metro where they were safe from the fallout. In the game you play as Artyom, a 20 year old Metro resident. At the beginning of the game you learn of the "dark ones" and of course you set out on your journey to save the world, or at least your Metro station.

Graphically I found this game quite pleasing. The lighting was great for setting the atmosphere, dark tunnels with only your headlamp to light the way definitely added to the spookiness of the game. The textures looked great most of the time and will please all but the most die-hard graphic enthusiasts. The sounds were great, adding creepy noises to the darkened tunnels. While the atmosphere is great and sets the mood, this game isn't all that scary. Sometimes its kind of creepy but doesn't have many jump out of nowhere moments like other survival horror games. The HUD is minimal, your watch shows how much time left on your gasmask's filter (you need to wear it in certain areas, like above ground or you choke and die) and how well hidden you are. For pneumatic weapons they have a gauge on them that shows how much pressure remains in them. Mission objectives are viewed via an in-game journal which you can bring up (without pausing the game). When switching weapons or picking up ammo the weapon and how much ammo you're holding show up for a short time then fades away. This minimal HUD definitely helps keep the player immersed in the world.

The gameplay is pretty standard first-person-shooter setup. Right trigger shoots, left trigger aims down sights or is a secondary attack (such as the auto-shotgun's melee attack). You can hold 3 different gun types: pistol, automatic, and special. Pistols are revolvers with different attachments like scopes and silencers. Automatics are AKs, SMGs and other assault rifles. Special guns are shotguns or pneumatic weapons. Each weapons type uses a different ammo type, with the automatics using 5.45 mm rounds which come in two varieties, dirty rounds and military grade. Dirty rounds are made in the Metro and are inexpensive. Military grade rounds are from before the war and are higher quality, do more damage, and are also used as currency in the Metro. You shouldn't shoot these if you want to afford to upgrade your guns or other equipment.

The game can be played like most other shooters as a run and gun, and when facing the mutants you pretty much have to dance around and try to shoot them (they usually move very fast and are hard to kill). When you are fighting other humans, you take a more stealthy approach. Just about any light can be turned off or shot out to create darkness. On your watch you have a light that shows red (fully visible), yellow (can be seen if the enemy looks your way), and green (in complete darkness, only those with night vision goggles will see you). If done correctly the stealth approach is greatly satisfying. You can clear a whole level using very little ammo and suffering little to no damage. While the run and gun approach can leave some players feeling the game is broken and the hit detection for the bullets to be very off. But when playing stealthily, just about every well-placed headshot finds it mark, and just about every human enemy will die with one direct hit to the head. Sometimes it will take two hits if the enemy is wearing a helmet (you can shoot the helmet or gasmask off their head and the next headshot will surely kill them). Sometimes however, a silent kill will still alert all the enemies to your presence and they will start to run around screaming about how they are going to kill you. In these cases, staying in the dark and behind cover will prevent them from zeroing in on your location and taking you down, and isn't really a problem if you have patience to take them out one by one.

There are other gameplay elements that are added in to help fuel the survival theme. These include your flashlight and night vision goggles needing to be charged and pneumatic (air powered) weapons needing to be pumped up. While your flashlight will never completely die, it will dim and you can get a brighter light that penetrates the darkness further when fully charged. Your NVG won't work at all unless charged. Charging your battery is easy as pulling out your hand generator and pumping it for 10-20 seconds (possibly less), until the gauge is filled. The battery doesn't deplete so quickly that it becomes a nuisance to keep recharging but just enough for you to think of conserving power by turning off your light or NVG when you don't absolutely need them. Similarly, the pneumatic weapons are pumped in a similar fashion, and can be "over pumped" to get a bonus to damage and range. The pneumatic weapons are great for stealth and are quite powerful at full charge or higher. Other elements to add to the survival theme is the scarcity of ammo. If you scavenge ammo you'll probably never run out of dirty rounds to use, but if you don't check every body for spare ammo or look in out of the way places for ammo crates, you could run into a problem with ammo, causing you to use your military grade rounds which in turn makes you very poor and unable to buy new weapons and other equipment.

As for the story, it's based on the book, but from what I've heard (not having read the book myself), it is only very loosely based on the book. The story is interesting to say the least. The whole post-apocalyptic world is fascinating and its amazing how they've shown off the way life goes on in such a world. Each station you go to is filled with NPCs going about their business and talking to each other. As mentioned before you start out in your home station, Exhibition, and after fighting off an attack from mutants you learn about the "dark ones" who seem to be making other Metro dwellers go insane. The Ranger named Hunter asks you to go on a mission for him, without your stepfather's knowledge, to deliver a message about these dark ones attacking your station. This sets you off on a journey throughout the Metro system fighting mutants, bandits, communists and Nazis on your journey to Polis station. The story is absolutely linear with only a few small choices dabbled here and there that have little effect on the storyline. One thing that gets annoying by the end of the story is the fact that Artyom is the luckiest man alive because no matter what situation he gets into someone is there to save or help him.

Overall the game is great for fans of the post-apocalyptic setting, who don't mind a linear game. I would suggest it to any fans of games like Bioshock or S.T.A.L.K.E.R. It has the same linear, with some slight exploration as Bioshock, with the great feeling of post-apocalyptic Eastern Europe as S.T.A.L.K.E.R.

text: Castlevania: Lords of Shadow is a fun game. I was totally immersed in the graphics and the story line has some wonderful twists, plus (I forgot her name) is kind of good looking. Very Athletic and has a companion that invites respect, this thing looks menacing so I just admire and enjoy. Come to think of it: who really needs to go to the movies and spend almost the value of a game like this? This is as good as a movie, plus you are in the comfort of your own home, properly baked, and in front of you is this amazing and challenging game. I have always favored the Castlevania series from Konami and this one is no exception. I am sure the experts, those that play and know so much, might be able to find faults or criticisms on this and any other game. But from where I sit, just about every chance I get, I love the hell (stress hell since the surroundings are very much like I could easily imagine hell to be...) out of Castlevania: Lords of Shadow. Had to learn the hard way what I was doing wrong in order to defeat and advance the many violent situation that one faces in this game. Money has been scarce, which attests to my limited abilities for now, but once you get those experience point and start investing in the future, let's just say I can't wait for the end result, for this guy is one tough hombre of the Castlevania era. I give it 5 for value, awesome graphics (although I must say that with Little Big Planet, Red Redemption, Unchartered 2, et., the Playstation is one powerful machine), story line and sheer entertainment factor. When it comes down to it: Why would you go to a movie where so many in the end suck, when you can make the best deal and start buying games such as this for a collection that surely will endure the test of time? Who needs a movie when you can be part of this movie? Beware! This journey is long and tedious, dangerous and exciting and will test the skills and endurance of Gabriel every step of the way. Yes, it has moments when it goes into full majestic movie mode where you are kind of required to watch instead of participate but us people of the stoner age rather welcome such moments. 5 Stars, no ifs or buts, for Gabriel is indeed the man of the hour!

title: Fun, but for how long?

title: Nintendo Labo is innovative and fun! text: The Nintendo Labo is one of the most innovative ways to enhance gameplay I‚Äôve seen in a long time. While I am an adult, I love building, decorating, and designing things so Labo seemed like the perfect game for me.

The kit comes with five toy-cons you can build: two RC cars, a fishing rod, a house, a motorbike (handle), and a piano. Each one has small parts to go with it as well, like strings, rubber bands, and marker stickers. It also comes with the cartridge for the game.

Most people are apprehensive about Nintendo‚Äôs use of cardboard but I think it‚Äôs actually better than making plastic add-ons. For one, it is easier and cheaper to replace. More importantly, it is better for the environment and it can be disposed of when children outgrow it, rather than sitting around collecting dust. The cardboard is actually quite sturdy and high quality. As long as it is not outright mishandled, I think it will do a good job holding up. Additionally, I love the ability to customize your toy-con to suit your tastes and make it unique to you.

Making the cardboard structures is incredibly fun--reminiscent of putting Lego together. For anyone worried about the strength of the toy-con, there are actually a lot of reinforcing pieces that help make certain otherwise flimsier parts more sturdy. Cute, witty comments pop up while you make your toy-cons, guiding you through the process while occasionally cracking jokes, making it feel very human.

The Discover section is a fantastic place to learn more about the engineering behind the toy-cons. Three characters converse and guide you through the science behind the genius of Labo. You can view cutaways of the toy-con and test the IR camera in a particular mode. There are also sections on easily repairing broken toy-con, troubleshooting, and creative ways to customize. There is even basic physics learning involved with certain joy-con--no doubt a good way to get children into physics.

Toy-con garage is the best part about the kit. It works through very simple input-output coding. You put in an input (pressing a button for example), select an output from a list, and connect the two to make the switch create the output. I love that this gives kids the ability to make their own toys, which will no doubt spark a love for engineering and design within the next generation.

There are a ton of different things to explore and secrets to find within the game. I highly recommend this for anyone who loves to use their hands and be creative!

title: Well made controller--may not be for you text: This is a well made controller that cannot replace a dual shock controller, but it can make a great complement for fighting games or a solid controller for Genesis emulators. The quality is there. Not $100 amazing, but nicer than the typical OEM or third party controllers. It's wired, which can be seen as a positive, especially for folks looking for low latency (handy for fighting games). This along with the lack of sticks makes this a downgrade from the stock controller for casual use.

For games where you need to use the d pad, it's much much better than what Sony provides. That's more of a knock on the standard controller than a compliment for this one, but you get a great d pad. Likewise, the buttons are more responsive than the mushy oem buttons. These two factors along with the revised layout makes it more of a traditional fighting d pad arrangement. As someone who grew up with old school arcade games, I prefer an actual digital stick vs a d pad, but otherwise, it's a great feel.

The upsides are there, but console games tend to be made for the console's oem controller. The d pad and front buttons work different, which can lead to some games not registering inputs the way you'd like. Most games work well without issues, and anyone could appreciate the snappy responsive feel of the buttons. I'd suggest checking out a couple YouTube reviews using this and the specific games you wish to play before buying.

title: Wii Version: Fine Play, lacks heavily in graphics text: We have a PS3 and Wii. My 5 year old loves the Lego Games, so I have a hours of "daddy can you help me" experience with Lego Star Wars, Indiana Jones 1 (&2), and Batman (all for the PS3). We got Harry Potter for the expecting that the "Wii wand" would fit well with a the concept.

The Good: my son loves it and has little/no problem with using the Wii controls to navigate.

The Bad: the graphics are notably lacking. I am no graphics snob, by any means, but they are very, very poor compared to PS3. Some may say of course they are and, yes, we expected some degradation. But if I had to choose again, I would not choose the Wii version (and I much prefer Wii for my son, over PS3, generally). Also, there seems to be little use of the Wii wand as a "wand" in the game. I'm not sure why I expected that one would wave the wand around as if it were a real one, but, thus far (about 1-2hrs in) there is none of that. That would be cool though right, so maybe I am missing how to do it, or some vital "option" to turn on - if so, then the Wii version has only the single glaring graphics issues.

The Summary: the game play is very fun. The game itself is great. My son loves it and doesn't notice any of the "bad" I listed above. Just be forewarned: if you get this for the Wii, it does not look crisp, smooth, or flashy, by any means whatsoever (enough so that I bothered to write a review).

title: Excellent value - many fun games text: The main reason I purchased this game was for the Motion Plus accessory. I was pleasantly surprised at how fun the games were! The game advertises that it comes with 12 sports. Many of the sports have several variations, so you are really getting double the games.

The twelve sports are:
* Swordplay
* Wakeboarding
* Archery
* Frisbee
* Basketball
* Power Cruising
* Cycling
* Golf
* Table Tennis
* Bowling
* Canoeing
* Air Sports

My family and I have tried all the games. Some are harder than others, but almost all are very fun. The Power Cruising wasn't quite up to par with the other games, so we don't play that one much.

Our favorites, which are all excellent, are the Swordplay, Archery, both variations of Frisbee (Frisbee Dog and Frisbee Golf), Table Tennis, and the Basketball 3-Point Contest

Wii Sports Resort is a great choice that has something for everyone in the family to enjoy. The Motion Plus accessory is a great bonus in this version. The games do require it, and it really seems to add to the enjoyment of the games.

title: Great build quality! text: I ordered the ‚ÄòLogitech G915 TKL Tenkeyless Lightspeed Wireless RGB Mechanical Gaming Keyboard, Low Profile Switch Options, LIGHTSYNC RGB, Advanced Wireless and Bluetooth Support - Clicky, Black‚Äô for review and would like to share some of my ‚Äúunprofessional‚Äù thoughts.

I have been using the Logitech G815 wired keyboard for several years now and I absolutely love it. It has actually been my all time favorite keyboard and I have used many different brands throughout the years. The G815 is basically the same style/construction as the G915 TKL except that the G815 is wired and has the ten key pad. The G915 TKL (Clicky) is very well constructed and flex is minimal due to the solidly built metal frame. Because it is the TKL version it is considerably smaller and fits well on the pull-out drawer of my computer desk and it gives me the freedom of being able to easily pull it out from the pull-out drawer and place it either in my lap or on top of the desk. I also like the idea that I can use it with my smart TV.

I love the media controls on the G815 and was very happy to see that even though the TKL version is smaller, they still included the media controls on the G915 TKL. If they would have removed those, I may not have been as fond of the TKL version.

I also love the fact that the G915 TKL has two different angle settings which are nice and sturdy.

The battery life is actually pretty amazing especially if you turn off the lighting but I tend to keep the lighting on and even then battery life is impressive.

Personally I am not all that savvy with keyboard switches and the different benefits so I can not give any specific details as to how well the switches work other than I love the feel of the shorter throw compared to other keyboards I have used in the past. The ‚ÄúClicky‚Äù keys are not as loud as other switches on other branded keyboards that I have used and I feel like I prefer the ‚Äúclicky‚Äù keys vs the ‚ÄúTactile‚Äù or ‚ÄúLinear‚Äù. This may be due to my love of the G815 that I have been using for a while which also uses the ‚ÄúClicky‚Äù switches. To me the other two feel mushy.

Overall I love this version and feel like Logitech has continued to make great products throughout the years and it is a brand that I trust! Personally I feel that the G915 TKL is a bit on the pricey side but you really are getting a solid and well made keyboard that should last a good long time if taken care of.

*On a side note - I am having some issues with the Logitech G Hub software which I had to uninstall, as it was not working properly and now I can‚Äôt get it to install. I would dock stars for this but I think it has to do with my current PC which is not aging very well. When the software was originally installed it worked fine so I am hoping with some effort, I will be able to get it installed again at some point.

title: Pok√©mon X text: I've got six badges so far, so I feel like I've seen enough of the game to make a review based on actual game-play rather than preconceived notions. I've only been playing Pokemon since HG/SS, so I'm definitely not a genwunner. I'm also not into competitive battling, so I won't really be talking too much about that, or things like the new fairy type. Those are topics for discussion on forums, not a game review. Since most of the changes are the online features, I'll probably discuss those more than anything else.

For starters, yes, it is the same as every other Pokemon so far. The same introduction, pick your starter, battle random trainers and gym leaders, collect badges, defeat the champ. The same limitations of having a party of six, with each having a max of four active moves. If you stop and think, everything else is gravy: story, graphics, music, etc. The fundamental mechanics are the same, and I think that is quite frankly the majority of the reason for the franchise's staying power. You can pick up any gen game, and knowing your basic types, weaknesses, etc, you'll know how to play.

A lot of the changes in this generation are based mostly around the online features, some of which were only in their beginnings in BW/B2W2. But you no longer have to find a Pokemon Center to participate in the online functions, they're all right on the screen. You can turn the online functions on and off at will.

Probably the most interesting is the PSS, the Player Search System. Like most native 3DS games, this game integrates with the 3DS friend codes, so you no longer have to manage separate friend codes. You just add their 3DS code to the 3DS friends app, and then you can see their status in-game. Now while you're in game, you can see their status: player profile, badges, and other things. You can battle, trade or chat with them. Pretty much like in the old Union Rooms, but not as limited as the Union Rooms were.

Over time, you'll see people being added to the PSS, under the headings of acquaintances and passerbys. Acquaintances are added as you interact with other remote players via the global trade, battles, etc. I'm not exactly sure how passerby's work, but I think they just are random people who appear on your screen; again, you can interact with them in all the same manners. One thing I enjoy so far is the "wonder trade", which is a random trade matchup: you chose which Pokemon you want to trade, and it'll find someone in the world, and you get what you get. You might get trash Pokemon, or you might get something good.

Beyond the online features are all the other changes to the game. Music is awesome, no longer grating to the ears (altho I'm a chiptune fan, you can only listen to the Pokecenter music for so long without wanting to stab your eyes out). The graphics are fantastic, altho I do not play in 3D mode. The avatars are nicely customizable. After a long-winded review, I'll just close with that I think this is a great addition to the franchise.

Post-game edit: I beat the champ in about 5 days, less than 25 logged playing. This is by far the easiest version I've played. Each gym, elite and champ, I was able beat in one attempt. I never felt it necessary to rethink my team, go back and grind up, or anything of that nature. I also played straight thru with my starter, Fennekin, in slot one. She was KO'ed a few times, but I never considered retiring her. With Exp Share, even my HM slaves become viable.

I'm still exploring post-game play, and since I have tried to refrain from strat guides, I don't know how extensive post-game is yet. So far, I've found a side-arc of working in a detective agency, and found daily jobs at a hotel. I found two stationary legendaries to catch, and ran into one roaming legendary but do not know how to catch it yet. I did not find anything similar to BW2's Join Ave, or the little and big stadiums, with their daily battles, but I'm probably not searching hard enough.

title: Phenomenal text: This is an excellent game.. Some people are complaining that it's the same exact thing as Modern Warfare 2.. Overall, it pretty much is, but I don't think that's necessarily a bad thing.. I'm a strong believer in not fixing what isn't broken. MW2 was amazing, as is this game. So far I've invested about 30 hours in this game between campaign, multiplayer and the new spec ops modes, and I still have a long way to go!

In the campaign, you continue on with Soap and Price's story. The campaign is fun, enthralling and action-packed. I played it on normal difficulty and it took me about 6 hours to complete. Again, a lot of people complain about the fact that the campaigns in the COD series are too short, but we don't buy these games for the campaigns, we buy it for the multiplayer.. However, in my opinion, the campaign is still a lot of fun.. From team-sniping with your AI partner to using predator drones, the campaign is still as awesome as ever.

Regarding multiplayer, it seems like it has improved! When it switches hosts I've yet to be dropped out of a game. I also get put into matches pretty quickly. There are also new game modes which are excellent! Team Defender is a variation of capture the flag. There is one neutral flag with no destination for it.. Your objective is to simply capture the flag and hold onto it as much as possible while teammates protect the flag carrier. Then there is kill confirmed, which is a variation of team deathmatch. In this mode, when you kill an enemy you must pick up his dog tags for points. You must also try to retrieve dog tags from fallen teammates before the other team picks them up. Both game modes are very intense and fun to play. In this game, each weapon has its own level so not only do you level up, but your weapons do too. The higher your weapon level, the more attachments and camo you unlock for them. Finally, killstreaks are better than ever! You make a different killstreak with EACH class.. You can also choose between assault, support and perks. It adds an entirely new element of strategy when making your classes.

Finally, there is spec ops mode. Spec ops mode brings back missions like there were in MW 2. I haven't played much of this mode so I don't have much to say on it, but also in spec ops mode there is survival mode! Survival mode alone is worth the price of the game! You can play solo, split-screen or online with 1 other player and you fight off waves of enemies. You can choose from any of the multiplayer maps (which there are plenty of!) and you start off with a pistol and fight off the first wave... Each kill earns you money which can be used at any of the three crates placed throughout the map... A gun crate where you buy guns, an air support crate where you can purchase predator missiles, air strikes, and even AI-controlled delta squad support! Then there is the equipment crate where you can guy frag grenades, flash bangs, turrets, etc. They are usually placed pretty far apart and you only have about 30 seconds between waves, so you need to prioritize what you need for the upcoming wave.. You start by killing foot soldiers in the first wave that take a few shots from a pistol to put down, and before you know it you're fighting attack dogs with C4 strapped to them, juggernauts, choppers, massive infantry forces, and eventually combinations of all of the above.. It gets INTENSE and this game mode is INCREDIBLY fun. Like I said, this mode alone makes MW 3 worth every penny.

So if you liked MW and MW2, definitely get this.. You will not be disappointed. Again, it is pretty much identical to MW2 in a lot of ways, but I think that's a good thing.. When Black Ops came out, the number of players seemed to dramatically decrease on MW2 to my disappointment.. Now Modern Warfare is back, and I will probably never touch Black Ops again. Also, since comparing MW to Battlefield seems to be the thing to do in reviews, in my opinion this game beats the living hell out of Battlefield.. It did win shooter of the year.. And if anything else, if you buy MW3 used, you won't have to spend extra money on an online access pass like BF 3 (which is ridiculous)

Hope this review helped!

title: Difficult UI and retarded groupies text: This game reminds me of a mix of Baldur's Gate and Oblivion. The graphics are quite good considering the third party view point but the UI is really difficult to get used to. Too much click in five places to get something to happen - you can pause the game at any point while doing this but it's still very cumbersome and takes away a lot of the enjoyment. My biggest complaint is that the other party members tend to stand around doing nothing. I've tried everything but the PC group members are complete retards. It should be trivial to say 'attack this until it's dead' but they stop attacking after a few seconds or if the foe moves away. They won't even follow me, I have to keep right clicking to get the to come to me. Now maybe I've missed something in the UI that would make them act intelligently but it's my review and I don't like this game. Plus I paid too much for it :-(

OK So I just figured out I must have hit the "H" key by accident.

Anyhow this is still a poor game with good graphics.

1. There are too many area transitions and they take too long.
2. There are too many loooooong boring conversations and set pieces.
3. The quests are poorly explained and too many of them are bugged (like abandoned orphanage).
4. Intermediate quest points are not indicated on map or when you mouse over them so you're expected to memorize all 40 active quests?
5. No free movement between places of interest (Oblivion got that right)
6. Anvil of the void quest is bugged (party members stopped responding) - happens other places too (no I didn't press H)
7. Difference in difficulty between trash mobs and bosses is way too great.
8. Fight with Loghain is too long w/o opportunity to save.
9. Mage keeps going loony and thinks she's a tank.
10.Mage won't use mana potions even though it's in her tactics.

I could go on but you get the point. Game depends too much on graphics and not enough on good game play. This can't hold a candle to Oblivion.

title: Not nearly as good as I'd hoped text: Just got these, setup was easy.

Two things dropped this to a 3-star:
1. The earpieces are NOT optimally shaped for the ear. I'm not sure why, but almost no one makes headphones so that they are actually comfortable. I have had exactly ONE pair of headphones where the company made them wide and oval-shaped so that the entire ear rested comfortably inside, as opposed to getting squished one way or another.

2. The cord attached to these headphones is HORRIBLE. Even the slightest brushing up of this cord against anything (such as happens when you just barely move your head) creates an awful, distracting, echoing rubbing sound up into the earpiece. It's really quite awful for a headphone of this quality to have made their cord of a material that would create this sound.

I stuck with 3 stars because the quality of sound is quite good - as long as you never move any part of your body so as to avoid rubbing that cord against something.

title: Not a Battlefield game, just a generic, lack luster FPS text: I have always enjoyed Battlefield more than call of duty. They are two different games. I liked call of duty for its faster paced online matches. Battlefield felt like a game about larger scale battles and being part of a team. The lack of battlefield components such as -
No classes
No single-player mode
No server browser
No general, team, or player scoreboard, only your own squad is shown
No score bonuses for headshots, multi-kills, or hit-based damage XP gain
No persistent lobbies (back to the main menu after every match)
Buildings are not as destructible as previous Battlefield games
No leaning/peeking out while in cover
make this a simple shooter game and not battlefield. These are some missing elements of what made battlefield a great series. A big disappointment to the franchise.

title: Top-tier mappable controller at a value price!
text: I have been using and testing this for the last few days. This is easily the best controller in its price range and competes with those that are 3X more. Buttons are mappable. You can save different profiles that have pre-set vibration levels, dead zones, hair triggers, and mappable paddle buttons among other settings. Really, the only negatives are that with the clickable paddles they are easy to hit as they aren't analog paddle switch-style and are just large buttons (that press VERY easy, though this could be a good thing in some scenarios) and also that the controller is wired only with no wireless/Bluetooth. I have been using another wired controller that competes with the high dollar elite controller, and this is better. The advantage the Gamesir has is how customizable it is, not only with what has been mentioned but also with the swappable faceplate that magnetically removes and attaches (though it doesn't budge one iota and is near impossible to tell that it is a faceplate). They give you a white one and a black one, and the white one can be drawn on with acrylic markers or paint and customized in that way as well! Extremely low latency (I have nothing to test with but can tell this is very very good when comparing to official Microsoft, as well as  other 3rd party aftermarket controllers). To be able to plug into a computer and modify settings, do firmware updates (and hopefully other features not yet implemented and/or realized) is a game-changer. This controller feels premium, not just for the price, but next to the other top "pro" customizable controllers as well. Highly recommended, and a salute to the Gamesir engineers!

title: Award-winning for a reason text: Galactic Civilizations II Ultimate Edition is the latest and best installment of the Galactic Civilizations series, packing in both currently-available expansion packs in addition to the base game. It is a turn-based strategy/conquest game, allowing play to stretch out over days or even weeks. There is a lot to this game, but once you get the hang of how to play this game it is very much worth the time and effort.

To be very clear, this is a turn-based game, not a real-time strategy game or a first-person shooter. If turn-based games do not appeal to you, look elsewhere. If you have not played a turn-based game in the past, it is a different experience from most other games on the market in that the planning and strategizing require thinking in a different way, and this style of play is not something everyone enjoys.

One of the very first things that a player will notice about this game is that the graphics are absolutely stunning. Stardock put an incredible amount of effort and care into the interface, from the menus to the cut scenes. Everything is smooth, seamless and, well, beautiful.

Although the graphics are well-done, the interface is exceptionally complex and busy. The player manages almost every conceivable aspect of the game - economy and tax rate, research direction and funding, relationships with other civilizations, planetary production, fleet composition, trade and more. It is very easy to get lost in the sheer volume of options available.

Gameplay starts with several choices, most importantly race but certainly not the only option. Victory conditions (more on that shortly), universe size, star cluster density, frequency of viable worlds, number of other civilizations, and a few other options are all specified at the start. After making all of these selections, the player gets a single planet, a colony ship, a survey ship and an asteroid miner.

Every turn consists of a number of important choices. The player decides how to allocate all of the resources available and takes steps to better their position, with the ultimate goal of meeting the victory conditions specified at the start. This may include exploration of space junk (there is frequently much benefit to doing so), colonization of a new planet, or perhaps cranking up the tax rate. Once all of the desired options have been selected, the player ends the turn and a new turn begins after all selections have been executed.

One of the most interesting aspects of the game is in designing new ships for the fleet. The player gets to pick hull type, armament, sensors and everything else a ship needs to be a successful contributor. Once a design is complete and named, any starport orbiting the player's planets can build those ships. It is important to keep in mind that some designs may not work well through the entire game but that sometimes a design should be retired in favor of new, more advanced designs.

Gameplay continues until victory conditions are met. There are several conditions that can be specified - military conquest, diplomatic victory (peace treaties with all other major civilizations), technological victory (done through research) or even a cultural invasion.

Every choice a player makes affects something else within the game. For example, higher taxes can cause a planet to mutiny and join a different civilization. More important, though, is how choices affect relations with the other civilizations. Most civilizations pay attention to ethical alignment and military might, and depending on how strong or weak a player's civilization can even incite a war. Finding a good balance is the key, and finding that balance is inherently tough.

As this version comes with both expansion packs, there are three campaigns that are available for play. I have not tried any of these so I cannot really comment on them.

This is a very engrossing game with slick graphics and many, many choices for the gamer who wants absolute control over every aspect of the game. If this style of play is appealing to you, seriously consider picking up a copy for yourself and say goodbye to your free time.

title: 3.5 stars text: The Amazon Basics Nintendo Switch case, above all, is a sturdy and large briefcase. People may think you've brought something dangerous on board your train, but behind its James Bond-esque appearance is a fairly simple storage space. This is a case conducive to the Switch owner who prefers their games digitally stored rather than physically purchased, as there's minimal space inside for games or cases. You get enough space for the Switch console with two attached Joy-Cons as well as a Grip with two more attached Joy-Cons, space for the dock and cords and that's about it.
The asking price as other reviewers mention feels a bit high for what you're getting, though not knowing how much it costs to put together - and given most things associated with the Switch are more expensive than I expect - I don't knock the cost too much.
I also concur with a reviewer who expressed surprise at its bulky size.
My only remaining concern is the stability of the actual Switch inside. It fits decently into its assigned slot, but based on the seeming fragility of the Switch device itself, I doubt I'd feel terribly comfortable carrying the case vertically as it's designed to be, since that would mean the Switch itself faces horizontally within the case, and though I'm sure it's designed properly to account for that, it still concerns me as a consumer considering the Faberge egg-like care with which I try to handle the system.

title: A Ton of Wasted Potential text: First of all, most comparisons will be to Prof Layton games. While that is a fair comparison, this game is really a hodge podge of genres...all of which I like, but doesn't work in the simplified format they provide in this game.

Prof. Layton-ish - Yes, this game has puzzles like Layton but it really has 5-10 different types of puzzles (Sequence, tangem, fill in the word, push blocks, find the difference, etc) that get re-used over and over. If you are looking for a Professor Layton clone for the 3DS, I think you will be disappointed.

JRPG-ish - You collect spirits to battle the boss spirit at the end of each dungeon. The spirits level up with each successful usage. These battles are okay, but far from good. Portrait conversations and people spread across town to talk to.

Zelda Adventure-ish - Go into a dungeon, sneak past some guards, push boxes to complete a path to get further in, with only a single boss battle.

The story and characters are done fairly well. They even have plenty of side quests which add more depth to the main characters and sub-plots. The voice acting and art style work well.

I like the detail they gave to the city. They filled it with plenty of locations and people, but in the end it's really empty. The people say mostly useless things like "I love Paris" and the locations are simply used to go underground.

There are supposed to be 250 puzzles, but they are really just the same puzzles re-hashed. You have to roam around the city to random points marked on the map to see if you have found the next dungeon or not. There is usually a sheepish riddle that can help you figure where you might go next. Then in the dungeons you wander around sneaking past guards and pushing boxes to get further into the dungeon. There are a couple of doors where you have to solve a puzzle to get past. And finally you battle the dungeon boss with leveled up spirits (basically one time attack cards).

In the end, I was very disappointed. I was mostly interested in this for the puzzles and this is definitely no competition to Professor Layton. The concept they put together is interesting but feels like you are doing busy work just to get to the next puzzle/story.

I would not recommend this game.

The only complaints are that the game is relatively short compared to others, and it's not overly complicated. Also I do not like the way they did two player on this game. The second player is woodstock, who can only fly and sort of bump enemies. You also both must stay on the screen at the same time, and it isn't always an easy task. Second player really could have been executed better.

Overall it's a decent game for Charlie Brown lovers or younger children up to early teens.

title: I should have listened to the other 1 star reviews text: I got this item because it was very cheap and looked exactly like the original Game Cube controller. I thought "Well, even though it is a 3rd party controller it is still brand new, cheap, and is identical to the original. I'm sure it'll last a few years." BOY WAS I WRONG!!!! I seriously played with this thing for, no joke, less than 5 hours of game play. It was good while it lasted, but once my character started running in only one direction I knew I wasted my money. I tried setting it down and picking it up an hour later just to make sure it was completely done with. Turns out my character started running in the other direction (opposite from where he was originally running). It's a piece of junk! And I originally thought that maybe some people were just rough with their controller and that's why it got some bad reviews, but no. I am very gentle with all my stuff and it broke already.

I should also mention that this 3rd party controller is not as comfortable as the official controller because you need to press some of the buttons harder than others to get a response.

LISTEN TO THE ONE STAR REVIEWS EVERYONE!!!! SAVE YOUR MONEY AND BUY THE "OFFICIAL" GAME CUBE CONTROLLERS THAT SAY "NINTENDO" ON THE FRONT OF THEM! AT LEAST THEY WILL LAST FOR A FEW YEARS AND THE BUTTONS AND ANALOG STICK RESPOND BETTER!

title: ***UPDATE: DEAD*** Great for normal headphones, AWFUL for Creative's own. text: UPDATE 08/24/13:
After months of letting this sit, I decided to try again. I downloaded all the drivers and firmware, but nothing. When I plug it in, my computer notifies me that a device has been entered in one of the USB ports, but the Recon3D doesn't light up. I doubt it's the Tactic Link card in it.
I downloaded Creative's updater, and it recognizes the device when it's plugged in, but the update constantly fails. It's a shame because I loved it when it worked. Now it's a paperweight.

Also, I never heard back from Creative after my last email earlier this year.

UPDATE 04/21/13:
DEAD!
My Recon3D is dead. Or, at least, it won't turn on when connected to either my Mac or Windows computers. It's strange, because my computer will recognize when it's plugged in as any sound will try and shoot to the device, but since the actual Recon3D itself won't light up (ie, turn on), it can't connect to my Omega headphones, thus defeating the purpose.
I've emailed Creative to see what the issue could be.

UPDATE 12/13/11:
I've kept the original review below. It turns out I was missing the card, but Creative was gracious enough to send it to me so I can experience the full sound explosion in its glory. As a company, they rock. Their products are amazing, albeit overpriced.

Pairing the Omega headphones with their Recon3D was easy with the TacticLink (though I did have trouble at first), and the sounds is fantastic. I tested Star Wars on Blu-ray, and, sure enough, there was a huge difference from just using the Recon3D with $20 Sennheisers. Not only do the headphones make a difference, but the Recon3D does a magnificent job of imitating true THX sound. Having the Recon3D, it eliminates the cords from the Omega connecting to the TV and PS3. You only need to connect the Recon3D via USB to the PS3 and the optical cable (included) from the PS3 to the TV, and that's it. The Omega headphones sit comfortably on their rest, no other cords, pucks, plugs necessary.

It's fantastic for console gaming, but at $300 for both, it's too pricey, considering that you can find some with slightly less sound quality for under $100. While it's multi-platform (though I've only used it with the PS3 and Macbook Pro), the price can detract some, but the sound quality makes it worth it.

----------

Shouldn't it be the opposite? I have Creative's Tactic 3D Omega headphones, and got the Recon 3D to pair with it. It should be easier, shouldn't it? With their own products?
Unfortunately, that isn't the case.

While I have praised the Recon3D, that's only because I'm using them with my $20 Sennheisers. That's where the two stars come. It gets docked enormously for the fact that Creative leaves out the TacticLink, a piece that is REQUIRED to pair their own headphones wirelessly. Unfortunately, the two items separately do not come with the TacticLink, but the bundle does--? If you buy the bundle, you save over $75, but it comes with a component that you need to pair the items. You can pair the headphones with the Recon3D, but by cable only, and I don't have the necessary cable to accomplish that.

Therefore, their pricing is extremely skewed, and the fact that you have to pay over $75 more for both items separately when you don't even get the necessary ("optional," as Creative says) component to get the full, wireless experience, make this customer a very unhappy one. Heck, I can't even get the full experience at all because the Tactic 3D Omega can't connect to the Recon3D unless I go out and buy the cable, let alone "optional" TacticLink, thus leaving me behind the full enjoying experience.

It's a shame because I defended the Omega in another review, but here's where it stops.
