title: Good wheel for the money text: Context- I spent the last 2-3 years with a Fanatec CSR on FM4 and was waiting for an affordable wheel to jump up to FM6. FM6 is the only game I play. So this review in many ways is a comparison between the two wheels. Overall, for the price, I am happy, though I am wondering if I may be more satisfied by jumping up to a Fanatec CSL.

Pros:

- Physical setup was super easy. Plug and play. I have a bootleg cockpit setup and all I had to do was drill new holes for the pedals.
- Configuration was relatively easy. Took a little trial and error, but I got it to where I'm almost not thinking about the wheel while I use it (which is my indicator of a good wheel)
- Overall precision and control is pretty good.
- Build quality is surprisingly good. The buttons all look and feel good, the metal paddles feel expensive, and the main wheel grip is great.
- Force feedback at 100% is strong enough to probably break wrists/fingers. For me that is useless; I dialed it down to 10% and it gives me enough feedback at that level. I've driven everything from Hondas with "power steering delete" to Ferraris on racetracks in real life, and I've never driven anything with the level of kickback this thing has at 100%.
- Former Fanatec users can save some money by getting an adapter that will enable the use of Fanatec pedals.
- Lap times dropped by about 2-3 seconds with A class cars around most tracks compared to controlled. Looking at telemetrics this seemed to be due to more precise braking and steering inputs. Naturally your mileage may vary.

Cons:
- Wheel is a little smaller than I'd like. Haven't checked the diameter but I'm pretty sure my CSR is bigger. Personal preference.
- No thumbwheel for advanced camera view change in car customization/paint mode/Forzavista in FM6.
- No bolt holes for mounting, and existing bracket hangs low, interfering with my knees when I work the pedals. May have to adjust my rig.
- Pedals feel really cheap (they had to save money somewhere)

Compared to my Fanatec CSR:
- CSR has better mounting system
- CSR has smoother, more nuanced feedback
- CSR turns smoother
- CSR has nicer pedals
- TMX has much nicer feeling wheel
- TMX costs half the price

So in summary, I definitely recommend this to anyone looking to make the jump from a controller to a wheel for the first time. However for my fellow FM4/Fanatec players you might not be satisfied. I only got this yesterday so I will give it a couple of weeks before making a final verdict, but initial impressions are good. This is a great wheel for the money.

title: Parts of This Game Are Fun, But Prefer Others in the Series - Here's Why: text: Some thoughts on ASSASSIN'S CREED UNITY:

* I played the PS4 version.
* I do not have the same frame rate issues that others are reporting.
* I think it's not one of the best of Assassin's Creed (AC) games. Having played most of them, I like Black Flag, the Assassin's Creed 2 games, and AC1 better, but like this more than Assassin's Creed III.
* This game pales in comparison to Shadows of Mordor and Assassin's Creed Black Flag.
* The movement in this game is often erratic. I always find that I get more comfortable with the movement in these games as I play them, but I think this game is particularly bad.
* The game feels buggy and glitchy overall. The animations are not as fluid as in other AC games and Shadows of Mordor, NPCs behave weirdly reasonably often, clipping, etc. However, I did not see any gamebreaking crashes or bugs which made me restart a mission/reload the game.
* Combat is about par compared to previous games in the series, but much worse than in Shadows of Mordor.
* Paris is a good setting for the game. AC gameplay benefits from the city streets, as opposed to open terrain, as in much of AC3 and Black Flag.
*In previous games, I really enjoyed the Abstergo/future storyline, but in the more recent games have stopped caring. The plot is overly convoluted and there's very little advancing of the narrative going on.
* Arno is a decent enough character though, and I enjoyed his storyline, but I wish that the rich history of the French Revolution was brought into the game more.
* Paris seems too chaotic, there's too much random robbing and looting going on. It can be distracting, and you'll get random events occurring during (at least some of the) missions, which can get in the way/become problematic.
* Did not try the multiplayer missions.
* Integration with the web games leaves something to be desired, in my opinion. I have heard that they are not very fun, and I'm not really interested in participating anyways. Am bummed that I have to do this in order to unlock some of the game's content.
* In short: if you haven't played Shadows of Mordor or Black Flag, play those first. If you like both of those games and still want more on a current gen console, Unity may be what you're looking for. Just don't set your expectations too high. I enjoyed playing this game - just not up to the quality of some of the previous games I've mentiioned.

title: Very good sound quality; a bit bulky for extended wear text: Overall, these are a pretty decent set of gaming headphones. They aren't loaded with options, but the basics -- namely sound and build quality ‚Äì are well done considering the price point.

The build quality in particular is impressive for the price point. These feel very solidly built. Even issues such as the cords are well done. I inadvertently gave the cord a stress test ‚Äì I‚Äôve been mainly using Bluetooth headsets and forgot this was corded. I got up from the PC and gave the cord a pretty good stress test that it passed with flying colors. No complaints at all about the build quality.

The sound quality is also very good for the price. It‚Äôs a bit thin on the upper and mid ranges, but nothing objectionable. Good bass response which is aided by the around the ear cup design. Very good sound isolation when wearing these. It‚Äôs not audiophile-level sound, but for the price, it‚Äôs very respectable.

The mike is adjustable and can be removed if you just want to use these for sound. There‚Äôs a handy in-line control for volume and mute.

My primary complaint is comfort. The ear cups are covered with a mesh-like material that I had hoped would allow for some air circulation. However, it‚Äôs not very effective ‚Äì the heat buildup becomes uncomfortable after about 45 minutes.

The upper arm padding is thick but could be a bit softer. The rather firm padding on both the ear cups and upper arm, coupled with the overall weight of the headset, got tiring after a while.

While these fall a bit short in terms of comfort for me, I feel they still warrant a solid four star rating for the sound and build quality. They are a good value set of gaming headphones that can withstand some measure of punishment without breaking.

title: White is more of a gray text: I ordered the white digitizer as part of a mod. I was disappointed to find that the border on this was actually gray - lighter gray than the border on the gray switch (I think, though I don't have a gray switch to compare it to), but still far from white and noticeably not the same color as the white buttons and joysticks.

I also wish there was a screen protector on the underside of the digitizer - nothing worse than putting a device back together only to realize you left a fingerprint on the inside of the screen (which can be avoided by giving the underside of the digitizer a good wipe down before attaching the screen, but still a potential problem that could be avoided by simply putting a screen protector on the bottom of the digitizer.

This also doesn‚Äôt come with adhesive. I feel like it would have been pretty cheap to include, but I got some kaisiking phone repair tape that worked perfectly and wasn‚Äôt too expensive.

Apart from some minor gripes, I am overall very happy with this part. It installed with no issues and works like it should.

title: Perfect for my voice. text: Main pro: I've gone through a lot of headsets, with varying price ranges and different brands, and the majority struggle to pick up my voice (being on the softer type) consistently and clearly. But this headset *always* manages to pick it up without issue.

Other pros:
Comfortable to wear (although partner has issues with it being too snug for their head, I like my fit). Has a manual volume, mute/unmute, and mic volume (?) box. Semi-adjustable mic point.

Cons:
Sometimes the cords wrap, at least for me. Been able to fix that with how I put the headset away. Some of the sensitivity capability of the mic means it picks up partner's voice, although this could also be from being in close proximity for our desks and their voice being distinct. Also can be mitigated by tuning down the mic level on the manual box and playing with settings.

EDIT:
The quality of the headset deteriorates. The plastic of the headband snapped on both sides- just from picking it up. And the sound now has to be turned up just to hear anything. And the mic now picks up more background noise than my own voice, and has to be mic-checked repeatedly- which is finicky. I rescind my recommendation.

title: Day 1 Editions come with a flippable cover text: Gotta say i'm in love with the game's combat mechanics (something Platinum games is know for).

Never played any of the previous games, so this is my first Nier game. About half way threw the game I found out there are multiple endings around 26 and it kinda pushed me away from replaying everything from the start, (I have a backlog of games) but later I found out that they dont require a full 26 game playthrough unless its the main, main, game. (Like game A,B and C) (3) But they are played from another perspective, have not started the 2nd play through yet, saving it for the weekend.

I also found out that some endings stack on your save file. For example, eat a fish that was considered poisonous and you die. Ending the game, but starting from the last save file. (Save before eating it). It saves that ending to your save file, showing which one you saw, but not ending the ability to finish the game like normal. The side endings are smaller text written. Not the main, main, ending. Just a "what if" sorta deal.

I'm not gonna be heavily critical of the game, since I have no knowledge of the previous games (how they fight, map layout, system etc to compare it too) but I bought primarily because it was designed combat wise by Platinum Games. I'm a fan of thier fighting system from Bayonetta, this Nier game and the original DMC 1. I will try to be more objective. Graphically its a personal opinion. It's not a Horizon Zero Dawn, but to me the graphics are passable. I'm also using this on a PS4 PRO so the frame issues are non existent.

*Negatives:

*The first half of the game's open world you lack the ability to fast travel. Which means you have to walk from point A-C every single time. Which makes the game feel like its dragging. You can run, and later you get the ability to teleport to a location or use animals. This isn't a full negative, I know the previous games normally had large open worlds, I just wasn't use to that and failed to plan my target spots to make the most of the trip. I found myself zig zagging back and forth which made the game drag.

*Some might get annoyed by the semi desolate open world. Not till later in the game when more enemies appear.

Positives:

*Fighting system is awesome, reminds me of Bayonetta but without the magical feel and wacky fighting attacks. You can combine various weapons in 2 sets and switch on the fly by hitting up. You can also add a heavy weapon into your quick attack slot, and light into hard attack, changing the way the weapon works. This was pretty interesting, since most would use a lighter weapon for light attacks and heavier for heavy hits.

*A lot of things to do, upgrade weapons, quest and find out how the weapons system combos into each other.

*The story is not that bad. Not the best in the world, but not the worst. You have to find a balance of moving the story forward, while at the same time doing side quest to level up. Keep in mind, I have beaten it 1 time and going for the 2nd and 3rd ending later to get the full experience. From what I saw so far, I enjoyed it.

EDIT 3/13/2017

So after being curious what the 2nd play through does. I looked into it online and played the first 12 minutes of the game. You play as the guy, and 3rd part as the Android A2. Everything carries over, including quest that you never finished. After thinking about it, since you now know the layout of everything, the play time should be reduced. From what I heard online 8-10 hours. You learn the events from the guys point of view, his missions are different and he has hacking sections. Your levels, items, etc carry over. This also includes unfinished quest. We have to assume it happens again on the 3rd run using Android A2.

title: I really wanted to like this game..... text: I've played the Harry Potter Game Boy Advance games on the DS....as well as HP 4,5 and 6 on the DS platform. I was really looking forward to this game and I have to say....it was a HUGE let down for me.

CONS:
* From the start, the graphics are mediocre. The characters still don't speak, there are subtitles for the conversation.

* The lack of conversation wouldn't have been so bad...if there was SOME background music. I thought I needed to adjust the settings on my DS because it was so quiet. But no, there is no background music. The only background sound that I have found, is when you are trying to cast a spell. Not even your decoy detonators make noise (I know, cause I wasted a bunch....couldn't tell if they were going off!!)

* The controls are COMPLETELY wonky! You are given an invisibility cloak....which is completely useless. I found that even while invisible AND standing still, the death eaters still walked right over and found me. Potion making is ridiculous! I was making a potion and I was told to shake a beaker up and down.....sounds simple right? So I shook it up and down and nothing was happening to the bar on the side (it fills up as you perform each task.) I lost time and had to start the potion all over again. I repeated this 5 times...and I still shook the beaker the same way (as instructed by the game) and for some reason, it worked on the last try. CRAZY! I found it awkward to try to walk thru this game using the stylus. I kept touching the up/down/let/right button by accident and as some of your spells are there.....I would end up unintentionally casting a spell and losing power....and sometimes brought unwanted death eater attention upon myself.

* The levels are long and you cannot save in the middle of them. The game only saves when you reach checkpoints. This wouldn't have been a terrible thing....IF my game had not frozen in the middle of one of these levels.

* I just found this game to be flat out BORING compared to the other HP games.

I really wanted to like this game. I lost count of how many times I decided to give it yet ANOTHER chance and start it over. Can't do it again. Already listed this game for sale.

title: Solid controller with much better workmanship than the Elite text: After burning through 6 Elite controllers since release day I finally gave up and bought this little guy.
-The Good
Its solid especially the micro switched buttons and feels much more premium.
Volume control's are at the bottom of the controller.

The less than Good
I'm not in love with the rear paddle placement but you've you get used to them it's not bad, but not as comfortable as the Elite.
This controller doesn't support on screen digital audio/chat balancing like they do with their first party stuff.
It's wired (which I prefer) but there's no option for wireless likely due to M$.
The buttons aren't as customize as the elite paired with the M$ accessory app.
Mine needed a secret firmware update to fix it not being recognized by the Xbox after waking up.

Conclusion
If you're burning through the Bumpers like I was this thing is the ticket, no real problems after 6 months, however you lose out on some nice features, but those features aren't anything if the controller breaks constantly.

title: Nice visual improvement over the originals text: FFX is an above-average FF game. Not my favorite, not even close to being the worst. Then there's X-2.....Aside from the fact that the entire thing is trying to get Tidus back, the story and characters are all TERRIBLE. It's literally J-Pop Girl Band The Game. The only redeeming factor of the game is a faux job system (which are easy to level due to a major exploit) and the combat system, which is actually a really fun take on the ATB system.

If you haven't played the games, it's worth getting this for the HD version. But if you've already played the PS2 originals, I wouldn't bother as there's nothing new here.

title: You get what you pay for text: ---- Contains minor spoilers ----

I only paid $10 for this expansion pack so I didn't really expect all that much. I'd played Mohaa all the way through without any major problems so I was suprised to find that some portions of this game are ridiculously difficult. I found I kept running out of ammo because the vast majority of bad guys don't drop ammo when you kill them.

Other parts of the game are also poorly designed such as the bit where your buddy is trying to unlock a door. You get swamped by grenade launching dudes and don't stand a chance. There are several other points which are extremely difficult too. There doesn't really seem to be a good reason for designing a game with this level of difficulty. And, yes, I'm playing on 'EASY'.

The standard cheats don't seem to work on this expansion set and I can't find any cheats online which either means there aren't any or no-one cares enough about the game to research them. Either way, the only way around these impossible sections is to jump to the next map.

There are some cool new weapons such as a powerful air-rifle, a wimpy sub machine gun, and an excellent machine gun. You also get to use mortars, ack-ack, and other heavy artillery. There's also a good dose of humor too.

Overall I'd say it might be worth $10 but not a penny more.

title: MUST Update 1st with PC before they will work on CONSOLE GAMING but GAME/CHAT VOLUME WON'T WORK text: This headset is great don't take my rating the wrong way but SteelSeries advertises these to be wireless for PC and Console gaming. Here's what they don't tell you.

-Headset won't work with consoles without being updated by the STEELSERIES app on your PC 1st.
-Headset GAME/CHAT volume adjustments won't work on console only PC. Got confirmation of this from STEELSERIES
-7.1 Surround Sound only works on PC

What I noticed while plugged into the controller of my PS4 was that it doesn't get very loud at all. Comfortable but definitely not loud enough to drown out any background noise. Also the game volume/chat rocker doesn't work on PS4. Nice and loud when paired with the receiver plugged into your PC you can make more adjustments

Pros-
- Amazing build quality
-Comfortable materials when on your head
-Microphone retracts out of the way
-Good range
-Adjustable EQ when used with a PC
-Mic quality is BEST there is on a Gaming Headset

Cons-
-Do not light up like the Arctis 5's (Customizable Colored rings on headphones)
-GAME/CHAT VOLUME ROCKER does not work on console gaming. only PC

title: Works great with the Xbox One and my TV text: I was a little hesitant after reading many of the negative reviews, however this remote has exceeded my expectations. After setting up my television on the Xbox One, the remote just worked. I believe it is the Xbox doing most of the work utilizing the HDMI-CEC standards. Now, when I turn off or on my Xbox, my TV will also turn off or on. Instructions online seemed to imply I would need an IR Blaster, or extender... however this was not required for me.

I imagine your success/failure with this product will have a lot to do with if the Xbox works well with your TV (mine is a Samsung UN46D6000). This, itself, doesn't seem to do much other than talk to the Xbox (it is not a universal remote). As other stated, the volume was a little funky at first, that is until I figured out where to point the remote, then, even that, pretty flawless. I think the trick was pointing it at the Xbox, not the TV. The remote even has dedicated buttons to jump to the Xbox's Movie or TV sections, although I don't use this very often. Only thing I really haven't tried yet is seeing if it is smart enough to switch the HDMI source on the TV to the one the Xbox is on.

title: I love them, my husband ins't so fond. Overall, very stylish and easy to use. text: I'm reviewing this based on occasional usage from me and regular, daily usage from my husband. I love the skin and thumb grips combo. It makes the controller easier to hold and feels better. It also makes it non-slip; there's no slipping and sliding even with sweaty hands. I have little hands, but I actually prefer the two taller thumb grips. I don't place my thumbs on top, though, instead I push them on their sides. It's just a personal preference.

My husband, however, does not like the skins. He only likes the two short thumb grips. It makes them easier for him to maneuver and control. He's not too happy about the girl colors (we have one purple, one pink, and one blue), but since we rarely have company he's OK with using it at home.

The skins and thumb grips are fairly easy to put on (the skins easier than the grips). They stay on while playing and look great. If you want better control and a better overall feel, these sets are a great choice.

I received this product complimentary in exchange for my honest review. All opinions are 100% mine.

This is an ideal game for these hot summer vacation days when it's too hot or too expensive to go anywhere, really. Which brings me to the play value of this game. It's a phrase I like to use with my kids when they want a toy that I think is going to interest them a total of about twenty minutes. This game, on the other hand, has almost UNLIMITED play value between solo and team efforts and then the various permutations on each game which you unlock as you play.

Couple this with the unique and brilliant motion controller concept and this is a MUST-HAVE GAME! It's fantastic!

title: Fantasy Star text: I'm 19 hours into the game and just finished the main story. This game is just that addicting. In a fun way. Even with the main story finished, there's an enormous amount of content to explore, and that's not even considering the DLC. I can easily see logging over 100 hours.

If I have any issues with the game:

People talk too much. They talk and talk and talk. Mostly during the main quest lines, and at times you'll wonder if you're playing an RPG or a visual novel.

Once you trigger a main quest line (and that also considers Live quest lines) you're sorta stuck in that arc until you finish it. There's a few points where you can take a break, but for the most part, if you need a break, just close the cover rather than waiting for a natural pause.

Luckily, the main story is not hard and the game's general progression will level you appropriately. I finished at level 25, and feeling cocky, I visited some new areas where some monsters took 50% of my health in two hits, so the difficulty is not so much in the main part, but post-game. And I haven't even touched multiplayer yet!

And finally, one of those few games where I was compelled to watch the cutscenes. The game lets you skip them, but I didn't, they were just beautifully done. Overall, I really want to call this a "masterpiece".

title: A whole new experience for me text: This is my first time to use the mechanical keyboards, and I had no idea how it works. Along with the upbringing sound, this keyboard provides pretty good typing experience overall. So here is what I think.

Build Quality & Design:

This keyboards have pretty good build. It has height adjustor on the back and the key is slightly augmented compared other conventional keyboards. It has uniform black color but the LED lighting gives a little design kick. It has welcome signature pattern, which is also looks nice. The fond on the key is larger than normal if it matters to you, and overall it has everything you need. The keys are pretty sturdy but I think it's replaceable if you want to as well. It has black-matte plastic finish, so it doesn't look particularly exquisite, though.

Sound & Touch:
To be honest, I think this keyboard is a little too sensitive on touch, I assume it is typical for mechanical keyboards. I hope it has function to ignore the light touch. It does make quite a bit of "noise" and I think it's very personal preference. I think you can't use this in the quite working environment, but it's very good if you like the typing sounds.

Buy this if you want: a mechanical keyboard on budget. It's 20% off so the price is very competitive
Don't if you want: some mechanical keyboards with low noise. I know there are other products that provide this feature, but they are much more expensive than 20 something dollars.

title: Disappointed text: I really don't see why Valve would even sell this disc package, as none of the games are actually on the disc. You have to download all of them. So really all you're paying for is the piece of paper with the activation code that comes in the DVD case. There are four games in this package, each requires a download of around 2GB ~ 4GB+ to install.

Ok, I should have known better. I'm one of the many people that even today who don't have high-speed broadband. I live in a rural area that isn't served by any of the regular ISPs. So I make do with dial-up and a cellular 4G MiFi service. Sure the 4G is high speed, but I'm limited to 5GB a month. So to get just one of these games, I would have to use up the bulk of my monthly data plan, or spend $10 per GB to buy extra. Which is why I ordered the physical box package, so that I wouldn't have to download anything. It really makes me a bit angry to find out that this disc was intentionally created by a company without the actual content on it. I could understand if they were just doing downloads to save the cost of a physical package (DVD & case), but they're not.

I'm sure these are great games, but since I haven't been able to play one, I'm just giving them an "OK" rating. Maybe some day I'll be able to download them and come back and give them a real review.

At least the activation code did work, I see from reading some of the other reviews that is not always the case.

title: Razer Kraken Pro v2 50mm driver 2017 white model text: I've read some of the older reviews tied to the 40mm models where they say the wiring was weaker and prone to fail. I bought the newer 50mm drivers and they seem to have upgraded wiring. They feel insulated, instead of the slippery wire you see on headsets or basic cables.

The headset is loud, clear, and you hear and feel the bass. I tested these on a computer with no special enhancements or 'effects' and they have excellent sound. The volume goes up pretty high too. People had no issues hearing me in a video call I made to test the mic. So the mic was also upgraded in the newer models. It feels high quality, heavy as in well built but not overly heavy while wearing. It looks and performs like a premium device. You can mute the microphone by sliding a button on the cord, if you dont, it stays active even when inside the headset. Clearly marked red for no sound making it easy to quickly turn on and off at a glance.

I had to return these once I tested these on my Playstation 4 Pro, which was the original reason I bought them for. The reason I rated a 5 star is because it does deliver, and works as advertised on a Playstation 4 console, computer, cell phone etc and has excellent sound and bass. They also seem to have fixed the complaints from the older models. The problem for me was the controller of the Playstation 4 that it plugs into. NOT THE HEADSET. The controller lacks a powerful amp built in for headphones.

What ends up happening is the high quality, volume levels, bass etc all take a dive. It ends up under performing because the controller does not have a built in amp or DAC to feed it power, so the controller feeds it compressed bluetooth audio on top of not having a built in amp. The difference in sound quality on a computer, sound system and even my LG v20 smartphone (which has a Hi-Fi Quad DAC) is like night and day. It sounds like a basic headset.

It's okay, but for the price and I was only planning on using these on a Playstation 4 I decided to return them. I can see how it would be phenomenal for computer gaming which Razer uses computer gamers on thier website as spokesperson and streaming films on a laptop or computer. In my case, I only use my computer for basic internet use, not gaming or streaming. (I leave that to my home theater system).

title: Great for Watching Special Effects Movies, Overall Excellent But Pricey text: Here's my review for what it's worth:

First, I'm a movie and music buff, not a gamer, and I usually prefer earbuds rather than headphones for my Samsung Galaxy 4S Blaze. I typically prefer lightweight, easy to pack headphones when I travel and am a little mystified about why there's been a throwback to much bulkier versions, like the ones from the 60s and 70s. Maybe I'm just getting old, but I don't see how bulk is better.

That said, I have to say I felt very cool wearing these red and black headphones. They are almost a dead ringer for the trendy Dr. Dre Beats headphones lots of kids wear these days. However, upon closer inspection, I can see these are so much better made, with small details that really make a difference in comfort and function.

PROS: Overall solidly made, though the plastic parts make me wonder how much use it will take before those vulnerable parts break. Judging by the other reviews I've read of this product, I have reason to be concerned.

Sound quality is excellent. I watched "Titanic" and "The Impossible" on my Windows PC and the surround sound was fantastic. I'm reserving these headphones for movie nights when disaster films are on my agenda.

Music. You can adjust the timbre, bass, etc., using the Bluetooth app. While I'm not a professional musician and there are those of us out there who are more discerning, I was quite impressed with the depth and clarity of the jazz, classical and rock tunes I tested these with. Bass started to crap out at a very high volume, but I would rarely use it at that extreme.

Comfortable to wear and lightweight, despite the size. Your head feels less sore because of a cushion cleverly stitched on the underside of the band that rests on top of your head. I can see myself using this on an airplane for hours, and the manufacturer encourages this by providing an adapter for flight use. Clever.

Easy to fold and store. Again, I'm not a fan of big headphones, so I'm glad I can shrink them down whichever way I can. I do wish, however, that the manufacturer had made the headpiece bendable and foldable as well, not just the muffs. For $300 why not?

Versatile. I like the fact it can be used like an ordinary headphone with a cord, used wirelessly for your cell and once charged, pumped up with surround sound for movie watching. Whatever situation you want, these headphones offer it. It comes with Bluetooth, USB, and 3.5mm jack cords.

The buttons are conveniently placed, though all of them are located on the right earmuff - if you're a lefty you'd have to switch. I especially loved the fact that I can control the volume by simply reaching up to the headphone and rolling the dial.

CONS: The included USB cable is kind of thick, which is good for durability, but it's also kind of short. I would have liked it to be longer.

The storage case has a zipper on the back, making you assume the cords would be naturally stored there. But the compartment is tight and stiff, and it makes the package bulky. I ended up wrapping the cord up with a pipe cleaner and putting it inside with the headphones. Not sure what I would use the exterior zipper compartment for.

Noise cancellation. The noise cancellation was OK but not as impressive as the BOSE headphones I used to own. I feel as if the noise cancellation works mainly because the earpiece covers the entire ear rather than having a true noise cancellation mechanism.

I still have to test these using SKYPE, but for now I'm impressed with these. For $300, I would not expect anything less.

title: Good For The Price text: Since there seem to be reviews for multiple models of Zalman keyboards here, I want to state up front that this review is for the Model ZM-K200M, which currently sells for somewhere in the $13 range here on Amazon. Obviously, Zalman has quite a wide-range of keyboards as they span from the cheapest (the one that I am reviewing here) to one that currently sells for over $100. I can't imagine paying $100+ for a keyboard, but prices do tend to be exaggerated when it comes to the PC gamer market.

Obviously, for $13 I was not expecting a lot of bells and whistles. Just something that wouldn't fall apart instantly and was as simple to use as any other keyboard. There are certainly cheaper keyboards here on Amazon, but most are not ones I would want to use on a daily basis. The thing that sold me on this particular model was that it is not only cheap but comes with a number of multimedia buttons that I figured would come in handy.

I am not super-impressed with the keyboard action, shape of the keys or the short and stubby ENTER key, but unlike an even cheaper multimedia keyboard I bought here a couple of weeks ago (which I gave one of my very rare 1 star reviews) this one actually works.

Going into a little more detail, there are no instructions that come with this model. Fortunately, it is largely a plug-and-play type of device though. It is pretty much self-evident what the volume control keys do, but others such as the Home and Mail keys are quite a bit less obvious. From what I can tell, the Home button simply takes you to whatever is set as the homepage in the particular browser you are using. This seems to work for Chrome and Firefox on Windows 8.1. I can't speak for other browsers or operating systems though. The Mail button only seems to open up a new browser window for me. There is another button with the image of a computer on it that seems to open up an instance of Windows Explorer. Another opens up the Calculator program. All of the audio controls seemed to work fine on my computer. Again, I have to caution though that there is no guarantee that these buttons will work with your own version of Windows, Mac, Linux, Android or whatever other OS you are running. The keys are not programmable in any way, to the best of my knowledge.

Construction is about what you would expect at this price range. The body is 100% plastic. It is very light, but not so light that it moves around when you use it. Neither is it so flimsy that I would expect it to break after dropping it from 3' off the ground. It is not a mechanical keyboard, so it obviously is not as responsive as you would expect from a more expensive model with that feature. At least the keys are not "mushy" like some others I have seen though. The USB cable seems long enough for normal use and the cabling uses a reasonably thick gauge. Honestly, it isn't something that I would want to spend hours at a time typing on, but it is good enough for most uses.

All things considered, this is an excellent value at its current price. Compared to most keyboards I have tested in this price range it has to be considered of above-average quality. I feel that I have definitely gotten my money's worth.

title: The Bad with the Good text: This is one of the newer Nancy Drew games, and there's both good and bad to it. I'll start with the good: the atmosphere of this game is great- very creepy. An old Irish castle after dark is bound to be spooky, and indeed it is. The graphics when inside the castle are also fantastic- high resolution, lots of detail. You really feel like you're in the castle. Part of the castle has been blown up, and it was never really clear why someone was staying in a room with half the roof missing, but we'll hold that thought until we get to the plot. Other pluses of this game- it's a fairly long game to get through, and some of the puzzles were quite challenging.

On to the negatives: the most important one is the plot. Quite simply, there isn't much plot- Nancy is searching for her friend's missing fiance, but beyond that, we get little plot development. On the same note, I found the ending to be quite unsatisfactory. I don't want to give anything away, so I won't go into to detail, and will just say that the ending severely interfered with my enjoyment of the castle's atmosphere. Also, I was unhappy with the outdoor navigation in this game. Outside the castle the player controls Nancy from above, meaning that the graphics are quite simplistic, and it's more like an arcade game than a mystery. I much prefer to see the game through Nancy's eyes. In sum, Nancy Drew addicts will definitely want to play this game, and there are certainly things to recommend here, but it's not one of the better Nancy Drew games. The first third of the game is decidedly the best part, and then it starts to go downhill.

title: Great for Storing, Packing, and Display text: I am in the middle of a move I don‚Äôt want to make. Long story short ‚Äì I‚Äôm being kicked out so the management team can spiffy up my unit to rent for more money.

One thing I have tried, over the past 30+ years has been to protect my NES and SNES collection ‚Äì my original devices and games. It hasn‚Äôt been easy. I only have ONE box that a game came in. The cases I used for my NES games ‚Äì long since broke and fell apart.

title: A Few Frustrations But Overall Great Gaming Experience So Far (And Some Things I Wish The Instructions Said) text: My entire family is into gaming and other applications that use headphones and speakers, so I was very interested in try out the Siberia P800 series wireless gaming headphones. There are a lot of excellent highly technical reviews out there for these, but I intend to approach these headphones for someone who is not as into gritty tech details as they might be into practical every day applications.

I am writing this review for those who really want to know about products prior to purchase. I am as detailed as I can be without being overly so, because I want to provide information that I would like to know before purchases. This is an expensive purchase, so it deserves some explanation and time given to research.

WHAT COMES IN THE BOX?
The box that these come in is excellent. It is sturdy and you can keep it for storage of the extra cords and parts if you like. Inside the headphones come carefully pressed into a molded insert. It comes with a wireless transmitter box, every cord you might possibly want to connect it to the Playstation, PC,or Xbox. It also comes with a mobile cable and analog cable for use with TV or mobile device.

The startup guide is, well, let me say really not as good as it should be with an expensive set of headphones like this. For visual learners, you might have some issues unless you are a real techie. There are no pictures of the back of the transmitter box or of the back of the playstation (or other items) you want to connect to so if you are not really good at understanding what goes where, you might have to look up online somewhere how to hook this up to your console or other devices.

WHAT ARE THE HEADPHONES LIKE?
The headphones themselves have a cushioned top and small ear covers on them. The retract and get slightly bigger, but not a huge amount. The top is cushioned and they hold onto the had pretty well, at times feel a bit tight. That will loosen up over time, I am sure.

The left ear pad has a retractable mic in it. When the mic is turned on, a red ring lights up. The disc on the outside of the left ear pad also twists off and that is there the lithium battery is put. When you want to replace, you quickly twist off the cover, replace the battery and you are good to go. There are two arrows that line up for you to replace the cover quickly so you don't have to fumble with it in a hurry to continue your game.

The right ear side has the on off switch on it located just slightly toward the back of bottom of the circle. If the ear pad was a clock with 12 at the top and 6 at the bottom and 9 toward your front with these on, it is about at 5 o'clock. To turn it on, you press for about a minute or so. The switch will light up. If you want to turn on the mic, you tap the same switch once and the mic goes on. Tap again and it goes off.

On the right ear side, there is also a control. It is a wheel which controls volume, but when pressing it, will change the menu on the transmitter box. Then if you move the wheel it will scroll the menu.

The ear pads do fold flat which makes them a bit easier to store when not in use.

I also find that the longer I use these, the more comfortable they seem to become- I imagine they will continue to loosen up over time.

HOW DOES THE TRANSMITTER BOX WORK?
I tested these headphones out on a PS3. I found very little on the internet about using these headphones with a PS3, so knowing that many still use the PS3, I wanted to test using that gaming console first.

SET UP WITH PS3
Optical cable- plug in to optical out on PS3 in back then plug into optical in on the back of the transmitter box.
USB- plug in mini USB side of the cable to the transmitter box and plug the regular USB side into the front of the PS3

POWER - this is optional. The power plug can be plugged in where it says DC but keep in mind that means the transmitter box will be on at all times. If you prefer that it turns off when your PS3 is off, then don't use it. The advantage of the power plug is if you want your battery to charge up when the unit is not on, you can have it plugged in for that. Once done, you can still remove the power plug until needed again.

SIDE SLOT
This package comes with an additional battery. One battery had a single bar of charge on it and the other had two bars of charge on it. So, while using on, the other is charging in the box. I found that with the power plugged in, it took about 45 minutes to reach a full charge or so. One battery took almost an hour. The battery pushes in and locks into place while charging, and then if you push on it again, it will dislodge and come out so you can use it and replace with the other one if you like.

FRONT PANEL
The front panel has a white light up design. It shows the battery charge, that the headphones are on and if you are using gaming and voice and the balance of the two. There is a dial on the right and a back button to the left of that. When turning on the headphones, I get a light that shows they are on then a quick large display of battery power left in them, and then it goes to the screen that shows me PS3 and how much volume is being used at that point. It will also show me the current battery charge of the battery that is charging on the side of the unit too so I can keep track of when it is ready to use should I need it.

The menu is pretty simple to adjust. You press the button to change menu and turn the dial to run through it. There are presets for equalizer and you can also set custom.

WHAT THE DON'T SAY IN THE INSTRUCTIONS
Call me dumb if you want, but although I have programmed computers and done a lot of technical work, I guess I was having a dull moment when I set up these headphones. I could not get them to work. I went through every setting over and over again and just could not make them work right.

Since I have never had headphones on my PS3, (I am the only one who hasn't) I did not realize that I had to change the settings in the sound menu. I should have, but I didn't remember. So, after much looking around, I finally found the setting that has to be changed. There is no mention of it at all in the instruction book. Since this review is geared more toward the casual gamer, I thought you might like to know that small important fact.

You have to go into the PS3 settings menu for sound and pick either the optical sound or you can have both going if you like- through the TV AND headphones. I like to do that when the family wants to be in the room and see what is being played but I want to hear details of sound you normally don't catch on just the TV speakers. You just have to remember to change the settings when you change how you prefer to transmit the sound.

HOW WELL DO THESE HEADPHONES PERFORM?
I am going to have to really work with these for a while to find the ins and outs of them. My first impression of them was awful. I really was disappointed. There was hissing, crackling and all sorts of noise with sound effects on various games. The music seemed fine, but every time there was an explosion or some sort of noise that was supposed to be electronic in nature, the headphones had so much other noise in them it was distracting and annoying. I messed with volume and settings and everything and it just didn't get as good as I thought it should have.

I kept on, however, changing to various games. As I moved through all sorts of different games, I realized that some games must be designed with engines that do not seem to transmit clearly over the wireless headphones. They just are awful. Then other games seemed to be clear and a lot easier to play.

DOLBY
So far, I have had the best results when removing Dolby on all of the games I have tried. I am not sure if that is because the headphones are designed for 7.1 and the PS3 is designed for 5.1, but it seems to be more muffled with the Dolby on and there are more annoying features that come up with sound effects. I will continue to play with this and see how to make it work if I can. I will update this review at that point. We have several different gaming consoles we can try these with, so over time I will elaborate if I find solutions or differences. The listing on these headphones does specify that it will work on both PS3 and PS4 so I plan to see what I can find out about this over time.

MUSIC
I have watched videos on these headphones and found them to be excellent. I can hear all sorts of nuances that I did not catch on just the TV speaker. I watched them via Netflix and also Bluray on the PS3. Sound was much better than some games. Like I said, however, it could just be the software used when developing some games that does not translate as well into the headphones as others.

I do want to point out, that these are GAMING headphones. They are not going to be the top of the line for music listening, so if that is primarily what you want them for, they probably will not be what you want. For the variety of needs I have on the PS3 of videos to music in games and movies, they are surprisingly good.

MICROPHONE
I have not had the opportunity to test out the mic yet with other players. I will update as that opportunity presents itself and will comment on performance during gameplay.

THE BOTTOM LINE
So far I really like these headphones but have a few issues with them. Some games do not sound right in these at all, and others sound beautiful. That is not always the fault of the headphones, but it does make for annoying experiences in some games. The design of the headphones is nice and I do love how they work when they work well with games. The transmitter is easy to use and battery life seems a bit shorter than 20 hours, but I like the fact that you can keep a battery charging while playing so when you need to replace you can.

I also like that you can opt to have the power on to them while the PS3 is off so you can recharge battery, but then unplug it so that it only turns on when the PS3 is on too.

For the price, I have rated these four stars at this time. As I continue to use them and learn more about them and the ins and outs over time, I will update and amend my rating if need be.

FUTURE UPDATES
I plan to test these out with other games as well on my PC games as well as tablet in the future and will comment on those experiences as well.

GAMES TESTED SO FAR (more coming soon)
Monkey Island (newest one)
Hydrophobia
Zen Pinball
Peggle
Planet Minigolf
Spellunker HD
Beyond Two Souls

title: No More Sliding Mouse! text: I designed a computer workstation where the keyboard and mouse sit atop a desk surface that swivels over the arm of a recliner. As with any custom built item, such as this, I‚Äôve run into unforeseen issues. One of them was, due to my preferred angle for my mouse platform the mouse would constantly move when I didn‚Äôt want it too.

Now I understand this may seem like a minor inconvenience but when doing detailed graphic editing it can end up being really frustrating. I had tried solving the issue in a variety of ways but none were successful.

This device ended up being exactly what I needed. The nonslip base rests at the top of my mouse platform and holds my mouses wire so there is no pull causing the cursor to move even when my hand is not resting on the mouse.

My entire system is lit with RGB lighting so this cable holder fits right in and looks great. I have it plugged in to a multi port charging plug so it doesn‚Äôt occupy a port on my pc just for the power supply.

Colors are easily controlled via the button on the front.

The spring loaded holder that supports the wire securely holds the mouse wire without it slipping and keeps it out of the way.

This is a great product that works exactly as intended.

title: Half vs Full Body cover... this is full body.
text: This is probably something you don't think about, we certainly didn't... We just searched for Nintendo Switch Lite cases and picked one out. If you want FULL body protection, these 2 piece hard shell cases are what you want. However, you should consider this "con" before making your decision... title: Emotional game with great storytelling ! text: Well, it seems most people here covered the reviews on the game so I will keep things short. Visually, it's impressive. One of the best AAA games out there right now. The story in general once you start it will be impossible to let go of and not finish it. They covered all past games and Nate's adventure around the globe. They show a side of him that deals with everyday life for everyone. Showing his normal life now vs his global treks around the globe. It really makes you see how everyday you wake up like a robot and do the same over and over again and not even notice it. However you see things from his perspective. Anyways, I have not completed the game but currently working on it and in chapter 11 and was blown away by the chemistry all the voice actors have, I would say this surpasses Uncharted 2. The music goes with the flow of what is happening inside the game which really sucks you into the storytelling and action sequences. I have nothing negative to say on it.

Multiplayer I was impressed with. Everything in game can be bought or unlocked by using multiplayer points won in game. The only thing is the points unlock items randomly or paying for points to allows you to select them. All stages are free to avoid dividing the community.

The MP plays like a mix of The Last of Us and Uncharted 3. You can revive downed allies like TLOU however they have boosters that can be bought in game (gun upgrades, more bombs, helpers etc) I liked the fact that every time you buy an "upgrade" inside the game (RPGs, GUNS etc) they cost more the next time so it avoids being abused. They have a section that teaches you how to use the new items or moves (hooks, one hit kill charge, bombs , mines etc) standards Deathmatch and capture the flag type modes. They also have a section for ranked matches online instead of friendly. It still 'feels' like an uncharted game when playing online similar to UC2-3.

I loved The Last of Us but Uncharted has always been fast pace and I was afraid that they would slow down the online in UC4. This time Naughty Dog found a good mix between fast pace action with timing and semi planing similar to (TLOU) so that made me happy. This time the online is fun and feels challenging not just run and gun. The online is also stable (I have 100 down and 26 up) results of online stability varies case by case but even a friend who has 50 down and 6 up stated that it was very stable.

title: You get what you pay for text: It isn't the original, nor does it have the pricetag or rarity of a USB version of the original Sega controller.
The build quality is not that of the real thing. It will creak and groan a bit when you squeeze it. I do not think it will give up on me tomorrow, though it probably won't last years and years like the official controller from back in the day.

However, that does not change the fact that in its own respect, this is a great controller.
The famous Sega d-pad is emulated quite nicely here. It's smooth, responsive, accurate and tactile. It's been a while since I've used my real Saturn controller but this does feel just right; it won't disappoint you. The face buttons have a great on/off, low travel, digital feel. The only complaint I have about the feel of the controller is the shoulder buttons. They're passable, but they require a lot of force, hit with a hard clack, and are difficult to push rapidly. Though obviously not an original design, the layout is still one of the best ever created.

If it breaks, it's cheap enough to buy another one. While it's still living, this controller will feel like the original and serve you well.

title: Great Dungeon Crawler! text: New Impression:
I've played several hours now. My initial intent on the review was to indicate that the game wasn't as bad as others have made it out to be. Now I'm hooked! The story continues to pick up, and there have been a few times when I find myself very much impressed by the sound and graphics. Over all, SE/Obsidian did a fine job on this one! Everything seems very fluid, and over all, I'm having a blast!

Previous Impression:
I'm seeing some negative reviews on this, and I'm rather surprised. This game pretty much delivers what's advertised. When I saw the initial trailers, I expected a clone of Diablo/Baldur's Gate: Dark Alliance, and that's exactly what you get. The graphics and sound are far sharper than it's predecessors, and the play control is solid. I'm about 5 or 6 hours into the single player game as Lucas. The story is fine enough (these types of games never have mind-blowing story lines anyway) and the characters are about what you'd expect. I'd say the voice-actors are about on par with Diablo/BG:DA.

Is this "Game of the Year?" Probably not.
Is this a fun game? Definitely!
Does this game offer anything new to the genre? Not really. It's just prettier and more polished.

If you've enjoyed previous dungeon crawlers, you might want to give this one shot.

Edit: 8/11/2011
I still really enjoy this game, and I'm rather disappointed by its over-all reception; it's a fun dungeon crawl, and I'm not sure why people expected anything else. Granted, it's a bit short, but there is some replay value here (thank the Trophy system for that.) I'd expect the average person to play through it in about 10 hours. Some grinding will be necessary if you want an easier time with the end. Trying to complete the game when you're in your low-mid 20's can be tough for some. If you're short on cash, this is definitely worth a rent. It's certainly easy enough to complete in a weekend.

title: Yummy! text: Just reading the name Final Fantasy VI makes me melt, and I'm not even joking.

Of all the FF games from the non-loser era of Square/SquareSoft/SquareEnix (FF1-12), this one probably had the most memorable lines ("welcome to my barbecue!"), though Zidane in 9 had all sorts of lines that were nearly as memorable (including, but not limited to "you and your fat queen!" and "I'm such a stud!").

Nobuo Uematsu's gorgeous soundtrack is, as always, haunting and gorgeous and evocative. If anything, I think that the music trumps the game. Not that the game itself doesn't rock, coz it does. (Five, on the other hand...)

Since every other review on the page mentioned the plot, I'll just say this--if you're an RPG-enthusiast, then do yourself a big fat favour and get this game!!!

(ps if you're a hardcore RPG enthusiast, the best FF to get are: this one (6), IX, X, and XII. Note that VII is also quite good, but some people freak out and think that it trumps VI, which it does NOT. Sure, 7 is haunting, too, but 6 is simply more fun all around.
Ok, time to go dream of Edgar and Sabin and Kefka (and SETZER :)~
6 RULES!!
:)

title: A great solution for a system that still has life left in it text: While I don't game as much as most, I use my controllers enough to make alkaline batteries wasteful and expensive and swapping AA NiMH batteries out of the controller and into the charger and back a hassle. I've used the MS Charge and Play kit with mixed results and wanted more.

This largely delivers. The Nyko batteries have enough juice left in them (not sure if there are old new stock or fresh cells) to last plenty of time, and the base makes keeping them charged a breeze.

The only complaint (and cause for losing a star) is the spotty indicator lights. Depending on how well charged the batteries are, you may not see any acknowledgement of what the status is. There's supposed to be a color coded LED indicator, but it seems to work intermittently. Despite this it does charge as you'd expect.

title: what do you do when you are traveling and don't have a power outlet?
text: If you have a Nintendo Switch, you already know that the full charge can quickly drain the battery, depending on the game being played. Some games will use 2.5 hours before the battery needs charging, others might last the full 6 hours. So, if you are on the go and your battery dies, this handy dandy charging battery pack will work wonders. You can play while you charge. If you want to charge it faster and to the fullest capacity, it will need the switch off and about 4 hours of non stop charging. This charging battery pack has a kickstand so you can continue your play while charging. There are also lights to display when you need to charge and the power level. You can charge via a usb connector to an outlet, a computer or a vehicle usb slot. Depending on the game you are playing, it can give you up to another 10 hours of play.

title: Comfortable; Excellent Noise-Cancelling; Wonderful Sound text: This EASY SMX COOL 2000 GAMING HEADSET (with Mic and Volume Control, Y Splitter Cable, Dynamic LED Light) is extremely comfortable for big-headed people (large craniums) like me. title: 4.5 stars text: The PDP Grip is sleek and on first glance you would assume it is made by Nintendo and not a third party peripheral company. It fits the sleek black aesthetic of the Joy-Con controllers and the box itself is akin to official products as this is an officially licensed peripheral.

The Grip itself works well and sits comfortably in the included dock.

Before purchasing this item, I recommend strongly considering how you use your Switch. If you primarily play with detached Joy-Cons on the TV, chances are it is no easier to leave them attached and charging on the Switch unit itself versus in the charging grip if you won't in fact be utilizing the grip for play. This is because the Grip includes as a benefit a top shell piece for the L/R buttons, and as a small side effect of this, the Joy-Cons can't be as immediately slid in or out of the Grip. Whereas when affixed to the Switch itself, the Joy-Cons slide right out in one step. And if you play on the go primarily or use the Pro Controller, the product will likely offer minimal benefit. For those who prefer their Joy-Cons in a grip, the PDP Grip is a bit comfier and more ergonomically friendly than the default grip as it offers larger shoulder buttons. The battery benefit in and of itself for grip preferrers will be significant.

title: Awesome controller but not customizable text: I have owned this controller for almost 2 years now and here's my honest review:
The design and layout is exactly what you expect since it's based off the Xbox controllers. The mechanical buttons are what drew me to this item and they did not/do not disappoint! I have never felt such smooth button movement in the 20+ years of video gaming. The amazing part is, 2 years later they still feel the same as they did day one! However, the print on the buttons has completely worn off. The final important pro of this controller is how securely the cable connection is into the controller. The connection points on wireless controllers are extremely weak, as they're just meant to be plugged in to recharge. Try playing with them connected and you usually knock out the cable once or twice a session. That DOES NOT happen with this. Once you plug it in it takes quite a bit of effort to remove. You definitely can't knock it out by accident.

Now the cons, and the reason why I knocked off a star. First, if you need replacement parts, good luck. Razer, nor any 3rd party make any spare parts for the controller. They have a few spare parts that they get from returns and things that they will sell you, but it's hit or miss if they have the part you need. Second, there is no way to remap the paddle buttons/spare buttons to keyboard binds. So if you play on PC but enjoy using a controller, you are limited to what you can do with it. For example, I play FiveM (GTA 5) often, and because there are so many functions, most important commands are bound to a key, not a button. If you have an Xbox or PS controller there is plenty of 3rd party software that allows you to remap one of the paddles to a keyboard key. Neither con alone was enough to knock a star off, but together they do.

Overall I have thoroughly enjoyed and continue to enjoy this controller. But, if Microsoft decides to release the Elite series 3 with mechanical operating buttons, bye bye Razer.

title: Worth the $! text: This isn't the type of game I normally play.....being a fan of games like Cake Mania and Diner Dash. Decided to pick this up after we read the Percy Jackson books (still on the mythology kick). I really like this game!

Being completely NEW to this type of game play....no cons, just pros for me. I REALLY appreciated that this game has tutorials for you to accomplish before being thrown into the missions. I specifically bought this game new because I thought I would need to look at the instruction book to figure out how to play. The instruction booklet was completely useless. The tutorials are all you need.

You start off with a few people in your military (heroes, archers, cavalry, etc.) You also have a builder who is used to build up your base, your farms, your mines. Every turn, you try to advance your borders a little further by challenging the armies of your enemy. Each member of your military has specific strengths and weaknesses (which are shown on the screen when you select them). When you obtain enough favor and materials, you can advance an "age". At that point, more god powers will become available and you can upgrade your military.

I have been playing this game (as I have time) over the last 5 months and I haven't even scratched the surface with all that it offers. I finished the Egyptian section and I am almost finished with the Greeks. I like that there is a lot of strategy involved in this game.....you don't just finish a level and win. You could sit there and play one level for over an hour and STILL lose if you don't plan your strategy well.

title: major eye candy that functions perfectly text: I've reviewed a couple of other Pok√©mon games and gave them high scores. Yes, I am a fan of the series. I average about 400 hours per game even though I'm no pro. Pok√©mon Omega Ruby is fun. It's the most fun I've had with a Pok√©mon game since Soul Silver (my favourite), and it is the best looking to date. I thought X was mind blowingly awesome but all the little improvements in this one, even minor things like how great reflective surfaces look, how tree lines have more detail and depth, how Pok√©mon attack animations look amazing is enough to push this game to the top of my list. This is not a stale remake but of course it follows tried and true Pok√©mon formula. It's a better game over all in every category than X with tons of content.

A FEW things I really like:
DexNav
Pokedex (homage to the GBA is awesome and the dex functions really well and is fun to use)
Graphics--true improvement in every aspect, even NPC models are a delight--battle animations are magnificent
2 different bikes that actually function completely differently--mach and acro
Pokemon Contests---while not as fun as Pokeathlon it's still great
Transferring Pok√©mon from other games considering they are "newer gen" Pok√©mon
Secret bases--customization is awesome
*Also, it's faster to heal your Pok√©mon with nurse Joy...battle animations have been amped up to be faster. Other than sneaking up on Pok√©mon, the rest of the game things can happen faster, including how fast you can go on the bikes.

To be fair---here are two things I really don't like--
1. Music--it sounds great but when changing areas, entering buildings, especially going into battle, it often seems like a jarring change instead of a smooth transition...it seems pretty major to me and is very annoying, maybe I'll get used to it
2. Not being able to customize your character is a step back for a game that took SO many steps forward. Even if they had limited the options, there should have been character customization options. People who play hundreds of hours get pretty tired of seeing the same character.

Wish--still wish Pok√©mon could follow my character. Simple but very great thing about SS.

Note....these Pok√©mon don't suck as some people want to continue to say. People who say this often continue by saying 1st Gen are the only Pok√©mon they've cared about. Every gen has great ones and some stinkers. Well, this game is set for you to catch them ALL.

Whether you played the originals or not, there's enough familiar content and new content and improvements that this game, like Heart Gold and Soul Silver gets to stand out on it's own as a major contender for best Pok√©mon game ever. It is just a sheer delight to play and Game Freak went above and beyond to give us another super great quality gaming experience.

(I didn't mention online play because I don't do that until I've spent around 50 hours on the game. Writing this review I am only about 30 hours in)

I hope you enjoy Pok√©mon Omega Ruby or Alpha Sapphire as much as I am

title: Cannot dock with a case, not even a thin one...
text: I'm still in search of a dock that can accommodate a switch with a case. A previous one I had was too narrow width-wise, so it couldn't seat. The design on this one seems pretty open, look at the pictures, you'll see the width is wide. So I had hopes this could be the one! My switch with the thin case sat on the dock with no issues at all. That's what I was hoping for based on the design. But I realized of a new issue. Even if you can seat your Switch with a case, it might not charge. The reason is because your case creates a rise that prevents the usb-c port and plug to fully connect. Logically, I knew about this already. But I anticipated that the contact would be enough for it to charge. Sadly, the answer is no. It needs to be 100% docked. The only solution is to modify the case, like cutting out a slot to allow it to fully seat with no rise. This isn't something I'm going to subtract a star for. The dock does it's job perfectly fine when I take my switch out of the case. But just a FYI to those who are trying to do what I'm doing. This is still a 5-Stars product!

title: If you liked Doom 3 you'll like this too text: Reviewed on a 2.4GHz Pentium with 0.5 Gig RAM and nVidia 6200 video card.

My overwhelming impression all the way through this game is that is simply a large Doom 3 expansion pack. The graphics have the same quality and the load times between segments are similarly slow. In fact some of the segments seemed to take longer to load than to play.

The weapons and opponents are largely similar to those you encountered in Quake 2 with a few, quite impressive, additions. There is a good variety of play environments ranging from outdoors and warehouse sized interiors, to claustrophobic mazes. Although Q4 doesn't suceed like Doom3 in making you jump out of your chair every few minutes, it's still pretty tense. Some of the cut scenes, especially the one where you get real ugly real fast, are exceptionally gross. Not for the weak-hearted.

Probably my biggest gripe is that there aren't a whole lot of hidden goodies. Many times I found myself exploring under stairs or elevated platforms or investigating little nooks only to be disappointed that there was no reward at the end. When developers put so much effort in to building interesting and realistic environments they should give you more bonus stuff for exploring.

I must say I wasn't a whole lot suprised to find out that this game runs on the same engine that Doom 3 uses. They really are very similar. Overall I would say this game is worth the $50 I paid for it, but it didn't blow me away like Doom 3 or Half Life II.

title: Great nose piece but headband needs work. text: This X-super Home product for the Oculus Quest 2 comes with a headstrap and silicone face cover. Both of these things are accessories that every Quest 2 must get and there are many options available to fit the bill.

Out of the box, the Quest 2 comes with elastic straps that just aren't enough to hold the VR Goggles in place very well. When turning your head, the goggle tends to swing around and feel like they will fall off. Also, if you're one of the early adopters that purchased the Quest 2 before Facebook issued their recall where they will send you a silicone cover for the goggles, you're stuck with a cloth face cover that lets too much light through and gets pretty disgusting after just a short time using the goggle due to sweat.

So the X-Super Home head strap features a battery holder at the back of the head, the theory being that the extra weight of the battery will help to counter balance the weight of the goggles, reducing neck strain while extending the play time of the goggles. In practice, the battery makes the entire setup too heavy and reintroduces the problem of the goggles swinging around when turning your head. In addition, there was a design error on the attachment bracket where the slot is shorter than the tab so the battery holder never fully slides into place.

Due to the placement of the battery, the tightening knob is offset to the right of the battery. This offset design creates a problem with the tightening system where one side would tighten more than the other, giving an unbalanced feel to the strap.

The silicone cover, on the other hand, is quite excellent. It has a texture on it that helps to keep a good grip around the eyes even when you sweat and the flaps over the bridge of the nose is larger than many others out there. While not perfect, it greatly reducing the amount of light that leaks in. Compare this to the silicone cover that Facebook sent as part of their recall, the Facebook cover is smooth and doesn't have a flap at all to cover the bridge of the nose. The X-super Home cover is much better.

So a less-than-ideal head strap and a great silicone cover. Unfortunately, this doesn't justify the price of this product.

title: of all keyboards, mechanical gaming keyboards are my personal favorite

title: A game worth playing. text: For awhile I was on nothing but destiny. I still love it. However I swayed away because I needed the change, and variety is important. I started with Dying light, side note here is that if you like a zombie game go get dying light right now. I loved the sh** out of that game. Could've been a bit longer.. I personally got rid of it after completion because I won't wait for or purchase "add on" garbage. because that's all it is.

Back to this game.
Graphically 4/5 I think theres some parts they could've improved but overall it's rather good. the system runs a little rough here and there, but It hasn't effected or bothered my game play yet. The classes are fun to be part of although I immediately changed my classes after getting through the first part with one class. If you've played DA in the past this is essentially a must have to feel complete.
The story is huge and i'm constantly picking up a new quest here and there while trying to complete another one for some fool who can't carry a sword to protect themselves.
I haven't even came to killing a dragon yet (although one killed me because I walked up on its roost and spooked it) and I'm already immersed in and loving this game. The more you get into this game the stronger it will hold you. There's endless areas to explore, things to collect, and evil doers to slay.

The menu system I think could've used a little bit of work as well, although i have grown more used to it. I get a bit mixed up gearing up all 4 of my characters at once trying to remember which one wears what can be stressful. however once you get past the rush style life we're used to and pay attention to what you have, one can carefully plan a magic defense, distance, or CQC defense depending on what area you're coming up on to attack.

I did do this game as a download through xbox live i'm not sure if the disk is any different but something I do love is that I turn on my xbox, watch some netflix or something and when I go back to the game it's loaded where I left, no boot up or anything, simply constantly ready. It's rather nice. It's made doing whatever I want or need to do easy and seamless to switch back to my game.

I've yet to get through the first map that i scouted a town at initially... i foresee many travels in my future. If you're up for a relax, tactical, strategic based game in which you can manage a few different classes at one time, watch reviews, see a twitch, check some youtube, and pick it up. this is NOT a fast paced game in any way.

title: Excellent gaming / everyday mouse text: I bought this mouse without reading many of the reviews. I searched for "silent mouse" and followed a trail of products until I landed on this Logitech G502 HERO mouse. I don't know if it was advertised as quiet or silent, but it doesn't matter too much at this point. The mouse is very well crafted, and the weights that are provided allow you to customize how heavy the mouse is. I didn't think this would make a big difference, but it truly does. The weight keeps the mouse parallel to the desk surface but doesn't seem to inhibit movement at all. It's a fantastic feeling. Additionally, the mouse is wired, which eliminates having to worry about batteries or latency with a wireless connection.
I use this mouse for gaming and for everyday office use, but gamers who are more "serious" about their gaming will find all the bells and whistles needed. There are around 10 buttons on this mouse, and the software that is downloaded from the Logitech website makes setting up the functions very easy.
I believe this mouse was under $40 or $50 dollars when I bought it, and it is worth every penny in my opinion.
(By the way, it is not a quiet or silent mouse, but the clicks don't make much more noise than you'd expect of a high quality mouse.)

title: Audio quality is not acceptable to me, even for phone calls, even for $24 text: Audio quality is not acceptable to me, even for phone calls, even for $24. This headset looked perfect for my needs - especially the 3.5 mm phone plug with 4 conductor bands, needed to pair with today's laptops and cell phones, which require that plug to get audio into and out of devices.

Unfortunately, the audio quality was bad, with missing high and low frequencies. I don't demand high-end audio quality for $24, but a headset must be better than this. I returned this unit for a refund and bought a Koss SB/45 headset instead, which has very good audio sound quality for its $23 price, so much so that I could recommend that unit as a budget audio headphone, when you're not making phone calls!

title: Best Game Collector's Edition Ever
text: If you're here for an opinion on whether this is worth the money, well, obviously, only you can answer that question.  I will say that three years ago, I was completely blown away by the awesome Songbird collector's edition for Bioshock Infinite and Recore's CE even dwarfs that one.  This is not in any way a cheap product.  The creators clearly spared no expense, especially the magnificent centerpiece of a statue.  It's tall, wide, heavy, and intricately detailed. The box and heck, even the Styrofoam that holds the statue is done up right!  The lithograph envelope is embossed and the lithograph itself is on nice, thick stock with vibrant color.  Whether you prefer a metal disc case (very well done, inside and out) or a traditional X1 case to line up with your other games, you're covered.  One thing to be aware of with this collection, however, is that it is a physical copy ONLY of the game which means the Xbox/Windows 10 Play Anywhere will not work with it.  The game itself is fantastic for those who like old school action adventure platformers ala Jak and Daxter or the Metroid Prime series.  All in all, worth every penny in my book.

title: A good gaming keyboard and other uses too.
text: I really like this keyboard.  I don't use color schemes, I only use the white light so that I can see the keys SO much better.  It took me a while to adapt to the touch because a long time ago I was taught to type on a manual typewriter!  Yes, I know, I'm ancient.  LOL!  However, I'm gradually learning to lighten my touch and it has increased my typing speed.  Also, I don't find it to be that loud - possibly because I don't pound on the keys.  I also like the fact that the letters, numbers, etc. on the keys will not wear off - big plus for me.  I do play Fortnite, but this is not just a gaming keyboard, it's  a very good keyboard for many, many needs.  I would recommend this keyboard to gamers and non-gamers.

title: Great until it stopped working text: I was using this on a gaming pc, things were great for months. Then out of the blue it disconnected and wouldn't reconnect. Synapse couldn't find it, device manager couldn't either. Other usb devices worked fine, and trying this is a different slot didn't change anything.

So I tried it on my work laptop. It surprisingly started working. However it has had every issue under the sun. Sometimes all the LED's will just stop lighting up. Only way to get them back is to restart. Other times it will complete change my key colors and go to a solid color with no animation.

Now it has decided to DC and reconnect every few seconds. I'm done with razer. Their synapse software is buggy and sucks, and it is dumb I have to login just to get updates.

Will be checking out competitor's mice and keyboards.
