title: Kids love it....mom not so much.
text: I got this game specifically for my 3 year old who LOVES stories.  Of course, she is too small to read the story herself but with the picture book game she loves to sit and listen.  My 8 year old loves to use the microphone (its included) to read the stories to her little sister.  You can turn the voice changer on or off while reading (some of the voices can be scary to sensitive children).  My 8 year old doesn't always follow the words and sometimes makes up her own (she thinks she's a comedian).  They only supply you with 16 stories or so some of which I haven't heard before.  The stories must be the original versions because the are very very sad and some are kind of graphic.  One, in particular, titled "The Little Match Girl" is especially sad (the child dies in the street).  Also, old favorites like "Little Red Riding Hood" has a hunter who promptly takes a scissors to cut Grandma and Red Riding Hood out of the wolf's stomach while he sleeps.  Obviously, it doesn't SHOW it but the hunter has a pair of scissors in his hand and afterwards they fill the wolf's stomach up with rocks while he his sleeping.  Like I said, it is probably the original version of the children stories which may be a bit to harsh for a sensitive child.  Overall, the idea is fun but I think the price is a bit expensive for what you get.

title: HALO is a Godsend to gamers everywhere! text: I must admit, I was very skeptical when I hear HALO was being moved from PC to XBOX. After playing the final version for the last week I can say this is honestly the best game I have ever played!!
I am a hardcore PC shooter fan, but after getting used to the controls I thought they played just as well as a keyboard/mouse! The graphics in this game? Phenomenal. The computer AI? WOW. The music? Fantastic.
When I first got in a fire-fight, and my marines started shouting tactical information (and all with their own unique voices) my jaw hit the floor. And to see my opponents using clever squad tactics against me was Awesome! And to play through the game on Legendary difficulty took me over 80 hours of continuous action-packed gameplay! And I am a FPS Veteran! Oh, and the story is very engrossing.
Buy this game and you will not regret it. HALO is honestly the BEST game I have ever played.

title: Five Star Keyboard text: I have been on what feels like a very long search for the 'ideal' keyboard for the office. After only one day on this keyboard, I know I made the right choice in resuming my search. I have other mechanical keyboards (ALPS, Cherry MX Blue, even Buckling-spring with the original IBM 'clicky' keyboard purchased off eBay), but none are wireless. I gave up on wireless capability, thinking there was no such thing as a wireless mechanical keyboard.

On cheaper mechanical keyboards, I encountered issues related to build quality. On mechanical keyboards within the same price range (and the IBM 'clickly' keyboard), noise was a factor. The issue was not related to disturbing anyone as I typed; noisy Cherry MX Blue or Buckling-spring keyboards inevitably become a distraction (for me) when I have to concentrate (while typing).

There is a huge difference between this keyboard and membrane/pressure pad and chiclet keyboards - but anyone who has used a mechanical keyboard would know this right away. There is also a discernible difference between this keyboard and the other (wired) mechanical keyboards that I already own. Perhaps it's because this is the first, and so far only, keyboard I have used with Cherry MX Brown keys. The keys are tactile but do not require heavy pressure. And, this the only mechanical keyboard (that I am aware of) that is wireless.

My typing is more accurate and much faster (95wpm versus approximately 65wpm on typingtest dot com). This keyboard allows me to concentrate on work rather than be hampered by the tedium of typing. It makes typing almost effortless, and dare I say, even enjoyable. The biggest compliment I can pay to this keyboard is to buy at least two more - one to use at home and one as backup.

title: Large capacity, sturdy, but poor design text: This organizer sound good in theory, but it's really not very practical. I got excited that it holds 80 games, but when I started putting my games in the sleeves, I quickly realized that it's not easy. It requires 2 hands to put a game into a sleeve. If you look at picture 1, you can see that the sleeve doesn't open easily by pushing the game into it. You need to use 1 hand to pull the sleeve open and your other hand to push the game into the sleeve. I found this to be very inconvenient, especially if you're going to fill it with 80 games.

My other big issue with the organizer is that the sleeves hide the labels of the games. I'm not removing any stars because of this because it's something I should have realized before I ordered it. If you look at picture 2, you can see that you can barely see any of the game titles, and even then, they aren't readable. The product images also demonstrate this, but it doesn't look quite as severe. Since you only see the red Switch label sticking out, it's difficult to organize your games alphabetically and difficult to retrieve them without pulling the game out to see if you got the right one.

I didn't use the tempered glass because I don't have the OLED model. I mainly ordered this for the game organizer case.

TLDR;

Overall, great value, but it's not convenient to use. If you really don't mind the inconveniences, then this is a great purchase.

Pros
- Sturdy
- Holds tons of games
- Good value
Cons
- Sleeves hide game labels
- Difficult to get the games into the sleeves

title: This game would be a LOT better if it had good documentation text: Did I play the same game the other reviewers did? Seriously?
Maybe it's just the version I got, but this game is far too flawed to enjoy on any kind of consistent basis. Commands are not detailed in the manual or on the tutorial (for example, how to QUIT). There is no ingame help system, either. There is no explanation for important concepts like question marks over buildings in the tutorial.. the manual just says to look at them, decide what to do, and handle it. Overall, the tutorial was almost useless as a way of learning the game. Each segment of it appeared to last about 2 minutes and provide about 10 text lines of material, most of it encouragement. The manual, incidentally, can only be retrieved from the CD using Explore -- the CD auto-runs any other way you try to access it. It sure has a lot of pretty pictures, but it doesn't tell you how to quit either, or how to get tools, the shortage of which I tended to knock up against on a regular basis.
Graphics are blocky, but survivable. There is no explanation of what stars mean in the initial game setup -- I thought it was a rating system, but turns out it's probably a difficulty level. I still have no idea why I couldn't build a warehouse on the scenario I tried -- I had enough stuff, but it just didn't want to do it.
I suppose if I were more intuitive or more patient I could probably figure it out, but as it is, it's just too frustrating to play.

title: New to Super Smash Bros. and I love it! text: This review is coming from the POV of someone who is new to Super Smash Bros. This is the only Super Smash Bros. game I have ever played, so if you are reading my review in hopes of a comparison to the older games, you might want to skip this review and go to another.

When I first picked up this game I wasn't sure I'd get into it. I knew it was a popular game that everyone was raving about, but after watching youtubes and trailers I just wasn't sure. However, I figured I'd give it a chance. Afterall, I've been a Nintendo fan ever since the NES games. I've played many Mario games in the past, just never Super Smash Bros. There's a first time for everything, right?

So after popping this baby in and picking up the controller, nostalgia hit me when I saw some classic stages and old characters from the NES/Sega Genesis days of my childhood. I also enjoyed the many characters there were to choose from, and the fact that more could be unlocked. They even added R.O.B. the Robot and the Dog from NES Duck Hunt (If you were like me, you wanted to shoot that dog for always laughing at you back in the day. Now you can get your revenge on him -once he's unlocked of course).

As for the gameplay, I had to teach myself a little bit by looking up the controls on how to do each move. I'm still a bit on the sloppy side since I'm brand new to all of this, but that's part of the learning experience. You could also just smash buttons like a crazy person (great for children if you have any lol) and still hit your opponents that way, but I prefer to learn the right moves. It's more fun that way for me to have total control over my character.

Oh, and I'd also like to add that I love all the controller options! You can choose between the Wii U Gamepad, 3DS (That's right, if you have one you can use it as a controller for this game!), Classic Controller, Wii Remote, Wii Remote plus Nunchuck, Gamecube controller (either the adapter or the one that plugs into the Wii Remote) ... You have so many options to choose from. I personally prefer the gamecube or the classic controller, but it's entirely up to you and your tastes! My husband prefers his 3DS as a controller (Btw, unlike myself, he's been playing Super Smash Bros. ever since the very first one came out back in the day and he LOVES this game).

Overall, this is a great game that the entire family can enjoy playing together. I highly recommend it!

title: Amazing! text: I am in love with this console.

The graphics are amazing. I love the look of the games on this system. The sound is impeccable. We run it off a 7.1 surround system, and I've had moments where a twig will snap behind me, or a beast will roar off to the left. It is a bit more precise that I'm used to in how it handles locating sound between speakers, by firing both off but not at the same volume. I really love that.

The controller is so comfortable. I had some problems early on with the rubber coming off, but each time Sony was great about quickly replacing the controller. The audio jack on the controller means even the most basic headset can be effectively wireless for gaming. I did not think I would like the touchpad, but now I love it. It has an accelerometer, so for Infamous: Second Son, when you are using the controller like a can of spray paint, you have to turn it sideways and shake it. And the embedded speakers are such, it sounds like a can of spray paint being shaken. The PS3 controller always bothered me a little that it is too easy to inadvertently push down the left thumbpad (so it thinks you hit L3) when you are trying to run around. I've yet to encounter that problem with this one, not even doing the various rundown sections of Assassin's Creed: Black Flag.

Sharing in-game video is quick and easy. It works so well, and so fast. I didn't think I would use that, but it turns out I kind of like sharing awesome moments on Facebook. I'm very much a solo gamer, and the library for that is still very impressive.

If you have PlayStation Plus, your games are backed up online. When I upgraded the hard drive, which is ridiculously simple, I just redownloaded my games, already in progress. It picked up where it left out without a hitch.

For stability, for elegance, for performance, and most importantly, for incredible game play, I give the PS4 five stars.

title: Nice keyboard even if you're not a gamer text: There's no doubt that this keyboard is intended for gamers. It's got weird stylized lettering on the keycaps, the sides of the keyboard glow, and of course there's the animated crazy lighting effects of the keys themselves. The lighting effects are described in a small two-page "manual", sort-of; the effects are named poetically, I guess you'd say; "the dragon and the tiger spread their wings" is one effect for example. Or maybe more than one; it's hard to say. It's fun to fool with it, for a while at least, though for me the only really useful modes are with the keyboard set up with plain boring continuous backlight.

Now, all that said, once I got used to the keyboard after having used a Deck for years and years, I *really* like typing on it. The keys are clicky and they definitely make noise, but they feel great. The keyboard casing is quite solid, with the aluminum top curving around in front, translucent plastic on the left and right sides and in the back, and black plastic underneath. The keyboard barely flexes if I try a "twist test" from the sides (not that that's representative of actual use). Mainly I'm just really enjoying the keyboard for ordinary boring work use; I'm not a gamer. Great value for the money.

After setting up CloneHero on my PC, I got the guitar assembled (super easy, 2 parts and some batteries). I plugged the dongle in, and it connected up immediately, no pairing needed. I followed the instructions included to get it set up (as a keyboard) in CloneHero, and away I went! I had to adjust the hardware input calibration a bit, but then I was playing again! It feels exactly like my Guitar Hero controllers of old, nice stiff buttons and very responsive. The whammy bar works great, and the tilt to activate star power never missed for me. 100% recommend to get back into the rhythm games!

title: Honestly one of the most entertaining games I have ever played text: Borderlands 2 is not a complicated game. It's a first person shooter (FPS) which is focused on all-out shooting and looting. And more shooting. And more looting. And then some more.

What makes the game so entertaining, then?

There are a few key areas. The first is the setting and the characters, both of which are steeped in humor and pure entertainment value. The graphical "style" of Borderlands 2 contributes to this -- it follows from the original Borderlands in following an animated comic book style of graphics, but upgrades this significantly with lighting and colors beyond what we saw in the original. This graphical style is supremely appropriate for the kind of setting and characters, and humor, that the game contains, because the game is not aiming for a "realistic" feel, but rather a more contrived, less serious, more funny, and ultimately more entertaining one. And this works to beat the band. It keeps the game light-hearted and fun, which makes it a great game to play after work in the evening as compared with a more "serious" game.

Another core area that makes the game great is the loot/leveling model. Although the game doesn't feature the same loot explosion/loot pinata effect of the original, nevertheless loot keeps flowing, and one of the core enjoyments of the game is comparing and optimizing your loadouts. And many of the weapons are just very, very entertaining to use. In addition, each class has a signature power which can be built upon and upgraded and which defines playstyles that are markedly different for each class despite the fact that the game is essentially a shoot and loot game.

The game is, in many ways, a hybrid of the loot system of an "action RPG" like Diablo or Torchlight, on the one hand, and a first person shooter, on the other, with a lot of humor thrown into the mix. It makes for a very entertaining game to unwind with, and ultimately an enjoyable and relaxing gaming experience. Frankly, this game is just pure fun to pick up and play, even if you are not generally a shooter fan. Highly recommended.

title: It works--barely text: I bought this figuring that a cheap s-video cable is all I needed and under the assumption that the cable sold by MS couldn't be that good anyway. What do I mean, well there is moire--lots of moire, anywhere it could exist it does. I didn't even realize that it could be that bad. It is distracting, even on the dashboard. In addition, there is a lot of dot crawl. It makes everything, games, videos, dvds, etc look rather bad. To be honest both issues make the composite signal (on the component adapter that came 360) seem quite a bit better. I guess I got what I paid for. At least the audio seems OK. I'd avoid this if you can.

title: 4.5 stars - great game
text: This game is awesome.  It would get 5 stars except for a couple negative things:  First of all, I would think someone from Remington would review the weapons being used in the game since a lot of the weapons are manufactured by Remington.  For example, most shotguns can only hold 3 rounds unless there's a magazine extension attached.  I've earned a shotgun that holds 12 rounds!  Great fun, but not realistic.  Yes, I know this is a shoot 'em up hunting game, and sometimes they do have to bend the rules a little to make it more playable.  I personally own an 870 SuperMag Turkey gun, and even with the mag extension, in real life, it only holds 6 + 1 in the barrel.  Ok, I know I'm nit-picking, but get it right, would ya?  The game creators did such a great job on this game that I would think they shoulda got the guns right.  Another gripe I have is the high-powered rifles that shoot the powerful 30 caliber rounds don't take down the game as well as the shotgun or bows do.  The bow is actually one of the best overall weapons you can use for big game, and the shotgun is great for small game and birds.  The bow usually takes down big game with one shot.  The shotguns are probably the best all-around weapons.  It's kinda cheesy, in my opinion, to use the shotgun to kill everything.  You can really rack up some combos with the shotgun, tho, because you are actually hitting the targets but not killing them with one shot.  Another thing I don't like is switching from weapon to weapon.  It would be nice if you could just pick a couple weapons like the bow, the shotgun, and one rifle, and have just 3.  Just like Cabela's Dangerous Hunts 2011, you switch weapons with the joystick on the nunchuck.  It's not too bad, but you actually have 5 weapons to choose from when you earn them, and in a pressure situtation, you can over-manipulate the joystick and pick the wrong weapon.  You have a bolt-action rifle, a semi-automatic rifle, a shotgun, a handgun, and a bow.  So far, I've determined the semi-automatic rifles and handguns are almost worthless in the game.  Starting out, your bolt-action rifle and bow are your best friends.  I'm using a 40" flatscreen TV, and it's still difficult to determine which rifle is which sometimes.  I actually look at the magazine capacity to tell which one is which most of the time.  That's another thing--I personally own a Remington 760 Gamemaster, and it does not hold 20+ rounds!  It holds 4+1 in the chamber in real life!  Anyway, I'm using my TopShot Elite rifle for this game.  I personally think it's the best option.  The Z button is the trigger, and the C button is the reload button.  A player shoots so much, it's nice to have the softer buttons.  It's also nice to have them located together.  I tried this game with my Wii Zapper, my CTA Sureshot rifle, and the TopShot, and like I said, the TopShot was and is definitely the best option for me.  High scores demand accuracy for this game (a lot like Grand Slam North America), so it's nice to use a rifle-type controller with a stock for stability's sake.  You don't ever want to miss to make it thru some of the levels.  I have made it through the first 18 levels in about 6 hours, and several of them are extremely challenging.  I think I have 3 more levels to go, and Level 19 is almost impossible!  I think the idea of the game is to get at least a bronze medal on each level, and then go back and get a gold medal on each level after you've unlocked the best weapons.  Ok, all that having been said, the game is extremely challenging, but also extremely fun.  There are so many critters to shoot that it's darn near impossible to get them all.  The sound effects and graphics are tremendous.  The music is also very good.  I know I concentrated a lot on nit-picking the negatives, but play this game for yourself, and you will see how good it is.  I put it in the same class as Cabela's Dangerous Hunts 2011 and Top Shot Arcade.  Overall, a very excellent game--well worth the money.

title: jrpg with spaceship spin...I really wanted to like it
text: This is not a space trading game and it is not a 4x strategy space game.  This is an rpg with a story-line and allows you to buy and customize your spaceships for battle.  It has the flow of games like Front Mission with different battle mechanics.  The story is your standard save the universe jrpg set in the future (not bad and not original).  Exploration is not very interesting just going from point to point to figure out where to advance the plot.  The battle mechanics are interesting with one ship but it is extremely repetitive and becomes boring.  I thought the ability to buy more ships for your party/fleet would spice things up and add more strategic elements to the game but it played out much like having a single ship.  I still wanted it to be good after 7 hours or but didn't so I didn't torture myself by thinking it would get better.  Graphically it was okay.  Sound and music were okay.  I had much higher expectations and cannot recommend this game.

title: Extremely disappointing. I bought it for the multiplayer, but doubt my friends any I will be playing it for very long. text: Highly disappointing so far. Very bad matchmaking, no locale only option, party chat isn't allowed in any group game type other than Ground War, group members dropped joining games can't tell you because you're in game chat, and there's no option to leave games as a party, forcing everyone to quit out separately. I sincerely hope a patch comes soon, but there are a lot of things that would need to be fixed to make this enjoyable.

I bought COD4 weeks after it had come out, so it could have had buggy matchmaking at it's release as well, but none of the eight people (friends and friends of friends) I just played with had seen issues like this with COD4 or COD:WaW. The matchmaking isn't necessarily fast, you can wait for a while before the game finally tries to match you with other people, but regardless of whether it was fast or slow, we were losing party members more than half the time. That is unacceptably bad. As the party leader, I've got an open NAT on a fixed IP that I pay an additional monthly fee for used only by my Xbox 360, on a connection with 3ms ping, 94.63 Mb/s upload and 65.67 Mb/s download. ([...])

I fail to understand how, with that connection, people who connect to me with no problems, who play COD 4 and COD:WaW with me with no problems, don't even have a 50/50 chance of joining a game with me successfully.

When we did lose people, they had no way of telling us, we had to figure out who was and who wasn't there. If Modern Warfare 2 would allow Party Chat, they'd be able to say, "Hey guys, I got booted." But virtually every game mode requires you to leave party chat to play. Even game modes where you can speak the entire time. Yes, you do have the option to mute people rather quickly, and my friends who played for several hours today muted hundreds of people today...but even then, if you want to talk with your friends about work, life and the game while playing, you have no idea who could be listening in to your conversation. If this is supposed to make us talk to people, it's just going to result in groups of people talking over each other, as I expect quite a lot of people will keep chattering away, but will have either muted everyone who's not their friend or set their Xbox settings so they can only hear people on their friends list. (The Xbox 360 party chat function had meant that that wasn't necessary...but if I do keep playing this game, I may have to set my account chat setting to friend list only...which I'd rather not do.)

When we did finally get into a game, over half the games we entered were yellow connections or worse, and the majority of those were quit out of because the connection was so bad it was unplayable. The same problem plagued Call of Duty 4 but wasn't nearly this bad. Treyarch was able to add a "Local" and "Locale Only" search option to Call of Duty: World at War, which allowed my friends and I to wait for a good game. If it took 15 minutes to get a game going, it was better than spending 30 minutes jumping out of unplayable games that we were repeatedly thrown into, losing friends on the way, and constantly having to reinvite people to the party but being unable to talk with them half the time due to the lack of Party Chat. (Party chat allows you to talk during loading screens and when people are booted or trying to join.) Infinity Ward failed to recognize how beneficial the "Locale Only" search option was, which was a key reason World at War was my group of friends' game of choice over the last year. After a full year of caring about each win (2,747), and loss (645), in World at War, I'm already of the mentality that I don't care about taking a loss in Modern Warfare 2, because the number of unplayable connections and friends lost when joining games is going to mean that dropping out of games is going to become a regular occurrence again. Win/loss stats mean nothing again.

Treyarch's World at War was also smart enough to include a "Leave with party" option that meant the party leader could pull everyone out of a game together. If someone was getting a drink or using the restroom, the party leader didn't need to wait for them to return to change game types. In MW2, everyone needs to quit out individually, and again, without Party Chat, people sometimes get lost.

Yes, Spec Ops is enjoyable, and I'm sure the Single Player campaign is enjoyable...but I bought this game for the single player, and the sheer volume of frustrating moments far outweighs the few really enjoyable games that were had. Even if the matchmaking is fixed, I don't see myself jumping in night after night to play Ground War over and over, and the lack of Party Chat is a huge strike against the enjoyability of this game.

I'm sure all my friends will pick this up, and I'm sure we'll play it for weeks...but unlike the +10 days of game time that we put into COD4 or the +15 days that we put into COD:WaW, I don't expect to be coming back to the multiplayer unless some major changes are made to fix the matchmaking and allow Party Chat. (I understand the lack of party chat in S&D...I fail to understand the reason for excluding it from other game types.)

As for the harsh grade, I would have gladly paid $60 for an updated version of COD4 or COD:WaW with new maps, weapons and other extras. I don't need a single player campaign or Spec Ops or anything else. I just needed an enjoyable multiplayer that my friends and I could play while we talked and had fun. The game does a very poor job of providing that. The underlying game looks like it could be great, but the hoops needed to jump through to get into one of those games with friends you can talk to is shocking.

------ UPDATED ------

I posted this review to the IW forums a few days ago, and I received the reply: "...these problems with matchmaking will sort themselves out eventually with our constructive feedback to IW."

I hope so. That reply made me think that my review could have been more constructive, and on the off chance that anyone from IW would read it, I made a list of constructive criticism that could help them. I thought that list might be worth adding here, as it clearly points out some of the things this game is lacking, possibly better than my original review did.

Please note that the list below is strictly focused on matchmaking, UI and the ability to play this game with your friends. None of the suggestions would impact the gameplay itself.

Here are the things I think urgently need to be addressed, as they're easy to fix but complete game breakers for many:

1. Party Chat: Put party chat back in for everything but S&D. Put in an MLG game room or whatever alternative rooms you want for angry young racists with a mic that don't want anyone using Party Chat, and let them yell at each other in there. Those of us who view online games as a social outlet to play with friends want this...BADLY. Even Penny-Arcade is wondering why this decision was made. If it was to keep us from talking after we die...why can we still talk after we're dead in game chat in every game type I've played so far? (I have not played S&D yet) Is it technologically impossible to prevent people in Party Chat from playing on the other team? I would love it if Party Chat guaranteed that people in your party would be on your team.

2. Match Making - Lost Team Members: I'm still repeatedly losing party members when trying to get games going. Is this really that difficult to fix? I can understand there are bugs that need to be worked out, but thanks to the lack of Party Chat, there's no way for dropped people to let their team know they've been dropped. A message like, "Party Members were unable to join the game, would you like to back out and get them or continue the game without them?" would be helpful. Baring that, making your squad members easy to visually differentiate (possibly a blue background or text for everyone in the party) which would make it possible to quickly confirm all X number of party members made it. Also, just enabling Party Chat would make it easier to communicate in cases where some people don't make it.

3. Match Making - Bad Connections: I'm still regularly being thrown into games where we have unplayable connections (people in our squad will be all red and yellow connections, even when there's six of us geographically within 20 km of each other jumping into a 6-on-6 game). A "Locale Only" option would be very welcome. I'm happy to sit around for minutes waiting for a playable game. I doubt a patch will come soon enough to make me care about my W/L stats...so I will continue jumping out of games with bad connections...but again, I'm more than willing to wait for a game where everyone on both teams has a reasonable playable connection. Net code improvements? Server upgrades? You guys can do whatever you want there...but until I see a "Locale Only" or "Maximum acceptable ping" or similar option, I'll be of the assumption that you really don't care about my interest in a playable connection, and my team will keep jumping out of matches with bad connections, which is a less than ideal solution when it isn't an issue in other games...

The following are improvements that seem obvious to me, most of which are probably seen in the majority of online games:

1. Leave with Party: This one is obvious. If a group of friends playing together wants to change games types, the party leader should have the option to leave with group. The group can enter games together...why can't they leave games together? COD:WaW did this, so it can't be hard to implement. Everyone dropping in and out separately is annoying enough when you are able to use Party Chat. It's horrible without Party Chat.

2. Add to Squad: There were squads in COD that meant we didn't all have to jump out every time a friend jumped on. They could join the game and if they were on our team, they could join our squad and stay on our team without everyone having to drop out and try to jump back into a game again. Again, this was in COD:WaW, so it can't be that hard to implement and it keeps people playing instead of having them search for games...(with the currently inevitable booting of people randomly and joining games with unplayable connections.)

3. "Invite" option: Why would I want to invite people from the game menu and then play against them? The only benefit I can see for this is people who spam invite people they've played against and beaten... If I use the invite option to invite a friend, I want to play with them. Why not have invites sent this way automatically add them to your squad when they accept? I don't want random spam invites to play against people I don't know, and I was excited at the possibility that we could just invite friends to our team without quitting out of the game.

4. X to skip: I'm not big on skipping levels, and I haven't played enough to dislike any levels enough to skip, so I didn't notice this at first, but why make skipping more difficult than it needs to be? Neither this or the items the follow below are nearly as important as the first six points in my mind.

5. Volume control: Another option I used in World at War that disappeared is the ability to adjust individual volume sliders for the game sound effects, music, and other noises. I have A40 headphones now, so it's no longer an issue for me personally, but if someone's trying to keep the volume at a reasonable level, let them lower the BGM slider and other non game sounds while keeping the SFX (the important game sounds) at the highest setting. When I did adjust these settings, I never felt it gave me any sort of advantage in hearing people in the game, it just lowered the pre and post game music enough to placate my wife.

Lastly, improvements that I'd like to see when getting into games with friends and having fun is taken care of:

1. Barracks Leaderboards: Where did the breakdown by game type go? I could care less about K/D in any game type other than Deathmatch, as that's the only time it's the main point. Even in Free-For-All, killing 25 people and dying 20 times is better than killing 15 people and not dying if you're playing in the spirit of the game...so why create leaderboards that encourage people to focus on kills in game types that focus on objectives? (In the last COD game, I'm 2.27 k/d in TDM and 1.5 in Headquarters, but I believe I have a better win rate in HQ because I play the game...) The new stat system leaves a lot to be desired. It would be great to see a lot of information available, and I understand this may be coming in the future.

2. Lobby Leaderboard: Something to look at between matches when you aren't adjusting classes, and wondering who exactly you're playing with and against.

3. Online Leaderboards: Again these are all things that can be added in the future, and would add to the fun, but aren't as important as the points above: Online stats, iPhone app, Web based challenges you can complete in game, being able to compare accolades with friends, being able to compare individual gun stats with friends, stats by game type, trending stats (k/d average for each hour of a given game type, etc.), etc, etc, etc. There's plenty of data people would love to gobble up, and stats added to my enjoyment of Halo 3 and Call of Duty: World at War. But really, it's secondary to all the multiplayer issues I listed above, and I'd be very happy if IW took those points into consideration and made changes to improve the multiplayer experience for everyone.

Honestly speaking, if all the improvements above were made, my rating for multiplayer would probably be either 4 or 5 stars, depending on how multiplayer holds up over time...but even if there's a great game under all the BS, the BS is currently getting in the way.

As for single player, it's too short, the airport level killed the game for me, and the levels felt uninspired compared to COD4. (Rent, don't buy, if you're only interested in single player) Spec Ops is very enjoyable if you a friend to play it with, but it certainly wouldn't have a big impact on whether or not I recommend the game to someone.

As far as how "fun" this game is...I still feel two stars is the best rating with the current problems it has, and I will update this if IW ever addresses them.

title: Nearly flawless, but flawless for RPGs. text: The Hori Digital Controller for the GameCube is one of my ‚Äúgrail‚Äù controllers. For over a decade I've casually eyed this controller, seeing its price rise from high double digits to what it is now. Still, I don't think the price is that bad for such a unique controller. I love it when companies take their own, fresh perspective on standard controller layouts without making them unwieldy. Comfort is usually the driving force for change, as well as quality-of-life improvements. 8BitDo has been doing a fantastic job in this regard, and now Retro Fighters isn't far behind.

Retro Fighters (‚ÄúRF‚Äù) is doing wonderful things in the controller world. My first controller was the Brawler64 when it came out in different colors. (While I was aware of the Kickstarter, I avoided it out of personal reasons with Kickstarter itself.) It was love at first touch. It perfectly conformed to my hand and felt wonderful. The d-pad could use some refinement, but overall it's great. Fast-forwarding through a bunch of controllers, we arrive at the BladeGC. I knew I had to have it. Initially, I thought 8BitDo would release a controller like this, or at least some other company, so I was super excited when Retro Fighters announced it. Though I'd still like to get the Hori one some day, it's no longer a must; it's wired and doesn't have features for modern systems. Let's list the upgrades:
- grip
- analog sticks
- two more shoulder buttons
- vibration
- Switch/PC buttons
- wireless (and 2.4 GHz to boot!), with both a dongle for the GameCube and one for USB

Already this is the perfect upgrade to the Hori Digital Controller. The little Z button is missing on the front, but of course it's not a requirement.

I'll start with commenting on the d-pad. It's‚Ä¶phenomenal. I'm *very* picky about d-pads. Nintendo's of course are best, with Hori a close second. 8BitDo's may feel nice, but they have a habit of mis-presses. This can be remedied by opening the controller and applying binder reinforcement tabs; not ideal, but definitely alleviates the issue. But this d-pad? Damn‚Ä¶ My thumb *skates* across it. When I first opened it, I was a bit disappointed with how it felt. It's low and has straight corners. But during play is when I noticed how marvelous it is. I tried Crash Team Racing, Stardew Valley, and Shredder's Revenge. Every input was precise and correct, and my thumb was able to just skate across it with speed and accuracy. Mein Gott.

I haven't extensively used the analog sticks since I didn't get this controller for them, but I tested them with Smash. There's an octagonal gate for each stick, and each movement was comfortable and, for the time I spent using them, precise as well. They're smooth but don't let your thumbs slide off. The tops are flat, with the outer ring (textured for gripping pleasure) jutting up just enough to prevent thumbs from steering off. They don't have as wide an area to move as the GameCube controller, or maybe that's because they're not as tall, but they work well enough. Because of how wonderful this controller feels, I now plan to get the BattlerGC.

The vibration is subtle. I'm unsure whether there's an option to change the strength, but the manual doesn't indicate that so I don't think so. It's not too low so as not to feel it; in fact, I think it's the perfect strength if you prefer a little feedback without it dominating the hands. I've had some third-party controllers that freakin' rattled the whole controller. Super uncomfortable. The BladeGC's gives you just a small jolt to remind you that you got hit, loser.

And the wireless connectivity? A non-issue. Since this is not Bluetooth, it can't be used with the Switch when in handheld mode; instead, the USB dongle plugs directly to the dock. The Switch then reads it as a wired controller (which must be turned on in settings) and away you go. There is no discernible lag from what I noticed.

Now on to the ‚Äúbad.‚Äù

Material. The controller is already light enough, but the quality of the plastic is very light and feels hollow. There is no grip texture. Rather, the whole thing is smooth and my hands can slide a bit easily. This is something I noticed with other RF controllers, so I know it isn't just this. Based on how it feels, it doesn't feel like a premium controller, though I certainly consider it one.

Stick placement. There is little distance between the right stick and the B button. I have relatively small hands (5'8", so whatever size hand that coordinates to) and haven't moved the stick accidentally, but I always feel it when pressing the B button. This made me wonder how people with bigger thumbs will experience the controller.

But that's it. No more bad. Everything good. Oh, maybe the back shoulder buttons. I prefer ones that stop with a noticeable press, but these go just straight down like a lot of modern shoulder buttons. Gross. Maybe the sticks can be bigger too, but I'll wait until I try the BattlerGC to comment on that.

This will be my main controller for RPGs, or any other game that utilizes the d-pad and A button a lot.

B for materials and stick placement, A+ for everything else.

title: Better than Civ V, but no Master of Magic text: I remember the original Civilization. it's spawned many copies and variants since then, one of those being Master of Magic, which kept the basic theme of Civ, but added in races and magic to the mix. It also gave us the first appearance of heros.

Many of hte original writeups about Elemental suggested that it was going to be the sequel to Master of Magic. I looked forward to getting it, as I love this type of game, and trying to run the odl Dos Master of Magic on my computer doesn't work all that well.

Sadly, when Elemental first came out it did have major bugs taht left the game nearly unplayable. Fortunately Stardock didn't quit on the game and they have made numerous refinements and improvements. I have no had a crash in months, and the game appears stable.

Unfortunately, it still is no Master of Magic. The races are divided effectively into a light and dark side and the dark "Empire" races have a huge initial advantage due to their tech tree. They don't get some of hte top Techs that the light "Kingdom" races can obtain if they have enough time, but they do have a huge early advantage.

It doesn't help taht the AI isn't very good especially at dealing with a well organized "stack of death". If you have time to put together a powerful stack of 8-9 high level units, you can easily crush anything the computer sends against you. Tactics tend to be simple. Keep one stack together and build it up to a high level doing quests and killing the wandering monsters until its powerful enough to kill anything it faces.

The game is in my mind better than Civ V. It doesn't have the city states, but it offers more choices in the city management and tech choices.

A good game, but not a great one. I hate that I paid full price considering what I know now, but its not a horrible deal either.

title: sad to say not up to par

title: Excellent experience and GOTY contender. text: As a long time video gamer who never owned a PlayStation, the Metal Gear Franchise was brand new to me. I immediately jumped into the game and enjoyed the unfamiliar narrative and game perspective. The cinematic scenes are wonderful and lead the story along well.
If you have never played a Metal Gear game, throw the following games in a blender, add ice, and enjoy:
1) Just Cause 2
2) Tom Clancy's Splinter Cell
3) Farmville

The reasoning?
1 - The game has quite a bit of open world, wander around and have fun, but with objectives still tied.
2 - While you can be deadly and run-and-gun in this game (the path I'm taking more of), this game rewards you for being stealthy. You will spend half of your time planning and the half executing your plan.
3 - The game provides you a base to help in research new items and maintain a constant flow of materials and money to further your progress. While there isn't much of a grind to the game, I do find that I have to watch my funds and make decisions on what I want to progress on next.

Two cons for the PC version - no multiplayer as of yet. If multiplayer does matter to you, then I would recommend holding off until Konami announces that their multiplayer servers are stable. Second issue controlling your horse when using a keyboard and mouse. The riding experience is subpar as the controls for riding are not adjusted for WASD so your horse will not make good angular adjustments until you move your mouse in that specific direction. This is fine when running away, but makes life difficult when attempting to fire a weapon while riding.

Based on just the single player experience, MGS V:TPP is a worthy contender for Game of the Year (GOTY).

title: Quietest gadget - powerful & compact too!

I stacked the deck in my favor by using this soft spoken product and doling out freeze dried liver - in just 2 days our dog tolerated all 4 paws being done! Hope it's well-made, only time will tell on that.....but I am a pleased customer and  happy that my new comforter won't have to suffer tears because of scratchy claws anymore - HURRAY!

title: Fun tennis game for a week text: Nice graphics and use of real life players. A lot of pretty well designed mini games. Career mode is fun but could be a lot better. I do like the ability to improve your player to the top level.

The game control is okay, but it feels kind of fake and limiting.

Overall, I enjoyed this game for a week or two, but after that it just seemed like the same game over and over. I had fun with the game for a little bit so gave it a 3 rating for fun...but only a 2 overall rating because I expect to enjoy a game for more than a week or two. Other games (like golf) are similar where I take a break with them but I always come back to play them because of the skill and fun. This game however, I traded in for credit for other games as I never had the need to play it again.

Buy discounted or used if you want to just try it out...but I would recommend renting or not purchasing at all.

title: A very good book... text: Of course this was a good book. A very good book, in fact. I thought the author did an amazing job capturing the voices from the point of view of each of the characters. The weakest, to me, however, was the voice of August himself.

In any writing, I don't like my protagonist to be all good, and my antagonist to be all bad. The world doesn't work that way, and writing that reflects that doesn't feel honest to me. But for Middle Grade or Juvenile fiction, I think it is even more important to not have such a black and white world. I would have liked to have heard Julian's story, too. Knowing his motive would still have kept him the antagonist but it might help to show why he was lacking empathy.

Via, the sister's, voice was the strongest. Her story was also the most heartbreakingly honest.

title: Surprisingly good with a silly flaw text: The good news is that this controller is way better than a Wiimote in a plastic wheel. It's honestly a great solution for driving games without the bulk, hassle, and cost of a full fledged wheel setup but better than the standard controller or the aforementioned Wiimote setup. At first it was a tough transition from the standard controller at first, with oversteer being the biggest issue. In time my times improved, mostly by avoiding the wild spells of oversteer turning into a complete loss of control. As an added bonus, in Forza my corners used to score mostly 1s and 4s, where now I routinely get 2s and 3s (plus the 1s and 4s). I'm guessing it's showing a greater deal of consistency, and I know passing and drifting is way easier. Would a full wheel setup be better? Definitely, but it would take way more room in my living room. With this, I can throw it under the couch or whatnot.

The bad news? Well that's baffling. I understand the lack of analog sticks, as the wheel replicates most of that, but the wheel has no should buttons. That's a huge loss for driving/racing games, as these buttons often are used for shifting. Hell, even Microsoft's own Forza series uses it extensively for setup. I couldn't even change the setup (to reduce the oversteer I mentioned above), as you need shoulder buttons to tab over. Frankly I cannot fathom why Microsoft didn't find some place to put the buttons. Even a crappy location is better than nothing. The light up ends are gimmicky, and I'd rather have should buttons. Other than that, ergonomics aren't great. It's not a huge deal, but, it could be quite a bit better. Do know that this wheel isn't compatible with rechargeable battery packs, the charge and play kit, or and voice chat capability. Frankly it really doesn't seem like a 1st party effort. It does work beautifully wirelessly however.

In the end, I really like the controller. It didn't cost too much, and it's not another bulky peripheral. If it had shoulder buttons, it would be a 5 star product.

title: Only fits one way - funky

title: Nice hardware, terrible software text: This would be a 5 star product if the software wasn't so terrible. iCue is slow, buggy, and crashes on a regular basis. Sometimes the headset wakes up and works in seconds, other times it can drag out to 30+ seconds. If you click on iCue in the system tray to open it, the software might eventually open. Keyword: Might. Eventually. If it does open, moving from screen to screen takes longer than your Grandma would take to run a marathon.

For some reason the percentage of battery life remaining is buried in the settings, and only occasionally shows when connected. It doesn't show at all when charging so you have no idea how charged it is until you unplug it.

The firmware of the headset is version 0.02. Yes, ZERO POINT ZERO TWO. Sometimes the voice prompts play when you hit buttons, sometimes you just get beeps. If you press the mute mic button it mutes, but when you unmute it the sidetone shuts off so it sounds like your mic went dead when it didn't, until you either hit mute/unmute over and over or power the headset off and back on.

Sometimes when fully charged the light on the headset turns green. Sometimes it stays yellow for days, but when you unplug it from charging iCue shows it's at 100% charged but the software was just too buggy to make the light turn green consistently.

The mic is too quiet. Even maxed out it barely registers when you test it unless you have the mic so close to your lips it tickles. The only way to make it a reasonable volume is to install a third party equalizer app named Equalizer APO and boost the Mic gain using it. This means it's a software issue not a hardware one that Corsair hasn't bothered to fix despite threads on it being all over gaming forums.

The only complaint I have about the physical hardware is the buttons for mic mute and power is hard to find by touch as they're smooth and have no ridges or anything else to identify them. This is a 5 star piece of hardware hobbled by 1 star software. Considering this product has been on the market since August 2017 there's no excuse other than Corsair being too cheap and lazy to fix the software.

Go buy something made by a manufacturer who knows how to hire decent programmers, Corsair definitely can't.

title: Best boxing game available! text: Let me just say this game is nothing short of fantastic. The gameplay is smooth, controls are nice, graphics are great, and even the commentary is decent in this game.

Between fights you manually heal your cuts, which is cool. Your trainer will give you pep talks specific to your situation. Example: "You really need to block that right eye, or the ref is going to stop the fight, that cut is awful."

The controls are beautiful. There are 5 different configurations you can choose from.

Career mode is alright. Rivalries are random, and there doesn't seem to be much importance put into championships and such. The rivalry thing is rather lame. Before you fight a rival it'll show you at the weigh in and your opponent always punches you and you have a little mini fight in first person view. Not my favorite, but again it's not bad enough to deduct from the rating of the game.

Character customization is pretty cool. You can buy different pieces of gear including trunks, boots, mouthpiece, gloves, etc, all having attribute additions to your figther. Ex: Speed +20%.

The only major drawback to this game is that it is extremely easy. Even on the hard difficulty, with a weight class or two lower than your opponent, you almost have to TRY to lose.

I love this game, and I can't wait for round 4.

PS. This is an open challenge to anyone that plays this game that has an internet connection :) Email me!

title: Great sound, but major hardware and driver problems text: I am generally a fan of logitech and have two of their other headphones but I'm having a lot of issues with this one.

First the cable is too stiff and you can CONSTANTLY hear it in the headset scrapping against your shirt. You immediately become aware of just how much and how often your head moves. This noise is horribly loud and annoying. You can hear it even if the headset is not plugged into anything so this is a physical design issue.

The headset seems to work all of 20-30 seconds when using Google Voice, which was the primary reason I got them. Then it just simply cuts out speaker and microphone, EVERY SINGLE TIME! Basically useless.

It will however play music just fine. I even tried playing music, then starting a call. First it cut out the music, then the call, then a few seconds later the music cut back in. That's reliability.

So I decided to download their drivers rather than relying on Windows 8.1 drivers. Their drivers made all sound on my laptop useless. Gone is the smart switch from the headset to the laptop speakers when I unplug the headset or the other way around. So is the builtin ability to have a default sound system for playing music and a default system for communications.

Worst of all? The drivers stop the ability to open Sound from Control Panel. I rebooted, tried again, then went to uninstall their drivers/software. Surprise, the Sound settings popped up on its own as soon as the it was uninstalled. It was being held back by the software. HORRIBLE programming.

title: Had i looked into this, i wouldn't have bothered trying this. text: This is not what a diablo fan wanted.... this hits highs and lows of the games history..

First off a kind note, this game was meant for the PC and I Love it on the PC. I do however actually enjoy the ability of playing this through a controller, they did successfully make that fun and worth its while. it was slightly clunky, but overall was a good experience for someone whose used to a mouse and key on this game.

However, they let Microsoft manage the servers... .this made it both great and beyond useless at the same time.... I realize blizz can't do it all but the servers being monitored my MS left hacks and cheats easily entering the game and spreading like a virus. Where I don't mind this... is a almost nostalgia feeling of diablo 1 and some of diablo 2 where people had some hacked items, making the game a joke. however on the PC I enjoyed this aspect. I still replayed the game as there were still items i wanted to find and enjoyed being "legit". Maphacks were always my favorite i wasn't always huge on the items being hacked up. every corner i turn in the counsel version there are paragon level who even knows how they made it that far's, and not a one of them understands the grind that really should have been needed to acquire such a level. It's not that i'm hating on these people, some of them are the regular old school diablo players just enjoying the new and slightly nostalgia experiences.

if these servers were "monitored" by blizzard... kept at their standards. I would be more interest in continuous play on this game. I'm going back to enjoying my PC version. sadly hundreds of thousands of us have already bought this and made them all think it was a huge success. and for some people it is and it is fun... it's likely a lot of pc users will shelf this game before they get far however.

title: A design flaw of the keyboard is a huge problem text: I am making these comments as a non-gamer. It may be that this keyboard is made specifically for gamers and not meant to be used by anyone else. However, I have owned for some time another brand of gamer keyboard that I use regularly, and it doesn‚Äôt have the design flaw that this keyboard does.

Pros

1. It's appearance is attractive, especially the fact that it lights up in blue when plugged in.

2. This keyboard comes with a mouse, and the mouse is also very attractive. It lights up in blue and red when plugged in.

3. This keyboard is both full size and compact in design.

4. The price is reasonable.

Cons

1. A design flaw of the keyboard is a huge problem! I have been typing on a computer keyboard for 40 years. And on every keyboard I have ever used, the Enter key is one key to the right of the Single-Quote/Double-Quotes (‚ÄúQuote‚Äù) key. When you want to press the Enter key, you simply lift up your right pinky finger and move it over one key. Inexplicably, this keyboard includes an extra key between the Quote key and the Enter key! I cannot state strongly enough how enormous a negative this is. There may be some reason for gamers to have a keyboard designed this way, but the keyboard is useless for everyone else. It is simply unusable to me. As a touch typist, the first time I used it, I reached my finger to hit the Enter key and was shocked when nothing happened. I wasn't looking at the keyboard, and for several additional, frustrated taps, I tried again and again to engage what I naturally assumed was the Enter key. Then I looked at the keyboard, and I couldn't believe my eyes. I was hitting an alien key between the Quote key and the Enter key.

Why would anyone design a keyboard this way? If I tried to train myself to use this keyboard, I would quickly develop repetitive stress injury. It is much too far for my pinky to comfortably stretch to reach the Enter key.

Again, this keyboard may be designed specifically by gamers for gamers. But if you are not a gamer and just are looking for a glow-in-the-dark keyboard for a reasonable price, I highly recommend that you look elsewhere.

title: 3 Stars for Star Wars text: Pilot your own X-Wing and kill Tie fighters. Hop on a speeder and shoot rebels trying to escape. Use a freaking AT-ST (the little 2 legged mech) escorting an AT-AT (my favorite, the big 4 legged monster you see on the cover). Play as either Lord Vader or Emperor Palpatine clearing out a rebel base... Oh yeah all this content is in the tutorial so you can learn the controls before you start a mission.

The game lost 1 star for being Origin based only, Steam is the only platform I like... I've hated the Origin platform since my computer came with Battle Field 4 free and it was only redeemable via Origin. I prefer the Steam layout to view game library much better.

UPDATE: The game has now lost a 2nd star from the review, at first I was like COOL check out these 8 solo missions I can play and get achievements on. ACTUALLY it is only 4 missions not 8, they just give you basic characters in 4, then your side gets a hero to destroy them on the other 4 missions, which made it go from a mission to a joke. I played as Hon Solo and absolutely destroyed the other team (AI of course, it's solo mission ...) honestly, the least fun I've ever had playing a Star Wars game, I own a couple they are listed in alphabetical order via Steam library STAR WARS: Battlefront II, Empire at War: Gold Pack, Dark Forces, Jedi Knight: Dark Forces II, Jedi Knight: Mysteries of the Sith, Jedi Knight II: Jedi Outcast, Jedi Knight: Jedi Academy (one of the BEST), Knights of the Old Republic, Knights of the old Republic II: The Sith Lords, Republic Commando, Starfighter, Star Wars The Clone Wars: Republic Heroes, The Force Unleashed Ultimate Sith Edition, The Force Unleashed II. Now I can't say I've played them all, because buying a bundle pack you get some of the old games that I used to play but look horrific this day and age. BUT all those games cost the same as this single Star Wars: Battlefront Standard Edition during a Steam bundle. I SHOULD HAVE WAITED FOR A SUPER $5 DEAL DAY, not this stupid $20 price tag.

UPDATING THE UPDATED UPDATE TO THE MOST CURRENT UPDATE: The game has risen back to 4 stars, because the graphics are pretty darn awesome, the training is still my favorite, the star is added mainly because how First and Third person is able to be changed at the push of a button during game play... Now take into account they have some really cool scenery, almost as good as The Witcher 3 in some spots! Third person shooters generally aren't games I buy,so it's nice to have a choice!

title: The acceleration works wonderfully and it is not overbearing
text: I've used many MMO and MOBA mice in my gaming career. And for the price i got this at it beats out any other mouse. I have used both the Razer Naga and the Razer Naga Hex, along with the Diablo 3 Steel Series. The buttons took 3-4 days to get used to and then i had no issue remembering which was which. It's DPI scalability is insane and i don't think any one needs to use the highest settings but you never know. The acceleration works wonderfully and it is not overbearing. I personally leave all the weights in because i like a heavier feeling in my hand but my brother likes it at half weight. I've noticed that on some of my mouse pads it doesn't track at all but this isn't really an issue for me because the main pad i use is the one it works best on. I love the mouse and it has made my gaming experience that much more fun. And at 34.99 it was a great price.

title: Good, but Rocksmith 2014 blows the original away. text: The original Rocksmith is a very good game, but I gave up on it quickly because I felt like I was forced down a path of learning specifc songs that I wasn't that interested in. Thankfully, I gave the series another try with Rocksmith 2014 which blows the original away. It's easily a 5-star game. I've picked up my guitar again and am playing about an hour a day and have seen significant improvement. There is a lot more freedom in how you approach the game in the 2014 edition.

I did recently purchase this original game again, but only because I've moved from the Xbox 360 to my Mac and needed the original Rocksmith to use the "Disc Import Tool" to get the Rocksmith 1 songs (and, annoyingly, some of the DLC is only available with a Rocksmith 1 license). Fortunately I was able to find it from an Amazon Marketplace seller at a great price.

title: Above average gaming headset text: The corsair virtuoso is a pretty good headset. I previously used my Void Pro SE, and draw most of my comparisons off that. I broke down my thoughts into few categories.

Fit: The headset feels stiff and a little tight on the sides of my head. I prefer the fit of the void pro. I think I have a pretty medium sized head, and I felt a fair amount of clamping pressure on my ears. This also makes the headset feel lighter because there was less weight resting on the top of my head. I wish this were more adjustable because it's a little too tight.

Sound: (tested in wired & wireless mode, and experienced similar results): Just to clarify, I am no audiophile and have not owned a high quality set of headphone, but the sound seems ordinary. I tried to give this a big sample of uses: thx intro video, streamed music, I still have some .wav files, and gamed a bit. The headset handled all of it, but in much the same way as my void pro.

Mic: This was my favorite part of the headset. My experience with detachable my microphones has been less than stellar. Most of the time they look incredibly flimsy and generic. This mic matches the rest of the asthetics of the headset, and has sounded better and crisper than any mic I've tried. The mic is flexible, but I wish you could change the color of the mic LED. It is solid green when unmuted, and red when muted.

Design, look, feel: very nice corsair style. Perforated side RGB is cool, ear pads are a nice cushy leathery feel. It feels like all the surfaced are metal, padding, or coated plastic to make it nice to touch. With the mic removed they look like a nice set of headphones.

Other thoughts: I had some pains with the setup of these. They did not auto sync with corsair's icue software, and had a lot of crackling when used just with plug n play. I had to manually update the software and plug the headphones into the usb via cable. This fixed the sound issues, but the headset will sometimes not show up next to my other corsair devices in icue. This is frustrating, and I did not have these problems with my Void Pro.

I feel like these are very nice for a normal gaming headset, but it doesn't seem to be worth more than $200.

Hope this has been helpful:)

title: Questionable Longevity
text: Let's start with the pros.  The setting for this time managment game is a new one- you're in charge of building a marina, and you get to select the beach on which you do so.  The new scenery is refreshing.  Each level contains a series of goals, and there are lots of levels, allowing for lots of gameplay.  Players also get to keep working on the same marina- so there's no repeated starting over from scratch.  But there are cons too, and most important among those, is the fact that this game gets very repetitive, very quickly.  Players do the same tasks over and over again.  While it's nice to keep improving the same project/beach, this also contributes to the overall repetitiveness.  In sum, this game offers a lot of gameplay for your dollar, but that gameplay is extremely repetitive.

There isn't anything gross or any graphic violence in this game, so it is good for kids and parents alike. There are some difficult to solve puzzles and sometimes finding the lost items in the game can be maddening, but really, overall, there is so much to do if you get stuck doing one thing, then you can easily move on to another.

This truly is a great game, although the graphics are a bit wonky, even though one expects that with these crafting games, it can make it hard on the eyes after a while.

title: Excellent expansion for the Sims 3 franchise. text: ** NOTE: This is an expansion pack (EP). You must have the Sims 3 base game in order to use this expansion pack. **

EA's struck gold again with this expansion to its mega-popular Sims franchise. In this one, the theme is "fun in the sun," with beach- and resort-themed play and objects to enjoy. With Maxis at the helm, what could go wrong? Indeed, this is just one solid hit after another, with gorgeously thematic objects and Create-a-Sim (CAS) stuff and added gameplay that reinforces the theme.

EA's well aware that one of The Sims 2's strengths was the ability to own and run a business, and here, they give players the ability to develop and run a resort. Resorts are one of the most obvious new features to the game, and they're addictive to create. They can be themed a variety of ways, though the ones EA's favored are a traditional beach theme which is a bit Bohemian, "Spanish," which looks like Southern California to me, and something modernistic. The blueprint system they introduced a while ago gets a major update here with a variety of new rooms including pools, which have been majorly updated too and aren't just pretty landscaping anymore; you can install pool bars, slides, and waterfalls as well as the old-school diving boards. Every day, guests visit the resort and rate it, and their activities and ratings influence how much money the resort owner gets. Resorts can be placed in any gameworld just like any other lot type. Along with resorts, players also now have the ability to have any number of home lots in a world--and can move between lots (as well as gameworlds) almost effortlessly.

As to home lots, players can build as many homes or resorts in one town as they like, or chuck it all and just go live on a houseboat. Yep, houseboat. They're easy to build and handle, and their biggest strength is that they can sail--and dock--just about anywhere! I love houseboats.

Beaches have also been updated. Now players can direct their Sims to "play in the ocean" or even play with toddlers in the ocean, holding their little hands so the tykes can safely kick and laugh in the water. Sims can lay out in the sun (they get their own bright-colored towels to lay on). Any age of Sim can now make sand castles. And with a lifeguard chair on the lot, a Sim can now be a lifeguard, one of the new professions.

One of the other major updates to the game involves dive lots. A Sim can now go snorkeling or SCUBA diving and find treasure and meet mermaids. These underwater dive jaunts are so incredibly beautiful and evocative. I can't say enough how gorgeous these lots are. Some have treasure chests that can be opened like mummy sarcophagi in World Adventures; many have secret caves that can be explored (but watch out for the tentacled beasts!) as rabbitholes. And with careful planning, players can create their own dive lots.

The expansion's town, Isla Paradiso, is incredibly thematic. Each rabbithole and house looks perfectly in place for a Caribbean sort of theme, with colorful yellows, blues, pinks, and oranges predominating. The plants and building supplies are colorful and gorgeously wrought. The pre-made Sims are also perfect--I liked the back stories and appreciated the diverse cast of characters. The islands are time-consuming to travel, but there are some new methods of transportation--windsurfing boards, swan boats, speedboats, or just water taxis if you're poor. Or your houseboat, of course. The island chain also features secret islands discovered via gameplay.

I didn't see much here that was too sexually suggestive beyond the stuff that the Sims 3 already features; there are some new WooHoo locations, but as always, sexual activity is adult-only and carefully censored. There is obviously no cursing, and aside from the pool bars that serve juices of various kinds, no suggestion of alcohol or drugs that I've seen. Some of the new outfits for men and women alike get a little skimpy, which didn't bother me but might be of concern to others. If so, make sure to check out the online fansites' writeups about them before picking this up.

The Limited Edition version of this game includes a bunch of "stranded castaway" objects and CAS stuff. I LOVED that stuff; it's well-made all the way around and definitely looks spot-on for what it is. Anybody wanting to build "poverty" lots or needs more ragged clothing for a werewolf will like this stuff. I recommend getting the LE if you can.

Overall, I hugely recommend this expansion to anybody even vaguely interested in this particular theme.

As noted, this is an expansion, so it requires the base game in order to be played. It doesn't require an internet connection or Sims 3 forum account to use. I use the disk on both my Mac and PC, and will mention that on the PC it runs like a charm, but on the Mac, I get a lot of memory errors due to my machine not being top-of-the-line anymore. It doesn't run at all if I use all of my expansion packs, stuff packs, and Store downloadable content, but with the game totally crippled (I use about 20% of my total TS3 purchases on the Mac), it runs fairly tolerably. I'd be very cautious about getting this expansion if your Mac is already throwing Error 12s or crashing-to-desktop and you don't want to uninstall oodles of stuff; as you might be able to tell from my description, this EP is very memory-intensive and will definitely wreak havoc on a delicate ecosystem. I'm reluctantly docking this EP a star because I just can't play it on my Mac without seriously gimping my Sims 3 build. I wish EA would make a more Mac-friendly experience with this franchise.

title: Very lightweight but feels cheap text: Logitech G435 LIGHTSPEED and Bluetooth Wireless Gaming Headset - Lightweight over-ear headphones, built-in mics, 18h battery, compatible with Dolby Atmos, PC, PS4, PS5, Nintendo Switch, Mobile - Black

This headset is kind of a mixed bag. They feel very nice and lightweight, 163grams. They are comfortable and have a cool, unique design. They have Bluetooth and Lightspeed wireless technology which is awesome. The headset charges via USBc and last a pretty good amount of time before needing a recharge. I don't play more than 4 hours in a single day and not every day, but I have gone almost a week before charging. The audio is good enough, not outstanding but good enough. The noise isolation really isn't there and I didn't really expect it to be a top performer. I really like this headset. For something casual it's great. The mic though, it's abysmal. Serious the sound is so tinny and hallow. I use a separate mic so it really not a problem. If you typically play solo this is a really good option for a comfy, good sounding, and carbon neutral headset.

title: Give it a chance text: I had to rework my expectations quite a bit, but I am in love with this game. I didn't expect that it was essentially a one-player game (2-player if you have a Pro controller), or that it basically presumes online play. With kids in the house I am generally uncomfortable with online gaming but Nintendo really did it well. I've still had a couple run-ins with vulgarity, but the kids didn't notice. It was inoffensive compared to plenty of standard voice chat language with more adult games.

The eccentric aesthetic put me off at first, and so did the initial impression I had with the gamepad motion controls. But give it a chance, it's so worth it.

There are some seriously deep gameplay mechanics at work here. Levels are brilliantly designed, every one has secrets to discover. The range of weapons is astounding. The sound effects and visuals of the ink are so satisfying.

I have spent way more time on this game than any other Wii U title. More than Super Mario Maker, Smash, Kart 8, or any of the other ~20 Wii U games I've bought (replaying Wind Waker might come close though). I'm a 35 year old mom and didn't expect I'd ever get this excited about a new franchise seemingly aimed at kids.

The game initially released with little content, so a lot of early reviewers were unimpressed. It's a shame that clouded Splatoon's reputation, but after playing it for a month Nintendo has been surprisingly awesome about updates and it's pretty exciting.

title: A worthy sequel! text: I‚Äôve been playing the Dragon Quest series for about 30 years now (the original Dragon Warrior game came free with a Nintendo Power subscription.) In fact, this series is what got me into RPGs, to begin with!

For months now, I‚Äôve been eagerly awaiting the release of Dragon Quest XI. To date, I‚Äôve played and enjoyed every release, except for DQX. A review I saw said that this new installment felt old ‚Äì it reused the same tropes that the previous games have played. Well, there is a bit of truth to it. Many of the familiar enemies show up, the combat, modes of exploration‚Ä¶ Yes, this does feel very much like a Dragon Quest game, and that‚Äôs exactly what I was hoping for!

The game is marvelously-rendered, and the scoring is beautiful. I can‚Äôt say the story has been all that standard so far (not terribly surprising, but it has started off different than the previous installments.) Some improvements have been made ‚Äì save shrines, camp sites and the fact that you can actually see the enemies (yes, this has existed for a few of the previous games, but still worth noting!) All the characters and NPCs I‚Äôve met so far have added to the game, rather than detract from it. While the main character is clearly someone in his mid-late teens, the game isn‚Äôt written to really make that a big deal, so I‚Äôm not getting the typical teen angst I normally pick up from JRPGs, and that‚Äôs a good thing. I‚Äôm pushing 40 myself, so I can‚Äôt identify with those characters anymore.

I would highly recommend this game to anyone who‚Äôs been a fan of the series, or to anyone who is looking to get started in the series, as it‚Äôs been quite solid so far.

title: Issues for Macintosh text: Be advised that if you buy the game on disc for Mac OS X, install it and try to play, it will tell you there's no disc in the drive, even though you have the disc in the drive. You can't play it until you go to Origin.com, register your purchase with the registration numbers that came with the discs, then download it and re-install from the download. After you do that, you can play the game locally without being online, and don't have to have the game disc in the drive. It's complicated and time-consuming to do all this. You might want to buy by download in the first place, instead of buying discs and replacing disc installation later.

Origin will try to get you to play online, but you don't have to, once the software is installed and properly registered.

The game launcher for SIMS 3 will also try to get you to log on before opening a world, but you don't have to.

The main thing is, if you got the game on disc, it's not going to work in Mac OS X unless you get the online download. The reason for this is that EA Games didn't build SIMS 3 for Mac, ported from the PC version without doing good porting. I learned this from a lot of study and research online when I couldn't get my disc-based SIMS 3 to work on my Mac.

I like the game, but caution, if you're using Mac, it's better to buy it online via download than buy discs and go thorough all the hassle later of having to download anyway to make it work.

Origin or EA Games would be original download sources.

title: Pure Flying Fun! text: This game is a great combination of flight simulation and arcade fun! The adventure mode really stands out with a variety of mission types in many different environments with varied terrain. The 3D databases are HUGE and nicely detailed (mountains, rivers, oceans, forests) with some cool dynamic effects thrown in - (waterfalls, geysers, rock slides). The weather effects (wind, clouds, rain, snow) are very good and add a lot to the impressiveness of the game. You'll almost find yourself shivering when flying through the snowstorms in one mission of the adventure mode!
The flying dynamics are pretty good - though perhaps a little "floaty". It does provide a good sense of being aloft. You can see the control surfaces deflecting as you apply controls. After playing for a few hours, you get a sense of "feel" for the aircraft you're flying. For example, using the rudders in normal (not "easy") control mode is important to tighten up turns and straighten the plane during wind gusts.
It is easy to see that a lot of work went into this game. If you enjoy flight simulations, I highly recommend this game.
