title: Gust does it again. text: I first started playing the Atelier series on the PS3 with Atelier Rorona, than was hooked, and bought Totori followed by Atelier Meruru: The Apprentice of Arland, so of course I had to get Sophie and was not disappointed. I missed Atelier Ayesha, Escha & Logy and Shallie since my PS3 died after Meruru and was upgrading to a PS4 at the time. (Can't comment on the last 3 games). Change of pace, light hearted, story character driven, they removed the time limit system from past games which helps you explore and develop characters without having to time every step and not make the days past. Share Play can be used, as well as streaming. No blocked parts.

I'm glad i'm back playing the series. One of the main reasons I like them is the change of pace. It's light hearted game play and nothing overly serious like end of the world scenarios you see in almost every game. Character goals are more important, as well as alchemy and exploring the world and meeting new people. Gust tends to always bring characters from previous games back as cameos. Logy is in this, I know he was from the Escha game and comes back as a sword smith. Pamela has become a recurring character in almost every game (she's also in this). It also helps move the story seeing past characters since you connect with the previous game.. While this may sound tamed or dull to some, it's far from it. It does have special events that pop up that you must beat (monsters, dragons and demons) but story focus is on personal developments and exploring the world around you. It's very story focused with events popping up randomly or on intervals and each person has a 'friendship' meter. Which triggers events tied to them.

Can't compare on the last 3 games fighting system but I do know they removed the "limit break" that was present Rorona, Totori and Meruru it was a special skill when a character reached a certain mode which was an ultimate attack and have now fused them into a team type ultimate attack instead on single. Each person does have thier own ultimate, they are just joined by the group present. They still have skills, items like uni bombs, lighting rods etc and the standard, heal, speed up, break, sleep, poison etc. If you're familiar with those (which is standard in most RPGS) it should be simple to jump into. If you're a fan of the series and missed a few games like I did, it should very easy to get use to it again. Alchemy system has been enhanced but for the most parts follows the standard theme. (traits, quality, levels) when mixing. You can still carry over traits like previous games. To people not use to the Atelier series, it may be hard to understand how the story flows since they dont hold your hand, you have to advance the story doing tasks or alchemy but eventually it opens up to character moment to move the story forward. In the status menu section the friendship meter appears in red or black. Some moments in the game require you to talk to characters to trigger events. Most the times it tells you in the "idea section" others you have to walk up to characters. They use a day/time system some events only happen at a specific time. This is not a negative, it just needs some getting use to if you're use to these types of games.

Even though I missed the last 3, they still have some of the best music. Everything fits the game perfectly and like previous ones, they include vocal parts on special events. The rest that seem basic, grow on you and you start to appreciate it as time passes. My only regret was not buying the special edition, since I missed the last 3 games I wasn't sure if they could "hook" me again. THEY DID.

title: Excellent, when it works
text: This headset has a good sound and, because they are lighter than other similar headsets and they have very soft cushioned ear pads, they are extremely comfortable to wear. I have also been extremely pleased with the quality of the sound recorded from the microphone. I've used this headset for voice-over recordings, online gaming, and talking on Skype, and I've been thrilled with the quality. I've recommended this set to numerous friends and family members because of the high quality combined with the low price. However, although this set has a good sound and records very well, this set won't last very long. I bought my headset about a year ago, and it has worked splendidly for the last year. But, today I was using it to record some audio for a project and it crapped out on me. The earphones still sound fantastic, but the microphone no longer works. However, because of the cheap price and great quality, I've decided to purchase another set. Some people have reported sound problems, which also happened to my sister. I suspect that problem might be related to the long cord. The cord on this headset is about six feet long, which is great for an extended reach, but bad because it means there's a bigger chance that you're going to roll over the cord with your chair or snag it on something and yank it off your head (I believe my sister did that, which damaged the headset). So, if you're careful you may be able to avoid that problem. In my case, the mic stopped working, so I assume that the wires in the positionable microphone have become frayed or loose. Although I'd expect that to happen over time, I do not expect that to happen in just a year. However, this headset is so cheap and the quality of the sound is so good, I'm still going to purchase another set. The bottom line with this set: Fantastic sound reproduction and recording capabilities from a cheap-as-dirt headset, but you pay for that in shortened lifespan.

title: Love this keyboard! Could use better instructions though text: [[VIDEOID:c90a1b30b08b7e7f29002ffa5c82bb00]] I really enjoy the 60% form factor of this keyboard. The board is solid and high quality and can be connected via Bluetooth, USB cable, or the included wireless receiver. It also comes with a USB cable, keycap puller, and switch puller.

My biggest issue with this keyboard is the confusing FN key combinations (that aren't listed in the included instruction manual). At one point, I somehow changed the current layer, and as a result, my number keys weren't working. I tried the combinations listed in the manual, but they didn't work. Fortunately I found a reddit post about long pressing FN+space to reset the keyboard (I believe this is also now listed on the product page, but it wasn't when this happened).

The keyboard has key-specific lighting and there are several different lighting styles that you can choose from. I'm not crazy about lights, but it is important to some people.

The keyboard is really satisfying to type on out-of-the-box, both from a feel and sound perspective. The space bar makes a nice sound (see video). I was not expecting such a nice typing experience at this price point.

All said, I really enjoy using this keyboard and I would definitely recommend it to anyone looking for a nice 60% keyboard without breaking the bank.

title: An outstanding game with seemingly endless possibilities text: I'm not big on FPS games. In fact, Morrowind, Oblivion and the newer Fallout games are about as close as I normally get to FPS. I couldn't resist this game, however. Being from Detroit kinda influenced that; I wanted to see how much of my hometown they incorporated. I have to say, some things are familiar (including bums digging in the trash cans!) They really encouraged exploration here, with shops and hidden passageways scattered about. The streets of Detroit are more accurate than I expected, and they also included some nice landmarks.

At any rate, I'm pretty much blown away by this game. I really dig the story! The game play is remarkably fluid, and I really love the graphics and the music. The voice acting, for the most part, is top notch. One thing that really draws me in is that combat isn't exactly forced on you. Sometimes it's easier to simply take out the thugs. Other times, moving a box and exposing a vent shaft will take you around them. When it does come to combat, it seems pretty well done. I'm terrible at FPS type games, but I seem to hold my own here (I am playing on "Tell Me A Story..." I admit, I'm lame in that sense!) Ultimately, this feels like a role playing game with a FPS twist. You're not going to get a lot of sandboxing here like you would in Fallout or Oblivion, as the world you're in feels a bit smaller. Don't get me wrong, there is some exploring to be done but not as much as the other titles mentioned.

The level-up system is also nice, and leaves a lot of room for customization. It seems like you really can't go wrong with whatever build you take. It also allows you to focus more on stealth, or combat too, if you so desire. Experience is given by completion of quest, as well as for kills and take-downs. Yes, you have plenty of quests available! Once you complete the first mission (after the introductory mission,) you'll be given several side quests, as well as "main quests" that push the story forward.

Another really nice feature: I've noticed no bugs! Granted, I try to get from point A to point B asap, and haven't seen everything I could. Over all, I highly recommend this title!

title: Everybody should have one of these
text: Hated the idea of having to leave my PS3 on to charge my controllers. I had tried to use a regular USB charger, but that didn't work (the controllers need to see some sort of circuit or they won't charge). When I ran across this charger unit I ordered one right away. Works as advertised. You can charge two devices at the same time (unit comes with just one USB cable, but it is the same one that comes with the PS3). One thing though - the description on the Amazon product page says you can also use this to charge PSPs (2000/3000), but I just tried to do that and the power light on the PSP never came on. I'll have to experiment and see if maybe you need to use a different cable or something.

title: Good, but could use a longer power cord. text: This charging station gets very good reviews, which is why I picked it. It does have a couple of down sides.

1. The included power cord is about 2-3 foot long. Barely enough to reach a desktop from a wall outlet located right behind it. Fortunately, the USB cable that comes with the PS4 is compatible and much longer.

2. As the PS4 doesn't have REAR USB ports, the cord routing to the cradle is a tad awkward. One would think it would be easier to have the cable connect to the front...especially when you consider the USB cable is only 2-3 foot long. Don't get me wrong, the rear plug-in is cleaner, but it works better with a longer USB cord.

Otherwise, plugging in is simple (once you get the hang of it), and it's very clean and elegant in appearance.

title: Good for the price; some nitpicks. text: Got this one for work. Eventually I'd like to get a Master, but that will have to be put on the back-burner for now. So far, I've used a basic Logitech mouse, an MX 518, and the Proteus Core in the last ten years. They all were my favorites mouses (yes, you heard me right: "mouses"), and I've been itching to replace the perfectly fine MX 518 I have at work, so I nabbed this one.

I think what they're trying to here is merge their lower-end mouses with their higher-end gaming mouses, so that they're able to offer their features to those on a lower budget. So far, I think this is fantastic, but that doesn't mean there aren't issues. It looks, when the lights are off, and feels like a $15 Logitech mouse. Which isn't a bad thing.
Every Logitech mouse I've used is far better than most of the alternatives. They make great mouse, and I will continue to source my non-trackball input devices from them in the future. On my desk, it looks like the old, beige Logitech one I had when I first started at this job, which most likely came with one of their computers years ago. The click isn't really sensitive as there's not much down stroke, and it's VERY low-profile. I use a fingertip grip and this thing can get a bit uncomfortable for me at times.

As for settings, you can use a few of the more basic settings you can from other gaming mouses. You can't switch between as many settings as more-dedicated gaming mouses, but they're still there. For a work computer, this mouse improves my navigation by a ton, but, like a said, the size does make it a bit uncomfortable for long periods of time.

The scroll wheel has no infinite scroll feature, which is the biggest physical downfall I found in terms of physical features. The side buttons are placed better than the MX 518 as I can reach them more easily, and the middle button behind the wheel acts as the tracking speed switcher. The scroll wheel can act as another button upon pressing, if you like, but I have that switched to off as I don't find it necessary for my use.

The light does have RGB, but I keep it on a cool blue all the time. You can have it set to either on or off, but I prefer on at a very low setting. I wish it would turn off completely after being idle after a while, but if you leave it on the "on" setting it remains on until the power source (i.e., the computer) is completely off.

If you think of it as a budget office mouse with neat little gaming features, then this one will serve handsomely. At $40 retail, however, I think it's priced a little high. Knock it down $10 and this will be the go-to mouse for all looking for a great mouse under $50.

title: Too Many Glitches, And Rude To French People text: The Burger Shop and the Sushi Shop are loads of fun, and not too difficult.
The Cake shop has lots of glitches: you clearly won a level by exceeded the money goal for the day, but for some reason the game says that you didn't, this happens for a lot of the Cake shop levels. Also the `play' button for the Cake shop once in a while is unclickable, so you cannot even begin the next level, it just freezes up.

The Flower shop is just way too difficult and takes all the fun out of the game.
Also, there is a town money glitch: I had upgraded all my shops, but for some reason the Flower shop wont stay upgraded. It reverts on it's own right back to the first level before upgrading, but yet all my money that I spent on upgrading it is gone. All the other shops stay upgraded, so I don't understand why the Flower Shop doesn't.

One thing I am very disappointed about is the blatant reference to the French people. In the game, when upgrading Jill's cake shop, she says: "Ooh la la, Customers Will Think They Are In Less-rude Version Of France".
If the game writers had said "Wow, Customers Will Think They Are In A Less-self Centered Version Of America" I bet the gaming public here in the USA would be upset and making complaints. But because this uneducated, derogatory, racist comment is directed at another country it is overlooked and dismissed I guess. I know from first hand experience from actually being in France, that this disgraceful stereotype is completely incorrect and unjustified, and shows the writers to be ignorant.
No entire group of people or country should be labeled in such way, it doesn't matter if it's Americans, Canadians, Russians, Germans, Italians, or the French etc.. There are rude people everywhere in the world, that does not mean that the entire population of one country are rude just because some of it's people are. The writers for this game are labeling all the people of an entire country as being bad-mannered and discourteous, when ironically their offensive comment shows them to be the ones who are bad-mannered, discourteous, rude.
I wish I could get my money back for this game.

title: More Accurately Described as a Workstation Pad - Flickers in Scrolling Mode text: [[VIDEOID:23b66e0d4d6deb4493df890cc9f52620]] I recently built a custom computer workstation that suspends next to my recliner with the desk surface swiveling over the arm for me to work. I thought this would be a nice addition although it was simply too big.

While based on the dimensions it should have worked, due to my swiveling desktop being made up of 2 surfaces, one for the keyboard and the other for the mouse, there was no way to have this lay flat across both. This is certainly not a failing of the product, only my experience.

I have ended up using this beneath my PC and server on the table next to my recliner and it looks great while providing a soft surface for my computer equipment to rest.

While this does not come with a micro USB cable I always have additional so this wasn‚Äôt an issue but should be known. I have mine plugged into a multi USB outlet that automatically adjusts to the power required for whatever is plugged into it, it‚Äôs provided constant power without issue.

I feel that the color descriptions are accurate. I have tested this product over the last 2 months and what I have found is when set to any of the scrolling color modes it continually flickers every few seconds which is very distracting (see video). While it didn‚Äôt do this in the beginning it now happens nearly continually. This is not an issue in the breathing color changing modes but, for me, makes the scrolling modes unusable. I have tested changing cables and outlets but neither makes a difference therefore this is a defect with the product.

While the lights are bright and vibrant, the patterns varied, the defect I have encountered makes this a product I would not recommend.

title: EA and maxis must think we're really dumb.... text: That's the only thing I could think of. Because this game has been dumbed down so much so that it isn't even challenging. The first day I got it I played for about 4 hours and thought "wow, this is really easy!". But that's not my only complaint. Here are my pro's and con's:

Pro's: The graphics are gorgeous and I like the attention to detail.

Con's: 1. This is my game, I bought it, so why are they telling me I have to be on their servers to be able to play it? 2. Speaking of servers, they are down, a lot. I haven't been able to get in since I bought it on Tuesday when it came out. That's three days of no game play for a game I paid $60 bucks for. 3. The size of land they give you is way too small. With the amount of residential they want you to build it gives no room to expand other buildings like your town hall for example. 4. Like I said before, this game has been dumbed down so much so that it presents absolutely no challenge. Be prepared to get bored very quickly. 5. I complained about this in SimCity 4, where are the scenarios? SimCity 3000 had them and they were awesome! I loved going in and fixing cities and making them prosper. Huge disappointment that they aren't there. 6. This game does not allow you to save, so when the servers go down you have to start all over again. My husband has this game and he has had to start over 2 times now. When I say start over I mean having to do the tutorial and completely start over. All his progress was completely gone. 7. Why can't I just plant some trees? Why does it have to be a park that has to be attached to a street? That takes up way too much space and wipes out houses all around it. Like I said before space is very limited. 8. Someone else said it and I completely agree. It feels like I am renting this game. I'm allowed to download it to my computer and take up space, but I'm not allowed to save it to my hard drive and play it when I want to. 9. Since this game is online only, what happens when EA decides to pull the plug permanantly on the servers? You will have a game you paid a lot of money for that will be unplayable. That right there is NOT acceptable!!

Well I guess I am dumb because I fell for the hype and bought it the day it came out. So I guess EA and maxis were right. I hope they get reported and get severely punished for providing such a sub-standard product.

title: Wonderful World -- Cranky Interface
text: Now having completed the single-player version of this game, I can say it is probably the best I've ever played in this genre, and certainly the best of the Myst series. At the beginning I was very put off by the nearly-unmanageable cursor, but after removing all the other [user] background tasks on my 3 GHz machine, I found it possible, though still very annoying, to work with. The problem with cursor management is simply that there is an extraordinary amount of other "stuff" going on in the game, and cursor positions are not updated often enough. One would hope that the relative amount of time devoted to mouse position polling and other functions can be slightly modified to give the kind of smooth mouse action usually found. In contrast to the mouse, the motion keys [arrow keys] are a bit over-sensitive, and one will find that a mix of walk/run and 1st person/3rd person views to be most useful.

title: A review from someone who is actually playing it....not just saying my kid likes it...and a bit of comparison to the 3ds version
text: Love it.  Great graphics, fun modes and lots to do. Terrific voice acting and characters.  I have the 3ds version and the portal works fine with the PS3.  The console version really is a whole lot better than the 3ds version but the 3ds version is more of a platformer, you can store two Skylanders and just swap them out by tapping their icon on the bottom screen and they can jump.  Other than that, the PS3 version is a much more immersive and richer game.  I think this is a game for the whole family to enjoy and I have played a heck of a lot of games since 1978.  Infact, it sort of reminds me of old fashioned Diablo type dungeon crawling (and some Skylanders have similar type abilities) but most of the adventuring takes place in well lit areas and even though the NPCs are cute they are not "sticky sweet" or too childish for adults who just want to experience a fun game. I love the bright colors and the little details like ice forming on the ship...or little puddles on the deck.  And it is FUN. I like buying the character updrades in this version as that is not an option but is automatic in the 3ds version.  Skylanders transferred from the 3ds retain their LEVELS but not their upgrades.  Hats in this version actually have a purpose and can effect stats in many different ways such as making a Skylander faster or better defensively.  In the 3ds version hats just sit on their heads and look cool...lol....no effects at all.  I waited for this version and the figures to become a little more affordable and honestly, it's one of those rare times I wish I had just bought it on release day because it's that good and would have been well worth the price. Finding new figures in the stores is almost impossible now. Good news-- It's ok to buy Skylanders used if you want to or don't have a bunch of cash....this version has an option to reset the Skylander so you can do all its stats, leveling up yourself.  Also...the best thing about BOTH games....you really only have to have 1 giant and a Skylander of each element to play the game effectively and enjoy all the parts.  So...I think that comes down to your giant and 7 of the other elements.  And since you can use Skylanders from the original game, there's lots to pick from and enjoy.  Of course, you'll want more than 8 but it's like eating an elephant---ONE bite at a time will get you there :)  At first I thought the figures were a horrible gimmick idea but now that more and more games on any system are requring you to pay for additional DLC...this is really cool since you have a figure and a game character to show for your money spent.  There's no online mode for the battle arenas....that's the only thing I don't like about this game. I've been fairly dependent on online for quick games with other people for several years so no online battle option feels like a step backwards in gaming.  Other than that, i think the concept is amazing, the game plays very well, the modes mix it up, replay value is strong for each level and for each figure you collect.  I think it's superb and would think anyone who likes games could enjoy this nearly perfect game.

title: Looks amazing, plus it adds Bluetooth (vs OG controllers) text: I've never used a Microsoft controller that let me down. I've used various 360 controllers, OG Xbox One controllers, and the Elite. This lacks some of the added nuances of the Elite, but it feels every bit as good. The look is great. It's not sexy or anything, and the overall lines are the same as any Xbone One controller, but the white is great, as is the details with the button colors or lack there of.

Range, response, and feel is all the same as any Xbox One controller, which I thing is great. Likewise battery life and ergonomics, save for the added grippiness, which is an upgrade here.

An added bonus that appeared a year or so ago is the ability to pair with phones, Nvidia Shield, etc... via Bluetooth. I suppose you can pair with a PC as well (I use the USB wireless adapter for my PC). I haven't really tested the range or battery life that much with Bluetooth. I imagine it's comparable, but I use Bluetooth as an added perk vs my primary usage.

As noted above, much is the same as other controllers. It likely won't make a hater of the overall design a convert, but it could be a nice upgrade for existing users.

title: *New* Nintendo 3DS text: I have an original Ambassador 3DS from the 2011 launch, long before they introduced the XL models. When the XL models did come out, I did not upgrade to the XL, because I had already gotten used to the form factor of the original 3DS. I carried it everywhere. I don't carry a bag, so it was always in my pockets. Not too big, and not too heavy, it was not uncomfortable.

When Nintendo announced the *New* generation, I was excited, but that excitement quickly diminished as they indicated their intent to only release the XL version in the US. Well, Nintendo can sell me a game based around an Italian plumber and I would buy it, so with the prospects of a regular sized 3DS looking dim, I reluctantly upgraded to the *New* XL model. It WAS big, and took a very long time for me to get used to the size. I don't have large hands, so I ended up getting a bit cramped, and forget about carrying it in my pocket. I would need a belt and suspenders to keep my pants up, it was so heavy. I could barely use the new C-stick because I felt like a 2-year old trying to learn piano when my fingers just didn't reach that far.

Nintendo does a U-turn and decides to release the regular sized *New* 3DS, so what else was I to do? I "downgraded" from the XL, and I'm a happy person now. I'm still amazed at Nintendo's original intent of a non-release, but at least they finally appeared to listen to us fans and we got what we've been wanting.

As for the *New* 3DS itself:

I've done a system transfer a few times now, and either it's becoming second nature, or they've streamlined it very well. The transfer process is a fairly painless walkthru, and afterwards, you move the SD card from the old to the new; the old gets wiped to factory defaults, and when you turn on the new, you'd never notice a difference. I exaggerate. Who could not noticed going from a brick sized XL model to a comfortable regular one? But you get my point, right?

This version came pre-shipped with three Happy Home Wrecker top faceplates, so I installed the Isabelle faceplate. Installing the top faceplate is tool-free, it just snaps in. The bottom faceplate requires a small phillips-head screw driver, but you still need to remove the bottom to install the SD card even if you are not swapping the plate. Right now, there are not many faceplates available outside Japan, but from my understanding, the Japanese plates fit the international models, so if you find a good cheap exporter, you should be good.

You will still need a 3DS charger, as they've stopped shipping those with the *New* generation. I dunno why. Packaging is a bit smaller, but it certainly doesn't endear brand-new customers who find out their shiney new handheld needs to be charged with an unsupplied charger. Unlike tablets or non-Apple phones, the charger is not any USB variant, but there appears to be several USB-to-3DS adapters altho I've not used one myself.

The stylus is smaller, and just as cramped as ever, so invest in a pen-sized one if you can. It's worth it. I actually use a retractable ball-point pen with the ink cartridge removed.

Both versions of the *New* generation have improved on the 3D aspects, so whether you like the XL size or regular size, that alone is something to consider. I barely used 3D mode, and I don't know how, but it works significantly better so that I'm starting to turn it on more often.

I can't comment on battery life, since I've not played very long, but there are indicators that it's about 4 hours. My original 3DS was upgrade with a Nyko PowerPak which gave it beefy battery life with minimal additional bulk or weight, so here's hoping that Nyko will have a new version out soon.

title: Excellent headset with high-end features; best bang for buck! text: This headset represents fantastic bang-for-the-buck. They're not "oh my god!" amazing, but they are far better than I expected for the ~$45 price tag. I anticipated burning through them fairly quickly (out of dissatisfaction or low build quality) and moving up, but I always like to give entry-options a whirl. These are a surprisingly great piece of hardware!

Pros include really decent sound (both headphone and mic), nice inline controls, really well designed microphone (I love how it bends and easily swivels out of your way if not using), comfortable padding around the ears, a nice braided cable, nice swivel ear cup design, and other features that I would anticipate on a higher quality set only. However, it's not without some drawbacks. The biggest drawback is that, despite the fairly ample padding on the headband, these things hurt the top of my head. I've gotten used to it, and they no longer bother me, but for a long time, I could only use them for 20 minutes at a time or so, before my head was really sore. Wearing a hat helped some, but ironically, now seems to make it worse. The only other problem I've had with these is that the sound from the headphones sometimes bleeds over into the mic. When I'm playing a game and I'm talking, people can often hear my in-game sounds, whereas they should only be hearing my voice. I don't think it's a volume thing with sound escaping the headphones. I get the impression that the audio is bleeding over somehow, be it a hardware or software problem. Then again, I could be wrong about the origin of the problem.

That said, it's a small drawback in an otherwise really great headset. I'm not sure that paying two or three times as much as any chance of netting you a two or three time gain in quality. The fact is, these things are surprisingly high-quality, and I'm impressed. From someone who has gone through a fair number of headsets, and who wasn't expecting much, I'm pleased to say I'd buy these again in a heartbeat.

title: Better than Cataclysm text: Over all, I would say that World of Warcraft remains to be the best MMO that I have played. There as a three month tryst with Final Fantasy XI before WoW, and another few month fling with Guild Wars 2 during my 2 year hiatus from WoW. But I inevitably came back to this game. I played until the launch of Cataclysm, which in my opinion, was dismal. They ruined my favorite class (ret paladin) and seemed to try to recycle a lot of old content. So I quit. Anyway, after chatting with some friends about our old days, I decided to give Mists of Pandaria a try. They insisted it was better. Well, they were right. It is an improvement upon Cataclysm.

I started playing about 3 weeks ago, and since then, I've managed to level 2 of my higher levels to 90, and see the first 2 sets of raids. I have returned to many changes. Many were for the better. Some, well... not so much. Here is what I've noticed. (Please note that I have been away for a couple years, and I might not know when such changes were implemented.)

The good:

1. On an asthetic level, WoW has seen some substantial improvements. You don't need the best hardware to crank everything up, which seems to be Blizzards MO. The world is still a bit cartoon like, but that is part of its charm (and always has been!)
2. The Raid and Dungeon finder has made things much nicer for casuals. You do run the risk of running with inappropriately skilled/geared players, but over all, it is a nice feature. It seems to have been improved since I quit (and Raid Finder is completely new.) Some folks complain about LFR for a number of reasons - lower gear quality and reduced fight mechanics. I am personally fine with this. I mainly play to see content. Not have the best purples. It would, however, be nice to see a buff given to tanks who meet the minimum gear requirement. Speaking as someone who started tanking heroics with an item level of 440 last week, it can be hard to maintain threat when 2 or 3 of your DPS are pulling 100k plus.
3. Guild Perks! Experience and rep boosts, mass resurrection, faster flying... The list goes on. Very nice for leveling an alt! (Though it could be bad if you're a sucker for the story... you tend to outgrow quest zones and dungeons pretty fast.)
4. Traveling is considerably more convenient. Most classes have at least an optional bonus to movement speed perk to choose from, and they seem to have allowed mounts in more areas.
5. I leveled a Death Knight from 55 as a blacksmith/miner. They rearranged the zones, so gathering had a few hang-ups. But once I got going, things were a lot easier (mainly because I could fly from level 60 on.)

The Bad:

1. The change I like the least is probably the Cross Realm business. Zones are flat out crowded now. I've had to wait in line to kill a unique mob, and folks seem to be fighting over items to be gathered. Depending on the time of day, questing can be nearly as bad as it is during launch week. I get that Cross Realm dungeon finder was necessary. I can even see why they'd want it for regular zones, as well. But they should tone it down a bit. (I was in Loch Modan last night, and the place was CRAWLING with panda.)
2. Scenarios! These are flat out boring. There is one that gives you a 450 weapon of choice. That is worth doing once you hit level 90, and if you didn't get lucky in any of the higher level dungeons on normal mode.
3. The Isle of Thunder. It's a crazy rep grind. I suppose it would be worth it if you're in a hard-core raiding guild. I took my Death Knight there as soon as he hit 90 (in quest greens and blues.) It seems to me that the place was tuned for people who were at least raid-ready. The non-elite mobs have about 500k health, and the elites have way more.
4. The music in this expansion is flat out annoying. This is sad, because music has been one of Blizzard's strongest suits in ALL of their games.
5. I didn't spend much time in Cataclysm dungeons, and I didn't step foot in a single raid from that content. The dungeons in this expansion are pretty lame. I don't care much for the story line in many of them (Stormstout Brewery, for example.) The boss fights and mobs seem pretty annoying. I appreciate that they are trying to add new mechanics into the dungeons. Some things worked. Some didn't. It would be nice if they allowed us to skip some of the NPC dialog once we've seen it once.
6. While the story line here seems a bit more original than what they did with Cataclysm, I still don't care for it as much. The Burning Crusade and Wrath of the Lich King both had outstanding stories.

The Nit-Picks:

1. Pandas! This was just like all the other expansions where they introduced new classes/races. Everyone needs to be the new thing. I rolled a dwarf shaman, and I was the only non-panda in a Shadowfang Keep run!
2. My Death Knight is a blacksmith. I've leveled up through WotLK in the passed. Cataclysm's gear seemed like it was pretty logical. I am not happy with some of the changes they made. All the ghost-forged armor pieces have "random enchants." This would be more annoying if we weren't tripping over ghost iron nodes, but is still slightly annoying none the less. There is no control over what stats you get on a piece of armor, and sometimes you have to make several in order to get the desired result. It is nice that they gave you about a 10% chance to make a level 415 blue, however. I also don't like how they made Living Steel a main component in all epic gear (in relatively large quantities, no less.) Lightning Steel is pretty much useless. The only purpose it serves is to "learn" new plans on a once-daily cool down.
3. A huge focus on daily questing for rep. I liked the dungeon grinds better. Wrath of the Lich King seemed to have the best flexibility with rep grinds! Choice daily quests and tabbards for the desired faction!

title: Proceed with Caution text: The Microsoft Wireless Adapter did not satisfy my wireless connection needs. My computer and wireless router are located on the first floor with my Xbox 360 on the second floor, one room to the left from being directly above the router. Although it establishes a connection, the signal strength is limited and greatly impedes game play. Playing Halo 3 on Xbox Live is nearly impossible due to lag in play, pauses, connection disruption, and ratcteting movement.
The problem did not seem to be attributed to the router. I tested this by placing my laptop next to the Xbox 360 console and compared signal strength. The laptop's signal strength had 5 green bars while the Xbox 360 adapter registered one red bar.
I also tested the adapter itself by bringing the Xbox 360 downstairs to the same floor. Under these conditions, the wireless adapter's signal strength measured 5 green bars.
In my opinion, the Microsoft Wireless Adapter is limited in it's capabilities. It appears well suited for specific wireless environments. These include large open rooms and same floor situations with few obstructions. Basically the adapter should be used in close proximity to your wireless router or wireless access point.
As for my dilema, I resolved my issue by purchasing a Belkin 100ft ethernet cable and spending an afternoon running cable through my basement and a few walls to establish a direct connection. No complaints now.

title: False advertising
text: Do not believe many of the photos posted at various sites. I believe they took the photo down, but in many photos they don't show the Bluetooth model. The D pad on the Bluetooth model sits around 1-1.5mm higher. It's not a huge deal for more casual players, but veterans will feel how raised it is. The d pad also has a sort of gummy feel  since it's been raised. I'm imagine you pressed a button but instead of stopping at the point of registering the input, you could still feel this almost stretchy feel where you can continue to depress the button. I am posting a picture of both the Saturn pad with appropriate d pad elevation and the retro bit controller for comparison. You can see how ridiculously high it's raised. It's too bad. Other than the weird d pad, the controller feels great. I tried to take it apart and fix it, but its a problem with the actual molding of the controller so you're stuck with the problem. This problem is exclusive to the Bluetooth model. You can avoid it by going with any of the other model genesis controllers from retro-bit.

title: Unexpectedly awesome text: I'm very surprised to be reviewing this game -- let alone giving it five stars. When my husband received "Mass Effect" for Christmas, I thought I'd be spending a lot of time rolling my eyes and reading a book while he was shooting stuff, not fighting him for the Xbox controller!

So, I'm not a hardcore gamer, and I'm not going to review this game pretending I'm one. I'm writing this from the perspective of a 31-year-old wife and mom whose interest in Xbox games has mostly been limited to "Oblivion" and "Guitar Hero" until now.

The graphics in "Mass Effect" are unbelievable, even better than "Oblivion," I think -- particularly when it comes to the characters. One thing I didn't like about "Oblivion" was that it was nearly impossible to make a female character who didn't look like a man. Maybe that seems like a minor thing to other people, but when I spend a lot of time playing a game (about 30 hours in this case), I want to be happy with the way my character looks. My "Mass Effect" character came out pretty darn cute, if I do say so myself! (One of my husband's friends was over once when I was playing and said, "Whoa! Who's she? I haven't met that character!")

In addition, the alien worlds that you visit look great. There are tons of them, and there's a lot of things to explore on each one (including stuff that doesn't show up on your map.)

The controls were easy for me to use. Normally, I hate "shooting games" because it's too hard for me to aim (I'd just rather hack away at something with a sword), but after a little practice, I was doing pretty good. By the end (with upgraded weapons), I found I was actually taking out guys with one shot. Sweet!

The way the weapons and armor were displayed also made it easy for me to figure out which was the best choice for my character or other team member. In some games, particularly "Neverwinter Nights" for the PC, I've had to ask my husband to help me figure out which one will do the most damage. Not a problem here. One small complaint: In the screen where you switch which weapon you're armed with, it'd be nice to have them labeled with the TYPE of weapon (pistol, assault rifle, etc.) -- I'm not gun-savvy enough to figure out which is which based on the little sketch.

I really liked the RPG aspects of the game. At times, it was a little talky, but I really liked that the focus wasn't 100 percent on combat. I also liked the option of incorporating romance into the game. (So sue me, I'm a chick!)

The plot -- about a rogue Spectre (sort of a special agent) who's trying to bring an ancient power back to the galaxy -- kept me interested, too. I guess it's just a variation on the standard RPG plot of "cult tries to take over the world," but it's done well.

The end does seem to leave the game wide-open for a sequel -- and I think that's a good thing. I'll definitely be fighting my husband to play that one, too.

title: Very fun until the last 1/4th of the game text: This game was GREAT!......up until the last fourth of the game. I won't spoil anything, but at a point in the game you get locked out of the world for the entire last chunk of the game. In this section, the plot seems to go into overdrive with the story speeding through plot twists like crazy with no explanation or delving any deeper or explaining anything. By the end, I felt exhausted, confused, and disappointed. I've been told that they will be expanding on this end content to fix this issue, but I don't know if this is true or how much this would actually fix this issue since it encompasses a good MANY hours.

Up until this point, I loved this game. It felt great to just chill on long drives and combat was a lot of fun. The best part of this game, as many others have said, are the bro-team. Like many others, I definitely recommend watching the short anime series first as it really does add more depth to the characters. You really do start to feel for these guys and come to really love them, which made it suck all the more when things got crap, but it was still a good rid until then.

I might bump it up a star if the last fourth of the game is improved, but for now I can't fully recommend the game as I only really truly enjoyed 3/4ths of the game.

title: Exactly as described
text: These remind me of the old attachments you would attach to Wii remotes when playing sports games. They definitely make it feel more "golf like" when using these instead of just playing with the remote. These are probably more fun for little kids since it makes them feel like they are playing golf. The golf club part can come off and be put back on, so it is possible to switch the red club part with the blue controller part and vice versa. The side buttons are still easy to use since they have a thing you can push down on over them, so that it works. The LR buttons are partially obscured by the plastic backs but still reachable and clickable. The joycons slip right into these and are easy to take out and put back in. And it has those straps that you can use to attach to your wrist when playing, so it's less likely for the remote to fly out of your hand if you use them.

title: Two Outs in the Bottom of the Ninth and ... He Swings and Misses!!! text: Mass Effect 3 is a very fun game for the first 30 hours or so. Unfortunately, the writing team decided to get "cute" with the ending of the space opera, and the ending(s), such as they are, are a wasteland of plotholes, inconsistencies, and themes that run contrary to the entire design of the series, never mind many of the main themes of the third game itself.

It's a cogent reminder that even a team of creatives that is capable of producing the fantastic series that was Mass Effect is nevertheless capable of stumbling, and stumbling badly, nay horribly, in the end.

title: Pros & Cons review text: Ok let me start by saying that this game is really fun but it does have some fatal flaws that you should look at before buying it.

The Pros:
-Good Campaign Story
-Brought Back and Revolutionized Zombies
-A lot of Extra Map Packs for Purchase
-A new and better lvling system in multiplayer
-A wide Range of Gun selection
-No more Noob-Tubing
-You can now Purchase your guns with money you earn rather than break your back with stupid achievements.
-You can Make your own Emblem
-Way better Killstreaks
-Improved Graphics
-Overall Very Fun!

The Cons:
-Campaign Gameplay is rather bland
-You'll lose connection to the game host more often
-Some Guns are not Accurately portrayed (Some Guns like M16 are 3 round bursts only and FAMAS is full auto only, also the AK47 is weaker than the M16?)
-They got rid of the SCAR

Overall you can plainly see that the Pros really outweigh the cons by A LOT! They have a storyline their just because but this really is a game that was made to shine for multiplayer and in fact in many ways I think it's much better than MW3 and MW2 and is a much more balanced and realistic gameplay. You get most of the most reputable guns of the cold war and even some rarely seen and unique ones! This is definatley a game your gonna want to pick up and try. The main reason I think people are dissapointed in this game is the same reason for most games/movies of this league.....OVER HYPE! Some people who gave this game a horrid rating do not have an open mind either to this style of gameplay or the reality of the design of this game. Is this game for everyone? No. But if you like fast paced action/first person shooters and like to interact with others than I highly urge you to give this game a go! Please note that if you do not have internet set up or dont like multiplayer games that you will HATE this game because it all revolves around human interaction for it's fun. If you like going solo go for Call of Duty 1,2,3, and World at War and maybe Call of Duty 4. And yes SCAR lovers I do feel your pain too. But try to lighten up, their are a ton of good guns that can take the place of your SCAR for at least one Call of Duty game.

title: Not bad, but not the best of the series. text: I grew up on the Dragon Warrior series. I've played all of the DW/DQ games, from the NES to PS1/PS2 and the DS. When it comes to the DS titles, DQ4 and DQ5 are amazingly good. This one isn't bad, but it felt "weird" do me. The story and game play, for the most part, were good. I really didn't like certain mechanics, however. For example, talking to EVERYTHING in a town before you can advance the story (including the animals) was frustrating and annoying. A tower was dark and filled with pit-falls, yet you had to navigate through them. I don't mind a little challenge, but I hate tedium, and that's what I felt like I had in this game from time to time (more frequent than the normal grind-induced tedium from the other games in the series.)

This game is certainly not bad, and definitely worth investing in for the hard-core Dragon Quest fan. I personally just found it a bit underwhelming, though I have pretty high standards (Dragon Quests 4 and 5 were two of my favorite RPG's of all time.)

title: A most excellent pinball game, even on XP, if you know how. text: Big Race USA is a well crafted 3D delight. The ray-traced graphics are true-to-life, colorful and stunning. The physics are superb, endowing the steel balls with realistic movement and mass. The tunes are catchy, sound-effects authentic and the voices and spoken lines are hilarious. At high power settings, a flipper will make the ball smack the glass hard, which is very satisfying. It's like having a real, spanking new, well-tuned pinball machine in your room.

The operator's menu lets you create a custom difficulty level where you can choose the number of balls, set how long the ball-saver remains active and tune every other conceivable parameter of game play and scoring. The table-setup option lets you adjust table slope, machine condition and flipper power. You can make it respond like a factory-fresh dream or like a beat-up bar machine if you want. Extras let you examine the 3D game surface in detail with the ability to zoom in to high-resolution close-ups.

I've had this CD for years but I recently tried it on Windows XP with my new Athlon 64 4000+ screamer and was disappointed to find the flipper response was slow and even intermittent. It turns out that XP is not entirely compatible with the versions of Windows that Big Race USA was made for, rendering it unplayable. Fortunately I found a solution on the Web. Run it in Windows 2000 compatibility mode! When I did, all the flipper sluggishness disappeared and the game was fun again.

I play this on my new system in full screen mode, at the highest video resolution with all the bells and whistles turned on. It runs flawlessly with minimal latency. This game is a beauty to behold, still plays well on modern hardware and I strongly recommend you get yourself a copy.

title: A solid entry level headset text: I have variety of wired and wireless USB headsets, and they span all aspects of the market. As this is an entry level set that uses a standard 3.5mm jack, it'll work with any PC, Mac, handheld, or phone (if so blessed). I use this with an external "gaming" mixer that outputs (and inputs) to 3.5mm.

Fit is good, but nothing special. If you wear glasses, it could be a bit rough. The feel is lower end, but Logitech doesn't try to do anything it can't deliver on at this price point. Come with the right expectations and you won't be disappointed.

The sound is OK. Better than most stuff 10-20 years ago, but nothing hifi and less than many higher end headsets. It's fine for 95% of people, but if you're looking for the best, this isn't it. It is however very clear, and it blocks outside noise.

Anyway this is well worth the price, and it's a solid sent for anyone who doesn't already have a $100+ set.

title: The Lost Valley, version 2.0 text: If you're familiar with Natsume's take on the Harvest Moon games called The Lost Valley (TLV), you'll already be familiar with this one. This is basically TLV 2.0. They improved a few things, tweaked the story a bit, but much is still the same. Like TLV, there's a lot of potential but it ends up being undeveloped or issues ignored.

For me, frustration factor outweighs enjoyment and after 30 hours and just over two in-game years, this is getting put away.

The camera is still the camera. It's an automatic camera that magically swings around without your input, but more often than not, ends up looking in a direction I don't want. You can use the shoulder buttons to swing the camera manually, but there is no way to override the automatic focus.

There are two other camera views: overhead and farming. Both are essentially the same, but farming view keeps your character pointed in the same direction, making it easier to more quickly terraform or farm. But these additional camera views still have an automatic focus and will still swing around. Take an example. I'm trying to dig out a path to the Underworld, which is on the same edge as the town entrance. No matter which camera view I try to use, it still swings wildly and makes it extremely difficult to see exactly where I am digging. Just give us a straight view with no automatic swings.

Objects such as people and animals are impassable barriers. If anything is in your way, you will not get around it. I found this more pronounced in the barn. I have four animals (horse, sheep, cow and donkey) and they can't get out of their way to eat their food. You can watch them try to perform this intricate dance to maneuver around each other to reach their feed troughs. If an NPC or two are in the barn, navigation space is even more limited. I've seen them get stuck in a corner, walking into the wall. The workaround is to either exit and re-enter (rezone) or pull up a menu like the save menu. If a harvest sprite is blocking the bridge to the harvest goddess, well, rezone...

Boulders spawning right in front of my house. Often. Like, several times a week. When I wake up and go to the valley, it's like there was a meteor shower, last night, and every night. Trees will respawn too. Sometimes you'll rezone on the same day, and where there was no boulder or tree five minutes ago, oh wait, there's one now... It's just too aggressive.

Resource acquisition is rage inducing. You'll need a metric ton of a particularly rare material but the resource node only respawns once every few days. I've long since been at 100% with my selected marriage candidate but I will never get material. The workaround is something called save scumming, which is to save just prior to hitting a resource node, and reloading if you do not get what you need. This should really not be a viable gaming strategy. Another workaround is to use the harvest sprites, but they only work once every other day, and weekends off.

I've mentioned "the work around" at least twice. Workarounds are illustrative of design flaws.

title: Sadly disappointed
text: My husband and I just completed this game and I wish I could say it was because we were enthralled by the amount of game play or puzzle action it provided. Instead, I have to say it's because we like to finish what we started. The impression we get of this game is that the programmers had to rush to get it to production and abandoned any hope of creative programming about halfway through it. It's less of a game, and more of a story line with things you can do to entertain yourself... at least until about halfway through when you have run out of things to actually do and end up simply wandering around the game platform hoping for encounters with characters. And there are no shortcuts to take you to places faster. How hard would it have been to include an interactive map where you could point to a destination and it would take you there? Apparently too hard for these programmers. Or maybe that would have just made the game too short because you can waste an incredible amount of time wandering around in this game, doing nothing. I can just hear the brainstorming that went into creating this game: "Okay, guys, we now have the story line and the gamer cannot mess with that until the end of the game, but the game is too short. Let's throw in a couple of seemingly important tasks to distract the player from the fact that they are actually doing nothing to solve a mystery! How about a parachute to nowhere? Or a radio that does nothing? You know what? The story is set around WWII, let's throw in a little meaningless Nazi teaser." I hate to give a bad review to something, but, really, if something is going to be advertised as a 'game', I'd like to see a little more finesse in how it allows the player to interact. Otherwise, just advertise it as a walk-through experience, which is more accurate. I'm so glad I didn't pay full price for this game, which is completely not worth it. If you are curious, save your money and rent the game.

title: Average Game/ DRM from Hell
text: I too have been reading about this game for years, watching every trailer as it was released and now even own the Galactic Edition.  I know there are people who love this game but I really found it just a little above average.  Cell stage is too short, creature stage was pretty fun, but keys are not reassignable.  OK, now the bad part.  I am NOT in to STEALING games, but this game penalizes the paying customer, and the paying customer ONLY.  You get three installs of this game.  If I put one on my laptop, and one on my computer, then upgrade my computer (I do this every three years or so), this game becomes useless.  I will have to write EA and get permission to install this game if I want to continue to use it.  Now here is the kicker.  People who STEAL this game will have unlimited usage and will not have to contact EA.  In fact if EA goes out of business some day I will be SOL, but the criminal will still have a working copy of the game....  You be the judge.  Consumers can STOP this type of DRM (Digital Rights Management) by not buying this type of product.

title: Singing gondoliers, gelato, nightclubs and sleuthing, oh my! text: In Nancy's eighteenth adventure from HerInteractive, Nancy makes good use of her passport in her second international outing, this time to Venice, Italy during Carnevale. Her old friend Prudence Rutherford (first heard from in [[ASIN:B000066ST3 Nancy Drew: Secret of the Scarlet Hand]]) has enlists her to discover the identity of the Phantom, a masked robber who's been making off with priceless antiques. The mysterious Phantom escapes detection, having knowledge of the security systems for each site.

Nancy's home base is Prudence's old palazzo, the Ca' Nascosta, now in a sad state of disrepair after Prudence sold it to a penny-pinching, ladder-climbing socialite. Nancy shares a room with Helena Berg, a young German journalist who is in love with Venice and hopes to move there. A British art restorer, Colin Baxter, develops a huge crush on Nancy while working on the Ca' and tries in vain to win her affection.

Italian culture is everywhere, and Nancy must even learn some basic Italian in order to participate in an important stakeout. You carry an Italian dictionary, which comes in useful for translating signs and documents. The background audio includes several conversations in Italian, but if you don't speak Italian, these aren't crucial to the game. Many times, characters are simply commenting on the Phantom and his adventures, or about personal events. Also included are several flavors of Italian gelato, the Italian card game Scopa, the various Carnevale masks, and Venetian architecture.

Nancy is working with the Guardia di Finanza, Italy's version of the FBI, to track the Phantom. Because it's Carnevale season, there aren't enough officers to tail him, so Nancy is given a PDA with tracking capabilities. There are several possible suspects, including Antonio Fango, the shady IT dealer who works across from Nancy's temporary residence, Enrico Tazza , a member of the Machiano Crime Syndicate and a fence for stolen goods , Colin, who has past secrets to hide, and the mysterious (and ungracious) hostess La Contessa Margherita Fauberg. Nancy has three modes of transportation: on foot (free), via vaporetto (water taxi, free), or by singing gondolier (between five and fifteen euros per trip). The main map is clearly laid out and is easy to navigate.

Like [[ASIN:B0009X6QJM Nancy Drew: Secret Of the Old Clock]], Nancy must earn money in order to purchase items needed in her investigation, including books and costume accessories. You begin the game with 200 Euros, and if you budget very wisely, you won't need extra money (those fashionable shopping trips, gelato cones and singing gondoliers really add up!). If you find yourself running short, there are several ways to earn extra income, including dancing in a nightclub dressed as a slinky black cat (!).I loved the variety of the nightclub dancing, although the character animation was jerky and I would have liked to see Nancy move more than just rotating her wrist in-between moves. From my own experience, you can earn between two to over thirty euros per dance depending on how well you nail the cues (for the hearing-impaired: the dance cues are auditory, but flashing colored lights also tell you which colored button to press).

I played the game on the Senior Detective level, which offers fewer step-by-step hints (there's no to-do list, for one) and more difficult puzzles, and the majority of the puzzles were sufficiently intuitive, but still challenging. The graphics are gorgeous as always; in scenes of the canals, visible from your bedroom balcony, the water ripples in real time. If you choose to ride a gondola (the amount varies depending on the gondolier), you're treated to a combination of still photos of Venice and rendered scenery which proves quite effective (along with the various Italian-language serenades taken from Italian opera and popular songs). Unlike some prior greats such as [[ASIN:B000V728P2 Nancy Drew: The Legend of the Crystal Skull]] and [[ASIN:B0002ZALES Nancy Drew: Curse of Blackmoor Manor]], the actual story in "Phantom of Venice" is spread a bit thin; the game could have benefitted from one or two additional suspects. But the variety of puzzles, some of which are new to the series (stakeouts, tracking, jewel heists), and the inclusion of Italian culture make up for these shortcomings.

title: Cannot see lighting effects when using text: I have to admit, I‚Äôm somewhat of a magpie for things that light up. Especially when said things have rainbow color options. I have LED light strips on my desk and external monitor, a LED mousepad, a rainbow backlit external keyboard, and various lamps. At night, my office looks like a space ship.

All of this is to say I was drawn to the Tilted Nation Gaming Laptop Stand because of the ‚Äúvisually striking aesthetics‚Äù of the lighting options.

But when my laptop is on the stand, I can‚Äôt see the lighting effects! The sides of my laptop block any view of the lighting.

And I have a 13‚Äù Macbook Pro, so a larger laptop will block even more. The only way I can see the lighting effects is if I look underneath my laptop.

When I took the stand out of the box, one of the foam blocks meant to hold the laptop in place fell off. I stuck it back on, but naturally, that makes me worry about it falling off again and my laptop sliding off.

The stand does have an extra piece that can be put in the front slot, for use with bigger laptops. It does impede using a touchpad but provides extra stability.

The USB ports are really high on the back of the stand. If your laptop has a thick lid, the lid might cover or come very close to the ports. The stand is powered by USB-C, the box includes a USB-C to USB-C cable and a USB-C to USB-A cable to accommodate all laptops.

Depending on where your laptop‚Äôs vents are, the top portion of the stand might block them. The top support is 2 inches wide.

title: Good construction. Terrible ergonomics. text: I have mixed feelings about this keyboard. Note that I use it for typing, not gaming. On the plus side, it's heavy and has a solid feel. The layout is standard and the multimedia controls with the big knob for the volume are convenient.

I'm so-so on the Cherry Brown switches. The key action takes some getting used to.The keys actually activate before you get to the "click" at the bottom of the stroke. So you can theoretically type lightly. But there is no tactile or auditory feedback at the activation point. So if you try to not push all the way down you may find that some key presses don't register. It takes more force than other keyboards to fully activate the keys, resulting in finger fatigue.

But the biggest problem is that the keyboard has terrible ergonomics. Many modern keyboards have a layout that angles at least slightly toward the outside to accommodate shoulder width so that your wrists stays straight. This keyboard is completely straight. And although the keys and the width of the keyboard look standard, the shape of the key caps or something else I can't figure out makes this keyboard feel very small and constrained. I have to keep my arms tight at my side in an awkward position to type on it. Otherwise, my wrists are bent so far that I get pain almost immediately when I use it. This keyboard is also taller than many keyboards. Which means unless you enjoy carpal tunnel, it desperately needs a wrist support. (Really, you charge well over $150 for a keyboard and you can't provide a wrist support?)

Honestly, I make more typing mistakes on this keyboard than any other keyboard I've ever used. I keep thinking I'll get used to it. But I've had it for a couple of months and it's still uncomfortable to me. I have a wrist pad on order. I hope that will help. The construction quality is good. But it doesn't really make up for poor design. Because I liked the qualify feel and thought I might get used to the design, I missed the return window. So I'm stuck with it. But if I had it to do over, I wouldn't buy it--particularly at the premium price compared to other keyboards.

title: Lovin' this game!! text: Just got the game this week......30% finished with it. I think it's great!

PROS : The music selections from the movies are fun to listen to while you play. Jack Sparrow....LOVE HIM!!! Lego really nailed his character...with his running while leaning back, arms flailing. The game play is fairly straight forward.....running around looking for cursed coins, ships in the rum bottles, etc. I like the layout of the bottom screen, showing all your players available....changeable with the L and R buttons.

CON : The ONLY things that bug me are the little movie clips between the levels. They ARE a little blurry and could be cleaned up a bit. But I definitely wouldn't NOT buy the game based on this.

I'm finding this game to be pretty easy....but very entertaining. Played it WHILE watching Pirates 3....really fun to watch LEGO's version of the scenes and then the same movie scene on TV. My 6 (almost 7) year old son is playing this game too and he is finding some of it to be difficult. But it is the same with all Lego games for him. He is finding this much easier than LEGO Star Wars Clone Wars.

Overall....LOVE this game! Our copy came with a little Jack Sparrow LEGO figure that my son carries around with him all the time.

title: Decent game - 3 stars
text: This is a decent game -- not great, but ok. 3 stars.  Here's why:  First of all, some of the screens are pretty dark.  I know they do this so you'll use the thermal imaging and x-ray vision (both pretty cool), but it takes away from the gameplay, in my opinion, when you can't see the whole screen.  Secondly, I'm using my Sureshot Rifle, so take this in stride, but pushing the C and Z buttons is a little cumbersome, but not too terrible.  I'm going to try this with the WiiZapper, and if it's a lot better, I'll post that on here.  I really think it will be about the same...  The power-up special weapons are a little difficult to use, too.  By comparison, they're much easier to use on my Cabela's Dangerous Hunts 2011 or Remington Grand Slam North America (two excellent games) than this game, but still usable.  It was pretty fun game what I've played so far, but didn't put me on the edge of my seat like the 2 games I mentioned above.  It's an ok buy, tho, for $20.

title: I don't understand why this reviews so well text: I normally like thinking persons' games but this one has me a bit confused. It's like a text based Adventure with minimalistic graphics and a sound track that doesn't live up to the hype- there's almost no music, just a rather odd ambient sound track.

It tries to be clever and occasionally it succeeds but just as often it fails. It was not at all immersive for me, and I found it rather boring to play. Quite frankly, I think I'd like my money back please. If not, could I please get some of the same recreational drugs the authors were on when they designed this?

title: Difficult for newbies, great graphics and storyline text: First thing - this game is really difficult for newbies to the gaming world. As adults with our first game system, we purchased several games in different genres for our new Wii system. We bought one of the other Resident Evil titles and loved it, so this one seemed like a natural choice due to the rave reviews and the first person shooter perspective. I love the graphics here - it's very easy to get sucked into the world and the feel of the game without question. Especially if you have the opportunity to set it up on a Hi-Def large screen television - gorgeous.

However, this is a hard game! It's not a game for beginners unless you just enjoy frustration and shrieking at the tv and starting over again and again and again. The little tricks and subtle ins and outs that long time gamers all pick up as they play game after game after game hours on end seem to be needed and assumed for Resident Evil 4. That in and of itself is not a dealbreaker, just something I wish I had known ahead of time - I would have waited and purchased this game later on. What ended up happening is we got frustrated and stuck at the first village, stopped playing the game for a couple of months, conquered some others, learned some gaming tricks in general and have now come back to Resident Evil 4 with a fresh perspective and attitude and we're enjoying it much more the second time around. So.... not a game a for first timers, but one worth playing when you've gotten your feet wet elsewhere first.

title: Never lose your keys in the heat of battle again! text: I love this! You can mix color sets for easier identification. The colorings help me with video editing, game-play and programming! Anything that keeps my eyes more focused on the screen is wonderful!

I am using the keys on my Perfect Razer Keyboard, but they work just as well on any mechanical keyboard that allows you to remove the keys.

It comes with various sized spaces, shifts and enter keys. It comes with US Dollars and GB Pounds so you can use it comfortably in the UK and in the USA. It comes with extra parts to help balance the keys - I cannot comment on those, I did not need them with my Razer keyboard.

Easy to clean, clear and very easy to see, a good feel to them. They are great for typing on (between writing reviews, working on a book, blogging and creating documentation for my business, I type a lot!) and excellent for game-play.

If you game, and have a mechanical keyboard. You need this.

If you do not yet have a mechanical keyboard, please check out the Razer keyboards. They really are the best - I have never been more pleased with a keyboard, or, for that matter, a mouse!

All the above is excellently constructed from the finest parts. The drivers are very well written, making these tools very easy to configure and use.

title: Uncomfortable text: I gave this headset a middle of the road rating. It has some good points...like good sound, nice fabric wrapped cord, easy controls, and the headpiece adjusts easily, but it has some drawbacks as well. One of the most glaring problems is the ear covers. They are just too small...and round. How many people do you know with ROUND ears? Most ears are oval in shape. I think my ears are pretty normal size, but they don't quite fit in the ear cushions. It is very uncomfortable.

I tried using the headset with my xBox One in a chat group with my friends. At one point they were having trouble hearing me. There are only two sound controls, the mute switch (which works fine), and a volume control. I thought the volume control was to control the level of sound I was hearing in the earphones. Apparently, it controls my voice to the group, because my friends were having trouble hearing me until I tinkered with the volume control. When I turned it up, they could hear me better. That was a little confusing.

In the end, I took this headset off and went back to using my Turtle Beach headset. I don't recommend this headset.

title: Perfection. text: Don't waste your time with any other stick or pad. This is probably the best controller I have used since Capcom released the 15th anniversary controller for the PS2. I have always used that particular controller with a converter cable up until the Hori Commander 4.

Although this is a straight D pad, it responds so crisply and perfectly, like the engineer or designer grew up playing fighting games. This controller has connected my thumbs to Street Fighter in a way that no controller in the past has done, even the Capcom 15th anniversary one (which was SO good, but the circular D pad was extremely fragile, I would snap a D pad every few months).

This Hori feels like it will last forever, its organic, and it works perfect. Having never played on it before, I went 10-0 with it on SFV so far. Just buy this, and forget about anything else.

title: Very useful and well-made product!! text: A short time after I purchased my Nintendo Switch console, I also bought this Excellent item, the HORI Compact Playstand for Nintendo Switch (Officially Licensed by Nintendo). I am very glad that I did!

If you think you will probably be using your Nintendo Switch often in what is commonly referred to as "Table Top" mode, then you will most likely want to pick up one of these incredibly useful Play Stand accessories.

The Play Stand itself is very easy to use, and it provides you with three different viewing angles.

And, because this Play Stand raises your Nintendo Switch up off of the table, you can then connect a USB C type connector to the bottom of your Switch, thus allowing you to charge your system, while the play Stand is being used. This is a nice plus.

The HORI Play Stand is well-constructed.. and I would definitely‚Äã recommend it to anyone who owns a Nintendo Switch!

title: LED is great, but smells strongly of rubber text: If you‚Äôre like me and like things that light up, an LED mouse pad is really fun to have on your desk. I also like big mouse pads that can fit my laptop, mouse, and drink, so this mouse pad from Zpose does double duty.

The mouse pad has several lighting modes. My preference is for the static colors (red, blue, green, purple, cyan, yellow, and white) since they are less distracting when I‚Äôm working. But some of the dynamic modes are fun; there are a few that slowly change color and don‚Äôt flash in and out.

The mouse pad remembers the last selected light mode, which is nice. The two different brightness options (tap the button twice quickly to change) are almost identical. It is powered by an included micro USB cable. The cable is about 70 inches long.

The LED stripe around the edge of the mouse pad is flexible, so the mouse pad can be rolled up for easy storage.

I‚Äôve taken off a star because the mouse pad has a *very* strong rubber scent. The smell is strong enough to turn my stomach and give me a headache. I let the mouse pad air out for over a week but it still has the rubber smell.

title: Sweet and well-written text: Auggie Pullman loves Star Wars, his family, and his dog. His parents and his big sister Via have always looked out for him, and the folks on his block in upper Manhattan are used to him and care about him too. But now that he's starting fifth grade, his parents decide that it's time for him to venture outside his little world and go to school -- regular school -- where he'll have to deal with a whole lot of new people. That would be a challenge for any kid, but it's especially challenging for Auggie, whose face is not like other kids' faces.

But this isn't a depressing, "kids-with-issues" book. In fact what struck me about it was how much Auggie's struggles are like other kids' struggles. His specific situation gives him difficulties that most other kids don't have to deal with. But he deals with them pretty much the way any kid would -- or maybe a little better. The story is told first from Auggie's point of view, then from his sister's and other characters', so we see the impact of Auggie's facial deformity on others around him as well. The book reminded me of the best of Judy Blume, with its realistic characters of various ages. But it's maybe a tad more optimistic about human nature. Aimed at ages 8 and up, I can see this book being enjoyed by teens and adults as well as younger kids.

title: Poor Performance All Around
text: Not happy with these at all. I gave them several days to adjust to these but the sound quality from games and music were muffled and just very lacking in all aspects. The microphone was the deal breaker for me. I was getting constant feedback that I sounded distant or muffled no matter what settings I changed. Issues were present on PC and PS4 so I can't blame settings on one or the other. The cool gel was pretty much pointless. You can feel the cooling affect for a minute or two when first using, but after that they felt just as warm if not warmer than other headphones. The so called "DAC" that is included is not a true DAC and I couldn't get any noticeable difference on the PC when playing with the settings. I wasn't expecting audiophile quality in the price range but I have other headphones that sound much better in this price range so in my opinion, these are not worth the price.
