title: I am very Pleased with my Wii U! text: I have owned a "normal" Wii for several years now. And I recently decided to purchase the Wii U, based on how much I had enjoyed many great games on my previous Nintendo system. Thus far I am loving my Wii U! I did a systems transfer of my old Wii game data, and everything went fine! So I am now playing all my old favorites on my Wii U, as well as looking forward to new games which will take advantage of the new system.

The Nintendoland game which came with the deluxe set I purchased is loads of fun, and I would recommend the Wii U to anyone who has either owned or enjoyed a "regular" Wii.

The new controller is fantastic and I can't wait to see what future games will be like!

title: A tad small, barely holds the essentials, but great item. text: A sturdy well built hard shell case for the Nintendo DS. It holds 16 games (both DS and 3DS game cartridges fit).

I bought this for an upcoming vacation so I would have something to protect my DS during the trip so I would have something to do on the long car ride down to the Florida Keys.

This case comes with a weird insert which I guess is for the smaller systems or something, however the insert does not fit the 3DS XL and after putting in game cartridges, the console itself and charger it doesn‚Äôt even fit in the case so its kinda pointless and I chucked it in the bin.

With that being said though the zipper pouch does not hold much It will hold a handful of Amiibo cards and your charger but not much else - be advised do not try to fit to much stuff in this case as it can barely zip up once console, games and charger are inside and putting to much stuff in may run the risk of you busting the zipper when you try to close the case.

If you are in doubt on if this will be big enough for you I recommend going with your gut instinct and find a bigger case, This works find for me as I have under 16 games and rarely travel with my system but for a more travel oriented person you might want something bigger.

Other than that well made case at a decent price!

title: Not quite what I was hoping for... text: Quick review, haven't used it a lot yet. First, the version I got (Atari Flashback 8 Gold Deluxe) has an HDMI port so I ordered a long HDMI cable to attach to my TV. For some reason I thought I needed the RCA converter, I did not.

Easy to set up and start playing, lots of great games including old favorites. Noticed that in Frogger, you need to be active in the game to exit back to the main menu.

Love the wireless joysticks, but the wired paddles are stiff and jump a lot, no smooth movement for play. Makes the games I wanted the paddles for (Pong, Circus Atari) almost unplayable, which is disappointing - this is why I got the Gold Deluxe version with the paddles. Note that two paddles are on one cord and connect to one of the two ports on the unit, it's hard to know which is player 1 or 2 without guesswork.

title: This adapter does what I expected- the IQIKU USB C to HDMI Adapter text: Recently, we purchased a mini projector (nothing too fancy, just a portable one), now that I've got it's permanent placement in the family room- it was time to see if I could attach the gaming console. A USB C to HDMI adapter was required to broadcast the Nintendo Switch (original system).

I'm happy to say it is compatible with the original Switch unit, as claimed.

The unit is true to the sizes given, is lightweight and very portable. It feels sturdy, and am very sure I'll have it for years to come. The included HDMI cable seems built well enough, though personally I'm using it with a different (much longer) cable.

I have no complaints with this product. It's one of those "it does what it says it will" things.

title: The way Xbox batteries should have been all along!! text: I'm so annoyed with myself for not finding these sooner. title: Confusing software or would be 5 stars. A little on the expensive side I paid the $170 for Rapidfire text: Update July 2019: I've owned the keyboard a little over 3 years. Customer support hasn't answered and it's been almost a week so I am dropping the review to 2 stars. That and because it is malfunctioning. I had a ticket in with support and their suggestion was to plug it into another computer, which I didn't have at the time so the issue was never resolved. Now I have tried the keyboard in multiple other computers, and the keys send multiple signals when I press them. Hit E once, anywhere from 2 - 10 E's show up, same with almost every key. So typing is a nightmare I'm constantly using backspace. Typing passwords is almost impossible. I do LOVE a mechanical keyboard but having a 2 year warranty, and after paying $170 for your keyboard, watch it die in 3 years sucks. I did order a renewed K70 keyboard from the corsair outlet for $70, because these keyboards are fantastic once you get used them. And I couldn't really go to another brand since I've invested in the corsair mouse, and corsair pad. The CUE to make the RGB colors schemed is also fantastic. The K95 Platinum is the expensive keyboard from them right now, Rapidfire was pretty new when I got it, I'm switching to the LUX for a quieter key click.

UPDATE: Putting the stars back to 4 stars, this keyboard keeps pretty clean, I did have to buy a can of air to shoot some cat hair out ( I could have just pulled a couple keys with the key puller they sent... ) this review is going back to 4 stars because the RGB lighting is cooler than cool, it's ice cold! Thanks to my new graphics card also having RGB I'm rocking a sick red white blue setup between my gear... Keyboard the american flag, mouse white, headphones red, front case fan blue, graphics card red and white... All red is a little intense for me, but most my friends seem to like it the best. Sadly I use an Xbox 360 controller for most of my gaming right now.

UPDATE: Amazon Prime day July 12 2017, I've had this keyboard about a month, new rapidfire switches, I paid like $180, today it is $109. I wish I waited until now....

UPDATE to the UPDATE: The keyboard is nice, and being able to change the colors is cool, I don't have another keyboard with switches so I don't know if these rapidfire switches are that much better than regular MX cherry reds, I wish I saved the $100 and got a regular mechanical keyboard and used money towards a new video card.

UPDATE: After 12 hours of intensive gaming, I love this keyboard even if I need to get used to how sensitive the keys are... I find myself strafing left because my finger is resting too hard on the A key (I'm used to holding it halfway down to get a fast strafe). I am in the processes of ordering a replacement, my volume adjustment makes a horrible squeal when adjusting volume down (sounds like nails on a chalk board). I am leaving this at 4 out of 5 stars because my extra keys do not include 1-6, I received the key puller WASD in the top half of the package, then keys, Q,W,E,R,D,F. Not my most used keys, my W&S keys definitely get worn off the fastest since I run mostly FPS games, then the number keys wear out.

This is only getting 4 out of 5 stars. Pros, fast key response, cool lights. Cons, expensive, keys are too close together (I used to have a partial key next to the A, so I didn't just bump capslock. Also F11 & F12 are really close to the backspace), software is horrible to learn.

My keyboard plugged in and looked badass to start, all red with white letters for WASD and my arrow keys on the right, after installing the software it started doing a crazy rainbow spiral. After halfway through a 40minute youtube video I got the Default lightning profile back to red with white (I wanted blue... to match my mouse). I can't even get the other K70 profiles on corsairs website to work. I downloaded a couple profiles to check them out, figured out how to import them into the right category, and they just blackout the keyboard like it doesn't have lights.

title: Top-notch sequel in "Escape From Monkey Island" text: "Escape from Monkey Island" is the fourth game in the "Monkey Island" series, which follow the adventures of wannabe pirate Guybrush Threepwood and the love of his life, Governor Elaine Marley, as they battle against the evil undead pirate Chuck LeChuck (who just won't stay dead after three games). In "Escape from Monkey Island" Guybrush returns from his honeymoon with Elaine to find out that they have been declared dead. Now he must investigate a slimy Australian developer who is buying up all of the Tri-Island area and "reforming" the pirates into docile citizens. In the meantime Elaine is running for governor against Charles L. Charles, a suspiciously familiar face. Once again Guybrush gets to rescue the damsel in distress, fight monkeys in Monkey Kombat (a hilarious Mortal Kombat spoof you have to see to believe), and test his wit at Insult Arm Wrestling, as well as downing Groggoccinos from Starbuccaneers and visiting his own theme restaurant Planet Threepwood (sound familiar?), all while trying to find a powerful Voodoo charm, the Ultimate Insult, before the bad guys do.
"EFMI" is the first game to feature 3D characters, and all of the familiar faces (Guybrush, Elaine, Carla, Otis, Herman) translate well to their new medium. The game's engine is basically an upgraded Grim Fandango GRIME system, but the graphics are gorgeous (and eccentric: the familiar swirly clouds, watercolour stars, nifty maps and gaudy costumes look great). The music is a mysterious blend of Caribbean and sweeping scores worthy of John Williams (steel drums, rowdy pirate music, Muzak in Starbuccaneers and Jambalaya Island (the same theme changes to a minor key once you visit Nuttin Atoll, nice touch) string-driven themes). The voice acting is superb, with Dominic Armato returning as Guybrush, Charity James as Elaine, Earl Boen as LeChuck, Tom Kane (Darwin on "The Wild Thornberries"), and Nick Tate as Ozzie. The dialogue is as sharp as any of the previous games (I loved listening to Ozzie Mandrill spouting Australian insults and throwing around Aussie slang at every opportunity), and the storyline is always a surprise. I had a few small technical problems even after installing the patch, but I found workarounds, and other than that the game ran great (it does require 3D acceleration, however). A pleasure from beginning to end, I only hope that there will be more "Monkey Islands" in the future!

title: Worst Version of the Sims text: **My review is based on the game, not the physical copy**

title: Not for large hands or intense gaming
text: Good vertical mouse for the money. The sensor is good. It doesn't spin out on fast movements. The sensitivity options and side buttons are must haves for a gaming mouse. But it has a few problems. The mouse wheel sometimes activates with side pressure, which can be disastrous in an intense game but it's otherwise not a big deal. Right click seems to fail about once every 100-200 clicks, but this might be hand size related. I don't recommend it if you have large hands (I'm six feet tall, average tall person hands). There's not quite enough room for all my fingers, so my pinky is kind of splayed out and my middle finger doesn't line up perfectly with the right mouse button. There other large hands issue is the buttons are inset, with a rim of housing along the front. Sometimes i accidentally press on that bit of housing instead of the button, which fails to click. Not an issue if you claw grip your mouse, but otherwise problematic. For office and non-competitive gaming, is a good semi-budget option. For esports or the large handed, I'd get something else.

title: RNG is horrific and non-existent customer service
text: Everything in this game is run on a random number generator or RNG. This system is horrific. I have played for years at this point and I have never gotten anything decent out of one of their luxury boxes. You would have better chances of getting jackpots for a week straight in Vegas, than getting anything decent out of their RNG. It would be a great game if the random number generator was not soo horrific. It is its whole foundation and that's the problem. Even knowledge gain is based off of RNG. It screws you out of soo much time and energy. A lot of people pay actual money just to be able to get past certain points in the game because the RNG is soo bad. You know it's really bad when casinos have better odds. Customer service is also basically non-existent, their general attitude is fluff the customer.

title: Great Mix of Humor and Hidden Objects
text: The MCF games are always high-quality, and this one is no exception.  It has excellent artwork, and objects are well-integrated into the scenes without being completely obscure.  In this game you act as an investigator trying to figure out who stole the diamond.  You investigate 20-odd suspects- and here's where we get to see some humor.  These suspects are all rather shady characters, humorously drawn, who fit into some amusing stereotypes without being offensive (think the stage diva who can't sing, the kind of shady carnival worker, the stay-at-home mom who has a side job as a bank robber).  As you investigate each character you'll find out if they have an alibi or not.  At the end of the game, you solve a final puzzle to determine which of the five is guilty.  This changes each time you play, preserving replay value.  This game is now several years old, but I remember when it came out it was leaps and bounds ahead of its time.

title: Dragon Quest Builders 2 text: I played and loved the origianl DQB, and as well as being an overall fan of Dragon Quest in general, so this was a must-buy for me.

The game is extremely engaging. No spoilers here, but I'm in the third chapter now. Now sure how big overall the game is. There are tons of improvements to the original which makes it a worthwhile investment. Even if you've never played Dragon Quest Builders 1, or the mainline franchise, if you like crafting and building, this is a great game.

I dock one star for a few issues:

* Slow pacing. Like a traditional JRPG, this has TONS of dialog. Most of the dialog is easy to step thru by just mashing the A button, but there are some story-centric scenes which cannot be skipped and just take forever to wait out.
* Very small UI scale. In handheld mode, it can make it a squint-fest and there is no way to increase the font or stuff.
* I haven't unlocked free-play mode. I guess just like the original, you have to finish the game first. That might be a turnoff to some people who just want to be creative. There is a built-in social media network where you can share screenies and some of those are AMAZING, I just wish we could get there sooner.
* Frame rating issues. Generally the game runs smoothly, but I've had one boss battle which was fairly involved, NPCs running all over the place, monsters popping up, and the boss itself hurling attacks, and it really hammered the Switch's performance.

Issues aside, it's a great game and no regrets.

Who else named their slime Rimuru?

title: Consider this before buying a PS2 within the next 2 months text: The Playstation 2 is, without a doubt, one of the best video game systems of all time. It has such a diverse library of games that you are bound to find something to apease everybody. So why am I giving it 4 stars instead of 5?

There are two factors about the current PS2 design that you won't find anywhere on the box. The first is reliability/quality of design. My first PS2 broke 2 weeks after I bought it. It started making a quiet rattling noise while the games were playing, so I would check the games when I heard the noise and they would be fine... well one day they weren't fine. In fact, Blockbuster wasn't amused when I told them my PS2 lacerated the bottom of their disc like a Cat from Pet Cemetary. That's one experience right?

My friend is on her 3rd PS2 (keep in mind the PS2 has only been out for about 4 to 5 years). Another couple I know is experiencing their first problem with their PS2 2 years after they bought it. It won't play any discs that are black on the back (Almost all PSone discs, and a lot of early PS2 discs).

A lot of people will tell you that the PS2 only has problems if you stand it upright (which Sony says is perfectly fine and even sells a stand for). That would be inconsistent with my experience because mine still malfunctioned and it was sitting horizontally. I even have a horizontal stand which is supposed to increse airflow (the horizontal stand made by Sony). Also, the friend I mentioned who is on her third PS2 console has never stood her's upright.

I'm not saying that every PS2 is going to up and die on you, but I think all consumers should be aware that the PS2 has reliability issues, and a quick browse through these reviews will confirm that. It doesn't mean it isn't still an awesome system!

The next thing you will want to consider is whether or not you want THIS model of PS2. You may have read lately that the PS2 got a major overhaul unveiled at the Tokyo Game Show. Well, that revised version of the PS2 will be available in the US on Nov. 1st 04 according to Sony. In my opinion, they may be responding to the quality problem with this new system... but that is speculation and really doesn't belong in a review so scratch that from the record books. The difference between the new and old version is sheer mass. In all ways the new design is much smaller. It can also be stood upright. It is some 75% smaller and 50% lighter. You can see it on Playstation.com. It will also be 150 bucks, no price difference. It looks a lot more solid. HOWEVER!!! If you plan on playing Final Fantasy XI get the current design before it is gone. So far the redesigned PS2 doesn't support the HDD Hard Drive necessary to play FFXI and Sony hasn't expressed any plans for that. So, the question becomes do you want the classic design or the updated version that hits in Nov. Me? I can't really wait until Nov. because MK Deception comes out in a few weeks hehehehe.

A word about accessories. As I mentioned before I have a horizontal stand for my PS2. The horizontal stand is supposed to increse airflow. Supposedly, this does good things for the system. The stand is worthless. It doesn't really connect to the system, the system just sits on top of it. It's kinda cool looking... other than that you should be aware that neither the horizontal or vertical stands are necessary because the system is designed so that it can stand or sit without a stand. The vertical stand adds a little extra balance but I recommend you never put your system on carpet or an uneven surface. The carpet causes static issues and, like uneven surfaces, can result in the system falling if shaken too hard (take note parents of energetic kids). The PS2 already has quality issues, don't give it any additional trauma to help the process along.

Third party controllers (Controllers made by a company other than Sony) just aren't as good as factory controllers. Plain and simple. They all have cool little features and they are getting better, but stick to the controllers made by Sony and avoid the headache of unresponsive controls. This is, of course, unless you absolutely need a wireless controller so people aren't tripping when they walk by, or if your hands (or your little gamer's hands) are too small for a standard controller, there are "mini" controllers available.

As far as online game play goes, the PS2 leads the pack for play features while the Xbox leads the pack for... instant messaging and lan party-esque mass multi-player gaming. Sometimes the Xbox is a little more like a computer that I approve of. NOTE- if you want to play online you need to make sure the PS2 you are buying comes with the online adapter (or if you wait till Nov. for the redesign it will be intergrated). If you don't have highspeed internet, don't worry! According to Sony 40% of it's online market is tapping online gaming with dial-up. Dial-up is an option if you have an online adapter.

That's about it. Hope this was helpful. PS2 Rocks!

title: Performance depends on your system text: When I got this I was a bit disappointed. Kiddo has an entry level gaming laptop (he's almost 8, entry is about all I trust him with right now) that gets full rather easy and the biggest space hog is his Steam library. I was hoping this would be a quick fix to moving the games off his laptop without a loss of performance. But moving the games took FOREVER and he kept knocking the external SSD around on his small desk. It also gets a bit warm when taxing it, so I called it a fail, and just ended up upgrading his internal M.2 SSD instead.

Since I was stuck with this thing, I decided I would use it as a temporary drive for my desktop. I needed to replace my rather old internal HDD and I didn't want to crowd my second smaller drive. My system is quite a bit better than the kids, with a newer i-7 Intel processor and a freshly installed vid card (GeForce RTX 2080 Super). This made all the difference, the file transfers zipped along including my Steam library. I was able to play games directly from the drive without a noticeable drop in performance, although I play things like Rimworld and Terraria, so I may not tax it as much as some of the more graphic heavy games out there. I was scared to test Ark, that poorly optimized game likes to crash my entire system... @#$%.

I did eventually put everything back onto an internal drive, I like having this though as a nice back up and quick way to transfer items. Some things like tax and other important documents I left a copy on the drive. Just in case my system blows up or has a major melt down.

TL;DR
This SSD Drive's performance is very dependent on your system. Which is going to be true of all similar products.

With so much build-up from The Pok√©mon Company for this milestone game, I expected more travel, more story, more side quests, and more fun. Instead I got a handful of Kurt's pok√©balls (one each), one nostalgic battle, and a few camio appearances from boring past characters.

Overall, 3 1/2 stars out of 5

title: It's gorgeous of course! text: I have bought more cases from these guys then I can shake a stick at. Everyone in my family wanted one design or another.
While the clear ones in various colors seems to be popular, the one everyone DROOLS over is this color.
Not surprising, really. It's gorgeous and pictures can't even remotely do it justice so, yes, I nabbed the chameleon as soon as I saw it and cannot wait for more designs to match more of their various Switch and joycon cases.
Sadly, there is one itty bitty caveat to the chameleon and, please do listen VERY closely because it is NOT their fault: the chameleon colors are basically car paint. You can ONLY get that kind of coloration from a really good car paint job. I mean, you have got to have talent to even do this kind of color but, yes, sadly, the inherent flaws of the medium just cannot be escaped.
Lemme rephrase: they HAD TO go with paint to get the sparkly, irredescent colors (the chameleon colors). The downside however is that those colors are a little more delicate than the others.
OTHER COLORS ARE NOT AFFECTED!!!
Sometimes, cool costs, whatcanisay?
That being said, on the Switch's backplate or, here, on the dock, I don't see it being much of a problem but folks may want to avoid harsh cleaners just to be safe.
Or, you may be like me and seriously just not care cause... *COOL*!!!!
Still thought folks might wanna know though when picking their color scheme.
:D

title: True to the Films is Priority #1 text: When it comes to making a horror videogame, atmosphere comes as a much higher priority than gameplay mechanics. This may be the reason you might've seen a few game critics being tough on SAW. Game reviewers are often looking for revolutionary game mechanics, new gameplay ideas, and a truckload of hyperbole from magazines and websites to score their games highly. But just like every SAW film, it's videogame cousin stands for much more than meets the eye, and doesn't need to defy conventions to be true to the source material.

In fact, SAW does not fight against any conventions at all. Mostly every aspect of the game is familar to horror game veterans: Dark, moody graphics, low lighting, first-person controls, third-person view, grimy and rusted environments, dark musical score, particularly gruesome etc. Combat controls are fairly basic and often sluggish, but get the job done nonetheless.

There are tons of exploring possibilities, and true to the films, these environments look fairly similar to one another. Puzzle solving is key in SAW: Levels consist of lots of puzzles; some basic, some more complicated, and a few are very clever. There are several puzzles in each level, so exploration and puzzle solving are more prominent than action-heavy combat. You may encounter only a few enemies in each level; all of them playing their own "game" to stay alive.

Each level ends in your character trying to free another from one of Jigsaw's many death devices; SAW's version of a boss fight. These puzzles are usually more perplexing, and may take a few tries to complete, but none of these puzzles are impossible.

What SAW gets particulary right is its atmosphere. The ambience from the films are nailed in this game version, and will immediately immerse you in the SAW universe. Several characters from the films make an appearance in an all-new storyline, and one voice in particular will be instantly familiar. Little things like this add up to a lot when making a licensed game.

If you like horror games and the SAW films, you'll be very pleased with the finished product. It doesn't have the production values or extra polish of what are considered to be top-tier games, and certainly doesn't introduce anything incredibly new. But the atmosphere alone is worth the price of admission, especially if you are more interested in using your brain than your trigger finger. Be aware that you'll likely need to be a fan of the SAW films to completely enjoy this title, but if you are, it's fan service at its finest.

The wheel jump is a manageable issue to deal with, however yesterday, only 7 months of moderate gaming and work usage, my wheel button is now difficult to use successfully. The mouse overall is nice, I wish it didn't have all these problems with the wheel, but it seems that this is an ongoing issue with Steelseries Sensei mice and they haven't addressed it. Just ordered my first Deathadder to replace this. Should have it on Monday and hopefully will be a more fine-tuned product.

title: A Magical Farm
text: In many ways this is your typical time-management farm game.  You have to grow crops and harvest animal products and complete orders.  The twist with this game is that you have magical powers.  In practical terms this affects gameplay very little- instead of a toolbox to fix your broken machines, you have a bag of magic powder to sprinkle on them.  That said, the goals are challenging without being impossible, and this game offers quite a lot of gameplay for your dollar.  This is not a game to be finished in one sitting.  Overall I found it to be quite similar to Ranch Rush.  If farm games are not a passion for you, then owning one or the other may very well be sufficient.  If you love farm games and can't wait for the next one, you'll probably want both.  In any case, this is one of the better farm games on the market, and I'd recommend everyone at least give the demo a try.

title: Hey Rocko let's race! text: Very good kart racing game. Sorry but I do get tired of MK sometimes after playing all itterations for years. I'd hate to add up all those hours....
This game controls well....I used a wired controller and played on the tv. You cant reconfigure buttons or use gamecube controllers. It wont take long to get used to it though.
Colors are vivid, tracks are good and good length. They also are not too wide or too narrow. But the magic of course is the characters! I was quick to unlock Heffer because he is my favorite. In this game you also unlock crew members and chiefs. They actually let you customize the gameplay....Muddy Mudskipper lets you go through slime really fast. You get to make different combos to make a really unique ride. I dont know how many combinations there are but its a LOT. Different ones can do things such as act as a magnet to suck up coins, add extra boosts, extra items, etc. This alone should keep the game fresh and fun for a long time.

The cars do feel different. You can change the wheels, engine and tail pipes to change vehicle stats such as speed, drift, handling, etc. Parts are unlocked to be bought with your coins collected and won. You can really change up the looks of a vehicle with paint schemes and they arent limited to specific characters so Spongebob can have Ninja Turtle paint on his vehicle. I dont think weight matters like it does in MK.

I ran through the cups in medium, all manual control in about 4 hours, taking short breaks, placing first fairly easily. The credits roll when you place 1st in all cups in any speed. But parents, dont let a kid fool you and say they beat the game and are done with it if the credits roll....I have also done several challanges and a boss "fight" and have only unlocked or accomplished 18% of the game on about 5.5 total hours playtime.

Theres a battle arena that would be awesome with other players in the room but you can play it alone.

So...is it as polished as MK? No. The music is lacking....i would like to have had show theme songs. Sound effects are great....slime sounds slimey! The game looks fine--really good most of the time. I did experience some disappointing lag at times and they need to patch that. Its bad when it happens and theres no excuse for it. Thats the only gripe i have.

I think this is good for fans of kart racing games, its not perfect but its similar to MK but ....I think its 28 different tracks and even though thats a lot less than MK, its unique tracks make it a decent game. I cant attest to online play....i tried several times and didnt get a match....in other words, no one to race. Of course, this game just came out though.
This is a good game for kids, a family or people like me who love the older Nick chatacters and Spongebob. There are newer characters as well. Its FUN and thers a lot of humor in the pit crew items. Fun--That is the most important to me.

Easy 8 out of 10

title: Awesome Game - 5 Stars
text: At $35 on sale, this is one of the best shooter games I've played on Wii.  The gun is worth $30 by itself--I've priced similar guns.  I started out on the first gallery, and within a very short time had 3 more galleries unlocked.  OK, so my hand did get a little sore from pulling the trigger and pumping the pump, but it's well worth the inconvenience.  As an avid hunter, I might have an advantage over someone who has never hunted, but I think anyone with decent motor skills could pick it up and be successful pretty quickly.  Once you get used to the controls, this game is SO addictive and so fun.  I would pay $35 just for the first 4 levels.  I priced the arcade version of Big Buck Hunter, and it's $5000 for the standup game!  It does get pretty hard at Gallery 4, and that's as far as I've gotten.  I didn't even play the campaign at all last nite--just the galleries.  If you've got an itchy trigger finger, this game is for you.  There are tons of critters to shoot, and you only have to switch back and forth between a rifle and a shotgun, pull the trigger and reload your 3-shot rifle or double-barrelled shotgun.  The power-ups are great--slow motion, unlimited ammo, 2x points, marksman (thermal imaging kinda), and health are all really cool.  This game tells you at the end (assuming you stay alive) of each gallery how many critters you shot, how many bonuses you got, and what your accuracy was.  The action and graphics and sound are all very good.  I think the game writers intentionally made the geese that fly up and over hard to see against the backgrounds in order to make it more challenging to shoot the geese--just like real life goose hunting.  The nunchuck is a little bit tricky getting into the gun (the cord from the nunchuck to the front controller specifically), but once you get it in there, it is very secure, and I didn't have any problems at all.  I haven't played a better shooter hunting game for the money.  If anyone knows of a better big game shooter than this game, please let me know.

title: Excellent hardware with broken software support, use Logitech's legacy software text: Excellent mouse, as advertised with no hardware issues.

However, Logitech's G Hub software is a dumpster fire of an application. Logitech pushes updates that break the app itself or hardware functionality (like not registering left clicks). Background cpu usage is upwards of 15% on a Ryzen 3600 system. G Hub feels like an alpha release and Logitech hasn't be able to improve stability or app performance since they released G Hub back in February 2019. Yes, thats 7 months of garbage software support for their flagship hardware products. Save yourself the pain and DO NOT DOWNLOAD G HUB.

The fix is to use the legacy 'Logitech Gaming Software' which is still available and does include support for the 502 Hero. I'm using the LGS 9.02.65 release hosted on TechSpot and have no issues. LGS supports button rebinding as well as LED color control in a reliable fashion, unlike G Hub.

This would be an easy 5 star review but in 2019 I should not be forced to use legacy software to ensure my hardware functions properly.

title: Great Workout text: First I would like to say that this game was a lot of fun. I got it yesterday and played it for an hour and was sweating so much it was crazy. If you're a MJ fan, then this is the perfect game for you. I danced, I sang, then I danced some more. Interesting enough it wasn't hard to follow the moves from the pictograms or even MJ himself because they depicted his signature moves. I'm totally in love with this game.

Now for the bad... unlocking training videos, really? Training and warm/up videos should have been a feature that is available to the user before they begin attempting the dance moves and not something that the user gets after he has attempted the dance moves. The next thing that I found annoying was that I had to enter my name each time I completed a song. I should have been assigned a avatar/user at the beginning of the game to eliminate this need.

Overall, BIG FUN!!! But, I couldn't in good conscience give this game the full five stars because of the problems with game usability. The realism and fun of the songs and dance moves are a solid 6 stars but the usability is a only worthy of 2 stars. Thus, I'll compromise with a rating of 4 stars.

title: Great addition to the Xeno games text: So I'm going to say right away that i'm a big fan of the Xenogames in general. It's the reason I decided now was the time to buy a switch, I'm also 100+ hours in.

That said I love this game, it feels like the xenoblade games before it but the combat does feel improved now that you no longer have to cycle through arts since they are now assigned to face buttons. The chain combos add a very satisfying feel to the combat as well.

A lot of complaints I read was that the combat takes too long, at first I agreed but when you use the combo chains effectively things feel pretty standard for a xenoblade battle.

The complaints of the map is all true, even with updates it's pretty easy to just be totally lost due to elevations mostly. If they add the follow guide thing from Xenoblade chronicles X then everything would be fine.

Another issue i saw people having was the high level beasts roaming around. I'm probably just used to it from xenoblade chronicles x because it doesn't bother me at all. Like X you learn your place in the food chain and almost like hungry shark, as you level up the usually aggressive beasts become humble no longer attacking unless provoked, this makes fetching stuff in previously visited locations easy.

I seem to always be a bit overpowered though so I tend to be able to stroll through new and expected dangerous areas without having to fight which makes things a little boring

Without spoilers, the story is great. In some ways I like it more than the xenoblade 1, X is different for me as it reminds me more of xenogears and xenosaga but its usually consider the weakest story-wise.

Obtaining the rare blades can be a pain though, 100 hours in and it looks like I'm still missing about half, perhaps they are mostly special story related/ quests ones.

Overall great for any fan of the series and new players as well, you don't have to play the others before it.

title: Challenging and Fun text: I was a little nervous when I ordered this game. I wanted something fun, something that would get my heart rate up, and maybe even teach me some dance moves, but I'll be perfectly honest -- I'm out of shape and I have no rhythm. This is why I don't dance publically but love the wii -- an opportunity to embarrass myself in the privacy of my living room to my heart's content and nobody knows it but me. I have a short attention span, so have long since grown bored of Wii Fit, DDR, Wii Cheer, and a couple of other exercise programs barely worthy of mention.

Why was I nervous? Quite simply, because a few reviewers reported that this game wasn't for people who didn't already know how to dance. For that reason, I had this in my shopping cart for a month before I cliked "buy". Too bad I didn't get over my wariness sooner.

To the naysayers: I see your point. This is not an easy game or an easy workout. There aren't easy on-screen guides with 4 possible places to stomp your foot. With a wii mote in each hand and your feet on the floor, you are expected to follow all manner of footwork from the basic to the complex. The tutorials works like this: slowly, feet only, for 3 moves, then slowly, hands and feet, for 3 moves, then normal speed. Wait! I wasn't ready. Rewind! Yes, I definitely felt that way the first few times I went through the routine.

But I wasn't looking for easy. Did I really expect, with my flabby thighs and embarassing upper arms, that I would smoothly glide into salsa moves in an afternoon? No! I expected to have to work for it, and that is precisely what I have been doing for the past 2 weeks.

It is worth noting, to those who can't keep up with the routines, that at the end of every routine you have the option of going back into the routine to work on indidividual moves. This option sends you back into the workout video and allows you to play a small segment in a loop, over and over again, until you decide you're done with it. Three slow moves not enough? Just go back into the turoial and repeat to your heart's content. It took me a few days to realize that I had this option, so I wanted to make sure to mention it.

That said, the game does do a pretty poor job of helping you figure out what move to do next. This is particularly true during the cardio boxing routines, where they tell you how to punch as they are throwing it. Um, two second's notice, please? That's one of the reasons I knocked off a star, but before I get ahead of myself, let me just do the pros and cons:

Pros:

*A great workout
*Fun latin dance moves
*Fun cardio moves
*Entertaining workout games such as dodging bulls
*A personal trainer to help you choose daily workout programs that gradually step you up from trainee to pro
*Good music
*Practice mode that allows you to select any part of a workout to retry over and over again, until you get it right

Cons:

*Some difficulty following the moves, especially in cardio boxing
*Only 20 songs
*The way this game determines calorie burn has to do with how many correct moves it detects from your wii mote, which means that if you are only using one remote (such as in 2 player mode), it counts about half the calories burned as if you're using both remotes.

I recommend this game if you want a fun workout, even if you aren't in great shape. If you're a lumpy couch potato, you might want to start with Wii Fit and try this when the cardio in that game fails to challenge you (which won't take long), but if you're determined and up for a challenge, there's no reason that this can't be the right game for you. I've only had the game for 2 weeks, so it's hard to know what kind of staying power it will have, but I have a short attention span...anything I stick with for 2-3 months is a good purchase for me, and I'm definitely not even close to being done with this one.

title: First impressions are GREAT! text: It's just my first impression since I have only been able to play for a couple days so far, but I definitely think it's the next big MMO. I've played more MMORPGs than I can count (FFXI, FFXIV, WoW, GW2, Aion, AIKA, MapleStory, Neverwinter, RIFT, Tera, LotR, etc.) so perhaps I'm just biased for the genre, but I am loving it!

I really appreciate the path system combined with the class system to give you a few options for playstyle as you progress through the game. Just pick a path that suits your style (soldier path for those who love to kill things and explorer path for those who like to find hidden areas - my fave). I've started 8 characters to get a feel for the different options and figure out what kind of character I really want to be, so I have a good grasp of the basics by now. I definitely prefer the explorer path, but I've tried them all. Settler is pretty awesome for the buffs too. Scientist was a lot of extra work, but I do miss it when I see a hidden door only a scientist can open! Soldier is not for me, I don't like to just kill endlessly, but some people do so that's the path for them!

I love the playstyle too, because you can choose your class based upon what kind of fighting you want to do and I don't feel like playing a button-masher so I am steering clear of the warrior and the spellslinger for now, but I really like my esper for some unique hybrid options as I level her.

My favorite aspect of the game so far would have to be the movement style (I love the double jumps as well as special items/areas that allow you to jump so high you're flying). It reminds me of the old Crash Bandicoot games in that sense and I do love to jump around hehe.

For my personal playstyle I really love the explorer path. Pretty much every RPG has inspired the urge to explore, but this game truly rewards you for it and caters to that kind of player in more than just an easter egg or hidden treasure kind-of-way. The explorer path opens up new quests in every zone for someone with just my sensibilities. It's so fun to be shrunken down to explore a hidden cave like Alice in Wonderland or find a way to open up a glowing path in the sky or to weave your way through the tree vines and up to the very top. These are the kinds of things I would do anyway, just to find a useless deadend that the programmers created for fun. Now that secret path actually has a purpose if you choose explorer.

I also love the AMP/skill tree kind of thing (always loved that setup in the old Final Fantasy games) so every character you level can be unique even if you choose the same exact race/class/path combo! I love that sort of flexibility that allows me to play how I want to and allows me to change the way my class works later if I realize I need different abilities for pvp or something.

The humor and cartoon style kinda lean Sam and Max for any fans of that old series and that's one of my favorite things so far if you actually take the time to read the stuff in the game lol (though nothing will ever truly compare to Sam and Max, Wildstar is the only MMO I've ever played that had even a little bit of that flavor). <3

I'm really looking forward to customizing my house and getting mounts later. That always adds more fun to any game. Wildstar looks like they really outdid themselves in those areas as well and I haven't even got to that stuff yet! I've been busy having fun creating characters and figuring everything out. Now I think I have a character I want to level as a main and I can get into the meat of all that soon! :)

Anyway, just wanted to share my initial impressions since a lot of people are considering this title. I love it so far and am so glad I bought it!

title: Really great for male gamers but most likely not for us gals text: First off, don't get me wrong, the earphones themselves are actually a lot better quality than I would have thought from the price. The design is very well-thought out. I love the fact that you can remove the mic when you don't want to use it and the inline sound is a very nice touch. The only problem that I can see is that while hubs says that they are seriously comfortable on him but for me? Alas, they are just too damned big. Even with the smallest adapters, my ears are sore from just 30 minutes of use.

Now, don't get me wrong. I'm not returning them or even upset because the hubs is getting a lot of use out of them, but unfortunately, because they aren't truly universal, I just can't give them all 5 stars either and really, that is the only reason: they just aren't universal.

Still, even though this is a very common thing for us female gamers to encounter, I thought it was worth noting that was the ONLY reason for the lack of 5 stars as not all of us have husbands/brothers/guildies that they can give those headsets that are just too big for us.

So, my conclusion is that these are really good if you have really big ears or are a guy.

title: Ignore the journalists! text: I've very troubled by many gaming journalists and top reviewers for some of the major on-line gaming magazines. Apparently, Start the Party was not much of a game for them, It's as if they reviewed this with 16 year old Call of Duty fans in mind. Come on folks, lighten up and have some fun.

While Sports Champions is without a doubt the strongest launch title for the PS3 Move, there's no denying that Start the Party has plenty of charm and some kick-ass augmented reality effects. Matter of fact, it's the best "show off" game of the bunch. Yes, there are only so many mini games you will take part of before they get repeated, but there are difficulty settings and various modes to break things up. This is not the kind of game you lock yourself in a room with and play through out the night. You invite some friends/family in front of the large screen TV and laugh your butt off! I'm sorry, but watching yourself on live feed holding various in-game items is absolutely eye popping hilarious. The mini games are actually quite fun, and technically make any WarioWare micro game look fossilized. Both young and old will have a blast; the very young will be hypnotized by the visuals, and teens will probably have fun but won't dare admit it (the sorry state of adolescent males).

title: Decent body, garbage keycaps, annoying stabilizers text: It's a good overall body, nice and solid with a metal faceplate. No tacky RGB, so good for the office.

A couple things to keep in mind about this before you buy. The included keycaps are garbage, as they get worn out super quick, so plan on getting a new set of keycaps by the end of your first year of using them. They use costar stabilizers, so you will need special inserts for the keycaps, which you cannot find on Amazon, only 2 sites in the US sell the inserts that I know of. The inserts that are already in the included keycaps feel like they are glued in, so you can't reuse them. Thankfully the stabilizers are snap ins on the board, so you can replace them pretty easily. In the end, I really wish I got a Ducky instead for the office, with the headaches that the keycaps and the stabilizers are.

title: Fine, but high defect rate. text: The Saitek Eclipse II is a fine keyboard... it has the traditional layout for the cursor keys, which is critical to me, and controllable backlighting with a bit of sidelighting. That's all good. The feel is a smidge mushy but works well for fast typing.

But... they aren't manufactured reliably. The biggest problem is half the spacebar not working. To fix this, you have to disassemble the keyboard, readjust the rubber membrane under, reassemble and readjust the spacebar springs. Do an internet search on the words "fix saitek eclipse" to get a sense of how common this is. Fixing it takes about 10 minutes, not a killer but kind-of annoying. I've had this problem with all three Saitek Eclipse IIs I've had.

My only other gripe is that there's no power key (for putting the computer to sleep) on the keyboard.

title: A great mouse but not for me, not full-time anyway text: I had high hopes for this mouse and wanted to love it. I will probably keep it, but it won't be my main mouse.

Pros:
* It is heckin' adjustable! I wasn't expecting thumb depth to even be a thing.
‚Äî The clickable side is adjustable to a higher angle than any of my other vertical mouses.
‚Äî Thumb tilts in several directions, moves forwards and backwards (closer and further away from your palm), and it's possible to pull the thumb rest out further from the clicky side.

Cons:
* It still feels really large for my hand.
‚Äî I can adjust to a good shape, but I feel like I barely have hold of it and it's going to slip out of my hand at any moment.
‚Äî Something about trying to grab it with my widdle hands means I often click accidentally when I don't want to and end up accidentally closing out windows. Oops!
‚Äî Also sometimes when I lose my grip on it, the thumb rest moves out of place. Maybe my hands are just too messed up to use mice any more. It's a real possibility.

* It's not silent. I know it wasn't advertised as silent, but I have gotten used to silent mice, and kind of expect that now. So no false advertising or anything, but I prefer silent clicks.

* I feel like it needs a skirt or some part protruding out the back for my hand to rest on. I don't like vertical mice with giant skirts, but a not toward a skirt might help me feel like I'm gripping it better.

* What the heck even with the middle button. This is maybe a "just me" thing. But I'm not used to middle buttons, and I keep hitting the middle button when I want to right-click, and DISASTER. I tried to reprogram the buttons with X-Mouse button control, and it fixed it sure enough, but then it messed up all of my other mice. [Edit: I set both middle and right buttons to right-click, so no more problem there, I guess.]

Oh yeah, time out: I have to alternate through a bunch of mice due to various RSIs, so having to reprogram buttons is no bueno for me. Also maybe a sign the mouse is too big for my hands.

So I doubt I'll send it back and will keep it for arm pain flare-ups, but it's not worth $80 *to me*. The concept is gold, and with some tweaking and maybe actual different size options, the product itself could be outstanding.

Maybe with more use I'll get used to it. Le sigh.

title: Hold off the Zerg Rush text: I like this expansion and yet also hate this expansion.

Overall, the new mechanics are well balanced. You can now play pagans, and work with the limitations of the religion. for the Norse, this means you can't avoid having each of your children inheriting and having to go to war or raiding every year or 2. It makes for a lot of early conflict.

The game does try to help at first, as the initial Norse counties have high levels of troops and a few pre-planned invasions. This makes it easy to get some quick conquests in.

Of course, that has a flip side. If you are facing this onslaught (Scotland, England, Ireland, Holland, etc.) you end up facing 20-30 years of heavy conflict, and will likely lose quite a few provinces early. And if you want to play as an independent count in any Norse region or one they are likely to attack expect to end up conquered because they will hit hard at first.

But once their initial leaders start dying the kingdoms tend to come apart with internal conflicts. So they really only have a major effect on the game for the first 50 years and then it does down a bit despite their need to keep raiding. (by then its hard to raid from a single province and the fragmentation of their kingdoms means they don't have multiple provinces to use.)

Good, but it basically just sets up a huge Zerg-rush at the start and then it settles down to the old game.

title: This is the one: a helpful review text: Here's the thing, I wanted a charging dock for my Xbox Series X controllers. So, I did what any person does nowadays, I searched for reviews... and then I searched for more reviews and then more. Spoiler, reviews were shockingly limited unhelpful. So, here is a helpful review.

1. quality - this charger feels solid and is easy to use; the controller fits on the dock easily, doesn't feel unstable or tippy. The led "breathes" to let you know it's charging and turns solid once charged. I've never struggled to connect the controller properly or fumbled with putting them on.

2. charging time - I haven't timed it (sorry?) but it's fast and you can charge both at once or only one at a time.

3. battery life - hours... I can't say more or I'll sound even less like I have a life than I do now, but it's hours.

4. battery covers - it comes with two one for the X and one for the Series X. They fit perfectly and they even look good on the blue controllers. The gap in the cover for the connection to the dock isn't too much. It's not too ugly and it doesn't interfere with use or plugging the controller in by usb-c.

5. usb - here's my biggest complaint, the plug for the dock is not usb, so you must use the cable it comes with, you can't use another cable and have to have a wall plug nearby. It was fine for me, but if you're out of room on your power strip, you have my sympathies.

6. battery - this one has the largest battery that I could find out of all the charging docks, so that's a plus.

7. licensed - it's officially approved by Xbox, so I don't have to worry about it killing my $60 controllers.

8. size - it's not tiny, but it doesn't take up unnecessary space, it isn't too tall or too long, pretty much perfect for storing / charging 2 controllers.

9. color - it only comes in black, which is fine because it matches my Xbox, but if you wanted it in white or to match your controller, it's not going to happen.

This is the charging dock to buy if you want to charge 2 controllers. It's easy to use, has a good battery life, doesn't take up too much space, quick charging, and looks cool. I appreciate the peace of mind of knowing Xbox was ok with it and the fact that I can store my controllers on it and not worry about where they are or if they've been charged lately.

title: Creepy Dungeon-Crawler text: The last Silent Hill game that I played was Homecoming. I thought it was decent - enjoyed the story and the creep factor well enough. When I pre-ordered Book of Memories, I realized that it wouldn't be anything like the series. I was actually grateful for the differences, as I am a fan of dungeon-crawlers in general. For the most part, the graphics and music seem very "Silent Hill'esque." The more "top-down-isometric view" is a complete departure from what we're used to from the series, so you will not get the same feel as you would from the previous titles.

**Combat**
Over all, I found the combat to be very fluid and easy to figure out. I don't care much for the weapons breaking, but thus far, so many are available in each stage, you should be OK (though you might not be able to use your favorite one all the time.)

**Story**
The story has only been OK so far. A little convoluted, but I expected that. The game play is why I'm here.

**Game Play**
Classic dungeon-crawler! Mash buttons when you see enemies. Move out of the way when they swing at ya. Some drop loot and of course you have limited inventory space (which is upgradable.)

**Verdict**
Hardcore fans that want another entry in the Silent Hill series might be disappointed. This is a game that uses themes and characters/monsters from the series, but feels almost nothing like any of it's predecessors. The game is pretty good in it's own right. I definitely recommend this to those who like hack-and-slash games (though this one has less loot) with puzzle-solving components. Actually, this game seems a lot like Zelda without an overworld!

title: Great Atelier game with more game balance, depth, and tons of positivity. text: Another really solid Atelier-series game.

It is much less breakable than previous games (no easy money loop, materials to make and upgrade weapons are separate so it's harder to dump all the game-breaking stats on every piece of gear). The time limits are also very few and reasonable, so you're free to experiment with tons of synthesizing and exploring.

The mini-game in applying materials on the grid has gotten more interesting. I can spend 15+ minutes trying to max out the effects on an item, and the interface makes it easy to change the board/materials after you select them all, so you don't have to cancel out and remember your choices every time you need to make a structural change to your grid.

I enjoy the two protagonists a lot. They are sooo cute, and other than a few ugh plot moments, they really take a reasonable and proactive approach to most problems. "Man, those other two people just need to be honest with each other and express themselves/communicate more clearly. Let's go make them do that." And they do. Yeay!

The other alchemists/characters that join from previous games play a large role in your party and in the plot. It really feels like you all work together to solve issues. The game is super positive and supportive: all the older characters in the game look after, take care of, and are invested in helping the protagonists grow to their full potential.

title: I want better gameplay content not just stuff
text: Heavy Sigh.  I got bored with this expansion in three days.  Three.  It's beautiful I'll give them that and we do get a lot of stuff, but if you don't add actual gameplay then this is just another stuff pack and not an expansion.  Sims 1 and Sims 2 really focused on the relationships and interactions between the Sims with random things that were both adorable and made you care about your Sims.  When they died you grieved for them.  I very much miss picking your sims characteristics based on their sign.  You could really see their individual personalities.  In Sims 3 the focus was more task oriented and less relationships and honestly I didn't like Sims 3 at all but I can see why others did.  Now comes Sims 4 and I was excited because the graphics are stunning.  What a huge disappointment.  They took so much away that now we don't have a focus on anything.  Not on relationships nor on tasks.  Not to mention how they dumbed it down with emotions.  Seriously I really hate that and wish I could turn that off.  It completely takes the challenge away.  I had hoped EA and Maxis would have listened to the people but they aren't.  The game is horrible and I seriously don't see a Sims 5 in the future at this rate.  So very sad.

title: ~~FANTASTIC Keyboard~~ Well made, affordable, versatile, easy-to-read, great feedback, & perfect LED intensity to improve vision text: This Azio Levetron is an awesome keyboard. Well made, affordable, and versatile, this keyboard is a good fit for many different tasks/needs.

I do want to note on two things:
1) I am not a gamer so I cannot say exactly how well this keyboard works if purchased solely for the purpose of gaming. I purchased this keyboard for work and home usage. I did so because I like LED backlit keys as well as the feedback gaming keyboards provide.
2) I have only used this keyboard for a short period, and so I cannot speak to long-term reliability. I will update this review down the road to report back on how the keyboard holds up.
------------------------

MY NEEDS & USAGE
I recently purchased a Dell IPS display so that I can run it as a secondary monitor next to my 15-inch MacBook Pro Retina, as this allows me to run Windows 8.1 via a virtual machine on the display, and OS X Yosemite on the MacBook‚Äôs display. As I use software that runs better on one OS over the other, this allows me to run whatever software does best in what OS. It also gives me easy access to legacy OS‚Äô if I need to test something like code.

I have apple‚Äôs wireless keyboard and think it is excellent. However, it favors mobility over performance. I find gaming keyboards tend to do the opposite‚Ä¶they are built for heavier usage, heavily favor accessibility and performance, and use features that make this possible (I own an unusually large amount of gaming gear.)
------------------------

DESCRIPTION: THIS KEYBOARD
This keyboard is the Azio Levetron L70, a wired, entry-level gaming keyboard that is LED backlit via blue colored LEDs. You can toggle these LEDs on and off, but you cannot change the color or the intensity.

The layout of this keyboard is pretty standard, plus it has a massive volume knob and a switch dedicated specifically to turning the LEDs on and off. Each side of the keyboard has an LED light. The keys themselves used oversized letters, and these markings are clear so the LED light can shine through. A removable palm rest is included and the cord length is about 5 feet. The bottom features non-skid, non-marking rubber feet as well as retractable feet to increase the angle.

I have used this keyboard with: OS X 10.10 Yosemite, OS X 10.8 Mountain Lion, OS X 10.7 Lion, Windows XP SP3, and Windows 8.1 (current build as of 2015.) They keyboard works reliably on all of these, but note that this is technically a Windows keyboard and so with OS X you may want to use a keyboard control suite to modify some of the commands.

The interface used is USB and it works on both USB 2 and USB 3 computers (can‚Äôt speak to USB 1.1 as I do not have computers that old anymore.) It does NOT seem to generate the harmonic distortion that some USB 3 devices can which can result in interference with 2.4 GHz signals.
------------------------

WHAT I LIKE
The light intensity is perfect‚Ä¶bright enough to see when lights are on, but not so bright that it is an annoyance in darker environments. Another LED backlit keyboard I had was so faint that the LEDs did not really increase visibility.

The lettering used is very large, making it easier to see and making it better display with the LEDs. If someone has trouble seeing most keys, this is an outstanding choice.

Typing itself is comfortable, and I find the palm rest makes typing even more comfortable. Like many other gaming keyboards, you get more pronounced feedback than the standard free keyboard that comes with desktops. I strongly prefer this feedback when typing as I find I can type faster and with fewer errors. Also like many other gaming keyboards, I find that the physical force required to push a key and have it register is very, very consistent. With keyboard without this consistency, it is easy to subconsciously start pressing certain keys with more force than others, and this can result in more mistakes while typing (least for me anyway.)

The cosmetic fit and finish of this keyboard is outstanding for the price. The numbers are neat, the patterns are sharp, there are no sharp spots from molding overspray, and the keyboard wire is quite beefy.

So while I cannot speak directly to how well this works for gaming, I can say it is a great keyboard for general usage. It is also great for data visualization, which I suppose in some ways has similarities to gaming needs.
------------------------

WHAT I DO NOT LIKE
At this price, I have zero dislikes with this keyboard.
------------------------

CONCLUSION
Overall, this is a whole lot of keyboard for 20-25 bucks. It‚Äôs well made, it has fantastic visibility, it gives a very consistent typing experience, and its LEDs are perfectly balanced in intensity so that they contribute to better performance (rather than detracting from.)

title: Definitely increases playtime by a significant amount, looks good on it, and is a great price!
text: I usually like using Airlink with my Quest 2, which absolutely drains power from it pretty quickly. This power pack keeps the Quest 2 ticking quite a good amount extra, and without worrying about a cable being a little loose and causing disconnection issues with the PC. It looks and feels very similar to the Quest 2's color and finish, with a good weight to it too. The price is excellent, and it also comes with a piece to change it from sticking directly out to more upright, haven't used that, but also haven't needed to either. Can easily recommend for any Quest 2 owner.

title: Great songs and very little overlap with the PS2 songs text: I own all the DDR titles that I know of for the PS2 (Flow-Urban Dance Uprising, DDR Max 1 and 2, DDR Extreme 1 and 2, Into the Groove, Pump it Up), so I was afraid that buying a DDR title for the Xbox would have a lot of overlap in the songs offered for the PS2, but there are tons of wonderful new songs to play, and a wider range of styles. This was well worth the money.

I love how many songs have videos, and I love the quirky song choices and the range of genres. There is Istanbul (Not Constantinople) by They Might be Giants, Rock Lobster by the B-52's (with a video), Alphabet Aerobics by Blackalicious (awesome, it speeds up as the song goes so by the end you are really skipping!), Sakura (the speed changes in this one really keep me challanged), Hey Mama by the Black Eyed Peas, and Nari Narien which is fun Indian-inspired techno. The difficulties are similar to DDR Max and Extreme titles - I usually play standard to heavy and I feel like there is a lot of room to grow into this game.

My RedOctane Ignition pad with the included XBox connector works great with this game. The load times are reasonably fast, too.

This is a great addition to a full DDR library of titles.

title: Great entertainment for a low price text: This DVD has a great selection of card games ranging from Crazy 8s to Pinochle with lots in between. It is important to note that this version is for OLDER operating systems. Most of the games can be be customized: for skill level; background; talking or non-talking computer players, etc. And -- you have the choice to play Full Screen or not. Full screen obviously makes the card sizes larger as a couple of folks commented on the cards being too small. So far, Hearts, Spades, Cribbage and Canasta are our favorites. There is no malware or adware on the DVD.

If you have an older operating system (read the listing specs) and want some fun card games, this is better than anything preinstalled.

title: I had fun, but regret buying Sim City Societies at full price
text: I wish I would have waited until now to buy Sim City Societies. $10 would be a better price for the amount of fun it offers. I bought it at the full retail price a year ago, had a good time with it for a couple of days but I haven't really played it since. I liked the aspects of the different types of cities but once I accomplished it I became bored. Perhaps I would have had enjoyed it longer if more of the aspects of Sim City had been left in. I'd been frustrated by some of the difficulties I'd encountered in Sim City 4 (staying profitable) but Sim City Societies was too easy, dumbed down way too much. It's a shame they didn't better incorporate aspects of both.

title: Perfect mouse for Destiny 2 text: HyperX Pulsefire Raid ‚Äì Gaming Mouse ‚Äì 11 Programmable Buttons, RGB, Ergonomic Design, Comfortable Side Grips

I've tried a few different mice to use with Destiny 2. I wanted one with side buttons I could assign key commands because Destiny uses a lot of keyboard actions. I didn't want to many so that I was constantly search the mouse for the right button to press. This mouse has the perfect balance and key layout. It has 5 thumb buttons that are easy to Identify by feel and the scroll wheel click right or left for additional key mapping. The scroll wheel has a very solid feel and doesn't spin freely. The mouse is pretty light but not the lightest. It is large though, about 5 1/2" long, which is great for me. I also tend to drift back with my grip and this mouse has triggers in the front and the back of the right and left clickers. My other mouse would not register when I clicked to far back on the mouse, not with this one, I can press anywhere on the right and left clickers and it will register. The Nginuity software is not as well refined as other brands but does what it should. all of the functionality is there and is easy to set up. The best part about the HyperX Nginuity software is that it is not a resource hog. I've seen 200mb+ of RAM from other software for controlling a mouse while this is at about 40mb of RAM. Overall I am extremely happy with this mouse.

title: Love it but lost a magnetic button quickly

title: Fantastic headset! text: These are amazing.

There is a separate control for chat volume and game volume. That feature only works on PS3, XBox One and PC. Because they can also use a standard audio jack, they are also compatible with the PS4, Wii U, Vita, and 3DS. There is an additional attachment to use them for your cell phone.

The mouthpiece is detachable, which makes them great (albeit large) for regular headphones.

These are powerfully noise cancelling, immersing you fully in the game experience. The sound quality is outstanding. They have tremendous range and seem to have some sort of built in leveling feature. If your teammate says something just as there is an explosion, the game volume reduces, the chat volume increases, and you can hear both no problem. If two players are talking, one softly, one loudly, it adjusts so that one doesn't drown out the other.

They are far more comfortable than they look, given their size. They are fully adjustable, and sit well on the head. I could wear them for hours. In fact, I may see if I can use them in place of my headset at work, because they are that comfortable and that high quality.

They have switchable side plates, either a montage of marvel characters, or Thor. The montage is very subdued, and isn't all that noticeable at a distance. The Thor plates are yummy.

title: CM 9000 and Mountain Lion text: CM 9000 is the last upgrade of the Chess Masters for Macintosh.
I purchased the product from Amazon.com in 2005, January. Thanks Amazon.com.
And this is why. There have been complaints that CM 9000 will not work on Lion or Mountain Lion.
The product will work with Mountain Lion.
This is what has to be done. 1. Contact Feral, the company that produces CM9000.
2. Locate your CM 9000 purchase receipt. Amazon.com retains your copy in Your Account.
3. Print the receipt as a PDF to your computer.
4. After the company contacts you, submit as requested an attachment of your CM 9000 purchase receipt.
5. Feral will contact you on how to get the game to run on Mountain Lion.
What is known is that the current update 1.1.3 will need to be downloaded.
As with the Windows version, to play the game you will need to place the DVD in the drive.
If you do not own a copy of CM9000 buy it from Amazon.com. Amazon.com as indicated saves your receipt in case you need it.
As to who used CM, The late Grandmaster, Larry Evans. The product will play a game either on low or high level. You decide.
The product teaches. (Josh Waitzken). Included in CM9000 are famous games. If you need to learn how to play this is the product to buy.
If you know how to play on a high level, this product is just right for you.

title: It's worth a rental. text: I bought this game mainly due to the fact that I'm a die hard fan of the movie, the book, and all of Chuck Palahniuk's work. I've never played any other games made by Vivendi.

Overall this game is fair at most. There are only 3 fighting styles, and quite a few characters. Each character has one of the 3 fighting styles, which all have the same moves. That gets boring quick.

There is a decent amount of levels to play on and quite a few characters, which is a plus. The narrator, Tyler, Raymond K Hessel, Angelface, etc.

I think the best part of this game is the bone breaking animations.

Like the title says, it's worth a rental. I bought it and I've only played it a handful of times.

Fighting game recommendations for ps2: Soul Calibur 2&3, Tekken, Mortal Kombat Armageddon.

title: Brings back memories text: Playing pinball is what we used to call skill. Every Friday and Saturday night it was a trip to the local mall to pick up chicks and play some skill. When there were no chicks that dug us, we'd spend more time playing skill. Needless to say, we became very good at playing pinball. The site of walking into that arcade will never be repeated. Three rows of machines lined up side by side at least 20 deep. The pesky and annoying video games were just starting to show up, but were in their own little area. They ruined pinball like MP3's ruined hard media. I remember playing Gorgar and Firepower at the mall and these are on this game.

As far as the game play goes, this game is done really well. It takes a little getting used to the PS3 controller instead of using buttons on the side of the machine. And shaking the machine is different too, but much less tiring! But other than that, the ball physics are very realistic and I can almost feel myself regressing back to those golden times in the arcade. Even the music is somewhat appropriate because we were metal heads. The best machine on this game is Funhouse. There's nothing like a wise cracking dummy egging you on to keep the game exciting. I don't think I could ever tire of it.

The only knocks on the game I have are that the replay should have been the traditional "thwack" sound that a solenoid produced when hitting the side of the cabinet. In the game it's just a cash register sound. The other thing I would have liked is the ability to view the play field under my control so I can examine every square inch of it. The instructions show you most of it, but it's not under your control. Also they don't show much of the back glass. The back glass was always a work of art and usually had some large breasted babe somewhere on it.

Now we just have to lobby for them to come out with Bally collection and redo the Gottlieb collection. Then there will no need to ever leave the house. This is an excellent game and would highly recommend it. Time for some skill!

title: EA You Need To Get Your Imagination Back.  This Is Boring.
text: I bought this for my daughter.  She played it for an hour and got bored.  Without knowing what other's have been saying, she said it was more a stuff pack and not so much an expansion. She liked the stuff that was in it, but didn't really see how this added to the overall gameplay.  So guess what?  She went back to playing Sims 2.  I play the Sims also and have to be honest with my displeasure of Sims 3 overall.  IT'S BORING FOLKS.  Even with the expansions it just is not as good as Sims 2.  Now before you argue with me and get all upset.  You have to admit that the Sims 2 when it first came out was far better than the Sims 3 when it first came out.  I got bored with Sims 3 within a few days.  Where as Sims 2 I played for months.  And when a new idea comes, I play again.  The interactions in Sims 3 are limited and I don't like the role-playing aspect of it.  It seems to me to be a little too controlling.  Having an expansion called Generations to me is a rip off.  Why?  Well because these sort of interactions should have already been in the game in the first place.  To me this should have been part of the appeal of Sims 3 when it came out.  As others have said, it looks like EA is nickel and diming us for each and every so called "improvement" to the game.  Seriously EA are ya that greedy?  Earning millions upon millions of dollars hasn't been enough for you?  Adding more interactions and "stuff" should not be an expansion and more like a improvement patch to the game.  I saw a photoshop cover for a Sims 3 Fantasy, totally made up of course but that caught my attention.  THAT would be an expansion.  A Sims 3 expansion with a new town that has everything Fantasy.  Fairies, Witches, Unicorns, etc.  And buildings/houses to go along with it.  It doesn't have to be Fantasy, it can be back in time like Victorian with the clothing and furnishings or Pirates, or Aliens.  See the possibilities?  With free play and NOT like Sims Medieval.  EA you need to get your imagination back.  These ideas of yours show a major disconnect with what the consumers want.  The only reason people are buying these expansions is because they are trying to get their Sims 3 to be the same caliber as Sims 2 and hoping beyond hope that just one more expansion will reach it; but it just doesn't and we the consumer are disappointed yet again.

title: SAVE OFTEN! One of the best JPRGs. Great Music, Voice Acting, and Gameplay! text: My dream come true. Vesperia on a portable system! I played the original on the Xbox 360, and the Japanese Version on the PS4. I'm really glad all the content from the PS4 is now on the Nintendo Switch and now I can start enjoying the new content that is translated! I can't wait to get more into the game to find out what's there. From personal experience just a couple hours in, and from some message boards out there, is to save often!

The first crash I encountered was after the Zagi fight in Flynn's room. This is one of the spots. It appears any dialog skits or dialog boxes that are repeated make the software/game forcefully close/crash. It's a good thing I saved before the Zagi fight.

If the fights are difficult for you, grind on easy mode. I recommend doing so, but note that for grade points you only get 0.00 points in easy mode. So right before a boss battle, make sure to switch it on normal to reap the grade points assuming you do well in the battle! Get the game and enjoy the ride!
