title: Almost perfect - 9/10 text: The controller feels fantastic in your hands. This is especially apparent after trying to use the tiny joycons with their even tinier buttons and joysticks. If your an adult with moderate to large hands you need this controller. Playing games like Resident Evil 5 or Doom feel worlds better with a controller that is designed for hands larger than a 10 year old's. Using the controller mount for the joycons is not a substitute for a pro controller. After using the pro controller, you realize that the joycon's tiny buttons, joysticks, and shoulder buttons are things you tolerate. Even if you decide against buying this controller (most likely due to the price), buy a cheaper third party traditional controller. Comfort - 10/10

The buttons are large, which I love, reminding more of the larger buttons seen on the original SNES controller. The buttons along with the D-pad have a matte finish that feel great. A special mention of the D-pad must be made. This D-pad feels fantastic. Compared to the 8bitdo SN30 pro, it is NO CONTEST. The D-pad for Nintendo's pro controller is top of the line and blows the third party D-pads out of the water. The Joysticks feel good, maybe even great. They have raised edges with ridges for increased grip which feel good on your thumbs. I still prefer the concave shape of the Xbox One joysticks but the switch pro controller joysticks are comfortable, responsive, and accurate. Compared to the Wii U pro controller, the joysticks feel less sturdy though. The Wii U pro controller feel sturdy and require more effort to move them, which I like. This is not a big deal but I feel some may not like joysticks that have less resistance. Buttons and Joysticks - 9/10

When it come to the value, the switch pro controller is a sea of grey. It really depends on the value you place on each individual feature found in the pro controller. The third party enhanced switch controllers are around 20$ cheaper and feel close to the same but lack many of the features the pro controller has (it doesn't even have basic rumble). You can also find even cheaper controllers that don't have even the most basic features of a pro controller but are still fine controllers if all your looking for is a comfortable gaming experience for your hands. I like the HD rumble and motion controls and would like to have the convenience of amiibo support (even though I don't really see it lasting much longer) so I don't mind paying the 70$. Nintendo's controllers are also known for lasting forever, so you most likely won't need to buy another one for the rest of your life (I still use the gamecube and Wii U pro controllers I got at the launches). Overall Value - 8/10

title: CM10 is a fairly good program with flaws (does run on Vista) text: This is a pretty good chess program for beginners & intermediate players, has a lot that helps you learn, including of course not-too-bad player simulation. It's not perfect, but I would recommend it if you're looking for something for anyone who wants to learn or get better.

There is a long list under "how this program could have been better". See some of the other reviews, but my top 3 gripes are: (1) dumb programming that chews up the CPU even when the program is supposed to be idle; (2) bugs, especially a "hang" problem on single-cpu/single-core machines, where the game program just gets stuck somewhere (looks like a race condition; solution is to temporarily lower the priority of the TheKing processes by using TaskManager); (3) explanations of bad moves, or recommendations of good moves, provide detail but not the big picture.

Finally, it does appear to run fine in Vista: I installed it normally and have been playing it without problems. (I haven't seen the hang problem, but since I have a dual-core machine now I don't expect the race condition to occur.)

title: SHMUP as Art text: This game is art as its finest. You can tell the personnel involved from top to bottom are professionals and makes other SHMUP makers look like amateurs. Its what Demon Souls/ Dark Souls is to the modern action RPG genre. Even though the first game was a groundbreaker, this "final" reiteration is at the top of my SHMUP list.

Sound 10
Graphics 10
Gameplay 10
Story 10 (extremely minimal but effective)

From the opening scene to the end, the creators did a great job taking you into their world. Its dark, its foreboding and its beautiful Its not about having super fast reflexes, dodging a million bullets at a million MPH, which has its place and is fine for other SHMUPs, but this franchise is different- you weave your way through traffic as if you are in the matrix- thoughtfully and deliberately, moving your force back and forth and angling them at just the right place. As the game moves along, it builds upon each stage, getting darker and presenting you with more unique and interesting challenges and bosses.

This game should be played with sound via the digital out port of the PS2 and into your stereo, properly attuned for best sound. Video wise either you use a component cable or RGB and have it line doubled via an OSSC or the like. It will be worth it because they did not skip on any facet of the game. It will suck you right in. Unlike other games which sound like you are in a techno club, (which can be fun) this game takes a different route and throws you into the midst of a cinematic experience with the quality sound and visuals.

This is one of those buy and keep games, no matter what console comes next.

title: Great game for fans of horror text: This is one of the most scariest games I've ever played. Silent Hill 2 and Alone in the Dark (Aline) are the others at the top of the list. The text is disturbing and the music is super creepy. So if you have a weak stomach, then this one isn't for you. At times, it can get very frustrating because basically the whole game you're going through a bunch of mazes. There's also some backtracking involved and it can get quite confusing and you can get lost very easily. It can get boring and repititive so you may want to take a break once in a while. The story is very chilling and has two parts, one that you can play after you beat the main game. Some of the puzzles aren't that difficult but others you may have a tough time. If you see a warning message about sharp metal, then DO NOT click on that spot. You will get hurt and you CAN die. So be sure to save.
If you're ready to explore the world of darkness and terror, then Theresia awaits.

title: Satisfying To Type On text: I've been through basically all of the gaming keyboards now. I've felt the top echelon each brand has to offer i.e. Razer, Corsair, Logitech, Steelseries.
The only other keyboard that I think comes close to this one is the Apex Pro TKL, but this one is still better.

Pros:
1. Switches offer just the right amount of feedback, so you aren't always making mistakes when typing on these very, very smooth linear switches.
2. The stabilizers are very good on these switches.
3. The feeling of the actual keycaps are pleasant. It just feels good to type on these switches. They have a nice bounce back to them that make them feel more responsive than other keyboards.
4. The RGB on this keyboard is far and away the best of any keyboard out there. There are other keyboards with brighter lighting, like the Apex Pro TKL, but the AIMO intelligent mode on this thing is unreal. It kind of just slowly and smoothly mixes the colors in and out on your keyboard. It's hard to explain, but it's easily the most pleasant rgb experience of all the keyboards I have had.

Cons:
1. ABS keycaps. Okay- so this doesn't matter to me this much, but these are ABS keycaps and they most definitely DO collect a lot of oil so, if you spend a lot of time looking at your keycaps for some reason, be prepared to clean them often.
2. Height- this keyboard is not low profile by any means. You will want a wrist rest with this keyboard. I bought a glorious wooden one and it wasn't too bad that way. I prefer using the one that came with my apex pro tkl though and it works perfectly.
3. The ping. This bothers some people apparently. It's there and you'll notice it but if you wear headphones, even open back ones- it's basically a non-issue. I like the sound otherwise.

Differentiating with the Apex Pro TKL, the keys on this keyboard are a little heavier but just as smooth. It's easier to make typos on the Apex Pro TKL because the keys are so light. Now, that can be taken care of by changing the sensitivity of the keys on the Apex, but I don't like messing with that all the time and prefer to keep the sensitivity high. That means it might not even be an issue for you.
Also, because the keycap design on the Vulcan TKL Pro is so different, it might be hard to find replacement keycaps for it. I put some Razer PBT keycaps on my Apex Pro TKL and it feels great. Took care of the ABS shine and everything.

Overall though, I spend my time using the Vulcan because I love the typing experience and I find the lighting very tasteful and pleasant.

title: PES 2012 text: Every year I had faithfully coughed up $60 for the new FIFA. And every year I felt like it was a steep price for what was basically a roster upgrade. The game played like an arcade game, with balls sort of ping-ponging around from player to player. I love FIFA's licensing (obviously), and its glitzy presentation. But this year, I finally decided to try PES instead. And I'm definitely glad I did. I think the gameplay itself puts it head and shoulders above FIFA.

"Head and shoulders" makes me think of headers, which were nearly impossible in FIFA. It's been a huge problem for years with that franchise. The PES functions a lot like real life. I can get the ball out wide and cross it in headers, that guys get on the end of, and sometimes score - or head out of bounds more times than not. This makes me happy because it looks like the real stuff you see on TV.

Teammate AI is better in PES - the defensive help is quite realistic. I think the opponent AI is good too. Even on Amateur (yes, I'm old and I suck), if you do dumb things, the game will score on you.

The goals in FIFA always seemed to come from specific spots on the pitch year-after-year. Once you found those spots, you were golden. In PES though, I've seen all kinds of crazy goals from different spots, which I love. I had a low cross from the end-line (almost impossible to perform in FIFA's past) - going across the front of the goalie - ricochet in off a defender's back, for example.

Obviously it sucks for the licensing and the player names. You have to edit some team names, players, especially in the English Premier League since only Tottenham and Manchester United are fully licensed. I think we can all agree that it is annoying. But, if you don't mind tweaking some of the info a bit (or I'm sure there are downloads available online), it is a worthwhile time investment.

Also, you can customize a lot of stuff in this. So you can build your own team with your own players then sub them into the EPL for example. I wish more games in general, especially sports games, gave you MORE customization. If you wanted to make your own City Men's 40+ year old's League, with their complete jerseys, you could do it...

I like the Champions League presentation (with the epic song) too. I hate the PES main menu music though; FIFA has the catchier menu music. I never thought I'd notice it, but PES is kind of cheap there, and you hear it ALL the time. Master League/ Manager Mode is pretty good, and I would say better than FIFA's version last year, but to be fair, they're similar to each other. It's easy to go over budget on player salaries, though, if you are not careful. Also, selling players on the Transfer market is very difficult, so I just end up releasing them and paying the severance fee. I don't play online, so I can't say how good/bad that part is.

Overall though, if you like football/soccer a lot, then this is the game to get. I wish EA didn't have a monopoly on the rights to most sports games, since competition is always a good thing. I would love to see what PES would do with EA's full licenses!

title: Nice update to a great game in a great series text: Rainbow Siege fans likely already bought this (or the Year 2 DLC to go with the original), and it holds its own for folks looking for more of the same. It doesn't really break any new ground but the scenarios and maps are of a great quality, and it will hold its own after hours (or days) of play.

For fans of other FPS games, well you may like it or may quickly revert to Battlefield or COD. For starters, while all of these series have a strong multiplayer, this (and Rainbow Six in general) has a week (and that's putting it kindly) single player. It's not a deal breaker for occasional multiplayers, but it is for folks who will only play this solo. In addition, this is much more tactical and far less run and gun. Life is precious and deliberate teamwork beats twitchy shooting.

4 stars due to the fact that some folks will prefer other FPS games, plus the fact that this is a $30 game (a year old) with new DLC. I appreciate the face that they made a package for those new to the series and DLC for existing owners, so it's really the former rather than the latter.

I wholeheartedly recommend this to Rainbow Six fans, but then again they likely already own the original Rainbow Six Siege game and will need the standalone DLC.

title: unique charm and gameplay without the gore text: It's fair to say that Steambot Chronicles is unlike any other game you'll have played, and it's probably best suited to fans of eclectic games. It is a fusion of game styles using elements of a sim-type game, a few economic principles, vehicle combat, roleplaying story, with some emphasis on musical performances. In other words, it's hard to define by normal game labels.

The game is not a big-budget production, and I would not want to pay full price for it. But as a collector of off-the-wall or niche games, this one is a perfect addition to my library. It makes me laugh, keeps me curious, and is usually relaxing.

You can only play as a boy character, a teenager who has lost his memory during a cruise ship accident. The technology is early 1900's, in a fictional country similar to the US. However, this world has developed the splendid Trotmobile, a sort of 19th century robot that requires a pilot. Your trotmobile can be used for commerce or combat and is the focus of the game. However, you will also spend a good deal of time meeting people, running errands, and raising money to support your other habits.

The game should not be taken too seriously, partly because is intentionally light, and partly because it's a bit choppy in places, and you'll be disappointed if you depend on every plot twist to make sense, every action to have a logical result. But if you can take the story with a grain of salt, it is wonderful and very charming. The graphics are not first-rate, but they do have a unique style and simple charm.

Technical prowess is not one of the game's strong points. There are sometimes load lags, as you pass into new territories, which seem unreasonably long. The camera work is sometimes choppy, and the camera angles are occaisonally frustrating. I find myself able to forgive these weaknesses for the sake of playing in this game world, but it is something to consider, if technical finesse is important to you.

Parents: Language used in the game is almost completely mild (there will be the occasional minor expletives). There is no graphic sexual or violent content. There are mild references to romance, as dating is a part of the game. There is also violence, as you'll be clubbing and shooting mechanical opponents fairly regularly, but it's all within tasteful limits, in my opinion. I would let a small child watch me play without any worries. A lot of girls might like this game, so it's a real shame they didn't allow for a female lead character.

The reviewers here critical of this game should probably be playing a more mainstream, less artful game. This game is for the rest of us, who enjoy a break from the dull, repetitive products that come from the major game houses.

title: Frustratingly difficult. Despite anything you do, you're punished! text: I've been playing the game for the last 3 days, and I'm about to just give up in frustration. A game is supposed to be fun, isn't it?

My Player mode is extremely unforgiving difficult game.
Part of the goal of the mode is to be a good team mate and work your way up as a starter. To do that, you do the nitty gritty things like set screens for your players. This works, only sometimes, and other times the AI players simply just stand there. Wasting time, waiting for your ballhandler to make a move. I'm begging the AI to come on, please start the play! We'll talk about being hypocritical in a moment here.
Playing as point guard, you get punished for holding the ball too long, by a large margin. Hey now, I'm trying to survey the floor looking for a good pass! Oh hey, a player is cutting towards the basket so I'll pass the ball to him. But oops! He continues running around the opponent and they intercept or tip the ball. Bass pass penalty, major points lost. What? So what is it? Do I take my time looking for the players to stop running and get the good pass or do I try to rush a pass to a running player?
Playing defense is brutal as well. You can't stand in close because the opponent will run right past you leaving you chasing them. Or you can't stand back a bit and they'll just shoot a jumper over you. Is there even anything we can do to prevent the major lost of points for allowing your man to score?
Okay well another problem is deciding who to defend running back after your team misses a shot. Well, hmm, the player defending arrows is pointing one way.. okay I'll go head there to defend. If you rely on the blue circles around opponents to defend, well, good luck because sometimes there are two players which you need to defend at once. Huh? WHAT? Okay, let's pick our position to defend instead. Makes sense right? Wait why is my team mate defending this guy too? The open opponent who just scored was the guy you were supposed to defend. You just lost a major amount of team mate points. Okay now we're chasing a fast breaking opponent down. There are 2 other team mates in front of him and the guy still makes the basket....just trying to help out, but yes more penalties to the team mate score. Oh also, sometimes the passes don't go to the right guy as well.

Whatever you do, you're going to get penalized. It's extremely frustrating.

There's probably more things I've forgot to mention that's wrong with this game, but let's close up this review. I realize I've ranted long enough already.

Another major issue is that it loads slowly. Can't the game play the cut scenes while loading? You simply have to wait out the load times, and watch the cut scenes that are forced on you, for the hundredth time. Get me into the game please!

I mean, parts of the game can be fun when you get to play but there are some really difficult things to master, like the shooting timing, the freethrow timing, the idiotic penalties. Don't add on to the frustration with it being just so darn slow to load. And come on, don't throw the player in there on Pro difficulty with no chance to learn the system. Why don't they have rookie enabled for My Player, I don't know.

I give up on you NBA 2K11. Maybe I'll try 2K12 when prices drop to more reasonable level.

My only comment after trying it myself, would be for the WII Controllers to provide motion-feedback similar to the controllers I have for my X-Box, as that way you could feel the (kick) from your shots (added realism).

So, if you've a young man in the house (or an old-man who still acts young), this game would probably be a hit (pun intended).

Gordon

title: The best 3DS screen protectors out now text: First...I'm not sure why reviewers keep talking about this item as if it's an anti-glare filter...it is NOT and does NOT advertise itself as being so. When placed on the 3DS, there is the normal amount of glare as should be expected.

What I like about this protector
- Made by Hori. Their products are good quality.
- It covers the entire top panel rather than just the viewing area like other screen protectors
- Most importantly, it covers the touch screen which needs the most protection due to usage

What bothered me
- The purple tint around the outer edges of the upper screen. It does not affect the viewing area at least, but it's there and annoying
- The steps for installing these are a bit strange at first. I have put on many protectors on my psp and ds and iphone and this has extra, unnecessary steps. read all instructions first and then apply this. Once it's on, it works as expected.

I personally prefer anti-glare protectors but I'm not sure if the matting would interfere with the 3D effect.

title: A big bundle of unnecessary clutter text: Adjective:
Not necessary: dispensable, inessential, needless, nonessential, uncalled-for, unessential, unneeded, unrequired

Add:

Superfluous
Redundant

And:

Fugeddaboudit

I thought that this would have been a fun accessory set for the Wii Sports package, but on reflection, I should have used the money towards an additional controller or nunchuck instead.

1. The pieces don't fit together well, and it requires some patience to get the threads to line up properly.
2. The base that holds the controller feels flimsy, and if you use too much force to unscrew the attachment, it'll probably break.
3. The base is uncomfortable for small hands, especially for the baseball grip.
4. You lose the vibration effect
5. In baseball, you have to take the controller out of the handle to pitch, or else look rather silly pitching with a bat in your hand. It doesn't take long, but it's something you don't need to do if you're not using the accessory.
6. You'll need to take the controller out of the padded sleeve before using these accessories. (And then put it back on when you're through)

The bottom line is that these accessories add nothing to the Wii Sports experience, and you're much better off keeping things simple and using the regular remote controller on its own.

Amanda Richards, March 7, 2009

title: Simple and fun game for young kids text: We got this for our DD for Christmas last year. She was 5. She had no problem playing the game on her own and it really kept her interest for a fair amount of time compared to other games. It is simple - no reading involved for the really little ones so they can navigate on your own. There is no fear of "dying" in the game or racing against a clock so it's good for young ones there as well.

Basically the kids can care for the hamsters - feed, water, exercise, put to bed, potty, etc. - and then they can also run them through tracks to earn points. You unlock more hamsters as you play the game and make it through the various mazes. Some are more difficult than others to find your way through - but my daughter just enjoyed running through them whether she made it to the end or not.

It's one of her most-played games so I really recommend it to the young crowd. Older kids would probably get bored with it.

title: Rather Nice Wireless Headphones {Edited} text: [[VIDEOID:27650cd0317fc1e6114d8bac39cb39d6]] These headphones sound really good. They're not world class but as far as affordable headphones go these fit the bill. I listened to a variety of music, classical, jazz, rock, prog, metal and using the Bass mode EQ/sound effect setting. I'm very amused the headphones pronounce bass like the fish. Other than Bass mode these have; Classic and Vocal modes.
Bass mode worked well once I adjusted the equalizers in my tablet and phone. A little fish, I mean bass, heavy but the highs are there, fairly sharp and clear.
Classic mode is the happy medium setting. I find this is good for listening to YouTube channels where someone is talking/reacting to something.
Vocal mode. . . Maybe good for phone calls? Unfortunately I didn't receive or make any calls. Honestly this mode made everything sound horrible.
The lighting is rather cool you can have static single colors, I was particularly fond of the green and red they're very vibrant but all the colors are well done. Then you can have your single color pulse/fade in and out, next you you can cycle all the colors one after the other. Finally you can have a color chasing rainbow where all the colors display and cycle around in a circle. This is my favorite mode. My only complaint is you can't see the groovy colors when you're wearing the headphones!
The microphone on these is clever. There's just a small nub not much bigger than a pencil's eraser that protrudes from the front of the left side. you gently pull on this to extend the microphone boom. It easily slides back into the headphone. It appears that even though the unit has a memory function, remembering color settings and which sound mode you used, you apparently have to mute the microphone each time you power on the unit.
Fit and finish are good, not great, I've got a kinda large head and these are just the slightest bit tight but I'd rather that than loose. I used them for a couple hours last night then fell asleep with them on and woke up hours later. They can be worn a long time. Cups are nicely soft and breathe okay. In a warm room you may sweat. I'm not sure these are suitable for kids or irresponsible teens/adults. The hinges that allow you to lay these flat look like metal but they're plastic. Heavy play, flexing too much and they'll break. They're hefty but have a very soft pad that sits on top of your head.
Battery life seems to be excellent. I had the rainbow colors cycling and had them powered on for over nine hours and they were playing at least six, my tablet rebooted sometime after I fell asleep.
As an affordable set of headphones that sound pretty dang good (adjust your devices EQ if it has one) have long battery life and fit well these are something I would definitely recommend.

P. S.
I know some reviewers have said these are too quiet or very quiet. I don't blast my ears like I did growing up (I'm 56) so with the volume on the headset maxed and each device having the sound up, never maxed, these were more than loud enough to hear everything I listened to.

Edit - A couple things to add.
‚Ä¢ I wear glasses, these are reasonably when wearing glasses.
‚Ä¢ I needed to open the headband up two notches on each side for a better fit. I just wanted to note that the corners of the plastic exposed when opened are pointy and quite sharp!
‚Ä¢ Had an accidental durability test the other day. I was sitting in my wheelchair when a nurse came in to talk to me. I pushed my headphones up and a little too far. They fell approximately four feet onto a tile floor. Absolutely no damage.
‚Ä¢ If you put these on and can't hear anything even after checking the volume in whatever app you're using and your system settings. Check the volume wheel on the headset, It's really easy to accidentally roll it all the way down.

title: Fun slots text: I like playing these slot machine games - I've got a number of the IGT Slots sets. This is the first time I've purchased one of the digital download versions. It was a fairly painless process. After buying you're prompted to download the software, I chose to instead download it later and had the download information sent to my email. But even then, when I had time to install this game, I did it from the 'My Games & Software' page here at Amazon. You first download a small file that in turns downloads the installation program for the game. During the installation process you're prompted for a security code, which is on your account page (and probably in the email). Once that code is accepted you can start the game. I installed this software on an old Windows Vista laptop with no problems.

The game consists of four different slot machines. You start out with $25,000. These are penny slots with the max bet around $5, so that should last awhile. You can add more money when that is gone. The games are a fun diversion if you're into playing slots. I think I like the Day of the Dead one best.

title: A great start with lots of potential - Potential failed... Cancelled my sub. text: Leaving my previous review below, because it was written before patch 1.2 and what this game was to become, so you can read my original optimism!

What ruined potential. Once you hit level 50, the game becomes an absolute mindless grind, with no sense of purpose at all. It is one thing to do the same raids over and over if they are fun or have purpose, but it loses its luster quickly and becomes the usual (stand on the x, hit the 3 key seven times, then the 5 key times and then stand on spot Y). The PvP (basically now reduced to warzones ONLY) have absolutely no sense of purpose, except to grind for gear. They are supposedly introducing "team" play, but they missed the opportunity to have a overall purpose to the PvP, such as helping your chosen FACTION. Open world PvP is non-existent and had no sense of purpose either.

For a game that started off telling an amazing story... it completely loses its way towards the end and you just don't care about what happens anymore.

Space combat.. great potential gone wrong. You wind up repeating the exact same space missions during your initial progressions. (The level 40 missions are the exact same as the level 20 missions, just with slightly higher goals (kill 40 fighters instead of 20).

When they added content to the story in patch 1.2.. I didn't both to complete it as I had stopped caring about the storyline.

It's a shame, because this could have been a fantastic game, but they took the easy way out and decided to turn it into a mindless grind.

This is defiantly one of the better MMO's and has some aspects that make it much better than the rest.

The Best Aspects:

The story line is fantastic and the voice acting makes it much more enthralling than other games which simply present you with a wall of text. It maintains the feel of both an MMO and single player game.

Crafting. Finally a game got this right. You don't have to spend endless boring hours grinding away at resource gathering and standing over a forge. You get companions in the game and send them on missions and they gather the resources for you and craft the items, earning you experience. This is the first MMO where I am actually doing the crafting.

They have nice bonus systems to encourage you to group, but you don't HAVE TO if you don't want to in order to complete your story line. (If you group with others you earn experience from them completing quests as well as you own, so you level much faster!)

The Good Aspects:

Space combat is a lot of fun, but isn't fleshed out yet. You can do space missions, but are essentially stuck on a rail as your ship steers itself through space and you control where and what you shoot, with small room for movements.

Characters are pretty customizable, as you can switch your skill tree. So you can go up the healing tree and then decide you want to do DPS and go back to your trainer and spend some credits to reassign your skills. (You get the first swap for free). You can also create interesting hybrid characters, who can serve dual purposes.

What needs work:

The PVP just isn't there yet. There isn't anything to encourage people into open world PvP, so it is pretty much restricted to "warzones". These are mini, repeatable instances where they put equal number of republic and empire and give them a goal to achieve. Great idea.. execution isn't there yet. There is no in game voice communication, so you get thrown into a random group and then it becomes difficult to execute because you can't communicate quickly. Further they put people of all levels into the same warzone and although they scale your HP up to level 50, unless you are level 50, your gear and skills aren't on par. (Hopefully they will bracket the warzones in the future to make them more balanced).

Overall, however, this is a great game that has lots of potential. Hopefully they resist the urge to go with other MMO's have gone before them and just turn it into a constant grind for gear. Right now, it isn't grindy and that alone makes it worth playing!

title: VERY Happy To Find These- Pinball Wears Out My Controllers Fast text: It is difficult to find parts for Playstation 3 these days, so imagine my thrill when I found a dual set of these controllers.

HOW THESE SYNC
These sync perfectly when plugged into the base unit via USB cord. They work great.

PERFORMANCE
These perform just as well as the older controllers I have. The only issue I have is the center PS button which sticks sometimes if it is pressed too hard. The buttons and triggers all work about the same. I am not worried about really long term because this machine is old.

I do love pinball, however, which wears the triggers out quickly. These help me enjoy pinball a little longer so far.

CHARGE
The charge lasts just as long (sometimes longer) than my SONY controllers. I have a charging stand which does two controllers at a time, so I use that.

THE BOTTOM LINE
This set of controllers syncs well, performs well, and holds the charge well too.

MY RATING
FIVE STARS. I am really glad I was able to get these. Now I can play pinball tournaments a little longer at my house. We all refuse to get any of the newer units because of the spyware and location in them. So, PS3 it is until it doesn't work anymore.

title: Works great on my Xbone and my PC. None one the dreaded 3rd party controller issues. text: I've used my share of 3rd party controllers, and it would be an understatement to say I had my doubts about this controller. So many have lackluster controls, dodgy build, and near compatibility. Worry not! This controller delivers on all fronts.

It works, it works well, it feels good when you use it, and I don't feel cheap when I'm using this controller. Yeah, it's corded, but the cord is a decent length and has a detach feature to keep things safe in a crowded living room. The sticks feel a little different from the OEM sticks, but they are responsive and don't feel alien. The buttons feel almost identical to the OEM controllers (I've used a couple 3rd party controllers that couldn't even manage that), and the overall texture is grippy but not "weird".

All this being said, I don't use these as my go to controller. I have a couple wireless ones, and wireless on the Xbox one works very well. I use these when they're charging or I need an extra controller. I also use these on my gaming PC. These just work with no need for drivers or other issues. As a Xbox One compatible controller (which itself is basically the same as a 360 controller), most PC games support this rather well.

title: Bright, responsive gaming mouse. text: This mouse is wide and long, and has a large footprint, but is not heavy or particularly tall. It leaves it in this strange place where the mouse is big, yet feels noticably smaller than most other gaming mice I've used. The lighting effects are very bright, and it's clear that the company has emphasized this in their design. All buttons work and are very responsive, with good haptic feedback when you press them. I'd like the sides to be a little nicer - the area wher your thumb and pinky grip the mouse are pretty low-quality in comparison to competitors, even in this price range.

Of note, the cord is particularly long. This is excellent for anyone who uses a setup like mine where my PC is on the "wrong" side of my desk, and my cable management requires a long distance to travel from case to desktop.

title: Great collection of games text: Honestly, this game would be worth it just for the KH1 and 2 HD remakes. Thankfully, this game also comes with the other games that came between 1 and 2 that were originally only available for handhelds. Days is only available as a short "movie" of all of the cutscenes (which is totally okay cause that game was awful). Unfortunately, you can't do the same for the others...I wish there was an option to watch them instead of play them cause I couldn't get into CoM at all (much preferred the short time I played the original 2d gameboy version). Thankfully YouTube had my back there.

All-in-All, you can't go wrong for the price and I can finally get myself caught up on all the games I originally missed thanks to not having 3 different handheld consoles.

From what I played (about 6-8 hours) of it, the story was pretty good, and the voice acting was decent as well. I had to put the game down, however, because of the camera and play controls. They were simply too frustrating for my tastes, and since this is an action-style RPG, I found that to be a deal-breaker.

Others might have better luck than I did with the controls. I can't "not recommend" this game, because it did seem to have some promise.

title: It was good while it lasted text: It just didn't last long enough. I don't expect a mechanical keyboard to fail in three years, yet, this one did. Correction: in a way, it failed from the beginning. Number keys kept popping off and had to be put back on at least once a day. Annoying, but not enough of a deal breaker to send it back.

But, recently, the left control key started failing on certain functions - such as cntrl shift end and home. It still worked on others, though. I tried taking apart the entire left side of the keyboard and cleaning it, but nothing worked. As a writer who often produces thousands of words a day, this was unacceptable. Oddly enough, the right control key worked just fine and for a while I limped along using that key for certain commands but I was afraid I was teaching myself habits I'd come to regret once I again had a fully functional keyboard.

When it worked, though, it was a great keyboard. Highly responsive with a great tactile feel. If I were rating on that alone, it would definitely be a five.

title: Did Santa bring this for my kids or my husband?
text: This game has seemed to awaken a newfound video game enjoyment for my 42 year old husband---not sure if that's a good thing or a bad thing quite yet. My boys ages 6 & 7 both seem to fancy it as well and it's the most exercise they've had since Christmas break began so I suppose that's an added feature :-) I also like that it appeals to all age groups that are coming to our house to visit as it makes game time (at least electronically) more appealing.

title: Impressive text: "Wow," is the best I can think of to say about this game. It's really something and I like it a lot. Usually I only play serious strategy games such as Civilization and my past forays into console games have been far less than satisfactory. Thanks to the other reviewers here I decided to give this one a try and I'm very glad I did.

At first I was wondering if it is just an interactive story. I'm not much for the story aspects of games and it took several scenes before actual game play comes up. Surprisingly, I held in there and after the first couple short missions I was hooked. The story itself is not overly original but also not so common as to be boring. The main characters are likeable enough and as things progressed I found myself interested in what was going on and anxious to find out what would happen next.

So then, the Pros: The Graphics, great! I wasn't sure what to think of the watercolor/cartoon/anime mix at first but after seeing it in action I'm hooked. While most modern games seem to be going for the "real as life" look this game looks softer, less in your face. Also on the plus side of things is the ease of play. It was easy to learn how things work and to understand the goals and objectives set out. I got an Xbox controller to use with it, my first time ever using one, and I'm having a great time with it.

Another plus, to me, is the music. I often turn the music or all sound off when playing games because I usually find it distracting or somehow undesirable. This one is different and interesting is that parts of the music, while certainly different, is reminiscent of songs I've heard, some old and some not so old.

On the Cons side of things I'm coming up a little short. I would prefer to not have go through a configuration launcher every time and sometimes the story plays on emotions in ways I'd rather it didn't. Sometimes the story scenes are a bit long and I would get impatient for the next mission. And of course there's always those times such as when my best gunner totally misses the house sized tank 20 feet in from of him and gets me ranting and wanting an undo/redo/wtf button. But that's part of luck and chance and it wouldn't be a real game without. None of these things warrant losing even one star so my rating stands at 5 out of 5.

All in all I think this is one of the most refined and polished games I've ever played. It's done. Totally complete and playable on initial download. No waiting weeks or months for patches and updates. No hours spent grinding through forums hoping to find a fix for some inane problem. This game works and works well.

When the next episode or book in the story is released for the PC I will most certainly buy it too.

5 out of 5 stars for this one and kudos for the developers. Well Done!

title: Mediocre. text: It's mediocre but a good way to waste 10 or so hours. The game graphics are OK, but there is a lot of character model clipping and it can be difficult to shoot around obstacles. Here are some highlights of why I give a 2 star rating, rather than rehash what has already been said:

1. The game starts pretty well. Heavy story and good usage of cutscenes to draw you in. The aiming system isn't such a stickler for accuracy so shooting isn't bad.
2. LOTS of guns! Each one is useful in some way. You'll never run short on ammo unless you are camping.
3. Lots of different things to do. From a guided drone tank to heli flying, you get to do lots of good stuff.
4. Lots of save points

What I didn't like:
1. Models are kind of clunky, even if they are detailed. Korean soldiers mostly wear yellow and red so you can see them; there's no tactical value in dressing like a paramilitary Ronald McDonald.
2. Over-the-top movie morals where the bad guys are so HORRIBLY bad that you have full license to kill them in any way you can....unless it's part of the plot to feel sorry to kill them.
3. There Is NO free will in this game. It's a shooter on rails. You fail at a mission, you just keep trying over and over until you figure it out. Prompts are not always helpful....
4. The enemy AI consists of two modes: super sniper mode (where you are behind cover but still get shot by enemies across the map) and move mode (where they either camp behind one obstacle until they die or run at you in the open without taking cover). This game also LOVES to have your teammates shout (IT'S CLEAR!) then you get killed by a single bad guy who suddenly pops up behind you!
5. Enemies respawn infinitely until you progress to a certain point. I didn't realize this until halfway through the game when I was running out of ammo and having to run forward to grab guns on the ground....then the enemies would stop coming.
6. You have magic regenerating health

I didn't play the multiplayer version (I got this used and wasn't about to pay for an online pass) so I can't comment on that. I CAN say that this is, like most THQ games, mediocre, at best. If you can get it for 5 or 6 bucks like I did, then it's worth a try.

title: Far more accurate to the books/movies than the other HP games text: Most of the other Harry Potter games I have played in the past do not follow the books/movies all that well, but this one (Lego Harry Potter) follows them very well! I was quite pleased and had a smile on within the first 5 minutes of game play. It's a very cute game, has it's comical moments, while still staying true to the Harry Potter story itself. I enjoy listening to the background music in this game as well because it comes straight from the movie itself, unlike other past Harry Potter games I have played that insert their own music. I'll admit that the controls are a little funny to get used to at first, but I quickly caught on to how it all works and it is now second nature to me. You use both the wii remote and nunchuck to play this game.

Overall, this game is a must for Harry Potter and Lego game fans. I would highly recommend this game. It is a lot of fun. I should add that I also own Lego Star Wars for the Playstation 2 as well. If you enjoyed Lego Star Wars, or probably any Lego game for that matter, and enjoyed it then Harry Potter is just as fun =)

UPDATE as of 1/23/2011: I decided to bump this from 5 stars to 4 stars. Why, you may ask? Well, I ran into a glitch that caused me a lot of problems. I got to a part in my game where I had to use magic to put lego pieces together in order to continue on with the story. Well, one of the lego pieces got stuck and continually disappeared, then reappeared, then disappeared, and then reappeared over and over and over again! I in turn kept attempting to use my magic to move the puzzle piece, but it kept disappearing too quickly to give me a chance to fix the glitch! I then quit the game and tried going back in a second time to see if it would go back to normal, but the glitch was apparently saved, so that was no help at all. At first I thought I had to start all over again, which angered me to no end because I was pretty far into the game. What I did instead was repeated another level from start to finish. Amazingly, this fixed the glitch. I replayed a previous level I had already beaten, and then when I went back to the level with the glitch I realized it disappeared!! I was finally able to continue!

It's unfortunate that I have to knock off a star due to a glitch problem, but it does ruin the fun when you have to replay another level just to fix a problem with the game. If it wasn't for glitches I would have kept it at 5 stars.

title: EA fails to anticipate high server load at launch
text: I must say, the short time I did get to play this game, I was happy when it was working.  I believe there is a great game here underneath all the bugs and the server connection issues.  I managed to create a couple of cities, my biggest has a population of 34k.  I actually played for about 8 hours total.  However, there has been a lot of downtime due to server downtime, updates and maintenance.  It is clear however that they are working on it.  They have added some servers, and they have patched the game twice so far.  The past couple of hours were pretty stable for me so things seem to be improving as of this writing.  I do believe they will resolve the issues they are having, it will just take a little time.  My biggest gripe is that it is clear they knew the number of people about to slam their servers based on pre-orders and other data from their forum traffic, why did they not ensure a smoother launch experience than they did.  To me that is just clear evidence that EA is not interested in ensuring their customers get the experience they paid for.  They happily took our money and kept silent about the potential issues we would face on launch day and beyond.  Shame on EA for treating paying customers like cattle.

title: Pretty good text: The game arrived very quickly and in good condition.

However, though the gameplay is decent, there is much to be desired. AI pathing and attack priority is pretty messed up. Units will target workers before attacking units and defensive structures and, once engaged, they will pursue their targets until you tell them to do something else. Some of the larger units (titans, colossi, etc.) are so large and slow they need to be manually controlled at all times or else they will stand behind the front lines and walk back and forth like idiots until an opening to attack appears (combine this with the retarded priority and you get units that will walk back and forth behind the front lines trying to get at a unit on the other side even though there are enemies right next to him posing an immediate threat).

Units need to deal more damage, as battles drag out much longer than they should.

title: Great for Young Kids! text: I've discovered that the PSP is not a (young) kid friendly gaming device. Most of the best titles are probably for older kids. My 6 year-old has a blast with this title and isn't even a big Toy Story fan. It's easy for him to master the controls with no real complex combos required.

Graphics are good and the storyline pretty much follows the movie plot, or at least retells it from the view of one of the characters. Character voices also appear to be from the actual movie actors. Not sure, but I suspect that alot of the dialog is lifted from the movie, but it works well.

There are downloadable levels on the Playstation Network that extend the playability of the game. We downloaded some and have enjoyed them, too.

I highly recommend this title for kindergarten aged kids, plus it also works well for 40 somethings.

title: Its one of the best mice I have ever used text: I have had this thing for three years and its one of the best mice I have every used. I dont tend to use the DPI settings all that much, but it does help a lot during 3d modeling work or spreadsheets. I also was able to remap a few keys so that I have a forward and back page button, a play/pause music button, and the thumb trigger is bound to zero for esior key binding in games. I do not get much use out of the unlock able scroll wheel unless im in a long PDF, but event then its more fun to play with then piratical.

my only complaints about it are-
-the wire will tangle and knot up under the fabric sheath, so I ended up having to remove that part
-its somewhat hard to clean, and dust gets into all of its cracks
-the scroll wheel has a side to side function that is useful but if you are trying to click with scroll wheel it sometimes misaligned and goes to the right or left instead of clicking. not too much of an issue but can be annoying in fast paced games.

But all in all its grate.

title: There's a reason this game is cheap text: One of the worst singing games I have ever played and I have played most of them. Do NOT waste your money, I am telling you now you WILL regret it.

Pros: 1) Game starts with 40 song options 2) cheap price of $10 or less 3) You can add the songs you want to play to a playlist.

Cons: Everything else. Most of the songs are covers and they don't sound too great. Combine their horrible singing with my equally as bad if not worse singing and you'll have the neighbors calling 911 reporting a disturbance. The sound quality is terrible. Your recording is like 0.5 secs behind the game, the playback audio is way too loud (and delayed) and just the over all sound quality of the cover is low.

Honestly this is a game I would expect from a college student practicing game development. The songs sound like they were recorded at home with a low quality microphone on a laptop with ProTools.

It doesn't take any skill or effort to get perfect pitch and 5 stars. You can sing in a high pitch off key voice the entire time and get a perfect pitch and perfect score. Also if you pause the game at all after you start a song it makes you restart at the beginning. You can't adjust the microphone during the song either so if it's too low or too loud you have to quit or sing thru it.

I wish Singstar would come out with a new game for PS4. I've been playing since Singstar: Pop came out on PS2. I have all of the games from Singstar on PS2 & PS3 (btw singstar mic doesn't work). I have a few other singing games that were okay but nothing compares to Singstar especially this game. I played 5 songs and probably won't play anymore. SINGSTAR PLEASE COME BACK!!

title: FINALLY a headset that is actually comfortable and feels premium text: I've been through a number of gaming headsets including the $80 PS4 gold one, which in my opinion was not intuitive, had poor battery life, wasn't very comfortable and felt cheep. This headset is none of those.

This headset hits the sweet spot between comfort/quality and price. Any less and you'll find yourself stuck with a cheap feeling headset that just doesn't work or feel as well. Any more, and you're wasting money. Without exaggeration, this headset reminds me of my Bose QC 35's.

Highly recommend.

title: Got for my son
text: I buy this for my son every year. He seem to appreciate it

title: Three Stars
text: Big Fan

title: Excellent Keyboard
text: This keyboard has a very nice clicking touch and works well. Great value for the money.  The front apron where your wrist rests is a little too big to comfortably set the keyboard on a slide out shelf.  I much prefer the K551 Red Dragon that I previously purchased.
